rows.inputs.query:
title: Azure Device Registry - Release Plan Missing our sdk packages in other language sdks

question: Hi
General! i'm trying to fill out the sdk planner for rolling out our service to GA for each of the supported language sdks. I tried adding them but other than java and .NET, i'm unable to find in the dropdowns the Device Registry sdk packages (Go, Python, JS). Typing in the dropdowns doesn't do anything. Meanwhile, I confirm that our sdks exist:
JS: Release @azure/arm-deviceregistry_1.0.0 · Azure/azure-sdk-for-js
go: azure-sdk-for-go/sdk/resourcemanager/deviceregistry at main · Azure/azure-sdk-for-go
python: azure-sdk-for-python/sdk/deviceregistry at main · Azure/azure-sdk-for-python
If someone knows how to resolve this, please let me know. thank you!
rows.inputs.ground_truth: They are all ready. Mariana Rios had to update information in our end to recognize the package
rows.inputs.response:
The issue where Device Registry SDK packages for Go, Python, and JavaScript are not appearing in the SDK release planner dropdowns—despite being present in the language repos—typically indicates that the release planner tool sources its selectable package list from metadata tracked in the Azure SDK engineering system. Specifically, the release planner uses metadata from the public repo (e.g., CSV files in azure-sdk/_data/releases/latest/) and internal release work items to generate its list.

To resolve this and make your packages selectable:
1. Ensure that your SDK packages are properly tracked in the Azure SDK release work items. You should run the Prepare-Release.ps1 script to mark the release status of each package and ensure all relevant fields (Service Name, Package Display Name, etc.) are filled out. This data is used to populate dropdowns and tables in the release planner.
2. Verify that the metadata CSV files for each language include entries for your Device Registry packages with correct information (Package name, Service name, DisplayName, SdkType, etc.). If the metadata is missing or incorrect, the packages will not show up in planner dropdowns.
3. After updating or correcting metadata, allow time for the automation job to run (every 2 hours during business hours) or manually trigger it to update the planner UI.
4. Double-check the release plan summary and milestone details to confirm the packages are now selectable.

Actionable next steps:
- Run Prepare-Release.ps1 and ensure metadata is present and correct for all target packages.
- If you find anything unexpected in the planner or the docs, check and update the metadata CSV file, then manually trigger the automation job if needed.
- Refer to the onboarding documentation for the required metadata fields and troubleshooting steps.

If issues persist, you can reach out to the Azure SDK Release Support channel for further assistance.

Learn more about our [latest changes](xref:upcoming_release_planner_change). A release plan is required to generate and release the SDK. If the API spec is written using *TypeSpec* then you can generate the SDK for all tier-1 in *Generate SDK* step in the release planner. This is the preferred JS flavor for codegen. :point_right: [JavaScript RLC](https://aka.ms/azsdk/rlc/js) (aka Rest Level Client). rows.inputs.query:
title: What's pending to consider "Onboard using Release Planner app..." item as done?

question: In order to address CPEX onboarding item "Onboard using Release Planner app...", we have created release planner for our control and data plane APIs. Azure SDK Release Planner - Power Apps.
What's the criteria to consider this item as done in S360?
rows.inputs.ground_truth:
It does look like you onboarded. We just introduced new KPI approval automation last week. It looks like the automation processed the onboarding KPI, but marked it as N/A instead of Completed. I am trying to understand why and will let you know when we have it figured out. Either way you shouldn't be blocked. For the data and management plane KPIs, those will be automatically approved once you complete the release plans.
The KPI has been approved. It was the date that was set to N/A. You should be good to go.
rows.inputs.response: To consider the CPEX onboarding item 'Onboard using Release Planner app...' as done in S360, the acceptance criteria are: you must create the necessary product entries for both your control plane (management plane) and data plane APIs in the Azure SDK Release Planner. The evidence required is that your product data has been added to the Azure SDK systems via Release Planner. Once you have submitted these entries and completed the onboarding steps in Release Planner (choosing the top-level service, filling out the onboarding form, and submitting), this onboarding item is considered complete for CPEX tracking in S360. No additional manual steps are required beyond successfully creating and submitting the Release Planner entries.

Complete the SDK release milestone of the release plan. | ## Get help - Admins Email Alias: azsdkapex@microsoft.com - [Azure SDK Onboarding Teams channel](https://aka.ms/azsdk/support/onboarding-channel)"},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"onboard#requirements.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/onboard/requirements","content":"# onboard#requirements.md | Short Link: | [aka.ms/azsdk/apex/launch-criteria](https://aka.ms/azsdk/apex/launch-criteria) and [aka.ms/azsdk/rest-api-scope](https://aka.ms/azsdk/rest-api-scope) | | --- | --- | # Requirements for Azure services Learn about the REST API and SDK process and requirements for services building on Azure. ## Product scope ### [Products in scope for CPEX](#tab/cpex) The Cloud Product Excellence Program (CPEX) is an overarching program to manage the entire product lifecycle of every Azure branded product/capability all the way from Private Preview to the Retirement. The program ensures that every product (Offering/SKUs/Features) meets a standard set of requirements prior to moving to the target lifecycle state. To learn more about the CPEX program, visit the [CPEX Engineering Hub site](http://aka.ms/plrwiki). ### [Products not in scope for CPEX (i.e. products that are GA)](#tab/non-cpex) The REST API and SDK process and requirements are applicable to all new API and SDK versions, even if the service and/or product are GA. ## Determining management plane (ARM) and/or data plane scope Management plane (ARM) and data plane scope is determined by the endpoints of the REST API Specifications that enable the new product or service. Azure operations can be divided into two categories: *management plane*, also known as control plane or ARM, and *data plane*. - Requests for management plane operations are sent to the Azure Resource Manager URL, for example `https://management.azure.com`. - Requests for data plane operations are sent to an endpoint that is specific to an Azure service, for example `https://{endpoint}/text/analytics/v2.0/languages`. ### [Management plane (ARM)](#tab/management-plane) initial API Spec and/or SDK (no API or SDK versions have ever been released).

Cloud Lifecycle exceptions are tracked as [extensions](https://eng.ms/docs/cloud-ai-platform/azure-edge-platform-aep/aep-engineering-systems/engineering-intelligence-standards/service-360/service-360-team-docs/cloudlifecycle/completelcs#take-action-on-lifecycle-requirements), with the expectation that there will be a revised timeline agreed upon for completion of the requirements. > [!NOTE] > It’s important to create a consistent developer experience across all Azure services and because of that, these CPEX SDK requirements were agreed on by SLT for all services. All exceptions require business justification, approval from the service partner's leadership team (CVP), and a plan to get compliant. > After the request is submitted, the Azure SDK team will review request within 7 business days. ## Request an exception To request an exception: 1. Send an email to your leadership team (CVP level) and copy [azsdkapex@microsoft.com](mailto:azsdkapex@microsoft.com). In the email, include the following information: - CVP acknowledgement that they are violating Azure CPEX global requirements and that they are working on a plan with you to get compliant. - Business justification - Details regarding what and why you are requesting as an exception. - Describe the developer experience in absence of not completing the requirement. For example, if the extension request is to delay releasing the initial beta SDKs for a new service or product, describe the developer experience without the SDKs. - Target date as to when the work will be completed. The Azure SDK team will document the exception details and the resolution date in our records. 1. [Request an exception in Cloud Lifecycle](https://eng.ms/docs/cloud-ai-platform/azure-edge-platform-aep/aep-engineering-systems/engineering-intelligence-standards/service-360/service-360-team-docs/cloudlifecycle/completelcs#take-action-on-lifecycle-requirements) for the launch item that requires an extension with the extension date requested. Provide any relevant details in the notes section. For manual products, follow same process but instead of requesting an exception in Cloud Lifecycle, the sign-off form will be **Sign-off with exception** and the follow-up date will be the agreed upon target completion date. After we review the email, we'll either approve or reach back out to your team or launch criteria owner if we need additional information or have questions. ## Acceptable exception criteria 1. Extensions should be as short as possible and must not exceed 30 days after service availability. 2. Exceptions to exclude language SDKs should include customer data to justify the exception. Exceptions are most commonly granted for beta SDK releases and are rarely granted for stable SDK releases. 3. CVP approval email is required. Extensions will not be granted for the following KPIs: - Onboard using Release Planner app to determine if your product is in scope for the REST API & SDK lifecycle requirements - Data plane Private Preview API review & approval - Management plane Private Preview API review & approval"},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"develop#sdk-review.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/develop/sdk-review","content":"# Schedule an SDK review ## Schedule a meeting Schedule a SDK Architecture review meeting with the Azure SDK Architecture board. > [!IMPORTANT] > Reviews must be scheduled ideally at least two business days in advance to give the team time to prepare. 1. Log in to [Azure SDK Release Planner](https://aka.ms/azsdk/sdk-release-planner). 2. Choose the top-level service that your product is associated with. 3. Click **Your release plans** and select the release plan you are interested in. 4. The **Summary** view will provide information about where you are in the process and who the contacts are. 5. Click on **Milestones** and select **Data-plane SDK Release**. This will open the app with the specific task to accomplish before you schedule the meeting. 6. The **Schedule SDK review** task contains the information to schedule the meeting with the [Azure SDK Scheduler](https://aka.ms/azsdk/schedulesdkreview) app. 7. Once in the scheduler app click **Create new**. 8. Choose a meeting slot and select your meeting attendees. In the **Meeting attendees** field, be sure to include the Cloud Product Excellence (CPEX) PM or owner who is responsible for updating your product in Cloud Lifecycle, as well as any engineering team members that will be generating or updating SDKs. 9. Indicate whether your service is on pre-release and not publicly disclosed. 10. Provide a links to your [hero scenarios](xref:api-design#start-with-hero-scenarios), architecture diagrams and [core concepts](xref:api-design#define-terms-and-concepts). These fields will be auto populated if you have provided these documents before. 11. Provide links to your APIView listings for each tier 1 language."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"faqs#glossary.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/faqs/glossary","content":"# Glossary terms for Azure SDKs ## R ### Release Planner An application that guides you through onboarding your product, creating plans for an upcoming API and SDK release, and tracking progress."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"develop#sdk-release#sdk-release.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/develop/sdk-release/sdk-release","content":"# Release SDK ## Next steps - For each released package by going to the public feed and verifying: - Metadata - Verify that the links, documentation, readme, etc. are correct and appear as expected. - Download - Download the package and verify that it is the same one you built/published. - In your release plan, mark the **Release SDK** task as completed and proceed to complete the release plan. - [Verify SDK reference docs](xref:sdk-docs) - Verify the content of the release notes PR generated during the release pipeline. Review and approve the PR. See [Producing Release Notes](https://azure.github.io/azure-sdk/policies_releasenotes.html) for details. - The release pipeline will submit a PR with a version bump for each SDK in their respective language repository. You need to review and merge each version bump pull request."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"plan#track-progress.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/plan/track-progress","content":"# Track your progress ## Get help - If you encounter bugs or want to make suggestions about Release Planner, click **Report a bug** in Release Planner. - If you have general questions about your release plan, reach out to us on the [Azure SDK / Azure SDK Onboarding](https://aka.ms/azsdk/support/onboarding-channel) channel."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"develop#sdk-develop.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/develop/sdk-develop","content":"# Develop client libraries (SDK) ## Get help - If you need help with an automation tool or the Release planner, reach out to [Azure SDK / Azure SDK Onboarding](https://aka.ms/azsdk/support/onboarding-channel) channel. - If you need help with the development of the SDKs reach out to the [language specific Team's channel](xref:support#get-help-with-the-azure-sdks-development). - If you need to request an exception for a language review the [request release exception](xref:request-exception)."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"onboard#index.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/onboard/index","content":"# Onboard to Azure SDKs ## Onboard your product If you're working with a new product that's in scope for Azure Product Excellence (CPEX), use Azure SDK Release Planner to submit an onboarding request. To onboard a product: 1. Log in to [Azure SDK Release Planner](https://aka.ms/azsdk/sdk-release-planner). 2. Choose the top-level service that your product is associated with. 3. Click **Onboard CPEX product** and follow the prompts to complete the form. 4. To confirm your selections, click **Submit**. You'll receive an e-mail that describes your next steps. An Azure DevOps item is also created to help us track the progress of your onboarding request."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"develop#sdk-release#sdk-release-prerequisites.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/develop/sdk-release/sdk-release-prerequisites","content":"# Prerequisites to release client libraries (SDK) ## Commit tests SDK usability is essential for customer success, so our SDKs must include tests. For GA SDK releases of the management plane, .NET recommends live tests to ensure compatibility with the new service version. For the data plane, according to the target phase of your SDK, these are the requirements you need to accomplish before the SDK release: - Public preview: at least one test per language for the most common usage scenario. - GA: at least one test per shipped method. Additional resources on adding SDK tests for various languages and SDK types are available at [test SDKs](xref:sdk-test)."}]

Azure SDK Release Planner - Power Apps.\\nWhat's the criteria to consider this item as done in S360?\", \"response\": \"To consider the CPEX onboarding item 'Onboard using Release Planner app...' as done in S360, the acceptance criteria are: you must create the necessary product entries for both your control plane (management plane) and data plane APIs in the Azure SDK Release Planner. The evidence required is that your product data has been added to the Azure SDK systems via Release Planner. Once you have submitted these entries and completed the onboarding steps in Release Planner (choosing the top-level service, filling out the onboarding form, and submitting), this onboarding item is considered complete for CPEX tracking in S360. No additional manual steps are required beyond successfully creating and submitting the Release Planner entries.\", \"ground_truth\": \"It does look like you onboarded. I am trying to understand why and will let you know when we have it figured out. Either way you shouldn't be blocked. For the data and management plane KPIs, those will be automatically approved once you complete the release plans.\\nThe KPI has been approved. It was the date that was set to N/A. You should be good to go.\"}"}]

rows.inputs.query:
title: change the sdk release planner version

question: Hi
General
is there a way to change the sdk release planner version for python sdk? The release planner says version 1.0.0 for our python sdk. however, that was our last GA release version, and our generated PR changelog shows it is actually 1.1.0 version we want to release. is there a way to change this version in our release planner? thanks
javascript is also incorrect version:  (should be 1.1.0) and Go sdk is blank when it should be 2.0.0 from changelog:
```
```
rows.inputs.ground_truth: the version of the packages reflects what currently exists on main on the languages repo,because your PR hasn't been merged, you are seeing the previous version,.NET was already merged, so you see the right version.
rows.inputs.response:
To update the SDK version information in the Azure SDK Release Planner for Python, JavaScript, and Go, you need to ensure that the metadata in the release work items and the relevant CSV files are accurate. The Release Planner and the documentation system rely on the metadata from these sources to display correct version information for each language. 

**Action Steps:**
1. Update the release work items for your SDKs using the Prepare-Release.ps1 script to ensure the correct version is reflected for each language (Python, JavaScript, Go). This script updates the metadata that Release Planner uses to track versions.
2. If your package has already been released or the changelog/metadata is not updated, check the corresponding metadata CSV file (for example, `python-packages.csv`, `js-packages.csv`, `go-packages.csv`) located in `azure-sdk/_data/releases/latest/` in the Azure SDK repo. Update the `VersionGA` and/or `VersionPreview` fields to match the desired version (e.g., 1.1.0 for Python/JavaScript, 2.0.0 for Go).
3. After updating, commit your changes and create a PR. Once merged, the Release Planner and documentation site will reflect the updated versions.
4. For tracking progress and verifying the update, use the Release Planner summary and milestones views.

If you encounter issues with the Release Planner not updating after these changes, report a bug directly in Release Planner or reach out to the Azure SDK Onboarding channel for support.

**References:**
- You can find more information about updating metadata and troubleshooting automated documentation updates in the onboarding and release docs.
- The changelog should be kept up to date before initiating release pipelines, as it affects automated version tracking.

For additional help, see the guidance below or contact the Azure SDK Onboarding channel.
rows.inputs.context: [{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"faqs#faqs.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/faqs/faqs","content":"# faqs#faqs.md | Short Link: | [aka.ms/azsdk/faq](https://aka.ms/azsdk/faq) | | --- | --- | # Azure SDK frequently asked questions This page lists various frequently asked questions (FAQs) and answers to them. The questions are organized into sub-FAQs pertaining to specific categories. ## Azure REST API specs PRs This FAQ pertains to [Azure REST API specs PRs](xref:api-specs-pr). ### I want to update my service Azure REST API specs, but I do not know how You need to follow a release process in which you will end up creating a PR with your spec updates. See [this article](xref:api-specs-pr) for more. ### I created a PR to the specs repo but nobody is reviewing it Carefully follow the guidance provided in the PR description. It will guide you through the process of getting your PR reviewed and inform you how to determine if your PR is on the correct review queue and if so, where it is on it. ### The pull request I created at azure-rest-api-specs[-pr] fails validation, what to do? Carefully follow the guidance provided in the PR description and in the `Next Steps to Merge` comment added to it by the automation. ### I believe the validation tooling is wrong; it reports a problem where there is none Carefully follow the guidance provided in the PR description and in the `Next Steps to Merge` comment added to it by the automation. It covers cases where the tooling is faulty and/or reporting false positives. ### I have a question about, or issue with ShiftLeft pipeline (aka API spec pipeline) If your issue concerns ShiftLeft, be aware that: - As of April 2023 we are not onboarding anybody else onto ShiftLeft pipeline. - We do not provide support for anyone who is already onboarded onto ShiftLeft. - If ShiftLeft pipeline is broken for you, we recommend stopping using it. As a replacement, you can open PRs directly against the relevant specs repositories. See [this article](xref:api-specs-pr). - Eventually we will provide proper replacement for ShiftLeft. If you still need help in maintaining existing legacy ShiftLeft setup, consult the [unmaintained, deprecated, legacy docs](https://dev.azure.com/azure-sdk/internal/_wiki/wikis/internal.wiki/611/API-First-with-Service-API-Toolset). ### I need help with ARM review for my PR Please see [Get your PR reviewed by ARM](xref:pr-arm-review). ### Why I do not see an assignee for my ARM PR? As of January 2024 the spec PRs are no longer getting automatically assigned to anyone, by design. Your PR will still get reviewed by the ARM team if you follow the relevant process. For details, please see [Get your PR reviewed by ARM](xref:pr-arm-review). ## TypeSpec / OpenAPI specs This FAQ pertains to generic questions about TypeSpec / OpenAPI specifications. If you have a question related to your PR updating such specifications, see [Azure REST API specs PRs FAQ](#azure-rest-api-specs-prs). ### I have a question about ARM (management plane) API specs > [!NOTE] > Other names for ARM are listed in the [glossary](xref:glossary#arm). To get your question about [ARM specs](xref:glossary#arm) answered, visit the [ARM API Wiki](https://armwiki.azurewebsites.net/rp_onboarding/process/api_review.html) or email the ARM API Review Board at [armapireview@microsoft.com](mailto:armapireview@microsoft.com) (the full alias name is `Azure Resource Manager RP API Review`). ### I have a question about data plane API specs Ask questions about [data plane](xref:glossary#data-plane) API specs in API Stewardship Board office hours: https://aka.ms/azapi/officehours If you need answer urgently, ask on the [Azure API Stewardship Board General Channel]. ## Release SDK package ### Can I release Beta SDKs during the product lifecycle GA? We encourage teams to release stable SDKs at the GA product lifecycle and to release beta SDKs for customer feedback and testing 30-60 days prior to a stable SDK release; however, if you need an exception to meet a deadline, please do the following:​​ 1. File an extension for the Management/Data plane API & Beta SDK release readiness KPI in S360 and provide justification for your decision in the request, see [Request an exception for Azure SDKs](xref:request-exception). 2. Create a release plan to generate and release beta SDKs from a stable API version, wait 30 days after release to proceed to the next steps to see if there are any issues with the SDKs. 3. If no API or SDK issues are reported, update the SDK version from beta to GA in each language SDK repo and update the respective change log. Create a GA release plan and email sdkowners@microsoft.com to inform them that you are going to convert your beta SDKs to Stable and that you don't have any changes to make to the SDK. 4. If API or SDK issues are identified, create a GA release plan and follow the release plan process as normal. ### Release of a package failed, now do I retry? Package releases can be retried by clicking the **Rerun failed jobs** button of the release pipeline. ### I accidentally published a package, how can I delete it? This is generally not possible. Most package registries enforce immutability to ensure the integrity of the developer ecosystem they support. If you need to republish a package you must increment the version number as appropriate and republish. Most registries allow you to delist packages but not completely remove them (sometimes exceptions are made fro actively malicious packages). ### How do I generate an SDK during private preview using MCP? SDK generation is not required for private preview. If you choose to provide SDKs early, follow this process: 1. Create a Private Preview Release Plan Go to https://aka.ms/release-planner-preview. Select Private Preview as the release type. Add your API spec PR link (from azure-rest-api-specs-pr). Complete API readiness milestones. 2. Clone the Private API Spec Repo (https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr) and the Private SDK Language repos (e.g. https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python-pr) to your local environment. 3. Set Up MCP Server Install MCP tools in VS Code: aka.ms/azsdk/agent 4. SDK via MCP Use MCP commands in VS Code Agent Mode - Example: Generate SDK for [service-name] in [language]. 5. Share SDK for Internal Use (Optional) The Azure SDK Team does not support publishing SDK PRs to public repos for private specs, and there is no formal release process for private preview SDKs. If you need internal distribution:Keep SDK changes in a feature branch within the private SDK repo and publish to a private Azure DevOps feed. Do not merge to main because it mirrors the public repo. ## General This FAQ pertains to various questions that do not fall within any of the other FAQs. This includes questions about: - TypeSpec (previously CADL) - Live Validation tool ### I was told about CADL, but not TypeSpec, what is the difference? CADL is an obsolete name for TypeSpec. TypeSpec is the official public name since February 2023. ### I'm used to generating my SDKs with AutoRest, and with the latest version I do not see any model generated anymore. Where are my models, and how can I generate them? [AutoRest] is a product that was originally designed to be wrapped entirely by a manual layer of code. The new approach taken with next generation of codegen, called DPG (Data Plane Generator), allows generated code to ship directly with no wrapper. However, generating shippable models from OpenAPI specs creates many challenges as OpenAPI spec standard is a poor source of information for versioning and typing information. Therefore, we are moving to TypeSpec for model generation. This means today: - Generation from OpenAPI specs will generate clients and protocol methods only - Generation from TypeSpec will generate clients, protocol methods, typed methods (a.k.a. convenience methods) and models ### I am having some issues with my SDK's reference documentation publication See [Package Onboarding step-by-step](https://dev.azure.com/azure-sdk/internal/_wiki/wikis/internal.wiki/602/Package-Onboarding-step-by-step). ### I need help with Live Validation Reach out to the [Service API Toolset Teams channel] for help. In your post, describe the issue and include links to the artifacts that are applicable to your problem. For example: - Pull request - Build log - Failing check ### I have a S360 KPI issue saying `Linter Validation Error Details` If you have a problem that says `Linter Validation Error Details` and `S360 KPI`, fill out the `Swagger Validation Feedback` feedback form link that is provided within. ### Is there a separate process that has to be followed for CLI, PowerShell, and Terraform updates or is it part of the SDK release plan? No, CLI updates are not part of the SDK release. For information relevant to CLI, PowerShell, or Terraform please review instructions here:  [aka.ms/azureclitools/](https://aka.ms/azureclitools/onboarding) [AutoRest]: https://github.com/Azure/autorest [Azure API Stewardship Board General Channel]: https://teams.microsoft.com/l/channel/19%3a3ebb18fded0e47938f998e196a52952f%40thread.tacv2/General?groupId=1a10b50c-e870-4fe0-8483-bf5542a8d2d8&tenantId=72f988bf-86f1-41af-91ab-2d7cd011db47 [Service API Toolset Teams channel]: https://aka.ms/azsdk/support/spectools-channel"},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"develop#sdk-docs.md","document_title":"Publish SDK reference docs","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/develop/sdk-docs","content":"# develop#sdk-docs.md # Publish SDK reference docs ## Before you begin - You have [access](xref:access) to the GitHub repositories and respective GitHub groups. be added to the [azure-sdk-write](https://github.com/orgs/MicrosoftDocs/teams/azure-sdk-write) GitHub group. This group is in the **MicrosoftDocs** org, not the **Azure** org. ## Onboard a released package Follow these steps to onboard a released package to Azure SDK reference docs on Microsoft Learn. Docs are built using CI pipelines maintained by the Docs team. Builds generate docs for all packages onboarded, run on a schedule, and take several hours to complete. Changes can be viewed on the reference review site. > Note: Android reference docs are not yet supported on Microsoft Learn. You will need to follow the [Android guidelines](./sdk-android-docs.md) > for publishing said documentation instead. ### Packages released through the Azure SDK engineering system during business hours on weekdays. If your data is not updated and you don't want to wait, [run the job manually](https://dev.azure.com/azure-sdk/internal/_build?definitionId=1284). This will update the metadata PR. If you find anything unexpected in the table of contents or service README, check the [metadata CSV file](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk/tree/main/_data/releases/latest) to ensure that the metadata is correct. If the metadata is not correct, open a PR with corrections. Once merged your changes will be released on the next available documentation release. ##### Update a published Package-level Overview > [!NOTE] > For packages released using the Azure SDK EngSys, changes need to be synchronized between the source SDK repo and the docs > repo. Changes to the docs repo that are not mirrored to the source SDK repo will be overwritten by content from the source > SDK repo on the next package release. 1. Find the Package-level overview using the table from [Package-level overviews](#package-level-overviews). 2. Find the corresponding README.md file for the library in the SDK repo (e.g. [azure-sdk-for-net](https://github.com/azure/azure-sdk-for-net)). 3. Update the "front matter" date field at the beginning of the file to today's date. To update other front matter metadata, see [Ensure CSV metadata is correct](#ensure-csv-metadata-is-correct). 4. Copy changed content from step 2 into the Package-level overview from step 1. 5. Open a pull request for the update file in the docs repo If your package is released through the Azure SDK engineering system, almost everything is automated. You'll need to take action if this is your first time releasing a package. When releasing a package for the first time: 1. Ensure that your package is tracked in the [release work items](https://dev.azure.com/azure-sdk/Release/_queries/query/7d106acd-a1c2-47b9-9676-996422328397/). This can be done by running the [**Prepare-Release.ps1** script](https://aka.ms/azsdk/mark-release-status). In each item for your release, you should have a value for **Service Name** and **Package Display Name**. The docs table of contents is generated from this data. > [!NOTE] > Do not skip this step. If you skip the service name, your item will appear in the TOC in the **Other** > **Uncategorized** section. 1. Ensure that your package-level overview file (the README.md file for your package in the SDK source repo) is up to date *before* releasing. In general, the automated system will ensure that updated docs are onboarded within a day or two of your release. To customize information about your package outside of the engineering system consult documentation for [CSV fields](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk/blob/main/eng/README.md#csv-fields) and [Service Level Overview](#service-level-overview) and [Package Level Overview](#package-level-overview). #### Troubleshooting automated documentation updates An automation job runs every 2 hours during business hours on weekdays. If your data is not updated and you don't want to wait, [run the job manually](https://dev.azure.com/azure-sdk/internal/_build?definitionId=1284). This will update the metadata PR. If you find anything unexpected in the table of contents or service README, check the [metadata CSV file](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk/tree/main/_data/releases/latest) to ensure that the metadata is correct. If the metadata is not correct, open a PR with corrections. ### Packages released outside the Azure SDK engineering system - **ServiceDirectory** -- Name of the service (e.g. `storage`). - **DirectoryPath** -- Path from the root of the `azure-sdk-for-*` repo to the package. If unknown or the package is not released from an `azure-sdk-for-*` repo, use the value `""` - **SdkType** -- Use values `client` or `mgmt` to place the package in the appropriate location in the table of contents. - **IsNewSdk** -- Use `true` if the package is a track 2 SDK, otherwise use `false`. - **Group** -- Required *only for Java* Place the metadata JSON file in the `metadata/` folder with the name of the package. For example, the metadata JSON file for the `Azure.Storage.Blobs` package would be named [`Azure.Storage.Blobs.json`](https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/azure-docs-sdk-dotnet/blob/main/metadata/latest/Azure.Storage.Blobs.json). For Java packages, name the file for the artifact and omit the group ID (e.g. [`azure-storage-blob.json`](https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/azure-docs-sdk-java/blob/main/metadata/latest/azure-storage-blob.json)). | | .NET | Java | JS | Python | | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | | Metadata Location | [Link](https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/azure-docs-sdk-dotnet/tree/main/metadata) | [Link](https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/azure-docs-sdk-java/tree/main/metadata) | [Link](https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/azure-docs-sdk-node/tree/main/metadata) | [Link](https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/azure-docs-sdk-python/tree/main/metadata) | For more information on CSV fields, see: [metadata CSV readme](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk/blob/main/eng/README.md#csv-fields) #### Service-level overviews Service-level overviews provide a list of relevant packages. Service-level overview pages are generated automatically for each service and contain a list of packages. Service teams can create their own service-level overview pages which contain more information. Service teams that create their own service-level overview pages are responsible for updating those pages. To create a service-level overview page, look for the relevant markdown for your service. Service-level markdown files are named in the format `service-name.md` where spaces are replaced with dashes (`-`). For example the service-level overview for the `Key Vault` service would be named `key-vault.md`. An `[!INCLUDE]` directive can be used to include a list of packages which will be automatically updated as metadata about new packages is available. ```md [!INCLUDE [packages](advisor-index.md)] ``` The list of packages is in a file whose name is of the form `-index.md`. Service-level overview examples: - Custom service-level overview requiring manual edits: [Python Storage](https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/azure-docs-sdk-python/blob/main/docs-ref-services/latest/storage.md) - Service-level overview generated automatically: [Python Advisor](https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/azure-docs-sdk-python/blob/main/docs-ref-services/latest/advisor.md) #### Package-level overviews Package level overviews are generated from the README.md file in the package source as part of the release process. For example: [JavaScript storage blob package README.md in SDK repo](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-js/blob/main/sdk/storage/storage-blob/README.md). update the data and [run the automation again](https://dev.azure.com/azure-sdk/internal/_build?definitionId=1284). For information about the CSV fields see the [CSV field README](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk/blob/main/eng/README.md#csv-fields). ##### CSV fields Relevant fields in the CSV for docs generation are: - **Package** -- Name of the package (e.g. `Azure.Storage.Blobs`) - **VersionGA** -- The latest GA version of the package (e.g. `12.8.0`) - **VersionPreview** -- The latest preview version of the package (e.g. `12.9.0-beta.1`) - **DisplayName** -- Display name of the package in the table of contents (e.g. `Storage - Blobs`) - **ServiceName** -- Name of the service (e.g. `Storage`) - **MSDocService** -- Used to ensure correct metadata for the docs site. Use an appropriate value for the service as defined in the [taxonomy service (filtered by **ms.service**)](https://taxonomy.learn.microsoft.com/TaxonomyServiceAdminPage/#/taxonomy/detail/2023-01-27T09:00:06.1263332Z!5a3ccca6-19ce-4f32-b516-88038fa259ae/ms.service) (Related: [taxonomy documentation](https://review.learn.microsoft.com/en-us/help/platform/metadata-taxonomies?branch=main#msservice)). - **Type** -- Use values `client` or `mgmt` to place the package in the appropriate location in the table of contents. For more information on CSV fields, see: [metadata CSV readme](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk/blob/main/eng/README.md#csv-fields) #### Service-level overviews Service-level overviews provide a list of relevant packages. Service-level overview pages are generated automatically for each service and contain a list of packages. Service teams can create their own service-level overview pages which contain more information. Service teams that | | Python | `azure-ai-formrecognizer` | `ai-formrecognizer-readme.md` | [`docs-ref-services//`](https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/azure-docs-sdk-python/tree/main/docs-ref-services) | ##### Monikers The **\** should be one of "preview" for pre-"},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"develop#sdk-release#sdk-release.md","document_title":"Release SDK","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/develop/sdk-release/sdk-release","content":"# develop#sdk-release#sdk-release.md # Release SDK | Short Link: | [azsdk/releases/partnerinfo](https://aka.ms/azsdk/releases/partnerinfo) | | --- | --- | > [!IMPORTANT] > TypeSpec usage for API definition is a mandatory requirement for all new (greenfield) data plane and management plane > services. This requirement is enforced by the ARM API Review Board for management plane services and by the API > Stewardship Board for data plane services. > Brownfield services will eventually be required to transition to TypeSpec as well. PRs for brownfields services > that have not transitioned to TypeSpec will receive notices in FY2024, followed by warnings in FY2025 and > errors in FY2027. The requirement to move to TypeSpec will ensure a consistent, high-quality developer experience across > Azure that aligns with Azure SDK guidelines. For more information on TypeSpec, visit [here](xref:api-typespec). ## Before you begin - You have [access](xref:access) to the GitHub repositories, respective GitHub groups, and release security groups. - You have a [release plan](xref:release-plan) created to manage and understand the steps required to generate, test, and release an SDK. - The REST API specs need to be merged in the main branch of the public repository [Azure/azure-rest-api-specs](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs). - Ensure to complete all tasks outlined on this page [Prerequisites to release SDKs](xref:sdk-release-prerequisites). - Breaking changes to GAed SDKs are not permitted as they conflict with the [Azure SDK design principle](https://azure.github.io/azure-sdk/general_introduction.html#dependable). If breaking changes are inevitable, ensure to get approval from [Azure Breaking Changes Board](https://aka.ms/azbreakingchangespolicy) in your service API Spec review. - Ensure your service is available to the public before the SDK release date. ## When to release ### [Management plane (ARM)](#tab/management) The Azure SDK release processes for management plane SDKs vary based on the API specification type - TypeSpec: On demand. - Open API: Request a release **before the cutoff date** for the month that you're targeting. :point_right: 2nd Friday of every month: Cutoff date :point_right: 4th Friday of every month: Release date The functionality to request a release for Java, JavaScript, Python, and Go is available as part of the management plane release plan. You can learn more about release plans [here](xref:release-plan). For releasing the .NET SDK release follow the [.NET release process](xref:sdk-release-mgmt-dotnet). ### [Data plane](#tab/dataplane) Although releases happen every month, you can release the SDK on demand. The Azure SDK team follows a monthly release calendar where we minimize disruptions to the release tools as much as possible. Outside of those dates, the tools might not be as stable. [Release Calendar](https://teams.microsoft.com/l/entity/com.microsoft.teamspace.tab.planner/_djb2_msteams_prefix_1611974298?context=%7B%22subEntityId%22%3Anull%2C%22channelId%22%3A%2219%3Adc2e34377e494a9292d89fbc34125eae%40thread.skype%22%7D&groupId=3e17dcb0-4257-4a30-b843-77f47f1d4121&tenantId=72f988bf-86f1-41af-91ab-2d7cd011db47): This calendar shows the Package Code Freeze and Package Ship dates for the year. ## Breaking change policy - Requires approval from Azure SDK Architecture Team - More information: http://aka.ms/AzBreakingChangesPolicy/ ## Next steps - For each released package by going to the public feed and verifying: - Metadata - Verify that the links, documentation, readme, etc. are correct and appear as expected. - Download - Download the package and verify that it is the same one you built/published. - In your release plan, mark the **Release SDK** task as completed and proceed to complete the release plan. - [Verify SDK reference docs](xref:sdk-docs) - Verify the content of the release notes PR generated during the release pipeline. Review and approve the PR. See [Producing Release Notes](https://azure.github.io/azure-sdk/policies_releasenotes.html) for details. - The release pipeline will submit a PR with a version bump for each SDK in their respective language repository. You need to review and merge each version bump pull request. ## Get help ### [Management plane (ARM)](#tab/management) [Azure SDK - SDK Release Support](https://teams.microsoft.com/l/channel/19%3A084875bb626242ed95f3ac8dddfaa12a%40thread.skype/SDK%20release%20support?groupId=3e17dcb0-4257-4a30-b843-77f47f1d4121&tenantId=72f988bf-86f1-41af-91ab-2d7cd011db47). ### [Data plane](#tab/dataplane) If you have any questions about the general release process, please reach out to either of the [Azure SDK Release PMs](#azure-sdk-release-pm) listed. If your question is related to one of the language specific release processes or you're having issues using a language specific release process, please reach out to the relative [Release Driver](#release-driver--build-facilitating-developer) for that language. #### Azure SDK release PM - Ronnie Geraghty rgeraghty@microsoft.com #### Release driver / Build facilitating developer - .NET: Jonathan Cardenas Jonathan.Cardenas@microsoft.com - Java: Jair Myree jairmyree@microsoft.com - JS: Timo van Veenendaal timov@microsoft.com - Python: Kashif Khan kashifkhan@microsoft.com - C/C++: Anton Kolesnyk Anton.Kolesnyk@microsoft.com - Go: Grace Wilcox gracewilcox@microsoft.com - Android: Victor Colin victor.colin@microsoft.com - iOS: Travis Prescott trpresco@microsoft.com - Rust: Ronnie Geraghty rgeraghty@microsoft.com"},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"develop#sdk-release#sdk-release-pipeline.md","document_title":"Run release SDK pipeline","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/develop/sdk-release/sdk-release-pipeline","content":"# develop#sdk-release#sdk-release-pipeline.md # Run release SDK pipeline | Short Link: | [azsdk/publishsdk](https://aka.ms/azsdk/publishsdk) | |--|--| ## Before you begin > [!NOTE] > These instructions are for packages that are built and release from our mono repos (i.e. `azure-sdk-for-`). If you are a partner that is trying to release a package from outside of those repos follow the instructions at [Partner Release Pipelines](https://aka.ms/azsdk/partner-release-pipeline). - You have a [release plan](xref:release-plan) for the release. - You have [access to the Azure SDK DevOps](xref:access#request-access-to-azure-sdk-devops). - You have read and understood the [Azure SDK approval release guidelines](xref:sdk-approval-release-guidelines). ## SDK release pipeline At a high level the process is: - Locate the appropriate pipeline for your set of packages. - Manually queue a build targeting the commit sha you want to release. - Wait for the build, signing and validation steps to complete. - Approve release via the pipeline. When you use our release pipelines, the SDK is released in the following package managers: | **Language** | **Package Manager** | | ----------- | --------------- | | **.NET** | [NuGet](https://nuget.org) | | **C** | GitHub source release (single source unit to GitHub and publishes doxygen documentation to github.io) | | **C++** | [vcpkg](https://github.com/microsoft/vcpkg) | | **Go** | [Go](https://pkg.go.dev/) | | **Java** | [Maven](https://search.maven.org/) (via oss.sonatype.org) | | **JavaScript** | [NPM](https://www.npmjs.com/) | | **Python** | [PyPI](https://pypi.org/) | ### Select a release pipeline 1. Go to our [pipelines hub](https://dev.azure.com/azure-sdk/internal/_build?view=pipelines&option=recent) contained within the _internal_ team project. 1. Select **All** to see all the pipelines aggregated by language folders. 1. Per language, you will need to locate and select the pipeline that is used to build your package. Pipelines are named after the language and service area that they are responsible for building and releasing. For example the _core_ libraries are named **java - core**, and the app configuration libraries are named **java - appconfiguration**. 1. If you don't find a release pipeline, you will need to create one. > [!NOTE] > In some cases where there was a pre-existing track 1 library and new track 2 libraries were introduced, > we have split the pipelines - so you may see some pipelines in the form **java - [service] - data**. > This means that the pipeline is the track 1 version of the unified pipeline. This distinction is made to optimize the > build and release process for teams doing active development on the track 2 versions of the library. #### Create a release pipeline To generate pipelines for a new service that does not yet exist on _main_, ensure that your PR contains the `ci.yml` and `tests.yml` files ([modified from the template](https://dev.azure.com/azure-sdk/internal/_wiki/wikis/internal.wiki/117/Setting-up-a-new-Unified-Pipeline)) and then issue the following comment on your github pull request: ``` /azp run prepare-pipelines ``` This will trigger a pipeline which analyzes the state of the repo-based on your commit and generates pipelines necessary to run PR validation. ### Run a release pipeline 1. Click on **Run pipeline**. 1. If the slide out panel displays checkbox on packages, select the package you would like to release, and deselect other packages. 1. If you want to release whatever commit is the HEAD of _main_, click **Run** on the slide out panel that is displayed. Our recommendation is to release against main. However, if you want to build a specific commit or branch, add the commit hash or branch name in the **Commit** field. > [!IMPORTANT] > Before running the build pipeline, make sure that your Core dependency (and any other inter-library dependency) > is correct for the current release. ### Wait for signing Once the pipeline started it will display a progress screen. Because releasing a package is a multi-stage process, we first build the package from scratch again, then sign the package. Wait until this step is completed. ### Inspect the package 1. Click on the **Artifacts** generated by the pipeline. 1. Select **packages-signed**. 1. Select each package you want to release and download it. 1. Spot check version and package name and inspect and/or test the package. Make sure you are satisfied with the quality. ### Approve the release > [!IMPORTANT] > Once a package is published to a package manger, the action is final and cannot be reversed. > While it is possible to remove or conceal problematic packages, reusing the same version number is not an option. > All future package releases require a version change at minimum. Each package generated by the pipeline has an individual approval checkpoint before it is finalized for publishing. This allows you to selectively approve a specific package for release while declining the rest. 1. Read our [Azure SDK approval release guidelines](xref:sdk-approval-release-guidelines). 1. Click on the **Review** button in the pipeline run to start the approval process. 1. Select which of the packages you want to approve for release. 1. Select **Reject** for the packages you do not want to release. >[!IMPORTANT] > Make sure to approve only your package's release stage as the pipeline is shared among multiple packages. ![Approve release example](../../img/approve_release.png) Once you click approve the pipeline will proceed to tag the sources that were just built with the package name and version and then publish the package to the appropriate package manager. ## Get help - Check our [FAQ](xref:faq#release-sdk-package) for common questions. - If you need help with the engineering system refer to [the EngSys support page](xref:support-engsys)."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"faqs#glossary.md","document_title":"Glossary terms for Azure SDKs","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/faqs/glossary","content":"# faqs#glossary.md # Glossary terms for Azure SDKs This glossary provides terms and definitions for Azure SDK concepts and tools. > [!NOTE] > This page is under construction. For more information about onboarding to Azure SDKs, check out our > [landing page](https://aka.ms/azsdk/join) or reach out to us on [Teams][Teams channel]. - *See* refers you to a non-preferred term to the preferred term or from an abbreviation to the spelled-out form. - *See also* refers you to a related or contrasting term. ----- [A](#a) - [B](#b) - [C](#c) - [D](#d) - [E](#e) - [F](#f) - [G](#g) - [H](#h) - [I](#i) - [J](#j) - [K](#k) - [L](#l) - [M](#m) - [N](#n) - [O](#o) - [P](#p) - [Q](#q) - [R](#r) - [S](#s) - [T](#t) - [U](#u) - [V](#v) - [W](#w) - [X](#x) - [Y](#y) - [Z](#z) ## A ### AFEC Azure Feature Exposure Control AFEC allows you to deploy your preview TypeSpec and OpenAPI ARM specs to a "private" set of customers. See [ARM wiki on AFEC] for details. ### API See [application programming interface](#application-programming-interface-api). ### API definition file A file that provides information about how an API functions, how it links with other APIs, and its expected results in machine-readable format. See also [API spec](#api-spec). ### API spec See [API definition file](#api-definition-file). ### API spec pipeline A pipeline that you can use to automatically check-in, validate, and sync API updates between the Azure DevOps repository where your service code resides, and the target GitHub repository where the files will be reviewed and published to external customers. ### APIView A tool that is used by the Azure SDK team to review APIs. It shows the full public API listing for REST APIs and client libraries, and lets you and others leave comments and feedback on specific lines of the API. ### Application programming interface (API) A software intermediary that allows two applications to interact with each other. It defines, for example, the kinds of calls or requests that can be made, how to make them, the data formats that should be used, and the conventions to follow. ### ARM [Azure Resource Manager](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-resource-manager/management/overview). In the context of [developing your OpenAPI specifications](xref:api-specs-pr), ARM is also known as: - `control plane` - `management plane` - `resource-manager` If you want to contact ARM team regarding questions about ARM API specifications, see [relevant question in the FAQ](xref:faq#i-have-a-question-about-arm-management-plane-api-specs). In the context of OpenAPI specifications, ARM specs are complemented by data plane specs. See also: - [data plane](#data-plane) - [ARM doc on control plane and data plane] ## B ### Beta SDK A test/early in-development version of a library. ## C ### Changelog History of all development for a library. ### Client library A library (tools, documentation, and samples) that customers can use to work with an Azure service. Each client library is published separately to the appropriate language-specific repository. ### Cloud Product Excellence Program (CPEX - Formerly called APEX) A process that provides a scorecard on launch readiness, where service owners review launch criteria and seek sign-offs with the criteria points-of-contact before major releases. Previously known as Product Launch Readiness (PLR). ### Control plane Another name for [ARM](#arm). See also [data plane](#data-plane). ## D ### Data plane The part of Azure that is responsible for providing data manipulation capabilities (e.g. CRUD operations) of resources deployed to Azure using [ARM](#arm). If you want to contact data plane team regarding questions about data plane API specifications, see [relevant question in the FAQ](xref:faq#i-have-a-question-about-data-plane-api-specs). In the context of OpenAPI specifications, data plane specs complement ARM specs. See also: - [ARM](#arm) - [ARM doc on control plane and data plane] ### Data plane code generation (DPG) Description TBU ## G ### GA **Generally Available**, a version of OpenAPI spec of given resource provider that has been released to the public. See also [Azure REST API versioning](xref:api-versioning). ### GA (Service) A final, vetted version of a service. ## I ### In-band Release Release during preset monthly release schedule. ### Informational meeting A type of meeting that you can book with the Azure SDK team. ## L ### Library The source code or binary code of the SDK. ## M ### Management plane Another name for [ARM](#arm). ## O ### OpenAPI A specification maintained by the OpenAPI Initiative for enabling humans and computers to discover and understand the capabilities of a service without requiring access to source code, additional documentation, or inspection of network traffic. Previously (until 2015) known as Swagger. > [!NOTE] > Due to historical reasons some of the tooling and artifacts you will encounter are named `Swagger` instead of > `OpenAPI spec`. > For example, `Swagger LintDiff` instead of `OpenAPI Spec LintDiff`. As of January 2024 in the context of this documentation OpenAPI refers to OpenAPI v2.0 Specification unless explicitly noted otherwise. See also: - [What is OpenAPI](xref:api-openapi) - [Swagger](#swagger) ### OpenAPI Hub This tool has been retired. For more information see our [migration guide](xref:openapihub). ### Out-of-band Release Release outside of preset monthly release schedule. ## P ### Package A client library after it is packaged and distributed for customers to use. For example: - A `NuGet` package for a .NET client library - A Maven package for a Java library - An `npm` package for a JavaScript library - A Python wheel for a Python library Can also be the zip file/ wrapper that contains and is used to deliver the library (may contain other files/metadata along with the library). ### Preview (Service) A test/early-in-development version of a service. ### Product Launch Readiness (PLR) See [Cloud Product Excellence Program (CPEX)](#cloud-product-excellence-program-cpex---formerly-called-apex). ## R ### READMEs A markdown file that introduces and explains key concepts and use cases for a service. ### Release Blog/Tweet Monthly notification of what is released. ### Release Notes Communication to customers about relevant/impacting changes. ### Release Planner An application that guides you through onboarding your product, creating plans for an upcoming API and SDK release, and tracking progress. ## resource-manager Another name for [ARM](#arm). ### REST API review A review that is designed to help you or your service team create developer-friendly and consistent REST APIs. All Azure REST APIs must be reviewed before they are published externally. ### REST API Stewardship Board Group of REST API experts at Microsoft that review REST API specs designed to help you create developer-friendly and consistent REST (data plane) APIs for your service. All Azure REST APIs need to be reviewed prior to publication. ## S ### Scheduler An application that you can use to schedule informational meetings, REST API reviews, and SDK reviews. ### SDK See [software development kit](#software-development-kit-sdk). ### SDK Archboard Description TBU ### SDK review A review that is designed to help Azure service teams create developer-friendly and consistent SDKs in supported languages. ### software development kit (SDK) The entire Azure SDK for a single language, which is broken up into numerous Azure SDK client libraries. ### Stable SDK A final, vetted version of a library. ### Swagger The name associated with some of the most well-known, and widely-used tools for implementing the OpenAPI specification. Blog post: [What Is the Difference Between Swagger and OpenAPI?](https://swagger.io/blog/api-strategy/difference-between-swagger-and-openapi/) See also [OpenAPI](#openapi). ## T ### track 1 library The set of client libraries that existed before Azure SDK design guidelines were established. ### track 2 library The set of client libraries that adhere to the design guidelines that were created were the Azure SDK team. All track 2 libraries reside in language-focused repositories on GitHub. ### TypeSpec A language for describing cloud service APIs and generating other API description languages, client and service code, documentation, and other assets. ## V ### Version (SDK) Indicates the iteration being released (X.X.X) - see [versioning guidelines](https://azure.github.io/azure-sdk/policies_releases.html#languages). ## Z [Teams channel]: https://teams.microsoft.com/l/channel/19%3ade3fce22c2994be18cac50502c55f717%40thread.skype/Azure%2520SDK%2520Onboarding?groupId=3e17dcb0-4257-4a30-b843-77f47f1d4121&tenantId=72f988bf-86f1-41af-91ab-2d7cd011db47 [ARM doc on control plane and data plane]: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-resource-manager/management/control-plane-and-data-plane [ARM wiki on AFEC]: https://armwiki.azurewebsites.net/rp_onboarding/afec/FeatureExposureControl.html"},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"develop#sdk-release#sdk-release-prerequisites.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/develop/sdk-release/sdk-release-prerequisites","content":"# Prerequisites to release client libraries (SDK) ## Update CHANGELOG file When SDK generation happens with automation, it automatically updates the `CHANGELOG.md` to track changes. The updates include: - Replacing `(unreleased)` with the current date in “YYYY-MM-DD” format. > [!NOTE] > Prior to starting the SDK release pipelines, you should confirm that the date for the latest version to be released is up to date to; or it can lead to pipeline failures. - Summarizing version updates under Features Added, Breaking Changes, Bug Fixes, and Other Changes. > [!NOTE] > To revise, you should only include sections that have content, leaving nonblank. rows.outputs.similarity.similarity_sample_inp: [{"role": "user", "content": "{\"query\": \"title: change the sdk release planner version\\n\\nquestion: Hi\\nGeneral\\nis there a way to change the sdk release planner version for python sdk? The release planner says version 1.0.0 for our python sdk. however, that was our last GA release version, and our generated PR changelog shows it is actually 1.1.0 version we want to release. is there a way to change this version in our release planner? thanks\\njavascript is also incorrect version:  (should be 1.1.0) and Go sdk is blank when it should be 2.0.0 from changelog:\\n```\\n```\", \"response\": \"To update the SDK version information in the Azure SDK Release Planner for Python, JavaScript, and Go, you need to ensure that the metadata in the release work items and the relevant CSV files are accurate. The Release Planner and the documentation system rely on the metadata from these sources to display correct version information for each language. \\n\\n**Action Steps:**\\n1. Update the release work items for your SDKs using the Prepare-Release.ps1 script to ensure the correct version is reflected for each language (Python, JavaScript, Go). This script updates the metadata that Release Planner uses to track versions.\\n2. If your package has already been released or the changelog/metadata is not updated, check the corresponding metadata CSV file (for example, `python-packages.csv`, `js-packages.csv`, `go-packages.csv`) located in `azure-sdk/_data/releases/latest/` in the Azure SDK repo. Update the `VersionGA` and/or `VersionPreview` fields to match the desired version (e.g., 1.1.0 for Python/JavaScript, 2.0.0 for Go).\\n3. After updating, commit your changes and create a PR. Once merged, the Release Planner and documentation site will reflect the updated versions.\\n4. For tracking progress and verifying the update, use the Release Planner summary and milestones views.\\n\\nIf you encounter issues with the Release Planner not updating after these changes, report a bug directly in Release Planner or reach out to the Azure SDK Onboarding channel for support.\\n\\n**References:**\\n- You can find more information about updating metadata and troubleshooting automated documentation updates in the onboarding and release docs.\\n- The changelog should be kept up to date before initiating release pipelines, as it affects automated version tracking.\\n\\nFor additional help, see the guidance below or contact the Azure SDK Onboarding channel.\", \"ground_truth\": \"the version of the packages reflects what currently exists on main on the languages repo,because your PR hasn't been merged, you are seeing the previous version,.NET was already merged, so you see the right version.\"}"}]

rows.inputs.ground_truth: This has been fixed in azure-sdk-for-net, and will be synced to azure-sdk-for-net-pr during the day. Your spec is in private repo, after the sync rerun should resolve this. And meanwhile, .NET SDK validation is optional for your spec PR merge, you can ignore it for now.
rows.inputs.response:
Based on your description and the provided build logs, the SDK Validation - .NET errors (CS0122: 'GeneratorPageableHelpers' is inaccessible due to its protection level) are caused by the generated C# code attempting to use the 'GeneratorPageableHelpers' class, which is not publicly accessible in the generated SDK. This issue typically arises from one of the following:

1. The TypeSpec C# emitter (@azure-tools/typespec-csharp) or its dependencies are out of date and do not match the expected helper accessibility.
2. Your tspconfig.yaml does not have the required configuration for management plane generation, resulting in incompatible or missing code stubs.
3. There is a known issue in the C# generator that needs to be resolved by updating the generator package or adjusting your configuration.

**How to resolve:**

- **Update your dependencies:**
  Ensure that your `package.json` contains the latest version of `@azure-tools/typespec-csharp`. Run `tsp install` to refresh dependencies.
  
- **Check tspconfig.yaml configuration:**
  For a management plane SDK, your tspconfig.yaml should include the following emitter options:

  ```yaml
  emit:
    - "@azure-tools/typespec-csharp"
  options:
    "@azure-tools/typespec-csharp":
      flavor: azure
      package-dir: "Azure.ResourceManager.Genome"
      clear-output-folder: true
      model-namespace: true
      namespace: "{package-dir}"
  ```

  Reference the [Contoso.Management sample tspconfig.yaml](https://aka.ms/azsdk/tspconfig-sample-mpg) for exact option usage.

- **Re-run code generation:**
  After updating your config and dependencies, run:
  ```bash
  tsp compile path/to/main.tsp
  ```
  and ensure the generated code does not reference inaccessible helpers.

- **If the issue persists:**
  This may be a regression or a bug in the generator. Reach out to the .NET Teams channel for help:
  [.NET Teams channel](https://teams.microsoft.com/l/channel/19%3a7b87fb348f224b37b6206fa9d89a105b%40thread.skype/Language%2520-%2520DotNet?groupId=3e17dcb0-4257-4a30-b843-77f47f1d4121&tenantId=72f988bf-86f1-41af-91ab-2d7cd011db47)
  Provide your PR link and details of the error.

**Summary:**
- Update your TypeSpec C# emitter to the latest version.
- Ensure tspconfig.yaml matches the management plane sample configuration.
- Re-run code generation and build.
- If unresolved, contact the .NET Teams channel with your PR and error details.

This approach is aligned with the Azure SDK engineering and TypeSpec guidance for .NET SDK validation issues.
