[{"document_source":"typespec_docs","document_filename":"emitters#clients#introduction.mdx","document_title":"Client Emitters","document_link":"https://typespec.io/docs/emitters/clients/introduction","content":"# emitters#clients#introduction.mdx # Client Emitters import { Aside, Steps } from "@astrojs/starlight/components"; ## How to Use Emitters to Generate HTTP Clients from TypeSpec ### Introduction This guide will walk you through the process of using different client emitters (JavaScript, Python, Java, C#) to generate HTTP clients from TypeSpec. Please note that all client emitters are currently in **preview** and are subject to changes in future versions. By following this guide, you will learn: 1. How to set up client emitters in `package.json`. 2. Update the client emitter configurations in `tspconfig.yaml`. 3. How to generate HTTP clients for each specific programming language. ## Location of All Client Emitters The client emitters are defined in the `package.json` file within your project. | **Emitter Name** | **Language** | **Version** | | ---------------------------- | ------------ | -------------------------------------------------------------- | | @typespec/http-client-js | JavaScript | ![](https://img.shields.io/npm/v/@typespec/http-client-js) | | @typespec/http-client-python | Python | ![](https://img.shields.io/npm/v/@typespec/http-client-python) | | @typespec/http-client-java | Java | ![](https://img.shields.io/npm/v/@typespec/http-client-java) | | @typespec/http-client-csharp | C# | ![](https://img.shields.io/npm/v/@typespec/http-client-csharp) | Below is an example of the `package.json` snippet where client emitters are defined: ```json "dependencies": { "@typespec/http-client-csharp": "^0.1.9-alpha.20250113.2", "@typespec/http-client-java": "^0.1.9", "@typespec/http-client-python": "^0.6.6", "@typespec/http-client-js": "^0.38.1", } ``` ## Client Emitter Settings This part provides an overview of the common and language-specific settings for each client emitter. These settings are stored in the `tspconfig.yaml` file. ### Common Configuration Options The below option applies to all client emitters. - `emitter-output-dir`: Defines where the generated SDK files will be stored. ### JavaScript Client Emitter Settings JavaScript generally requires minimal configuration. However, it is recommended to provide `packageDetails` for package metadata, which is used in `package.json` and `README.md` files. #### packageDetails Provide the metadata for `package.json`, `README.md` information. | Property | Description | | ----------- | ---------------------------------------------------------------------- | | name | Package name used in `package.json` | | description | Package description used in `package.json` file | | version | Detailed version for your package, the default value is `1.0.0-beta.1` | Example configuration: ```yaml packageDetails: name: "${your_package_name}" version: 1.0.0 ``` ### Java Client Emitter Settings #### Prerequisites Before using the Java client emitter, ensure the following dependencies are installed: - **Java 17 or later** - [Download here](https://docs.microsoft.com/java/openjdk/download) _(Verify installation with `java --version`)_ - **Maven** - [Download here](https://maven.apache.org/download.cgi) _(Verify installation with `mvn --version`)_ ### C# Client Emitter Settings Before using the C# client emitter, ensure that the [.NET 8.0 SDK](https://dotnet.microsoft.com/en-us/download/dotnet/8.0) (or higher) is installed. Full configuration options can be found in the [C# Client Emitter README](https://github.com/microsoft/typespec/blob/main/packages/http-client-csharp/readme.md#configuration) ## JavaScript Client Emitter Example ### Step 1: Install Dependencies Add the following dependencies to your `package.json` file: ```json "dependencies": { "@typespec/http-client-js": "^0.38.1" } ``` Run the following command to install the dependencies: ```bash tsp install ``` ### Step 2: Update Configuration Update your `tspconfig.yaml` file with the following configuration: ```yaml emit: - "@typespec/http-client-js" options: "@typespec/http-client-js": emitter-output-dir: "{project-root}/clients/javascript" packageDetails: name: "your_package_name" version: 1.0.0 ``` ### Step 3: Generate Client Run the following command to generate the JavaScript client: ```bash tsp compile {path to main.tsp}/main.tsp ``` ## Python Client Emitter Example ### Step 1: Install Dependencies Add the following dependencies to your `package.json` file: ```json "dependencies": { "@typespec/http-client-python": "^0.6.6" } ``` Run the following command to install the dependencies: ```bash tsp install ``` ### Step 2: Update Configuration Update your `tspconfig.yaml` file with the following configuration: ```yaml emit: - "@typespec/http-client-python" options: "@typespec/http-client-python": emitter-output-dir: "{project-root}/clients/python" ``` ### Step 3: Generate Client Run the following command to generate the Python client: ```bash tsp compile {path to main.tsp}/main.tsp ``` ## Java Client Emitter Example ### Step 1: Install Dependencies Add the following dependencies to your `package.json` file: ```json "dependencies": { "@typespec/http-client-java": "^0.1.9" } ``` Run the following command to install the dependencies: ```bash tsp install ``` ### Step 2: Update Configuration Update your `tspconfig.yaml` file with the following configuration: ```yaml emit: - "@typespec/http-client-java" options: "@typespec/http-client-java": emitter-output-dir: "{project-root}/clients/java" ``` ### Step 3: Generate Client Run the following command to generate the Java client: ```bash tsp compile {path to main.tsp}/main.tsp ``` ## C# Client Emitter Example ### Step 1: Install Dependencies Add the following dependencies to your `package.json` file: ```json "dependencies": { "@typespec/http-client-csharp": "^0.1.9-alpha.20250113.2" } ``` Run the following command to install the dependencies: ```bash tsp install ``` ### Step 2: Update Configuration Update your `tspconfig.yaml` file with the following configuration: ```yaml emit: - "@typespec/http-client-csharp" options: "@typespec/http-client-csharp": emitter-output-dir: "{project-root}/clients/dotnet" ``` ### Step 3: Generate Client Run the following command to generate the C# client: ```bash tsp compile {path to main.tsp}/main.tsp ``` ## Running Language-Specific Emitters in CLI 1. Ensure that your package.json file is correctly configured to include the necessary dependencies for running the emitters 2. Update the tspconfig.yaml file for properly configured for the language-specific emitter. ```yaml emit: - "@typespec/http-client-csharp" - "@typespec/http-client-java" - "@typespec/http-client-python" - "@typespec/http-client-js" options: "@typespec/http-client-csharp": emitter-output-dir: "{project-root}/clients/dotnet" "@typespec/http-client-java": emitter-output-dir: "{project-root}/clients/java" "@typespec/http-client-python": emitter-output-dir: "{project-root}/clients/python" "@typespec/http-client-js": emitter-output-dir: "{project-root}/clients/javascript" ``` 3. Once the package.json and tspconfig.yaml files are updated, you need to install all required dependencies by running the following command in the project root: ```bash tsp install ``` 4. Run the emitter to compile your TypeScript code into the desired language. Use the following command to trigger the emitter and compile your project: ```bash tsp compile {path to main.tsp}/main.tsp ``` ## Disclaimer
**All client emitters are in preview**. These emitters are actively being developed and may experience changes or updates that could affect their functionality. Please follow the official documentation for the latest updates. - [TypeSpec C# emitter library](https://github.com/microsoft/typespec/blob/main/packages/http-client-csharp/readme.md) - [TypeSpec Python emitter library](https://github.com/microsoft/typespec/blob/main/packages/http-client-python/README.md) - [TypeSpec Java emitter library](https://github.com/microsoft/typespec/blob/main/packages/http-client-java/README.md) - [TypeSpec JS emitter library](https://github.com/Azure/autorest.typescript/blob/main/packages/typespec-ts/README.md)
"},{"document_source":"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki","document_filename":"TypeSpec-Validation.md","document_title":"Table of Contents","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/TypeSpec-Validation","content":"# TypeSpec-Validation.md # Table of Contents - [Running Locally](#running-locally) - [Examples Source and Destination](#examples-source-and-destination) - [Validation Rule Suppression](#validation-rule-suppression) - [Rules](#rules) - [SdkTspConfigValidation](#SdkTspConfigValidation) - [JavaScript](#JavaScript-Sub-Rules) - [Python](#Python-Sub-Rules) - [Go](#Go-Sub-Rules) - [Java](#Java-Sub-Rules) - [.Net](#Net-Sub-Rules) # Running Locally To ensure you see the same results from TypeSpecValidation in your PR check and `tsv` on your local machine: 1. Merge latest from parent (e.g. `main` or `RPSaaSMaster`) to your PR branch 2. Run locally 1. `git clean -xdf` (may revert any local changes) 2. `git pull` 3. `npm ci` 4. `npx tsv specification/widget/resource-manager/Microsoft.Widget/Widget` 5. `git status` 6. If any changes, `git add`, `git commit`, `git push` to update your PR. 3. If you are still having problems, try cloning your branch to a new folder, or try on another machine. 4. If the problem can be reproduced on a clean machine, request assistance from the [TypeSpec Discussion](https://teams.microsoft.com/l/channel/19%3A906c1efbbec54dc8949ac736633e6bdf%40thread.skype/TypeSpec%20Discussion?groupId=3e17dcb0-4257-4a30-b843-77f47f1d4121&tenantId=72f988bf-86f1-41af-91ab-2d7cd011db47) teams channel. # Examples Source and Destination If you are having problems with diffs from "tsp compile" related to examples, ensure you understand how examples flow from source to destination. The **source** of examples is under your TypeSpec source code folder, and the **destination** of examples is under the Swagger folder. The TypeSpec compiler copies from source to destination. In our sample: * source * https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/tree/main/specification/contosowidgetmanager/Contoso.Management/examples/2021-10-01-preview * destination * https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/tree/main/specification/contosowidgetmanager/resource-manager/Microsoft.Contoso/preview/2021-10-01-preview/examples If you are changing examples, you must **first** change the copy under your TypeSpec folder, and then run `tsp compile` (or `tsv` which calls `compile`) to update the copies in your Swagger folder. # Validation Rule Suppression You can suppress specific validation rules within `TypeSpecValidation` by creating or modifying a `suppressions.yaml` file in the root directory of your service specification. > **Note:** Currently, only the `SdkTspConfigValidation` rule supports suppression. ## Suppressing SdkTspConfigValidation Rules The `SdkTspConfigValidation` rule is responsible for validating emitter options and parameters defined in your `tspconfig.yaml` file. You have the flexibility to suppress this rule entirely or target specific sub-rules within it. ### Suppress the Entire SdkTspConfigValidation Rule If you need to skip **all** validation checks for emitter options and parameters within a particular `tspconfig.yaml` file, you can suppress the entire `SdkTspConfigValidation` rule. To do this, add or update the `suppressions.yaml` file in your service's root folder with the following content: ```yaml - tool: TypeSpecValidation paths: # Specify the path to the tspconfig.yaml file where suppression should apply - /path/to/tspconfig.yaml rules: - SdkTspConfigValidation reason: the-reason-you-want-to-suppress # Explain why this suppression is necessary ``` ### Suppress Specific Sub-rules within SdkTspConfigValidation If you only need to bypass validation for **specific** emitter options or parameters, you can suppress individual sub-rules. Add or update your `suppressions.yaml` file with the following structure, specifying the sub-rules to ignore: Sub-rule Syntax: - For parameters: `parameters..default` - For emitter options: `options..` - For nested options (e.g., `package-details: name: "xxx"`), use dot notation: `options..package-details.name` ```yaml - tool: TypeSpecValidation paths: # Specify the path to the tspconfig.yaml file where suppression should apply - /path/to/tspconfig.yaml rules: - SdkTspConfigValidation sub-rules: # Example: Suppress validation for a specific parameter's default value - parameters..default # Example: Suppress validation for a specific emitter option - options.. # Example: Suppress validation for a nested emitter option - options..package-details.name reason: the-reason-you-want-to-suppress # Explain why this suppression is necessary ``` # Rules ## SdkTspConfigValidation ### Parameters - **`parameters.default.service-dir`** - Allowed values: strings that matches the regex `/^sdk\/.*$/` - example: `sdk/aaa` ### JavaScript Sub Rules Plane - [**`@azure-tools/typespec-ts.options.package-dir`**](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/specification/contosowidgetmanager/Contoso.WidgetManager/tspconfig.yaml#L33) - Allowed values: strings that matches the regex `/^(?:[a-z]+-)+rest$/` - example: `arm-aaa-rest` - [**`@azure-tools/typespec-ts.options.package-details.name`**](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/specification/contosowidgetmanager/Contoso.WidgetManager/tspconfig.yaml#L35) - Allowed values: strings that matches the regex `/^\@azure-rest\/[a-z]+(?:-[a-z]+)*$/` - example: `@azure-rest/aaa-bbb` > Please follow the below steps to configure. If you encounter any issues, please seek help in the JS channel #### Management Plane - [**`@azure-tools/typespec-ts.options.experimental-extensible-enums`**](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/specification/contosowidgetmanager/Contoso.Management/tspconfig.yaml#L32) - Allowed values: `true` - [**`@azure-tools/typespec-ts.options.package-dir`**](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/specification/contosowidgetmanager/Contoso.Management/tspconfig.yaml#L30) - Allowed values: strings that matches the regex `/^arm-[^\/]+$/` - example: `arm-aaa-bbb` - [**`@azure-tools/typespec-ts.options.package-details.name`**](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/specification/contosowidgetmanager/Contoso.Management/tspconfig.yaml#L34) - Allowed values: strings that matches the regex `/^\@azure\/arm(?:-[a-z]+)+$/` - example: `@azure/arm-aaa-bbb` #### Data Plane - [**`@azure-tools/typespec-ts.options.package-dir`**](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/specification/contosowidgetmanager/Contoso.WidgetManager/tspconfig.yaml#L33) - Allowed values: strings that matches the regex `/^(?:[a-z]+-)+rest$/` - example: `arm-aaa-rest` - [**`@azure-tools/typespec-ts.options.package-details.name`**](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/specification/contosowidgetmanager/Contoso.WidgetManager/tspconfig.yaml#L35) ### Python Sub Rules > Please follow the below steps to configure. If you encounter any issues, please seek help in the python channel #### Management Plane - [**`@azure-tools/typespec-python.options.package-dir`**](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/specification/contosowidgetmanager/Contoso.Management/tspconfig.yaml#L19) - Allowed values: strings that matches the regex `/^azure-mgmt(-[a-z]+){1,2}$/` - example: `azure-mgmt-aaa` - [**`@azure-tools/typespec-python.options.namespace`**](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/specification/contosowidgetmanager/Contoso.Management/tspconfig.yaml#L20) - Allowed values: strings that matches the regex `/^azure\.mgmt(\.[a-z]+){1,2}$/` - example: `azure.mgmt.aaa` - [**`@azure-tools/typespec-python.options.generate-test`**](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/specification/contosowidgetmanager/Contoso.Management/tspconfig.yaml#L21) - Allowed values: `true` - [**`@azure-tools/typespec-python.options.generate-sample`**](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/specification/contosowidgetmanager/Contoso.Management/tspconfig.yaml#L22) - Allowed values: `true` #### Data Plane - [**`@azure-tools/typespec-python.options.package-dir`**](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/specification/contosowidgetmanager/Contoso.WidgetManager/tspconfig.yaml#L18) - Allowed values: strings that matches the regex `/^azure(-[a-z]+){1,3}$/` - Allowed values: `true` #### Data Plane - [**`@azure-tools/typespec-python.options.package-dir`**](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/specification/contosowidgetmanager/Contoso.WidgetManager/tspconfig.yaml#L18) - Allowed values: strings that matches the regex `/^azure(-[a-z]+){1,3}$/` - example: `azure-aaa-bbb-ccc` ### Go Sub Rules > Please follow the below steps to configure. If you encounter any issues, please "},{"document_source":"azure_sdk_for_python_docs","document_filename":"dev#issues#resolve_issues_effectively.md","document_title":"Resolve Issues Effectively","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/main/doc/dev/issues/resolve_issues_effectively.md","content":"# dev#issues#resolve_issues_effectively.md # Resolve Issues Effectively Azure Python SDK is an open-source project. It allows users to create issues in the forum to ask questions, report bugs and provide feedback. Most issues can be classified into 3 categories. They are 1. Usage error. 2. Feature request. 3. Bug report. ## Usage error (For users) If you are not familiar with the SDK usage of a service, you can find relevant examples in [this repo][sample repo] in most cases. For some common errors, you can check [here](#summary-of-common-errors). ## Feature Request (For users) Python SDKs are automatically generated based on REST API, so we generally do not recommend modifying SDK code manually. If you need a new function, but the SDK does not provide it, you need to open an issue in the [REST API repository](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/issues) to describe clearly the feature you want. ## Bug Report (For users) Please describe the bug in as much detail as possible, such as listing the SDK package name, version and operating system info you use. If you can provide detailed reproduction steps, it will help us locate and solve the issue. ## Summary Of Common Errors ### Error from Track1 to Track2 If the code you use needs to set wait() function for the Long Running Operation to wait for the result, it should be the SDK of Track1. We have stopped maintenance at present. We strongly recommend that you update the SDK version. Then you will find that in the SDK of Track2, we all use the function name prefixed with `begin_` for LRO operations, and the result() method can be used to get the returned result. (More Details: [guidance][guidance]) ### Possible Error from Service Since the python SDK is generated based on the [rest API][rest API], it will not deliberately change the returned results. So if you think the returned result is not as expected, please open the issue under the [rest issue][rest issue].
## Resolve issue (For contributors) Bug report is one of the most common issues reported in open-source community. Basic steps to resolve a bug report are 1. Confirm the bug. 2. Locate the fault. 3. Fix the bug. ### Confirm the Bug Confirm whether it is a bug. If you can definitely identify it is a bug according description of the issue, then go to next step. Otherwise, try to reproduce the bug by yourself. You can ask the issue reporter for details such as version, concrete steps and logs so that you can understand the issue better and it is more likely to be able to reproduce the bug. It is not rare that it is not a bug. Instead, it is a usage error. Refer to "Usage Error" section. ### Locate the Fault Fault localization is critical to bug fix. Some tips: 1. Analyzing logs. It helps you understand the bug. 2. Step-by-step debugging. Most modern IDEs provide integrated debugging experience. ### Fix the bug Once you have confirmed the bug and found the fault location, it should be easy to fix the bug. Add a sample if it is missing. Remember to tell users when the fix will released. ## Common Principles If the issue is not from the SDK but from the [rest API][rest API], you can reply to the user and reopen the issue in the appropriate place. ### Error like (AttributeError: 'PipelineResponse' object has no attribute 'get') When this error occurs, you can check the version of `msrest` and upgrade it to latest version then try again. [sample repo]: https://github.com/Azure-Samples/azure-samples-python-management [rest API]: https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs [rest issue]: https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/issues [SDK dependency]: https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/main/shared_requirements.txt [guidance]: https://devblogs.microsoft.com/azure-sdk/migrating-python-management-libraries/"},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"support#support.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/support/support","content":"# support#support.md | Short Link: | [aka.ms/azsdk/support](https://aka.ms/azsdk/support) | | --- | --- | # Get help and support If you have problems or questions when using Azure SDK tools or releasing your updates, you can get help by following guidance provided in this article. ## Get help with PRs submitted against the Azure REST API specification repositories If you submitted a pull request against the specs repositories by following the [Create or update an Azure REST API spec](xref:api-specs-pr) article, first check the description and comments on the pull request to troubleshoot any issues. Next, check [relevant section in our FAQ](xref:faq#azure-rest-api-specs-prs). Finally, if you need more help, see the [Get more help](#get-more-help) section. ## Get help with the Azure SDKs development If you need help with the development or testing of the SDK refer to the language-specific teams channels: - [.NET Teams channel] - [C Teams channel] - [C++ Teams channel] - [Java Teams channel] - [Go Teams channel] - [Mobile Teams Channel] - [Python Teams channel] - [Rust Teams channel] - [TypeScript/JS Teams channel] ## Get help with the Azure SDKs Engineering system (language repositories) If you need help with the engineering system supporting the `azure-sdk-for-*` language repositories, like e.g. [azure-sdk-for-python], refer to [the EngSys support page](xref:support-engsys). ## Provide feedback on this documentation Please use the **Is this page helpful?** buttons. We read your comments! ## Get more help [C++ Teams channel]: https://teams.microsoft.com/l/channel/19%3aa5180a2de11a40cb83a822f588d60c15%40thread.skype/Language%2520-%2520C%25E1%2590%25A9%25E1%2590%25A9?groupId=3e17dcb0-4257-4a30-b843-77f47f1d4121&tenantId=72f988bf-86f1-41af-91ab-2d7cd011db47 [Go Teams channel]: https://teams.microsoft.com/l/channel/19%3a104f00188bb64ef48d1b4d94ccb7a361%40thread.skype/Language%2520-%2520Go?groupId=3e17dcb0-4257-4a30-b843-77f47f1d4121&tenantId=72f988bf-86f1-41af-91ab-2d7cd011db47 [Mobile Teams Channel]: https://teams.microsoft.com/l/channel/19%3aae8aa86450294f31872cb9e2b1b13290%40thread.skype/Language%2520-%2520Mobile?groupId=3e17dcb0-4257-4a30-b843-77f47f1d4121&tenantId=72f988bf-86f1-41af-91ab-2d7cd011db47 [C Teams channel]: https://teams.microsoft.com/l/channel/19%3af6e9c4bfec9246feb4920537e08c0a4d%40thread.skype/Language%2520-%2520C?groupId=3e17dcb0-4257-4a30-b843-77f47f1d4121&tenantId=72f988bf-86f1-41af-91ab-2d7cd011db47 [Rust Teams channel]: https://teams.microsoft.com/l/channel/19%3A93ad56ee1ff149eb9f233bcf6432399e%40thread.skype/Language%20-%20Rust?groupId=3e17dcb0-4257-4a30-b843-77f47f1d4121&tenantId=72f988bf-86f1-41af-91ab-2d7cd011db47 If none of the scenarios in this article describe your situation, reach out to us on the [Azure SDK / Azure SDK Onboarding] channel. When applicable, provide a URL relevant to your problem, like validation check failure, pull request, documentation page, etc. [Azure SDK / Azure SDK Onboarding]: https://aka.ms/azsdk/support/onboarding-channel [azure-sdk-for-python]: https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python [.NET Teams channel]: https://teams.microsoft.com/l/channel/19%3a7b87fb348f224b37b6206fa9d89a105b%40thread.skype/Language%2520-%2520DotNet?groupId=3e17dcb0-4257-4a30-b843-77f47f1d4121&tenantId=72f988bf-86f1-41af-91ab-2d7cd011db47 [Java Teams channel]: https://teams.microsoft.com/l/channel/19%3a5e673e41085f4a7eaaf20823b85b2b53%40thread.skype/Language%2520-%2520Java?groupId=3e17dcb0-4257-4a30-b843-77f47f1d4121&tenantId=72f988bf-86f1-41af-91ab-2d7cd011db47 [TypeScript/JS Teams channel]: https://teams.microsoft.com/l/channel/19%3a344f6b5b36ba414daa15473942c7477b%40thread.skype/Language%2520%25E2%2580%2593%2520JS%25E2%2580%2589%25EF%25BC%2586%25E2%2580%2589TS%2520%25F0%259F%25A5%25B7 [Python Teams channel]: https://teams.microsoft.com/l/channel/19%3ab97d98e6d22c41e0970a1150b484d935%40thread.skype/Language%2520-%2520Python?groupId=3e17dcb0-4257-4a30-b843-77f47f1d4121&tenantId=72f988bf-86f1-41af-91ab-2d7cd011db47 [C++ Teams channel]: https://teams.microsoft.com/l/channel/19%3aa5180a2de11a40cb83a822f588d60c15%40thread.skype/Language%2520-%2520C%25E1%2590%25A9%25E1%2590%25A9?groupId=3e17dcb0-4257-4a30-b843-77f47f1d4121&tenantId=72f988bf-86f1-41af-91ab-2d7cd011db47 [Go Teams channel]: https://teams.microsoft.com/l/channel/19%3a104f00188bb64ef48d1b4d94ccb7a361%40thread.skype/Language%2520-%2520Go?groupId=3e17dcb0-4257-4a30-b843-77f47f1d4121&tenantId=72f988bf-86f1-41af-91ab-2d7cd011db47"},{"document_source":"static_typespec_qa","document_filename":"typespec_2025_09_12.md","document_title":"SDK Validation steps are failing with not much helpful logs","document_link":"","content":"# typespec_2025_09_12.md # SDK Validation steps are failing with not much helpful logs ## question We’re in the process of creating a new API version within our RP. However, all SDK-related checks are currently failing, and we’re unable to identify any issues flagged in our changes. Could you please assist us in resolving these failures at the earliest? Your support will help us move forward without further delays. ``` Errors occurred while generating SDK from specification/advisor. Follow the steps at https://aka.ms/azsdk/sdk-automation-faq#how-to-view-the-detailed-sdk-generation-errors to view detailed errors. "package-dir" support is deprecated and will be removed in future versions. [ERROR] Error reading tsp-location.yaml: Error: ENOENT: no such file or directory, stat '/mnt/vss/_work/1/s/azure-sdk-for-go-pr/sdk/resourcemanager/advisor/armadvisor/tsp-location.yaml' [ERROR] Diagnostics were reported during compilation. Use the `--debug` flag to see if there is warning diagnostic output. [ERROR] /mnt/vss/_work/1/s/azure-sdk-for-go-pr/sdk/resourcemanager/advisor/armadvisor/TempTypeSpecFiles/Advisor.Management/back-compatible.tsp:7:37 - error invalid-ref: Namespace Azure.ClientGenerator.Core.Legacy doesn't have member flattenProperty [ERROR] /mnt/vss/_work/1/s/azure-sdk-for-go-pr/sdk/resourcemanager/advisor/armadvisor/TempTypeSpecFiles/Advisor.Management/client.tsp:7:37 - error invalid-ref: Namespace Azure.ClientGenerator.Core.Legacy doesn't have member flattenProperty output. SDK Validation - .NET - PR Failing after 7m — Build #20250911.25 failed SDK Validation - Go - PR Failing after 4m — Build #20250911.25 failed SDK Validation - Java - PR Failing after 4m — Build #20250911.25 failed SDK Validation - JS - PR Failing after 3m — Build #20250911.25 failed SDK Validation - Python - PR Failing after 7m — Build #20250911.25 failed Merging is blocked ``` PR: [Advisor Risks : 2025-09-01-preview by pranatiy0701 · Pull Request #24395 · Azure/azure-rest-api-spe…](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/pull/24395) ## answer It looks like your PR is against the main branch of the private repo - we don't check api specs into this branch. The sdk failures for flattenProperty are due to those SDKs not being up-to-date with the latest version of typespec-client-generator-core, which was released earlier this week. Since you are not checking this spec in to the main branch of the private repo, these can be safely ignored."},{"document_source":"static_typespec_qa","document_filename":"typespec_2025_05_22.md","document_title":"Typespec Validation Failing on PR due to `typespec-go` configuration missing","document_link":"","content":"# typespec_2025_05_22.md # Typespec Validation Failing on PR due to `typespec-go` configuration missing ## question Hi TypeSpec Discussion, CI has been failing constantly for our PR ([Azure Load Testing\] Add 2025-03-01-preview Data-Plane APIs by Harshan01 · Pull Request #32585 · Azure/azure-rest-api-specs](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/pull/32585)) for Typespec Validation step. The logs show that we are missing the Go SDK configuration and I am able to produce this error locally as well. However, our service doesnt have a Go SDK and we are not planning to put it in scope right now. This check has suddenly started failing for our PRs, what should we do? ``` Executing rule：SdkTspConfigVa1idation [SdkTspconfigVa1idation]：validation failed． - Failed to find "options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.generate-fakes"．Please add "options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.generate-fakes". - Failed to find "options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.inject一spans“．Please add "options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.inject一spans. - Failed to find "options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.service-dir"．Please add "options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.service-dir". - Failed to find "options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.package-dir"．Please add"options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.package-dir". Please See https://aka.ms/azsdk/spec-gen-sdk-config for more info． For additional information on TypeSpec validation, please refer to https://aka.ms/azsdk/specs/typespec-validation. ``` ## answer Suppressing go specific rules worked for me (locally, checking CI now). Thanks Mike. Also FYI Darren Cohen. Here's our suppression file: ```yml - tool: TypeSpecValidation paths: - tspconfig.yaml rules: - SdkTspConfigValidation sub-rules: # Suppress validation for a Go emitter options - options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.generate-fakes - options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.inject-spans - options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.service-dir - options.@azure-tools/typespec-go.package-dir reason: 'Azure Load Testing does not support a Go SDK currently' ``` Let me know if I can help with anything!"},{"document_source":"static_typespec_qa","document_filename":"typespec_2025_06_26.md","document_title":"Swagger breaking change","document_link":"","content":"# typespec_2025_06_26.md # Swagger breaking change ## question PR check run: https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/pull/35346/checks?check_run_id=44501918225 My typespec conversion PR is failing in swagger breaking change check with the following error: "new":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/a1ac3f6f98bb1ea3583b765d00dfceab6d85654f/specification/devtestlabs/resource-manager/Microsoft.DevTestLab/stable/2018-09-15/DTL.json", "old":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/specification/devtestlabs/resource-manager/Microsoft.DevTestLab/stable/2018-09-15/DTL.json", "details":"incompatible properties : tags\n definitions/TrackedResource/properties/tags\n at file:///mnt/vss/_work/1/azure-rest-api-specs/specification/common-types/resource-management/v3/types.json#L489:8\n definitions/Resource/properties/tags\n at file:///mnt/vss/_work/1/azure-rest-api-specs/specification/devtestlabs/resource-manager/Microsoft.DevTestLab/stable/2018-09-15/DTL.json#L12397:8" This PR is just having typespec conversion change and I am avoiding any change to the swagger file that is generated as part of typespec conversion. In the old swagger there is a Resource definitionwhich is similar Azure resource definition. Should I suppress this check and how to do it? ## answer This occurs because in your original swagger, you did not use swagger common-types. The 'tags' definitions are compatible, so there is no change in the actual api from this. This could result in changes in some management sdks, although this change to using the common resource types has generally been accepted. docs on suppressions for false positives are here: [Suppress validation failures on a PR](https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/specs-pr-guides/pr-suppressions) Note that it is important to go through these violations, as the conversion is not guaranteed to be 100% accurate."},{"document_source":"static_typespec_migration_docs","document_filename":"typespec-migration-docs-2025-08-14.md","document_title":"The number of enums in the old and new Swagger don't match","document_link":"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/migrate-swagger/faq/breakingchange","content":"# typespec-migration-docs-2025-08-14.md # The number of enums in the old and new Swagger don't match ## question ```diff { "name": "recommendationType", "in": "query", "type": "string", "enum": [ "CreateIndex", "DropIndex", + "ReIndex", "AnalyzeTable" ], "x-ms-enum": { "name": "RecommendationType", "modelAsString": true } } }， ``` ## answer This may be caused by two enums with the same name but different content being treated as the same enum by TypeSpec, which cannot be resolved at the moment and needs to be documented in the PR description"},{"document_source":"static_typespec_migration_docs","document_filename":"typespec-migration-docs-2025-07-17.md","document_title":"Missing "externalDocs"","document_link":"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/migrate-swagger/faq/breakingchange","content":"# typespec-migration-docs-2025-07-17.md # Missing "externalDocs" ## question ```diff "put": { "operationId": "SavingsPlanOrderAlias_Create", - "externalDocs": { - "url": "https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=2215851/" - }, "parameters": [ ``` ## answer Add above the corresponding operation: @OpenAPI.externalDocs("https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=2215851/ ")"},{"document_source":"typespec_azure_docs","document_filename":"howtos#generate-with-tsp-client#repo_setup.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/howtos/generate-with-tsp-client/repo_setup","content":"# Repo setup Each repository that intends to support `tsp-client` for generating and updating client libraries will need to set up an `emitter-package.json` file under the `eng/` directory at the root of the repository. Client libraries generated with this tool will be outputted based on the information in the tspconfig.yaml file of the TypeSpec specification. The service directory is specified through the `parameters.service-dir.default` parameter in the tspconfig.yaml, additionally the `emitter-output-dir` option for the specific emitter is appended to the end of the path. See the following example of a valid tspconfig.yaml file: https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/specification/contosowidgetmanager/Contoso.WidgetManager/tspconfig.yaml Using the tspconfig.yaml linked above, by default, the client libraries will be generated in the following directory for C#: `/sdk/contosowidgetmanager/Azure.Template.Contoso/`."},{"document_source":"typespec_azure_docs","document_filename":"howtos#generate-client-libraries#10versioning.mdx","document_title":"","document_link":"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/howtos/generate-client-libraries/10versioning","content":"# Versioning ## Multiple api versions ### Override to a specific version You can override the signature to return the api surface area for a specific api version. In this example, you can see how this change is made in tspconfig.yaml, and we are going to override to return the preview api surface area for our spec. The preview api surface area contains all of the functionality. ```yaml title=tspconfig.yaml options: "@azure-tools/typespec-python": api-version: "2023-11-01-preview" "@azure-tools/typespec-csharp": api-version: "2023-11-01-preview" "@azure-tools/typespec-ts": api-version: "2023-11-01-preview" "@azure-tools/typespec-java": api-version: "2023-11-01-preview" "@azure-tools/typespec-go": api-version: "2023-11-01-preview" ``` ```"},{"document_source":"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki","document_filename":"TypeSpec-Validation.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/TypeSpec-Validation","content":"# Rules ## SdkTspConfigValidation ### .Net Sub Rules > Please follow the below steps to configure. If you encounter any issues, please seek help in the .Net channel #### Management Plane - [**`@azure-tools/typespec-csharp.options.package-dir`**](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/specification/contosowidgetmanager/Contoso.Management/tspconfig.yaml#L14) - Allowed values: strings that matches the regex `/^Azure\.ResourceManager\./` - example: `Azure.ResourceManager.AAA` - [**`@azure-tools/typespec-csharp.options.namespace`**](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/specification/contosowidgetmanager/Contoso.Management/tspconfig.yaml#L17) - Allowed values: `package-dir` or `{package-dir}` - example: `package-dir`, `Azure.ResourceManager.AAA` - [**`@azure-tools/typespec-csharp.options.clear-output-folder`**](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/specification/contosowidgetmanager/Contoso.Management/tspconfig.yaml#L15) - Allowed values: `true` #### Data Plane - [**`@azure-tools/typespec-csharp.options.package-dir`**](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/specification/contosowidgetmanager/Contoso.WidgetManager/tspconfig.yaml#L24) - Allowed values: strings that start with `Azure.` - example: `Azure.aaa` - [**`@azure-tools/typespec-csharp.options.namespace`**](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/specification/contosowidgetmanager/Contoso.WidgetManager/tspconfig.yaml#L26) - Allowed values: `package-dir` or `{package-dir}`"},{"document_source":"azure_sdk_for_go_docs","document_filename":"development#breaking-changes#sdk-breaking-changes-guide-migration.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-go/blob/main/documentation/development/breaking-changes/sdk-breaking-changes-guide-migration.md","content":"# Azure Go SDK Breaking Changes Review and Resolution Guide for TypeSpec Migration ## TypeSpec Configuration Changes TypeSpec configuration changes should be made in the `tspconfig.yaml` file located in the service's specification directory. This file configures the TypeSpec compiler and client generator options. For example: ```yaml options: "@azure-tools/typespec-go": fix-const-stuttering: false ``` For client customizations and `client.tsp` setup instructions, refer to the [main breaking changes guide](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-go/blob/main/documentation/development/breaking-changes/sdk-breaking-changes-guide.md)."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"design#api-spec-gen-sdk-config.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-spec-gen-sdk-config","content":"# SDK generation configuration ## Enable SDK generation ### [TypeSpec](#tab/typespec) Add the specific SDK language emitter settings to `tspconfig.yaml`. For example, to generate CSharp SDK code from your TypeSpecs: 1. Add `@azure-tools/typespec-csharp` to the `options` settings in `tspconfig.yaml`. 2. Refer to the 'ContosoWidgetManager' samples to set the default values for each SDK language emitter: - For management plane TypeSpecs, refer to [Contoso.Management tspconfig.yaml](https://aka.ms/azsdk/tspconfig-sample-mpg). - For data plane TypeSpecs, refer to [Contoso.WidgetManager tspconfig.yaml](https://aka.ms/azsdk/tspconfig-sample-dpg). ```` "@azure-tools/typespec-csharp": flavor: azure package-dir: "Azure.ResourceManager.Contoso" clear-output-folder: true model-namespace: true namespace: "{package-dir}" ````"},{"document_source":"typespec_azure_docs","document_filename":"howtos#generate-client-libraries#00howtogen.mdx","document_title":"","document_link":"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/howtos/generate-client-libraries/00howtogen","content":"# How to generate client libraries "latest", "@azure-tools/typespec-azure-core": "latest", "@azure-tools/typespec-autorest": "latest", "@azure-tools/typespec-python": "latest", "@azure-tools/typespec-java": "latest", "@azure-tools/typespec-csharp": "latest", "@azure-tools/typespec-ts": "latest", "@azure-tools/typespec-go": "latest" }, "private": true } ``` Always update your `tspconfig.yaml` file rather than passing options through the command line. ```yaml emit: # Emitter for Swagger files with Autorest Extensions - "@azure-tools/typespec-autorest" # add "@azure-tools/typespec-python" to your package.json to generate Python code - "@azure-tools/typespec-python" # add "@azure-tools/typespec-java" to your package.json to generate Java code - "@azure-tools/typespec-java" # add "@azure-tools/typespec-csharp" to your package.json to generate C# code - "@azure-tools/typespec-csharp" # add "@azure-tools/typespec-ts" to your package.json to generate Typescript code - "@azure-tools/typespec-ts" # add "@azure-tools/typespec-go" to your package.json to generate Go code - "@azure-tools/typespec-go" options: "@azure-tools/typespec-python": flavor: azure "@azure-tools/typespec-java": flavor: azure "@azure-tools/typespec-csharp": flavor: azure "@azure-tools/typespec-ts": flavor: azure "@azure-tools/typespec-go": flavor: azure ``` Several language repositories utilize the `tsp-client` tool to simplify generating client libraries. For more information on the tool, see [Getting started with `tsp-client`](<./../Generating with tsp-client/tsp_client.md>)."},{"document_source":"typespec_docs","document_filename":"getting-started#code-generation-csharp.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://typespec.io/docs/getting-started/code-generation-csharp","content":"# Getting started with TypeSpec server code generation for C# ## 3. Understanding the default TypeSpec service The `main.tsp` file contains a default "Widget Service" example that defines: ```typespec import "@typespec/http"; using TypeSpec.Http; @service(#{ title: "Widget Service" }) namespace DemoService; model Widget { id: string; weight: int32; color: "red" | "blue"; } model WidgetList { items: Widget[]; } @error model Error { code: int32; message: string; } model AnalyzeResult { id: string; analysis: string; } @route("/widgets") @tag("Widgets") interface Widgets { /** List widgets */ @get list(): WidgetList | Error; /** Read widgets */ @get read(@path id: string): Widget | Error; /** Create a widget */ @post create(@body body: Widget): Widget | Error; /** Update a widget */ @patch update(@path id: string, @body body: Widget): Widget | Error; /** Delete a widget */ @delete delete(@path id: string): void | Error; /** Analyze a widget */ @route("{id}/analyze") @post analyze(@path id: string): AnalyzeResult | Error; } ``` This defines: - A `Widget` model with properties for id, weight, and color - A REST API with standard CRUD operations (list, read, create, update, delete) - A special `analyze` operation for widgets The `tspconfig.yaml` file configures your emitters: ```yaml emit: - "@typespec/openapi3" - "@typespec/http-server-csharp" options: "@typespec/openapi3": emitter-output-dir: "{output-dir}/schema" openapi-versions: - 3.1.0 "@typespec/http-server-csharp": emitter-output-dir: "{output-dir}/server/generated" ``` This configuration: - Generates OpenAPI 3.1.0 schema in the `tsp-output/schema` directory - Generates C# server code in the `tsp-output/server/generated` directory"},{"document_source":"typespec_docs","document_filename":"emitters#clients#http-client-python#reference#package-structure.mdx","document_title":"","document_link":"https://typespec.io/docs/emitters/clients/http-client-python/reference/package-structure","content":"# Namespaces ## Controlling the Generation Directory When migrating existing SDKs or working with brownfield services, you might need to place generated code in a specific subdirectory, like `_generated`. For these scenarios, you can use the [`namespace` configuration option](https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/libraries/typespec-client-generator-core/reference/emitter/#namespace) in your `tspconfig.yaml` file. If you want the published SDK to follow closely with the package structure and namespaces in your TypeSpec file, you should also pass in the `package-name` flag with the desired value."},{"document_source":"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki","document_filename":"SDK-Validation.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/SDK-Validation","content":"# Table of Contents ## How to Re-run SDK Validation Checks To trigger a re-run of a specific SDK Validation check, add a comment in the format: `/azp run SDK Validation - {Language}` For example, commenting `/azp run SDK Validation - Go` will initiate a new run of the "SDK Validation - Go" check."},{"document_source":"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki","document_filename":"SDK-Validation.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/SDK-Validation","content":"# Table of Contents ## How to Re-evaluate `SDK Validation Status` Check Re-running any `SDK Validation` checks will automatically re-evaluate the `SDK Validation Status` check. If you don't see any `SDK Validation - {Language}` checks in your PR's checklist, it means you don't have the required permission to trigger them. Refer to the instructions at https://aka.ms/azsdk/access to get the necessary write access. Additionally, make sure your membership in the `Azure` GitHub organization is set to _public_, for example, you can verify your membership visibility on [Azure](https://github.com/orgs/Azure/people?query=) page."},{"document_source":"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki","document_filename":"SDK-Validation.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/SDK-Validation","content":"# Table of Contents ## How to Download the Generated Artifacts ### Prerequisites Ensure the **SDK Validation** CI check succeeds. If the check fails, the artifacts might not have been generated."},{"document_source":"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki","document_filename":"Swagger-LintDiff.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Swagger-LintDiff","content":"# TypeSpec Check `Swagger LintDiff` may fail for the OpenAPI generated from TypeSpec, even if there are no warnings or errors reported from the TypeSpec compiler. Causes include bugs in the TypeSpec OpenAPI emitter, bugs in LintDiff rules, incompatibilities between TypeSpec and LintDiff, or checks duplicated in TypeSpec and LintDiff. We are working to address the root causes (where possible). Until then, we recommend you [suppress](https://aka.ms/pr-suppressions) these LintDiff errors, using a "permanent suppression" with a descriptive "reason"."},{"document_source":"azure_sdk_for_python_docs","document_filename":"dev#release.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/main/doc/dev/release.md","content":"# IMPORTANT NOTE If this is a new package (i.e. first release), the "microsoft" account MUST be added as owner of your package. Please contact the engineering system team to do so."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"design#api-specs-pr#api-versions-and-branches.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-specs-pr/api-versions-and-branches","content":"# API versions and branches ## Advanced cases ### Internal-only services There are some services that are "internal only" - none of their API versions are published in the public specs repo. The Azure SDK team tooling running on the specs PRs may need to be updated to handle such cases. [source](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-tools/issues/7697#issuecomment-1980956741)."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"design#api-spec-gen-sdk-config.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-spec-gen-sdk-config","content":"# SDK generation configuration ## Enable SDK generation >[!IMPORTANT] > You cannot enable SDK generation for both TypeSpec and OpenAPI simultaneously. Disable one before enabling the other."}]

This issue typically arises from one of the following:\\n\\n1. The TypeSpec C# emitter (@azure-tools/typespec-csharp) or its dependencies are out of date and do not match the expected helper accessibility.\\n2. Your tspconfig.yaml does not have the required configuration for management plane generation, resulting in incompatible or missing code stubs.\\n3. There is a known issue in the C# generator that needs to be resolved by updating the generator package or adjusting your configuration.\\n\\n**How to resolve:**\\n\\n- **Update your dependencies:**\\n  Ensure that your `package.json` contains the latest version of `@azure-tools/typespec-csharp`. Run `tsp install` to refresh dependencies.\\n  \\n- **Check tspconfig.yaml configuration:**\\n  For a management plane SDK, your tspconfig.yaml should include the following emitter options:\\n\\n  ```yaml\\n  emit:\\n    - \\\"@azure-tools/typespec-csharp\\\"\\n  options:\\n    \\\"@azure-tools/typespec-csharp\\\":\\n      flavor: azure\\n      package-dir: \\\"Azure.ResourceManager.Genome\\\"\\n      clear-output-folder: true\\n      model-namespace: true\\n      namespace: \\\"{package-dir}\\\"\\n  ```\\n\\n  Reference the [Contoso.Management sample tspconfig.yaml](https://aka.ms/azsdk/tspconfig-sample-mpg) for exact option usage.\\n\\n- **Re-run code generation:**\\n  After updating your config and dependencies, run:\\n  ```bash\\n  tsp compile path/to/main.tsp\\n  ```\\n  and ensure the generated code does not reference inaccessible helpers.\\n\\n- **If the issue persists:**\\n  This may be a regression or a bug in the generator. Reach out to the .NET Teams channel for help:\\n  [.NET Teams channel](https://teams.microsoft.com/l/channel/19%3a7b87fb348f224b37b6206fa9d89a105b%40thread.skype/Language%2520-%2520DotNet?groupId=3e17dcb0-4257-4a30-b843-77f47f1d4121&tenantId=72f988bf-86f1-41af-91ab-2d7cd011db47)\\n  Provide your PR link and details of the error.\\n\\n**Summary:**\\n- Update your TypeSpec C# emitter to the latest version.\\n- Ensure tspconfig.yaml matches the management plane sample configuration.\\n- Re-run code generation and build.\\n- If unresolved, contact the .NET Teams channel with your PR and error details.\\n\\nThis approach is aligned with the Azure SDK engineering and TypeSpec guidance for .NET SDK validation issues.\", \"ground_truth\": \"This has been fixed in azure-sdk-for-net, and will be synced to azure-sdk-for-net-pr during the day. Your spec is in private repo, after the sync rerun should resolve this. And meanwhile, .NET SDK validation is optional for your spec PR merge, you can ignore it for now.\"}"}]

title: Permission to merge to RPSaaSMaster

question: Hi
General
,

Could you please help me with that?
Thank you
rows.inputs.ground_truth: https://aka.ms/azsdk/access
rows.inputs.response: Hello! Thank you for reaching out and congratulations on your new role. I recommend contacting the repository owners or maintainers directly, or submitting a request through your team's standard process for access permissions. If you need help finding the right contact or have any other questions, please let me know. And thank you for providing details about your PR—it makes the process smoother!

rows.inputs.query:
title: MSWB API spec removal

question: The Azure Modeling and Simulation Workbench (MSWB) preview service has been retired, so I'm trying to remove its related API specs from the REST API specs repository.
PR Deleting 5 API specs for the deprecated MSWB service - RPSaaSDev by yochu-msft · Pull Request #2508… targets RPSaaSDev to delete 5 API specs.
I want to move forward with merging this PR without resolving the Swagger LintDiff failure since the specs are being removed.
'Next Steps to Merge' says "If you still want to proceed merging this PR without addressing the above failures, refer to step 4 in the PR workflow diagram." but 'PR workflow diagram' step 4 loops back that "Follow the instructions in the Next Steps to Merge comment." How should I merge the PR without fixing the failure?
cc Mick Zaffke
rows.inputs.ground_truth:
PRs to RPSaaSDev have no required checks, so you can merge this as-is.
If you need to remove this spec from another branch like public/main or private/RPSaaSMaster, you will need more approvals.
rows.inputs.response:
You are following the correct process for removing retired API specs, and encountering a Swagger LintDiff failure is expected when deleting specs. According to Azure REST API specs guidelines, when retiring or deleting preview API versions, the PR should fail the Swagger BreakingChange check but pass all other required checks. LintDiff failures do not need to be resolved when deleting API specs.

Here is how to proceed:
- You do NOT need to resolve the Swagger LintDiff failure for a PR that removes retired specs.
- The official process is:
  1. Open a PR deleting the TypeSpec sources (*.tsp), related examples, generated swaggers, and remove tags from readme.md.
  2. The PR should fail Swagger BreakingChange but pass other checks.
  3. Request approval for the breaking change by contacting the breaking change review board (https://aka.ms/brch or azbreakchangereview@microsoft.com).

If your PR is blocked from merging due to the LintDiff failure, request an explicit approval from the breaking change review board. In practice, once approval is given, a maintainer may override or force-merge the PR despite the LintDiff failure.

References below confirm that LintDiff failures can be ignored for spec deletions and breaking changes in this context. You do not need to suppress or fix LintDiff for deletions. Simply follow the breaking change approval process and proceed once approved.

# Create a PR against main

> [!NOTE]
> You must have a [GitHub account linked with your Microsoft account](xref:access) and permissions to any of the
> repositories listed in this tutorial.

When you're ready for a final review, it's time to create a pull request (PR) from your release branch you created
originally to the `main` branch on [Azure/azure-rest-api-specs](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs).

* :warning: Do not merge `main` or other release branches unless you know there are changes required.
* :white_check_mark: Rebase on `main` if changes are required in a separate topic branch.

## Clean PR against main

If you're fairly certain there should be no conflicting changes in files you added or modified in the release branch,
you can most often just create a pull request (PR) against `main` on  
[Azure/azure-rest-api-specs](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs).

1. Go to your branch in [Azure/azure-rest-api-specs](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs) or  
   [Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr). Read more about  
   [our repositories](xref:api-repos) for what is public and what is private.

2. If you do not already see an open PR in the upper-right just above the list of files, click **Contribute** and click
   **Open pull request** to open a new one.

3. Select either the **Control Plane (ARM) API** or **Data Plane API** PR template, depending on the type of REST API
spec updates you are submitting.

<!-- Todo: Figure out best way to embed videos on site.
:::video source="https://microsoft.sharepoint.com/teams/AzureDeveloperExperience/_layouts/15/embed.aspx?UniqueId=b199159f-5d7c-4b22-8ba4-98025a2a1f2e":::
-->

## Update your branch with changes from main

If you know there are other changes in the `main` branch or that other services have updated shared files in `main`
already and you need to pick up changes before merging, we recommend you take a merge from main. This is particularly interesting
for common infrastructure changes that are committed in the repo (i.e. github actions, tools, etc). Depending on how old your
branch is some of the pull request checks may not correctly function without taking a merge from main. 

If you are working in a non-protected branch you can do a `git merge main` like you would normally do a merge and then push
your changes to your remote branch. However, if you are working in a branch with branch protection enabled (i.e. `release-*`) then
you will need to make a pull request to your branch with the merge. Depending on how out-of-date your branch is from `main` your 
merge may have a lot of unwanted and unnecessary changes and the checks not pass. In such cases see below on how to [update the infrastructure](#updating-only-the-infrastructure-changes-from-main).

### Updating only the infrastructure changes from main

In cases you need to only update the infrastructure code and not the specifications we have a helper pipeline 
which you can run that will create a pull request with a selective merge. The selective merge will include everything except for specs 
under the specifications folder. This will enable you to only update the infrastructure and not other specs which should get your checks 
passing in your protected branch. Follow these steps to run the helper pipeline.

> [!NOTE]
> This should only be needed for protected branches, such as `release-*`. If you are in an unprotected branch, just use a normal `git merge main`.

1. Go to [tools - update-release-branch-in-specs](https://dev.azure.com/azure-sdk/internal/_build?definitionId=7487) and select **Run Pipeline**.
If you don't have permission see [GitHub account linked with your Microsoft account](xref:access).

2. Enter the name of your branch in the **BranchToMergeTo** parameter. Usually this will be in the form `release-<name>`.  You shouldn't need to set 
the other parameters but if your branch is in the private repo then you will need to update **Repo** to be `Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr`.

3. Click the **Run** button.

4. The pipeline should only take a few minutes to run and once it is complete then go find the pull request it created. You can find a link to it in the 
pipeline logs under the **Create Pull Request to merge** step. 

5. Monitor the created pull request and approve it. Once the checks are green then merge the pull request and then your branch should be updated with the latest infrastructure changes.
If you have open PRs against your branch with failing checks, go to those PRs and retrigger the checks. The easiest way to retrigger all checks
is to hit the close button followed by the open button, which should cause the checks to re-run.

## Next steps

1. [Create a new branch](api-tutorial-1-branch.md)
2. [Work against the release branch](api-tutorial-2-update.md)
3. Create a PR against main"},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"design#api-specs-pr#api-specs-pr.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-specs-pr/api-specs-pr","content":"# design#api-specs-pr#api-specs-pr.md

# Create a pull request with your Azure REST API spec update

This article explains how to create a pull request (PR) in the [Azure REST API specification repositories](xref:api-repos).
Such PR is a part of the [release plan](xref:release-plan).

## Before you begin

Ensure that:

- You have onboarded to Azure SDK team processes by following our [onboarding process](xref:onboard).
- You have [access](xref:access) to the GitHub repositories and respective Azure open source organization.
- You understand the conventions for the [Azure REST API specs GitHub repositories](xref:api-repos).
- You have reviewed and validated your REST API spec updates within your team, using a development branch in one of
  the specs repos.
- You are ready to release the features described in your REST API spec updates in a private preview, public preview,
  or GA release.

>[!TIP]
> We are piloting our new AzSDK tools MCP server which includes the ability to generate the SDKs and
> create a draft pull request in the respective language repository. Refer to [AzSDK tools MCP server](xref:azsdk-tools-mcp)
> for instructions on how to install it and use it.

## Create a PR against a specs repo

> [!TIP]
> If you have an existing PR in the private repo and you want to move it to the public repo, refer to [this guide](xref:pr-move-private-to-public).

When you are ready to submit your REST API spec updates for review, you must create a pull request (PR) in either the  
[public or private specs repository](xref:api-repos). When creating the PR, you should select either the
**Control Plane (ARM) API** or **Data Plane API** PR template, depending on the type of REST API spec updates you are
submitting.

> [!NOTE]
> The PR template and comments added by the PR automation will guide you through the process of getting your PR reviewed,
approved, and merged.

## Get your PR merged

| Short Link: | [aka.ms/azsdk/specreview/merge](https://aka.ms/azsdk/specreview/merge) |
|-|-|

To get your PR merged:

1. Ensure the `Next Steps to Merge` comment and `Automated merging requirements met` check are green. 
1. Ensure at least one person has approved your PR. Generally another person from your team that has [write access] to the repo.
1. Ensure all required checks are passing and at least investigate to understand any other non-required checks that may be failing. 
1. Once all required checks are green and any other issues understood you can merge the PR yourself as long as you have [write access] to the repo.
1. If your PR is targeting public `main` you will need to first apply the `PublishToCustomers` label to acknowledge you understand this 
   will cause your spec to be published so customers can consume it.
1. If your PR is targeting private repo `main` branch, it **cannot** be merged.
   Instead, you can publish your changes to customers by following the guide at [aka.ms/azsdk/move-pr]."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"design#specs-pr-guides#pr-suppressions.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/specs-pr-guides/pr-suppressions","content":"# design#specs-pr-guides#pr-suppressions.md

# Suppress validation failures on a PR

> [!NOTE]
> This article assumes you came here from your REST API specs PR.
> See [this documentation section description](xref:specs-pr-guides) for details.

On your Azure REST API specs PR, some of the GitHub check failures (see the `Checks` tab on your PR) can be suppressed.
The suppression can be either just for the PR, or permanent.

## To suppress given validation failure

1. Determine which failing check you want to suppress: see its name in the `Checks` tab in your PR.
1. Determine if you have one of the [valid suppression reasons](#valid-suppression-reasons).
1. Determine if you want to suppress the failure only for the PR, or permanently.
1. Consult [the suppression cases table](#suppression-cases-table) for instructions corresponding to your case.
1. If you want to apply temporary suppression:
   1. Mention in a comment on your PR the PR assignee asking to apply the suppression. Provide justification.
      See [valid suppression reasons](#valid-suppression-reasons).
1. If you applied permanent suppression:
   1. It will manifest by the PR getting a label `SuppressionReviewRequired`.
   1. Verify the suppression works by the check changing from **failed** to **neutral**.
   1. Wait until your suppression is reviewed. If it is approved, the approved will add the `Approved-Suppression` label.
   1. Understand the suppression won't be approved if it is not one of the  
      [valid suppression reasons](#valid-suppression-reasons) as explained in relevant section.

## Suppression cases table

|
| SDK azure-sdk-for-python           | See [step 3 in the diagram] but note [1]. | `BreakingChange-Python-Sdk-Suppression-Approved`     | Same as **PR suppression**                                      |
| SDK azure-sdk-for-python-track2    | See [step 3 in the diagram] but note [1]. | `BreakingChange-Python-Sdk-Suppression-Approved`     | Same as **PR suppression**                                      |
| Automated merging requirements met | Not possible                              |                                                      | Not possible                                                    |

[1] Applies only if the SDK generation check failed with a breaking change. For details of SDK breaking change suppression, see https://aka.ms/azsdk/sdk-suppression.
General SDK generation check failure suppressions are not supported. See [#6509].

|
| Swagger Avocado                    | See [aka.ms/ci-fix]                       | `Approved-Avocado`                                   | Not possible                                                    |
| Swagger PrettierCheck              | See [aka.ms/ci-fix]                       |                                                      | Not possible                                                    |
| Swagger SpellCheck                 | Not possible                              |                                                      | Not possible                                                    |
| Swagger SemanticValidation         | See [aka.ms/ci-fix]                       | `Approved-SemanticValidation`                        | See [suppress AutoRest extension](#suppress-autorest-extension) |
| Swagger ModelValidation            | See [aka.ms/ci-fix]                       | `Approved-ModelValidation`                           | See [suppress AutoRest extension](#suppress-autorest-extension) |
| Swagger Breaking Change            | Email [Breaking Change Board]             | `Approved-BreakingChange`                            | Not possible                                                    |
| Breaking Change(Cross-Version)     | Email [Breaking Change Board]             | `Approved-BreakingChange`                            | Not possible                                                    |
| Swagger LintDiff                   | See [aka.ms/ci-fix]                       | `Approved-LintDiff`                                  | See [suppress AutoRest extension](#suppress-autorest-extension) |
| Swagger LintDiff(RPaaS)            | See [aka.ms/ci-fix]                       | `Approved-LintRPaaS`                                 | See [suppress AutoRest extension](#suppress-autorest-extension) |
| SDK azure-sdk-for-net              |

Table legend:

- `Check name`: Check to suppress.
- `PR suppression`: instructions to obtain suppression for given check for given PR only.
  First, [read the about process](#to-suppress-given-validation-failure).
- `Label`: the label your PR will get if your suppression is approved.
- `Permanent suppression`: instructions how to get permanent suppression.
  First, [read the about process](#to-suppress-given-validation-failure).

| Check name                         | PR suppression                            | Label                                                | Permanent suppression                                           |
|------------------------------------|-------------------------------------------|------------------------------------------------------|-----------------------------------------------------------------|
| TypeSpec Requirement               | Not possible                              |                                                      | [suppressions.yaml](#suppressionsyaml)                      |
| TypeSpec Validation                | Not possible                              |                                                      | Not possible                                                    |
| license/cla                        | Not possible                              |                                                      | Not possible                                                    |
| Swagger Avocado                    | See [aka.ms/ci-fix]                       | `Approved-Avocado`                                   | Not possible                                                    |
| Swagger PrettierCheck              | See [aka.ms/ci-fix]                       |                                                      | Not possible                                                    |
| Swagger SpellCheck                 |

|
| Swagger LintDiff                   | See [aka.ms/ci-fix]                       | `Approved-LintDiff`                                  | See [suppress AutoRest extension](#suppress-autorest-extension) |
| Swagger LintDiff(RPaaS)            | See [aka.ms/ci-fix]                       | `Approved-LintRPaaS`                                 | See [suppress AutoRest extension](#suppress-autorest-extension) |
| SDK azure-sdk-for-net              | Not possible ([#6509])                    |                                                      | Not possible                                                    |
| SDK azure-sdk-for-net-track2       | Not possible ([#6509])                    |                                                      | Not possible                                                    |
| SDK azure-sdk-for-go               | See [step 3 in the diagram] but note [1]. | `BreakingChange-Go-Sdk-Suppression-Approved`         | Same as **PR suppression**                                      |
| SDK azure-sdk-for-java             | Not possible ([#6509])                    |                                                      | Not possible                                                    |
| SDK azure-sdk-for-js               | See [step 3 in the diagram] but note [1]. | `BreakingChange-JavaScript-Sdk-Suppression-Approved` | Same as **PR suppression**                                      |
| SDK azure-sdk-for-python           | See [step 3 in the diagram] but note [1]. | `BreakingChange-Python-Sdk-Suppression-Approved`     | Same as **PR suppression**                                      |
| SDK azure-sdk-for-python-track2    | See [step 3 in the diagram] but note [1]. | `BreakingChange-Python-Sdk-Suppression-Approved`     | Same as **PR suppression**                                      |
| Automated merging requirements met |

## suppressions.yaml

File `suppressions.yaml` is used for all checks created in 2024 or later, like
`TypeSpec Requirement` and `TypeSpec Validation`.

For simplicity, we recommend adding all suppressions to a single file at the root of your spec folder:

```
specification/myservice/suppressions.yaml
```

Alternatively, you can use multiple files in separate folders.  Currently, tools will use the first
instance of `suppressions.yaml` found walking up the directory tree.  We are planning
future support for "merging" files up the hierarchy.

A suppression follows this general format:

```
- tool: ToolName
  path: applies/to/**/*.json
  reason: Why this can't be fixed
```

`path` uses "glob" matching.  For syntax, see https://www.npmjs.com/package/minimatch.

Scope your `path` as narrowly as possible.  For example, if a suppression only applies
to a single version of your spec:

```
# good
- path: data-plane/Azure.Contoso.WidgetManager/preview/2022-11-01-preview/**/*.json

# bad
- path: data-plane/**/*.json
```

When in doubt, search the repo for examples:

https://github.com/search?q=repo%3AAzure%2Fazure-rest-api-specs+path%3A%2F%28%5E%7C%5C%2F%29suppressions%5C.yaml%24%2F&type=code

### `TypeSpec Requirement` check

To suppress `TypeSpec Requirement` check for given pattern of OpenAPI spec .json file paths, provide an entry with
`tool` set to `TypeSpecRequirement`. Provide the pattern as `path` and provide a `reason`.

Example:

```
- tool: TypeSpecRequirement
  path: data-plane/**/*.json
  reason: Brownfield service not ready to migrate
```

## Suppress AutoRest extension

To suppress tooling that is an AutoRest extension (see [the suppressio"},{"document_source":"azure_resource_manager_rpc","document_filename":"v1.0#patch-resource.md","document_title":"Patch Resource #","document_link":"https://github.com/cloud-and-ai-microsoft/resource-provider-contract/blob/master/v1.0/patch-resource.md","content":"# v1.0#patch-resource.md

# Patch Resource #

## Overview ##

A `Patch` operation updates a resource and it is strongly recommended that service teams implement it. ARM requires RPs to support `Patch` for updating tags for a **tracked** resource.

### Request ###

| Method | Request URI |
| --- | --- |
| Patch | `https://<endpoint>/subscriptions/{subscriptionId}/resourceGroups/{resourceGroupName}/providers/{resourceProviderNamespace}/{resourceType}/{resourceName}?api-version={api-version}` |

**Arguments**

[Common Arguments](./uri-format-and-arguments-for-crud-apis-on-resources.md)

**Request Body**

The request body of a `Patch` operation **must** contain atleast one property. The properties specified **must** be present in the resource definition as defined in the response of the corresponding `Get` or the request body of a `Put` operation. For the explanation of these properties please see the PUT Resource section. Of note, just like for a `Put` operation, a user can \*not\* update the location, type or name of their resource with a `Patch` operation. These properties are either immutable or readOnly.

The behavior for patching of the fields inside the properties envelope should follow JSON merge-patch ([RFC 7396](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7396)).

### Response ###

The response includes an HTTP status code, a set of response headers, and a response body. 

**Status Code**

The resource provider **must** return 200 (OK) to indicate that the synchronous `Patch` operation completed successfully. 202 (Accepted) **must** be returned to indicate that the operation will complete [asynchronously](async-api-reference.md#asynchronous-operations).

If the resource group \*or\* resource does not exist, 404 (NotFound) should be returned.

**Response Headers**

Headers common to all responses.

**Response Body**

The response body **must** contain the updated resource using the existing values for all other properties and the updated value(s) for properties provided in the request body of the `Patch` operation. The response body of a `Patch` operation **must** be the same as the response body of the corresponding `Put` or `Get` operation of the same resource type.

### Common scenarios for implementing Patch ###

**Tags**

A common scenario for the usage of a `Patch` operation is to update the `tags` section of a **tracked** resource. The behavior for a `Patch` operation of the tags property is to replace the tags property with the  keys and values provided with the `Patch` operation. Eg: if the resource currently has tag1 and tag2, and a `Patch` request sends tag3, the final resource should have tag3 (and \*not\* tag1, tag2 and tag3).

**SKU** 
If a respource provider exposes the notion of SKUs for their resource types, the `Patch` operation may be supported for the SKU property to support scaling. For example, the following operation should update the SKU of the resource to be Free and not affect any of the other properties of the resource:

**Request Body**

```json
{
  "sku": {
    "name": "F0",
    "capacity": 1
  }
}
```

## Rules ##

### General impact of violating the rules ###

|
| RPC-Patch-V1-11 | Resource providers may implement `Patch` for the Identity property if the service allows it to be updated. | Required | No additional impact. | Design |  [Click to view documentation](https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/blob/main/docs/patch-identity-property.md) |
| RPC-Patch-V1-12 | Every `Patch ` request **must** have a request body. | Required | No additional impact. | Design |  [Click to view documentation](https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/blob/main/docs/request-body-must-exist-for-put-patch.md) |

Providing support for `Patch` for as many properties as possible helps avoid accidental and unintentional updates to other properties that need not be touched. Only the property set that really needs an update are specified in a `Patch` payload thereby limiting the surface area of any potential impact. Violating these rules result in APIs across Azure becoming inconsistent with each other. Such inconsistencies degrade customer experience as they now have to deal with slightly different behaviors while interacting with each Resource Provider. 

<br>

| RPC Guideline code | Title | Conformance level | Additional impact |  Applicable scope | Linter rule |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| RPC-Patch-V1-01 | The request body **must** contain at least one or more properties. These properties must always be present in the request and response bodies of the corresponding put operation for same resource type. | Required | Not specifying any properties in the request body for a `Patch` operation serves no purpose for your customers. | Design | [Click to view documentation](https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/blob/main/docs/patch-properties-correspond-to-put-properties.md) | 
| RPC-Patch-V1-02 | A `Patch` operation must not update the `id`, `name`, `type`, `location`, or `properties.provisioningState` of the resource and so these properties must not be marked as updatable in the request body of the `Patch` operation. | Required | These properties are deemed either readOnly or immutable and therefore not updatable. These properties may be defined in the request body of the `Patch` operation and if so, they **must** be marked as readOnly or immutable as appropriate. | Design | [Click to view documentation](https://github.com/Azure/azure-openapi-validator/blob/main/docs/un-supported-patch-properties.md) | 
| RPC-Patch-V1-03 | Every **Tracked** resource type **must** support a **Patch** operation for the `tags` property. | Required |

is synchronous and 202 if the operation is asynchronous. Additionally, the 200 status code **must** also be specified in the Open API specification for asynchronous `Patch` operations.
