# Azure Versioning Guidelines

## History

<details>
  <summary>Expand change history</summary>

| Date        | Notes                                                          |
| ----------- | -------------------------------------------------------------- |
| 2024-Nov-14 | Azure Service Versioning & Breaking Change Guidelines       |

</details>

## Guidelines

**DO** remove retired API versions from the azure-rest-api-specs repo.

:white_check_mark: **DO** review any change to service behavior that could disrupt customers with the Azure Breaking Changes review board, even if the change is not part of the API definition.

Some examples of behavior changes that must be reviewed are:
- Introducing or changing rate limits to be more restrictive than previously
- Changing the permissions required to successfully execute an operation

:no_entry: **DO NOT** change the behavior of an API version that is available to customers either in public preview or GA.
Changes in behavior should always be introduced in a new API version, with prior versions working as before.

:no_entry: **DO NOT** introduce breaking changes from a prior GA version just to satisfy ARM or Azure API guidelines.

Avoiding breaking changes in a GA API takes precedence over adherence to API guidelines and resolving linter errors.

:no_entry: **DO NOT** keep a preview feature in preview for more than 1 year; it must go GA (or be removed) within 1 year after introduction.

This document provides a "Dos and Don'ts" list for complying with the Azure Versioning and Breaking Change Policy,
as documented [internally](aka.ms/AzBreakingChangesPolicy) and [externally](https://learn.microsoft.com/azure/developer/intro/azure-service-sdk-tool-versioning).

:white_check_mark: **DO** thoroughly ensure/test the API contract is entirely correct before merging it into a production branch of the specs repo.

Testing helps avoid "BugFix" changes to the API definition. Testing should be done at the HTTP level as well as through generated SDKs.

:white_check_mark: **DO** retire all prior preview API versions 90 days after a new GA or preview API version is released.

:white_check_mark: **DO** contact the Azure Breaking Change Review board to coordinate communications to customers
when releasing an API version requiring the retirement of a prior version.

:white_check_mark: **DO** create a new preview API version for any features that should remain in preview following a new GA release.

:white_check_mark: **DO** use a date strictly later than the most recent GA API version when releasing
a new preview API version.

:white_check_mark: **DO** deprovision any API version that has been retired. Retired APIs versions should behave like
an unknown API version (see [ref](https://aka.ms/azapi/guidelines#versioning-api-version-unsupported)).

:white_check_mark: **DO** remove retired API versions from the azure-rest-api-specs repo.

:white_check_mark: **DO** review any change to service behavior that could disrupt customers with the Azure Breaking Changes review board, even if the change is not part of the API definition.

Some examples of behavior changes that must be reviewed are:
- Introducing or changing rate limits to be more restrictive than previously
- Changing the permissions required to successfully execute an operation"},{"document_source":"static_typespec_qa","document_filename":"typespec_2025_06_26.md","document_title":"Swagger LintDiff failed","document_link":"","content":"# typespec_2025_06_26.md

# Swagger LintDiff failed

## question

I have many lintDiff failures in this [PR](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/pull/34318). The interesting thing is, the place I'm violating the rules, its swagger is the same as before. Why these violations are not reported before?

## answer

The LintDiff errors in your PR are not necessarily new violations. Many of them already existed in the main branch, but previously, CI failures weren’t blocking, so these issues were effectively allowed to persist unnoticed.

Now, because your PR is part of a TypeSpec (TSP) migration, the generated Swagger includes many differences—over 3,000 diffs in total—due to normalization by the AutoRest emitter. These changes are functionally equivalent but not textually identical, which makes it hard for the LintDiff auto-baselining algorithm to recognize unchanged areas. As a result, you’re seeing errors flagged as new, even if the same issues existed in main.

Given the unreliability of the auto-baselining mechanism, we recommend not depending on it. Instead, all LintDiff errors—regardless of whether they are newly introduced or pre-existing—should be explicitly suppressed in the `readme.md` file. This is the mitigation approach we advise for all PRs, especially TSP migrations."},{"document_source":"static_typespec_qa","document_filename":"typespec_2025_09_19.md","document_title":"Swagger LintDiff validation for certain models","document_link":"","content":"# typespec_2025_09_19.md

# Swagger LintDiff validation for certain models

## question

I have the below PR [adding shared limit typespec by parthshah2305 · Pull Request #24115 · Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/pull/24115) where some of the LintDiff validations are failing with the exception 
``` 
  Violation: file:///home/runner/work/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/after/specification/limit/resource-manager/Microsoft.Limit/Limit/stable/2025-08-15/Limit.json:578
    Level: error
    Code: RequiredPropertiesMissingInResourceModel
    Message: Model definition 'SharingDetail' must have the properties 'name', 'id' and 'type' in its hierarchy and these properties must be marked as readonly.
```

This particular model is defined as follows - 

```
model SharingDetail {
  role: SharingRole;
  sharedLimits?: QuotaLimitProperties[];
  guestSubscriptions?: string[];
  host?: string;
}
```
 
Is it possible have a suppression for this validation? If so, how?

## answer
the link for lintdiff suppressions:
 
https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Swagger-LintDiff#adding-scoped-suppressions
 
you probably want to fix this in your spec, not suppress the error
 
You need to fix check "TypeSpec Validation" in your PR, before other check results will even be valid.  This is documented in the "next steps to merge" comment in your PR.

The `Swagger LintDiff` seems to be related with this question: [Emilio D'Angelo: Asynchronous resource delete | Azure SDK > TypeSpec Discussion |

## answer

The issue you're encountering is caused by a regression in the path-to-regexp dependency used by oav. Specifically, patterns like {width}x{height} or {x}/{y}@{scale}x in your API paths are now breaking validation due to stricter parsing rules introduced in path-to-regexp@6.2.1.

Previously, your spec passed validation because older versions of path-to-regexp were more lenient. The recent update introduced security fixes that inadvertently caused this break.

To unblock your PR, we’ve deployed a temporary fix that pins path-to-regexp to an older version. This means your Swagger checks should no longer crash. Meanwhile, we’re working on a permanent solution that doesn’t rely on pinning old code.

If you still need to validate locally, you can manually install the older version and run oav like this:
```
<install node 20>
mkdir testdirectory
cd testdirectory
npm i oav path-to-regexp@6.2.2
npx oav validate-example /path/to/your/openapi.json
```
Alternatively, you can use validate-spec instead of validate-example if you're checking the spec directly. This workaround has been confirmed to pass for your PR.

We’ve also applied the approved-modelvalidation and approved-semanticvalidation labels to your PR to unblock progress. Just note that if other issues surface later due to this regression, you may need to address them in a follow-up PR."},{"document_source":"static_typespec_qa","document_filename":"typespec_2025_06_26.md","document_title":"Breaking Change(Cross-Version) failure","document_link":"","content":"# typespec_2025_06_26.md

# Breaking Change(Cross-Version) failure

## question

We have the [PR](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/pull/22834) to introduce new API version with new features for existing RP. The [Breaking Changes(Cross-Version) detected problems](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/pull/22834/checks?check_run_id=43004413278). How to fix it?

## answer

It depends.  Even across versions, some changes are discouraged/disallowed.  If the breaking changes reported in your PR are all intentional, then you just need to follow the instructions in the "next steps to merge" comment to work with the breaking changes board for approval: https://aka.ms/brch
Generally, breaking changes between preview api-versions are allowed if there are good reasons,  breaking changes relative to a stable api-version are more of a concern.  Also, if preview api-versions are old enough, they count as stable api-versions (I doubt that is the case here).
The case here is a preview with breaking changes relative to the last stable. And in this case, making a property optional would be considered breaking if the property occurs in responses."},{"document_source":"static_typespec_migration_docs","document_filename":"typespec-migration-docs-2025-07-17.md","document_title":"Change scope name for extension name.","document_link":"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/migrate-swagger/faq/breakingchange","content":"# typespec-migration-docs-2025-07-17.md

# missing `x-ms-secret`

## question

How to fix missing `x-ms-secret`?

## answer

specification/databoxedge/DataBoxEdge.Management/models.tsp:
```diff
+   #suppress "@azure-tools/typespec-azure-core/no-openapi" "This needs to be a secret"
+   @OpenAPI.extension("x-ms-secret", true)
    privateKey?: string;
```
```diff
+   #suppress "@azure-tools/typespec-azure-core/no-openapi" "This needs to be a secret"
+   @OpenAPI.extension("x-ms-secret", true)
    encryptionCertThumbprint?: string;
```"},{"document_source":"static_typespec_migration_docs","document_filename":"typespec-migration-docs-2025-09-12.md","document_title":"missing externalDocs","document_link":"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/migrate-swagger/faq/breakingchange","content":"# typespec-migration-docs-2025-09-12.md

# missing externalDocs

## question

how to resolve missing externalDocs?

## answer

*.tsp files:
Added @externalDocs decorators to multiple interfaces and operations such as
```diff
+   @externalDocs("https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/rest/api/consumption/")
    get is Extension.Read<Extension.ScopeParameter, Budget>;
```
generated openapi.json file:
```diff
          "description": "Gets the budget for the scope by budget name.",
+         "externalDocs": {
+           "url": "https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/rest/api/consumption/"
+         },
```"},{"document_source":"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki","document_filename":"Specification-Folder-Structure-Guide.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Specification-Folder-Structure-Guide","content":"# Azure REST API Specification Directory Structure
## Legacy and deprecated patterns
Due to the evolutionary nature of the Azure REST API specifications repository, many existing services follow deprecated directory structures that do not conform to the current recommended guidelines. Understanding these legacy patterns is important for maintenance and migration efforts.
> [!IMPORTANT]
> **All new services must follow the recommended structure** outlined in this document. Existing services are being migrated over time to align with the current standards."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"design#specs-pr-guides#pr-brch-deep.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/specs-pr-guides/pr-brch-deep","content":"# Deep-dive into breaking changes on spec PRs
## Addressing `BreakingChangeReviewRequired`
### `BreakingChange-Approved-BranchPolicyException`
The API version that triggered the review violates the GitHub repository branch policy, but we allow it.
Usually this is because it has not yet been released, despite having been merged to a production branch.

> [!TIP]
> As a PR author, you are allowed to apply the `BreakingChange-Approved-BranchPolicyException` label,
> but only in the [private specs repo]. See [aka.ms/brch] for details."},{"document_source":"azure_api_guidelines","document_filename":"azure#ConsiderationsForServiceDesign.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://github.com/microsoft/api-guidelines/blob/vNext/azure/ConsiderationsForServiceDesign.md","content":"# Considerations for Service Design
## History

| ----------- | -------------------------------------------------------------- |
| 2024-Mar-17 | Updated LRO guidelines                                         |
| 2024-Jan-17 | Added guidelines on returning string offsets & lengths         |
| 2022-Jul-15 | Update guidance on long-running operations                     |
| 2022-Feb-01 | Updated error guidance                                         |
| 2021-Sep-11 | Add long-running operations guidance                           |
| 2021-Aug-06 | Updated Azure REST Guidelines per Azure API Stewardship Board. |"},{"document_source":"typespec_azure_http_specs","document_filename":"azure#versioning#previewversion#main.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/typespec-azure/blob/main/packages/azure-http-specs/specs/azure/versioning/previewversion/main.tsp","content":"# Usages for Supported api versions including preview.
## Scenario: Test @previewVersion decorator with stable operations
Should send a preview api-version and response should contain color field.
``` typespec
@doc("Get widget by id (available in all versions)")
@get
@route("/widgets/{id}")
op getWidget(
  @path id: string,
  ...global.Azure.Core.Foundations.ApiVersionParameter,
): Widget | NotFoundResponse;
@doc("Update widget color request.")
model UpdateWidgetColorRequest {
  @doc("New color for the widget.")
  color: string;
}
```

## Scenario: Test @previewVersion decorator with preview-only operations
Only available in preview API versions.
```"},{"document_source":"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki","document_filename":"Deprecating-Preview-APIs.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Deprecating-Preview-APIs","content":"## Policies
* General
  * https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/retirement/api-retirement
    * _Once a service API version is fully retired, the corresponding API spec should be removed from the specs repo_
  * https://aka.ms/cpexretirementsprocess
* ARM (resource-manager)
  * https://armwiki.azurewebsites.net/api_contracts/APIDeprecationPolicy.html
    * _Preview APIs have a life-span of not more than 12 months, after which they must be retired._"},{"document_source":"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki","document_filename":"Deprecating-Preview-APIs.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Deprecating-Preview-APIs","content":"Spec owners are encouraged to remove old preview API versions from the specs repo, once they are retired from the service."},{"document_source":"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki","document_filename":"Swagger-LintDiff.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Swagger-LintDiff","content":"# TypeSpec
Check `Swagger LintDiff` may fail for the OpenAPI generated from TypeSpec, even if there are no warnings or errors reported from the TypeSpec compiler.  Causes include bugs in the TypeSpec OpenAPI emitter, bugs in LintDiff rules, incompatibilities between TypeSpec and LintDiff, or checks duplicated in TypeSpec and LintDiff.
We are working to address the root causes (where possible).  Until then, we recommend you [suppress](https://aka.ms/pr-suppressions) these LintDiff errors, using a "permanent suppression" with a descriptive "reason"."},{"document_source":"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki","document_filename":"Deprecating-Preview-APIs.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Deprecating-Preview-APIs","content":"## Process
1. Open a PR deleting one (or more) previews.  All of:
   1. TypeSpec sources (`*.tsp`)
   2. Example sources (examples closest to `*.tsp` files)
   3. Generated swaggers and examples (`preview/YYYY-MM-DD-preview/**`)
   4. readme.md (remove tags)
2. PR should fail check `Swagger BreakingChange`, but pass all other checks.
3. Request approval following the normal process for breaking changes
   - https://aka.ms/brch
   - azbreakchangereview@microsoft.com"},{"document_source":"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki","document_filename":"Specification-Folder-Structure-Guide.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Specification-Folder-Structure-Guide","content":"# Azure REST API Specification Directory Structure
## Contact Us
[Specification index]: https://azure.github.io/azure-sdk/releases/latest/all/specs.html
[uniform versioning guideline]: https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Azure-Service-Versioning-Guideline
[Conflict Resolve Guide]: https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Resolving-Folder-Migration-Conflicts:-A-Guide-for-PR-Authors
[Widget]: https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/specification/widget
[TypeSpec Discussion]: https://teams.microsoft.com/l/channel/19%3A906c1efbbec54dc8949ac736633e6bdf%40thread.skype/TypeSpec%20Discussion?groupId=3e17dcb0-4257-4a30-b843-77f47f1d4121&tenantId=72f988bf-86f1-41af-91ab-2d7cd011db47"},{"document_source":"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki","document_filename":"Folder-Structure.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Folder-Structure","content":"# Overview
Specifications in this repository must organize their files and folders according to strict guidelines.

In June 2025, the guidelines were updated to version 2.  New specs are encouraged to start with v2, and existing specs are encouraged to convert to v2 when convenient.  The [widget](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/tree/main/specification/widget) sample uses v2.

Prior to June 2025, all specs were using v1.  The [contosowidgetmanager](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/tree/main/specification/contosowidgetmanager) sample uses v1."},{"document_source":"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki","document_filename":"Azure-Service-Versioning-Guideline.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Azure-Service-Versioning-Guideline","content":"# Azure Service Versioning Guide
## What If Your Azure Team Currently Violates the Above Rules?
regards to versioning, breaking change detection, SDK packaging, etc. In the past, our repo structure didn’t force teams to adhere to the service versioning rules. The various teams (ARM, API Stewardship, Breaking Change, and EngSys) have worked together to define a new repo structure. Not only does this force service teams to adhere to the versioning rules but it allows the EngSys team to remove their error-prone heuristic code and have their tools produce better, predictable results.  

The bottom line is that all operations within a service must version uniformly and each service version must have a 1:1 relationship to its API contract (TypeSpec/OpenAPI), customer docs, SDK packages (and other apps/packages that depend on them [Azure CLI/PowerShell, Terraform Modules, etc.]), and the lifecycle of these things (as described earlier in this document). Customers MUST be able to mix and match service versions as they see fit as services evolve by introducing/retiring preview versions as well as GA/broken versions. A customer using one service should NOT be impacted by another service. Combining multiple services and/or service versions in a single SDK package version complicates this for Azure engineering and customers causing all the problems I mention in this section."},{"document_source":"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki","document_filename":"TypeSpec-Validation.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/TypeSpec-Validation","content":"# Running Locally
To ensure you see the same results from TypeSpecValidation in your PR check and `tsv` on your local machine:
1. Merge latest from parent (e.g. `main` or `RPSaaSMaster`) to your PR branch
2. Run locally
   1. `git clean -xdf` (may revert any local changes)
   2. `git pull`
   3. `npm ci`
   4. `npx tsv specification/widget/resource-manager/Microsoft.Widget/Widget`
   5. `git status`
   6. If any changes, `git add`, `git commit`, `git push` to update your PR.
3. If you are still having problems, try cloning your branch to a new folder, or try on another machine.
4. If the problem can be reproduced on a clean machine, request assistance from the [TypeSpec Discussion](https://teams.microsoft.com/l/channel/19%3A906c1efbbec54dc8949ac736633e6bdf%40thread.skype/TypeSpec%20Discussion?groupId=3e17dcb0-4257-4a30-b843-77f47f1d4121&tenantId=72f988bf-86f1-41af-91ab-2d7cd011db47) teams channel."},{"document_source":"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki","document_filename":"API-Spec-Review-FAQ.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/API-Spec-Review-FAQ","content":"Answers to frequently asked questions in the [Api Spec Review](https://teams.microsoft.com/l/channel/19%3A0351f5f9404446e4b4fd4eaf2c27448d%40thread.skype/API%20Spec%20Review?groupId=3e17dcb0-4257-4a30-b843-77f47f1d4121&tenantId=72f988bf-86f1-41af-91ab-2d7cd011db47). Within that channel, EngSys should be answering questions about validation pipelines and tools that run in those pipelines. Specific questions about typespec, the API Review process, etc. should be answered by others who specialize in those topics. 

| If the question is about | The answer should be | 
| --- | --- | 
| Authoring typespec | Send to [TypeSpec Discussions](https://teams.microsoft.com/l/channel/19%3A906c1efbbec54dc8949ac736633e6bdf%40thread.skype/TypeSpec%20Discussion?groupId=3e17dcb0-4257-4a30-b843-77f47f1d4121&tenantId=72f988bf-86f1-41af-91ab-2d7cd011db47) | 
| My PR is ready to review, will someone review it? | See the "Next steps to merge" comment in your PR and follow directions to ensure you're in the review queue. No need to post here. | 
| API Doc Preview is broken | If the error message linked doesn't make sense, follow instructions at [Troubleshooting REST API documentation](https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-docs-troubleshooting). API Doc Preview is not a required check so you can ignore the failure if it's not relevant to your documentation needs. |
| My PR needs to be reviewed by the ARM team right now | PRs are generally reviewed in order of the ARM queue.  If your PR needs special treatment, you can contact the ARM team: https://aka.ms/armofficehoursinfo | 
| I need a review to merge changes to a non-standard branch (e.g. not `main`, `RPSaaSMaster`, etc.) | Contact the owner of that branch. |
| EngSys is behaving badly in my non-standard/release branch | Update the state of the branch to match with `main`. The owner of the release branch is responsible for doing this."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"design#specs-pr-guides#pr-brch-deep.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/specs-pr-guides/pr-brch-deep","content":"# Deep-dive into breaking changes on spec PRs
## Addressing `VersioningReviewRequired`
### `Versioning-Approved-Previously`
- The PR contains breaking changes that were previously reviewed and approved.
- It is desirable but not mandatory to add a link the previously approved PR in a comment on given PR.
- As of 3/11/2024 we have planned work to reduce occurrences of this scenario.
See [#7259](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-tools/issues/7259) for details."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"design#api-specs-pr#pr-move-private-to-public.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-specs-pr/pr-move-private-to-public","content":"# Move private specs to public
> [!CAUTION]
> Copying over specs from private specs repo to public specs repo is effectively converting a `private preview`
> API version to `public preview`. The copying of specs is only one element of a larger process.
> Consult with the service & spec owner to ensure you complete all the required steps, like disabling [AFEC] flags,
> publishing relevant docs to external customers, etc.
> ([example requirements doc for ARM][ARM lifecycle stages requirements])
> Do this consultation **before you open the PR** to the public specs repo.

> [!NOTE]
> These instructions replace the former OpenAPI Hub feature **Publish a pull request**"}]

rows.outputs.similarity.similarity_sample_inp: [{"role": "user", "content": "{\"query\": \"title: MSWB API spec removal\\n\\nquestion: The Azure Modeling and Simulation Workbench (MSWB) preview service has been retired, so I'm trying to remove its related API specs from the REST API specs repository.\\nPR Deleting 5 API specs for the deprecated MSWB service - RPSaaSDev by yochu-msft \\u00b7 Pull Request #2508\\u2026 targets RPSaaSDev to delete 5 API specs.\\nI want to move forward with merging this PR without resolving the Swagger LintDiff failure since the specs are being removed.\\n'Next Steps to Merge' says \\\"If you still want to proceed merging this PR without addressing the above failures, refer to step 4 in the PR workflow diagram.\\\" but 'PR workflow diagram' step 4 loops back that \\\"Follow the instructions in the Next Steps to Merge comment.\\\" How should I merge the PR without fixing the failure?\\ncc Mick Zaffke\", \"response\": \"You are following the correct process for removing retired API specs, and encountering a Swagger LintDiff failure is expected when deleting specs. According to Azure REST API specs guidelines, when retiring or deleting preview API versions, the PR should fail the Swagger BreakingChange check but pass all other required checks. LintDiff failures do not need to be resolved when deleting API specs.\\n\\nHere is how to proceed:\\n- You do NOT need to resolve the Swagger LintDiff failure for a PR that removes retired specs.\\n- The official process is:\\n  1. Open a PR deleting the TypeSpec sources (*.tsp), related examples, generated swaggers, and remove tags from readme.md.\\n  2. The PR should fail Swagger BreakingChange but pass other checks.\\n  3. Request approval for the breaking change by contacting the breaking change review board (https://aka.ms/brch or azbreakchangereview@microsoft.com).\\n\\nIf your PR is blocked from merging due to the LintDiff failure, request an explicit approval from the breaking change review board. In practice, once approval is given, a maintainer may override or force-merge the PR despite the LintDiff failure.\\n\\nReferences below confirm that LintDiff failures can be ignored for spec deletions and breaking changes in this context. You do not need to suppress or fix LintDiff for deletions. Simply follow the breaking change approval process and proceed once approved.\", \"ground_truth\": \"PRs to RPSaaSDev have no required checks, so you can merge this as-is.\\nIf you need to remove this spec from another branch like public/main or private/RPSaaSMaster, you will need more approvals.\"}"}]

rows.inputs.query:
title: Deprecation of PostgreSql Single Server and its SDK Guidance

question: Hi, PostgreSql Single Server officially deprecated in March 2025 with support completely ending September 2025. Efforts these past few months have been made to migrate users to PostgreSql Flexible Server.
We wish to remove the operations associated with single server found here: https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-net/tree/main/sdk/postgresql/Azure.ResourceManager.PostgreSql/src/PostgreSql
Want to confirm what is the exact process to remove the operations:
Is official request needed?
Do we manually remove the files associated to the resource?
Thank you for the help.
rows.inputs.ground_truth:
You will need to update the libraries for all 5 languages, not just .NET, to support the deprecation / retirement and migration.
For .NET, does the library currently contain operations for both the single server and flexible server?  If so, the REST API version(s) in question would need to be retired first, and then new SDK libraries would need to be generated.
For some of the other languages (like Python, Go, and Java), were there separate libraries for single server and flexible server?
I'm looping in our Shanghai team for assistance - Josephine, Arthur, and Renhe.
Once we work out how the libraries map to the different service versions, the instructions on how to deprecate an entire library for each language are here: [Deprecating Azure SDKs](https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/retirement/sdk-deprecation)
rows.inputs.response:
To remove the management-plane operations for PostgreSql Single Server from the Azure SDK for .NET, you must follow the official Azure API and SDK retirement/deprecation process. Manual removal of files from the SDK repository is not sufficient and should only occur after all required steps are completed.

Here’s the process you need to follow:

1. **Service/API Retirement Approval and Coordination**:
   - Confirm that the API version and service are fully retired per Azure’s retirement policy. You must have gone through the official breaking change approval and customer communication process, especially since Single Server is a GA service. See [CPEX Breaking Change Process](https://aka.ms/CPEXBreakingChangesProcess).
   - Coordinate with ARM/API owners and ensure that the corresponding REST API spec is removed from the [azure-rest-api-specs](https://github.com/azure/azure-rest-api-specs) repository once the service/API version is fully retired.

2. **SDK Deprecation and Dashboard Update**:
   - Mark the relevant .NET SDK package as deprecated in the Azure SDK inventory dashboard. This requires editing the `dotnet-packages.csv` file in the Azure SDK repo and setting the `Support` field to `deprecated`, the `EOLDate` to the end-of-support date, and providing a `Replace` and `ReplaceGuide` (e.g., pointing to Flexible Server and a migration guide).
   - Submit a PR for this change; this triggers the update on the public [Azure SDK dashboard](https://aka.ms/azsdk) and will notify the repo owners for review.

3. **Package Manager Updates and Deprecation Notices**:
   - Ensure NuGet is updated with a deprecation message, replacement package info, and migration guide. This is automated after the CSV change is merged, but you may need to manually request popularity transfer for search ranking (see instructions for emailing NuGet).
   - Update README files in the repo and package manager pages with deprecation notices and migration guidance.

4. **Code Removal**:
   - After all deprecation steps and notifications are complete and the API spec is removed, you may then submit a PR to remove the actual source files for Single Server operations from the SDK repository.
   - The PR should clearly reference the official retirement and deprecation approvals, and include breaking change details in the release notes and CHANGELOG.
   - The removal is a breaking change and must be tracked as such in the release notes and communicated to customers (typically a 3-year notification period is required for GA breaking changes unless otherwise approved).

5. **Release Pipeline**:
   - Once the removal PR is approved and merged, run the SDK release pipeline and verify the release package, documentation, and notes reflect the change. Ensure all steps in the release plan are marked complete.

**Do not manually remove files before the above steps are completed.** All removal actions must be traceable to the official deprecation/retirement process to avoid accidental breaking changes and ensure compliance with Azure customer communication policies.

If you have questions or need support, reach out to the [Azure SDK Onboarding channel](https://aka.ms/azsdk/support/onboarding-channel).

[{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"retirement#api-retirement.md","document_title":"Retiring Azure APIs","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/retirement/api-retirement","content":"# retirement#api-retirement.md # Retiring Azure APIs Note: In this documentation, the words "retirement" and "deprecation" are used interchangeably. Both terms refer to the process of phasing out support for SDKs and APIs. Azure services may retire the entire service (and therefore all service API versions) or may retire a subset of service API versions. To see general information about retiring REST APIs visit [CPEX Retirement Process Overview](https://aka.ms/cpexretirementsprocess). To see ARM-specific information about retiring ARM APIs visit [API Deprecation Policy](https://armwiki.azurewebsites.net/api_contracts/APIDeprecationPolicy.html). If you want to retire GA APIs, you can only do so if you introduced an approved breaking change in a new GA version and retire the old GA version. This process requires going through the breaking changes approval process and the subsequent breaking changes customer communication process. To learn more visit [CPEX Breaking Change Process](https://aka.ms/CPEXBreakingChangesProcess) Once a service API version is fully retired, the corresponding API spec should be removed from the [REST API specs repo](https://github.com/azure/azure-rest-api-specs). ## Removing published REST API reference documentation Before removing the corresponding API spec from the GitHub repo, the REST API reference documentation need to be unpublished. Please reach out to the Learn API Reference Docs team first and/or fill out [this template.](https://dev.azure.com/msft-skilling/Content/_workitems/create/User%20Story?templateId=b10b9359-9b36-46ba-9840-848ce407a8b3&ownerId=c4a28f90-17ae-4384-b514-7273392b082b) ## Deprecating Preview REST APIs Follow the process described in the [Azure REST API wiki](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Deprecating-Preview-APIs) to remove your REST API spec from the specs repository."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"develop#sdk-release#sdk-release-prerequisites.md","document_title":"Prerequisites to release client libraries (SDK)","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/develop/sdk-release/sdk-release-prerequisites","content":"# develop#sdk-release#sdk-release-prerequisites.md # Prerequisites to release client libraries (SDK) After [executing the automation to generate SDKs](xref:sdk-generate) directly from your API specification in TypeSpec, it is necessary to perform all required tasks outlined on this page before [initiating the SDK release pipeline](xref:sdk-release-pipeline) for publication. ## Before you begin - You have completed [the SDK generation](xref:sdk-generate) and created an SDK pull requests to the respective Azure SDK repository. - For an initial SDK release of your service, ensure that the [review of your SDK package name](xref:namespace-review) — specified in the tspconfig.yaml configuration file — has been completed. ## Customize SDKs After generating client code with automation, it may be necessary to rename models, attributes, operations, or parameters to maintain consistent naming conversions. > [!NOTE] > Azure SDK mandates adherence to a consistent set of naming conventions, which significantly enhances the overall usability of the SDK. For instance, in the case of Azure SDK for .NET, developers are required not only to follow the [general naming conventions of .NET](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/standard/design-guidelines/general-naming-conventions), but also to comply with specific guidelines regarding the naming of classes, properties, and methods. Further information is available at [Azure SDK for .NET – naming conventions](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-net/blob/main/doc/dev/Mgmt-Naming-Conventions.md). Guidelines for additional languages are available at the [Azure SDKs site](https://azure.github.io/azure-sdk/general_introduction.html) To customize the SDK as needed, you need to configure `client.tsp`. More details can be found at the [setup for SDK customization]( https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/howtos/generate-client-libraries/01setup/) and [renaming types](https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/howtos/generate-client-libraries/09renaming/#customizations). After set up SDK customization and apply renaming, ensure to re-run the SDK generation to regenerate the client libraries. ## Resolve Breaking Changes The automation that generates the SDKs detect and report any breaking changes in the APIs to maintain backward compatibility. It is necessary to review these breaking changes, retaining only those that are unavoidable and have been evaluated and approved through the [CPEX Breaking Changes Review Process](https://eng.ms/docs/cloud-ai-platform/azure-core/azure-core-product/product-lifecycle-management-plm/service-lifecycle-and-actions-team/service-lifecycle-actions-team/cpex/media/overview_breaking_changes#cpex-breaking-changes-review-process). > [!NOTE] > CPEX (Cloud Product Excellence) Breaking Change Policy documentation covers Azure's requirements on service versioning and breaking changes. Generally, we must avoid introducing any breaking changes into our services, products, APIs, or SDKs. If a breaking change is unavoidable, we must provide customers a three-year notification for migration and fully support the prior versions during that period. More details about CPEX Breaking Changes Review Process can be found at this [Azure Breaking Changes](https://eng.ms/docs/cloud-ai-platform/azure-core/azure-core-product/product-lifecycle-management-plm/service-lifecycle-and-actions-team/service-lifecycle-actions-team/cpex/media/overview_breaking_changes) page. ## Commit tests SDK usability is essential for customer success, so our SDKs must include tests. For GA SDK releases of the management plane, .NET recommends live tests to ensure compatibility with the new service version. For the data plane, according to the target phase of your SDK, these are the requirements you need to accomplish before the SDK release: - Public preview: at least one test per language for the most common usage scenario. - GA: at least one test per shipped method. Additional resources on adding SDK tests for various languages and SDK types are available at [test SDKs](xref:sdk-test). ## Write samples Every SDK needs a quickstart guide with code samples, as developers prefer learning from examples over lengthy documentation. Each management plane SDK release needs at least one sample per language for the main usage scenario. For the data plane, according to the target phase of your SDK, these are the requirements you need to accomplish before the SDK release: - Public preview: at least one sample per language for the most common usage scenario. - GA: at least 4 samples for the most common usage scenario. Additional resources on adding SDK samples for various languages and SDK types are available at [write SDK samples](xref:sdk-samples). ## Update CHANGELOG file When SDK generation happens with automation, it automatically updates the `CHANGELOG.md` to track changes. The updates include: - Replacing `(unreleased)` with the current date in “YYYY-MM-DD” format. > [!NOTE] > Prior to starting the SDK release pipelines, you should confirm that the date for the latest version to be released is up to date to; or it can lead to pipeline failures. - Summarizing version updates under Features Added, Breaking Changes, Bug Fixes, and Other Changes. > [!NOTE] > To revise, you should only include sections that have content, leaving nonblank. Take an example of the [CHANGELOG.md of Azure Core](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-net/blob/main/sdk/core/Azure.Core/CHANGELOG.md) ## Get SDK pull request merged Once you confirm :white_check_mark: your SDK libraries are generated :white_check_mark: tests and samples are added :white_check_mark:`CHANGELOG.md` is up to date All changes should be committed to the pull request generated by the SDK generation automation (if not already present). Monitor and address review comments from the SDK engineer for each language as needed until approval is granted to merge the pull request. > [!NOTE] > For GA releases, .NET requires APIView approval from the .NET SDK owner on the SDK pull request for release."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"retirement#sdk-deprecation-guidelines.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/retirement/sdk-deprecation-guidelines","content":"# retirement#sdk-deprecation-guidelines.md | Short Link: | [aka.ms/azsdk/deprecation](https://aka.ms/azsdk/deprecation) | |--|--| # Azure SDK deprecation guidelines fixes. Track 2 libraries must follow the standard 3-year notification as per the Azure Retirement Guidelines linked at the top of this document. | | **After 12 months** |
  • Track 1 library no longer builds in the engineering system.
  • Only high-impact customer-impacting (i.e., Sev1) bugs are addressed in Track 1 when no mitigation to Track 2 is acceptable. This would require re-creating or fixing the engineering system for that one fix.
  • Do a telemetry search on the old SDK. Any subscription that is currently submitted via the old SDK will receive an email informing you that the old SDK is being deprecated and points to the blog post for upgrade information.
  • Get Azure Advisor involved to show an alert saying that an app accessing resource X is using an SDK that will soon be deprecated, and they should upgrade. If it’s an internal resource, identify the resource making the call. | | **After 18 months** |
    • Track 1 library code moved out of the repository.
    • This can mean that either the code is deleted from the repo or archived. Note: As we have release tags, the code will continue to be available when directly accessing the release tag. | | **Beta libraries less than one year old** |
      • Beta packages with a later GA library release are automatically considered deprecated
      • Beta packages with no planned future development can be marked deprecated at any time
        • Update README if available and package manager with deprecation notice
        • If a GA release is available, direct customers to it in the README and package managers
      • Beta packages have no obligation to receive support once marked deprecated
      | **Beta libraries older than one year** |

      Beta packages with a GA release can follow the same guidance as provided for betas less than one year old, once the following requirements are met:

      • Inform customers that the library is deprecated. Note: In this documentation, the words "retirement" and "deprecation" are used interchangeably. Both terms refer to the process of phasing out support for SDKs and APIs. | **Lifecycle Stage** | **Action** | | --- | --- | | **GA libraries that have a Track 2 library available** |
        • Update the old package to point to the new Track 2 library.
        • Update the package manager of the old package as per guidance above on updating package managers. if the package has a README in the Azure SDK language repo, update the README with the same message as the package manager.
        • Post a blog on the Azure Blog, essentially stating that a new package is available which replaces the old package, the old package is scheduled to be deprecated on a specific date, and guidance on adjusting code to use the new package.
        • No new features should be added in Track 1. If the feature request is valid for the new SDK, transition the issue to the new SDK.
        • Major customer-impacting bugs should continue to be addressed in both Track 1 and Track 2, including security vulnerabilities.
        • Serious security vulnerabilities in dependent libraries are addressed in both Track 1 and Track 2.
        • For Track 1 SDK libraries, the EOLDate must be slated for 12 months after a replacement Track 2 library is available. Support during the first year may be limited to critical security fixes. Track 2 libraries must follow the standard 3-year notification as per the Azure Retirement Guidelines linked at the top of this document. | | **After 12 months** |
          • Track 1 library no longer builds in the engineering system.
          • Only high-impact customer-impacting (i.e., Sev1) bugs are addressed in Track 1 when no mitigation to Track 2 is acceptable. This would require re-creating or fixing the engineering system for that one fix.
          • Do a telemetry search on the old SDK. and package manager with deprecation notice
          • If a GA release is available, direct customers to it in the README and package managers
        • Beta packages have no obligation to receive support once marked deprecated
        | **Beta libraries older than one year** |

        Beta packages with a GA release can follow the same guidance as provided for betas less than one year old, once the following requirements are met:

        • Inform customers that the library is deprecated. The GA library should have an updated README and package manager
        • Provide customers with a link to GA library (via README and package manager)

        Beta packages without a GA release can be marked deprecated when the following requirements are met:

        • Inform customers that the library is deprecated (update README and package manager)
        • Provide customers with a link to alternative library (if available)
        • Provide customers with a migration guide (if alternative library is available)
        • Inform customers that source is available for those that want to continue using the library

        Deprecated beta packages have no obligation to receive support once marked deprecated. Source code will remain available for those that want to continue using and maintaining the library themselves.

        ## Next steps - [Deprecating Azure SDKs](xref:sdk-deprecation) ## Get help If you have general questions about the deprecation guidelines and process, reach out to us on the [Azure SDK / Azure SDK Onboarding] channel. [Azure SDK / Azure SDK Onboarding]: https://aka.ms/azsdk/support/onboarding-channel"},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"retirement#sdk-deprecation.md","document_title":"Deprecating Azure SDKs","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/retirement/sdk-deprecation","content":"# retirement#sdk-deprecation.md # Deprecating Azure SDKs This section describes the process of marking SDK packages as deprecated on the Azure SDK inventory dashboard and on package managers that host the packages. It does not cover the wider retirement or deprecation process defined by Microsoft. For information on that process, refer to the [Retirement Process and Policy Overview](https://aka.ms/aprwiki). The Retirement Process and Policy Overview uses the term "retirement" instead of "deprecation," but we use the terms interchangeably. ## Before you begin - You are familiarized with the [Azure SDK deprecation guidelines](xref:sdk-deprecation-guidelines). ## Azure SDK deprecation process using a PowerShell terminal: ``` git clone https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk.git ``` - Create a branch in your local copy of our repo: ``` git checkout -b package_deprecation ``` - Launch VS Code and open the local repo folder: ``` File -> Open Folder -> ``` - Open the relevant CSV file in VS Code, located under the following directory: ``` \azure-sdk\_data\releases\latest\ android-packages.csv c-packages.csv ## Update package managers The Azure SDKs are hosted on public package managers: | **Language** | **Package Manager** | | --- | --- | | **.NET** | [NuGet](https://nuget.org) | | **Python** | [PyPI](https://pypi.org/) | | **JavaScript** | [NPM](https://www.npmjs.com/) | | **Java** | [Maven](https://search.maven.org/) | | **Go** | [pkg.go.dev](https://pkg.go.dev/) | The download page for each deprecated package on each package manager needs to be updated with a deprecation message. ### Deprecation message | **Package Status** | **Message** | | --- | --- | | Deprecated with differently named replacement | This package has been deprecated and will no longer be maintained after ``. Upgrade to the replacement package, ``, to continue receiving updates. Refer to the migration guide (``) for guidance on upgrading. Refer to our deprecation policy (link) for more details. | | Deprecated with same name | This package has been deprecated and will no longer be maintained after ``. Upgrade to the latest version to continue receiving updates. Refer to the migration guide (``) for guidance on upgrading. Refer to our [deprecation policy](https://aka.ms/azsdk/support-policies) for more details. | ### Package specific requirements | **Package Manager** | **Deprecation Process** | | --- | --- | | **NuGet** | If you are deprecating .NET packages, there is automation in the Azure SDK GitHub repo that will update NuGet after your dotnet CSV commit is merged. You will need to have the NuGet search popularity for the deprecated package forwarded to the new replacement package to ensure it shows up in search results. This is a manual step and requires sending an email to account@nuget.org with the names of deprecated packages whose popularity should be transferred, and the list of stable packages that should receive the popularity transfer for each deprecated package. If deprecating more than ten packages, list them in tabular form using two columns: new ID, old ID. After the application is submitted, the NuGet team will notify you of the application's acceptance or rejection status (with the criteria that caused rejection).

        Popularity transfer requirements:
        - The legacy packages and new packages must share all owners.
        - The new packages must be clearly related to the legacy packages in naming and function (i.e., an evolution or next generation).
        - All versions of the legacy packages must be deprecated and point to the new packages receiving the transfer.
        - The popularity transfer must not cause confusion for NuGet users or worsen the NuGet search experience.
        - The new packages must have a stable version.
        - The legacy package must not receive popularity transfers from another deprecated package. **PyPI** | Follow the process outlined in the [package deprecation wiki](https://aka.ms/azsdk/python/deprecation-process) located in the Azure SDK for Python GitHub repo. | **NPM** |File a deprecation issue on the Azure SDK for JS GitHub [repo](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-js/issues/new?assignees=xirzec&labels=bug%2Cneeds-triage&projects=&template=deprecation_request.yaml&title=%5BDeprecate%5D%3A).| from another deprecated package. **PyPI** | Follow the process outlined in the [package deprecation wiki](https://aka.ms/azsdk/python/deprecation-process) located in the Azure SDK for Python GitHub repo. | **NPM** |File a deprecation issue on the Azure SDK for JS GitHub [repo](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-js/issues/new?assignees=xirzec&labels=bug%2Cneeds-triage&projects=&template=deprecation_request.yaml&title=%5BDeprecate%5D%3A).| **Maven** |Follow the process outlined in the package deprecation wiki located in the Azure SDK for Java GitHub [repo](https://aka.ms/azsdk/java/deprecation-process). | **pkg.go.dev** |Follow the process outlined in the package deprecation wiki located in the Azure SDK for Go GitHub [repo](https://aka.ms/azsdk/go/deprecation-process). |"},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"design#specs-pr-guides#pr-brch-deep.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/specs-pr-guides/pr-brch-deep","content":"# design#specs-pr-guides#pr-brch-deep.md | Short Link: | [aka.ms/azsdk/pr-brch-deep](https://aka.ms/azsdk/pr-brch-deep) | | --- | --- | # Deep-dive into breaking changes on spec PRs ## Important information about this article This article provides a deep-dive into breaking changes on spec PRs. It applies if your spec PR has `BreakingChangeReviewRequired` or `VersioningReviewRequired` label. > [!IMPORTANT] > This is an advanced deep-dive. If your PR is blocked on breaking changes or versioning issues, you should always > start by following the guidance at [aka.ms/brch]. ### Prerequisites This article assumes you are familiar with [API versions and branches](xref:api-versions-and-branches). ### Video overview and slides For video overview of the breaking changes process, see this [Azure Core Day of Learning talk from March 6, 2024]. Slides for the talk are available [here][talk slides]. ### Summary Per the [PR diagram], the first step of getting your specs PR approved is ensuring your PR obeys the [Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy]. Relevant details of this policy follow. - Once published, no changes to given API version are allowed, except when fixing the spec to match actual implementation (see the `-Approved-BugFix` labels in this doc). This applies regardless of whether the API version is for `private preview`, `public preview`, or `GA`. - When introducing a new API version (any `preview` or `GA`), the new API version must be backwards compatible with the previous, latest `GA` API version. - During a (`private` or `public`) `preview` cycle, a new `preview` API version does not have to be backwards compatible with the previous `preview` API version. - The rules listed above are checked by automated GitHub checks. The exact ruleset is given in [`oadMessagesRuleMap.ts`]. Details follow. ## Breaking changes and versioning issues There are two automatic checks running on your PR checking for conformance to the [Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy]: - `Breaking Change(Cross-Version)` that ensures you don't introduce breaking changes or violate versioning policy *across* two API versions. - `Swagger BreakingChange` that ensures you didn't introduce breaking changes or violated versioning policy *within* any single API version. The result of running these checks may result in one of these labels being applied: `BreakingChangeReviewRequired` or `VersioningReviewRequired`. If this happens, your PR is **blocked** from any further review, including ARM review, if applicable. The breaking change/versioning checks are performed only on PRs targeting the `main` branch in the [public specs repo] or `RPSaaSMaster` branch of the [private specs repo]. These two branches are `production branches`. Merging an API specification to either of them publishes it for all customers to use & consume. ### `BreakingChangeReviewRequired` label The label `BreakingChangeReviewRequired` is added to your PR if the tooling detects a change that could be breaking for customers. This can happen in two cases: - In your PR you have possibly introduced a breaking change in a new API version, placed in a new folder, as compared to most recent previous `GA`. The new API version can be either `preview` or `GA`. - For example, an existing `GA` API version in leaf folder of `2023-11-15` may contain API route of `GET .../resoruces/{resourceName}`, but a new `preview` API version of `2024-03-15-preview` may no longer have this route (REST API path), because you are removing the `resoruces` typo and instead introducing `GET .../resources/{resourceName}` route. - In your PR you are modifying existing `GA` API version in-place. For example, you have recently released `2024-03-18` API version and realized you made a typo and are editing the contents of the leaf folder `2024-03-18` containing that API version. ### `VersioningReviewRequired` label The label `VersioningReviewRequired` denotes that your PR has a **versioning issue** possibly violating the [Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy]. This happens when you made a **non-breaking change**, aka **compatible change** to an API version that was already published (merged to a production branch). > [!NOTE] > According to [the policy][Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy], compatible (non-breaking changes) are not > allowed within an existing API version. You must create a new API version. Otherwise, we would confuse our customers > by having to explain "which version of given API version" has a particular change/feature. `VersioningReviewRequired` label is added by automation if: - You made any compatible changes **within** any API version, `GA` or `preview`. - You made any breaking changes in a `preview` API version. If your PR has both breaking changes and versioning issues, only `BreakingChangeReviewRequired` label is added to it. ### In case there is no latest GA API version If there is no latest GA OpenAPI spec, then the the cross-version check is instead comparing to latest available preview if it more than 1 year old. If neither a GA API version or at least 1 year old preview version exists, then the cross-version check automatically passes. ### Diagram explaining breaking changes and versioning issues The logic for automation adding `BreakingChangeReviewRequired` and `VersioningReviewRequired` labels explained above can be summarized in the following diagram: ![Breaking Changes Confusion Matrix](../../img/breaking_changes_confusion_matrix.png) ## Addressing `BreakingChangeReviewRequired` If your PR is labelled with `BreakingChangeReviewRequired`, per Step 1 from the [PR diagram], you must follow the process given at [aka.ms/brch]. If the Breaking Change Review Board determines the breaking changes in your PR are acceptable, they will be approved by one of these labels: ### `BreakingChange-Approved-Benign` The changes to the REST API definition are not breaking at the REST API level and have at most minor impact to generated SDKs, so the change is allowed. ### `BreakingChange-Approved-BugFix` The changes to the REST API definition are correcting the definition to accurately describe the service behavior. > [!TIP] > As a PR author, you are allowed to apply the `BreakingChange-Approved-BugFix` label. See [aka.ms/brch] for details. ### `BreakingChange-Approved-UserImpact` - The spec PR describes actual breaking changes to the service. - This is the only case that triggers customer notifications, a 3 year migration period (possibly shorter), etc. - Within this set, the changes may be distinguished further for security or legal compliance, which may be granted a shorter migration period. - Details at [aka.ms/brch]. ### `BreakingChange-Approved-BranchPolicyException` The API version that triggered the review violates the GitHub repository branch policy, but we allow it. Usually this is because it has not yet been released, despite having been merged to a production branch. > [!TIP] > As a PR author, you are allowed to apply the `BreakingChange-Approved-BranchPolicyException` label, > but only in the [private specs repo]. See [aka.ms/brch] for details. ### `BreakingChange-Approved-Previously` - The PR contains breaking changes that were previously reviewed and approved. - It is desirable but not mandatory to add a link the previously approved PR in a comment on given PR. - As of 3/11/2024 we have planned work to reduce occurrences of this scenario. See [#7259](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-tools/issues/7259) for details. ## Addressing `VersioningReviewRequired` If your PR is labelled with `VersioningReviewRequired`, per Step 1 from the [PR diagram], you must follow the process given at [aka.ms/brch]. If the Breaking Change Review Board determines the versioning issue in your PR caused by non-breaking (compatible) changes is acceptable, the board will approve it by one of these labels: ### `Versioning-Approved-Benign` The changes to the REST API definition are not breaking at the REST API level and have at most minor impact to generated SDKs, so the change is allowed. ### `Versioning-Approved-BugFix` The changes to the REST API definition are correcting the definition to accurately describe the service behavior. > [!TIP] > As a PR author, you are allowed to apply the `Versioning-Approved-BugFix` label. See [aka.ms/brch] for details. ### `Versioning-Approved-PrivatePreview` The API version change that triggered the review is in `private preview`, and non-breaking changes are permitted in the same API version during `private preview`. > [!TIP] > As a PR author, you are allowed to apply the `Versioning-Approved-PrivatePreview` label. See [aka.ms/brch] for details. ### `Versioning-Approved-BranchPolicyException` The API version that triggered the review violates the GitHub repository branch policy, but we allow it. Usually this is because it has not yet been released, despite having been merged to a production branch. > [!TIP] > As a PR author, you are allowed to apply the `Versioning-Approved-BranchPolicyException` label, > but only in the [private specs repo]. See [aka.ms/brch] for details. ### `Versioning-Approved-Previously` - The PR contains breaking changes that were previously reviewed and approved. - It is desirable but not mandatory to add a link the previously approved PR in a comment on given PR. - As of 3/11/2024 we have planned work to reduce occurrences of this scenario. See [#7259](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-tools/issues/7259) for details. ## Common misconceptions ### FALSE: compatible (non-breaking) changes are allowed in published API versions **Why?** An API version is a contract, and once the contract is published it cannot be changed. Otherwise, it would create customer confusion about "which version of this API version" are they using. Any change of this kind w"},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"develop#namespace-review.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/develop/namespace-review","content":"# Review SDK package names ## Request a namespace review ### [Management plane (ARM)](#tab/management) create namespaces for each programing language. Use your service's resource provider name in place of `[ResourceProviderName]`, and be sure to keep the same casing as the example. After you create the issue, the proposed namespaces will be reviewed by our management SDK team. After the management SDK team approves the proposed namespaces, the proposed namespaces will be brought in front of our SDK architects who will have 1 week to state any concerns they may have about the namespaces. After the week is up and all concerns from the architects have been resolved, the namespaces will be approved. The management plane namespace review process usually take 1-2 weeks. ***Note that during November and December the turnaround time could be sightly longer.*** If the SDK architecture board determines that an in-person review session is needed, Ronnie Geraghty will be in touch to schedule the in-person review. #### Example management (ARM) library namespaces Use the following examples as guide for naming management plane packages. Replace Confidential Ledger with the name of your service. - .NET: `Azure.ResourceManager.ConfidentialLedger` - Java: `azure-resourcemanager-confidentialledger (com.azure.resouremanager.confidentialledger)` - Go/Golang: `sdk/resourcemanager/confidentialledger/armconfidentialledger` - JavaScript: `@azure/arm-confidentialledger` - Python: `azure-mgmt-confidentialledger`"},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"develop#sdk-release#sdk-release.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/develop/sdk-release/sdk-release","content":"# Release SDK ## Next steps - For each released package by going to the public feed and verifying: - Metadata - Verify that the links, documentation, readme, etc. are correct and appear as expected. - Download - Download the package and verify that it is the same one you built/published. - In your release plan, mark the **Release SDK** task as completed and proceed to complete the release plan. - [Verify SDK reference docs](xref:sdk-docs) - Verify the content of the release notes PR generated during the release pipeline. Review and approve the PR. See [Producing Release Notes](https://azure.github.io/azure-sdk/policies_releasenotes.html) for details. - The release pipeline will submit a PR with a version bump for each SDK in their respective language repository. You need to review and merge each version bump pull request."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"mcp#mcp-getting-started.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/mcp/mcp-getting-started","content":"# Getting started with the Azure MCP Server ## Before you begin - The Azure MCP Server project is focused on expanding Data Plane access to Azure services primarily, as management plane commands are often covered by ARM (which is supported via the Azure MCP Server + Azure CLI integration today). - If you're building Azure MCP Server functionality for your particular service, you must first have Azure SDK support for your intended use cases, either on the data plane or management plane. - To find out more about the Azure SDK release process, you can find the Azure SDK team guidance [here.](xref:onboard)"},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"develop#sdk-release#sdk-release.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/develop/sdk-release/sdk-release","content":"# Release SDK ## Get help ### [Management plane (ARM)](#tab/management) [Azure SDK - SDK Release Support](https://teams.microsoft.com/l/channel/19%3A084875bb626242ed95f3ac8dddfaa12a%40thread.skype/SDK%20release%20support?groupId=3e17dcb0-4257-4a30-b843-77f47f1d4121&tenantId=72f988bf-86f1-41af-91ab-2d7cd011db47)."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"develop#sdk-release#sdk-release-mgmt-dotnet.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/develop/sdk-release/sdk-release-mgmt-dotnet","content":"# Prerequisites to release .NET management plane SDK | Short Link: | [azsdk/releases/mgmtnet](https://aka.ms/azsdk/releases/mgmtnet) | | --- | --- | Azure services are required to work on .NET management plane SDKs. >[!IMPORTANT] > This guidance is only applicable for OpenAPI API specs."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"plan#upcoming_release_planner_change.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/plan/upcoming_release_planner_change","content":"# SDK self-serve for TypeSpec generated management plane SDKs ## Get help [Azure SDK - SDK Release Support](https://teams.microsoft.com/l/channel/19%3A084875bb626242ed95f3ac8dddfaa12a%40thread.skype/SDK%20release%20support?groupId=3e17dcb0-4257-4a30-b843-77f47f1d4121&tenantId=72f988bf-86f1-41af-91ab-2d7cd011db47)."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"develop#sdk-release#sdk-release-pipeline.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/develop/sdk-release/sdk-release-pipeline","content":"# Run release SDK pipeline ## Before you begin > [!NOTE] > These instructions are for packages that are built and release from our mono repos (i.e. `azure-sdk-for-`). If you are a partner that is trying to release a package from outside of those repos follow the instructions at [Partner Release Pipelines](https://aka.ms/azsdk/partner-release-pipeline). - You have a [release plan](xref:release-plan) for the release. - You have [access to the Azure SDK DevOps](xref:access#request-access-to-azure-sdk-devops). - You have read and understood the [Azure SDK approval release guidelines](xref:sdk-approval-release-guidelines)."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"develop#sdk-release#sdk-release.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/develop/sdk-release/sdk-release","content":"# Release SDK ## When to release ### [Data plane](#tab/dataplane) Although releases happen every month, you can release the SDK on demand. The Azure SDK team follows a monthly release calendar where we minimize disruptions to the release tools as much as possible. Outside of those dates, the tools might not be as stable. [Release Calendar](https://teams.microsoft.com/l/entity/com.microsoft.teamspace.tab.planner/_djb2_msteams_prefix_1611974298?context=%7B%22subEntityId%22%3Anull%2C%22channelId%22%3A%2219%3Adc2e34377e494a9292d89fbc34125eae%40thread.skype%22%7D&groupId=3e17dcb0-4257-4a30-b843-77f47f1d4121&tenantId=72f988bf-86f1-41af-91ab-2d7cd011db47): This calendar shows the Package Code Freeze and Package Ship dates for the year."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"develop#sdk-release#sdk-release-mgmt-dotnet.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/develop/sdk-release/sdk-release-mgmt-dotnet","content":"# Prerequisites to release .NET management plane SDK ## Next steps ### Release SDK SDK release process is different for management plane SDK based on the type of API Spec. You can learn more about [release process](xref:sdk-release)."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"develop#sdk-develop.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/develop/sdk-develop","content":"# Develop client libraries (SDK) ## Before you begin - You have [access](xref:access) to the GitHub repositories and respective GitHub groups. - You read our [repository branches strategy](https://azure.github.io/azure-sdk/policies_repobranching.html). - You are familiarized with the [Azure SDK Architecture design guidelines](https://azure.github.io/azure-sdk/general_introduction.html). - You have a [release plan](xref:release-plan) created to manage and understand the steps required to generate, test, and release an SDK. - [Request a namespace review](xref:namespace-review). This review process take 1-2 weeks to complete or longer depending on the complexity of the review."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"develop#sdk-develop.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/develop/sdk-develop","content":"# Develop client libraries (SDK) ## Get help - If you need help with an automation tool or the Release planner, reach out to [Azure SDK / Azure SDK Onboarding](https://aka.ms/azsdk/support/onboarding-channel) channel. - If you need help with the development of the SDKs reach out to the [language specific Team's channel](xref:support#get-help-with-the-azure-sdks-development). - If you need to request an exception for a language review the [request release exception](xref:request-exception)."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"develop#sdk-release#sdk-release.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/develop/sdk-release/sdk-release","content":"# Release SDK ## When to release ### [Management plane (ARM)](#tab/management) The Azure SDK release processes for management plane SDKs vary based on the API specification type - TypeSpec: On demand. - Open API: Request a release **before the cutoff date** for the month that you're targeting. :point_right: 2nd Friday of every month: Cutoff date :point_right: 4th Friday of every month: Release date The functionality to request a release for Java, JavaScript, Python, and Go is available as part of the management plane release plan. You can learn more about release plans [here](xref:release-plan). For releasing the .NET SDK release follow the [.NET release process](xref:sdk-release-mgmt-dotnet)."}]
