rows.outputs.similarity.similarity_sample_inp: [{"role": "user", "content": "{\"query\": \"title: Deprecation of PostgreSql Single Server and its SDK Guidance\\n\\nquestion: Hi, PostgreSql Single Server officially deprecated in March 2025 with support completely ending September 2025. Efforts these past few months have been made to migrate users to PostgreSql Flexible Server.\\nWe wish to remove the operations associated with single server found here: https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-net/tree/main/sdk/postgresql/Azure.ResourceManager.PostgreSql/src/PostgreSql\\nWant to confirm what is the exact process to remove the operations:\\nIs official request needed?\\nDo we manually remove the files associated to the resource?\\nThank you for the help.\", \"response\": \"To remove the management-plane operations for PostgreSql Single Server from the Azure SDK for .NET, you must follow the official Azure API and SDK retirement/deprecation process. Manual removal of files from the SDK repository is not sufficient and should only occur after all required steps are completed.\\n\\nHere\\u2019s the process you need to follow:\\n\\n1. **Service/API Retirement Approval and Coordination**:\\n   - Confirm that the API version and service are fully retired per Azure\\u2019s retirement policy. You must have gone through the official breaking change approval and customer communication process, especially since Single Server is a GA service. See [CPEX Breaking Change Process](https://aka.ms/CPEXBreakingChangesProcess).\\n   - Coordinate with ARM/API owners and ensure that the corresponding REST API spec is removed from the [azure-rest-api-specs](https://github.com/azure/azure-rest-api-specs) repository once the service/API version is fully retired.\\n\\n2. **SDK Deprecation and Dashboard Update**:\\n   - Mark the relevant .NET SDK package as deprecated in the Azure SDK inventory dashboard. This requires editing the `dotnet-packages.csv` file in the Azure SDK repo and setting the `Support` field to `deprecated`, the `EOLDate` to the end-of-support date, and providing a `Replace` and `ReplaceGuide` (e.g., pointing to Flexible Server and a migration guide).\\n   - Submit a PR for this change; this triggers the update on the public [Azure SDK dashboard](https://aka.ms/azsdk) and will notify the repo owners for review.\\n\\n3. **Package Manager Updates and Deprecation Notices**:\\n   - Ensure NuGet is updated with a deprecation message, replacement package info, and migration guide. This is automated after the CSV change is merged, but you may need to manually request popularity transfer for search ranking (see instructions for emailing NuGet).\\n   - Update README files in the repo and package manager pages with deprecation notices and migration guidance.\\n\\n4. **Code Removal**:\\n   - After all deprecation steps and notifications are complete and the API spec is removed, you may then submit a PR to remove the actual source files for Single Server operations from the SDK repository.\\n   - The PR should clearly reference the official retirement and deprecation approvals, and include breaking change details in the release notes and CHANGELOG.\\n   - The removal is a breaking change and must be tracked as such in the release notes and communicated to customers (typically a 3-year notification period is required for GA breaking changes unless otherwise approved).\\n\\n5. **Release Pipeline**:\\n   - Once the removal PR is approved and merged, run the SDK release pipeline and verify the release package, documentation, and notes reflect the change. Ensure all steps in the release plan are marked complete.\\n\\n**Do not manually remove files before the above steps are completed.** All removal actions must be traceable to the official deprecation/retirement process to avoid accidental breaking changes and ensure compliance with Azure customer communication policies.\\n\\nIf you have questions or need support, reach out to the [Azure SDK Onboarding channel](https://aka.ms/azsdk/support/onboarding-channel).\\n\", \"ground_truth\": \"You will need to update the libraries for all 5 languages, not just .NET, to support the deprecation / retirement and migration.\\nFor .NET, does the library currently contain operations for both the single server and flexible server?  If so, the REST API version(s) in question would need to be retired first, and then new SDK libraries would need to be generated.\\nFor some of the other languages (like Python, Go, and Java), were there separate libraries for single server and flexible server?\\nI'm looping in our Shanghai team for assistance - Josephine, Arthur, and Renhe.\\nOnce we work out how the libraries map to the different service versions, the instructions on how to deprecate an entire library for each language are here: [Deprecating Azure SDKs](https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/retirement/sdk-deprecation)\"}"}]

rows.inputs.query:
title: Confirm deprecation workflow for HDInsightOnAks (Preview, usage = 0): API & SDK

question: Hi team,
HDInsightOnAks service is already in deprecation, which is Preview and currently has 0 usage. We need to retire both API and SDKs. After reviewing some discussions about Deprecation of PostgreSql, I’ve drafted the following workflow and would like the SDK team to confirm and help clarify a few questions.
Workflow and Questions:
1. Remove the HDInsightOnAks spec folder from azure-rest-api-specs
2. After removing the HDInsightOnAks API, send SDK deprecation email to Josephine
a) For SDK deprecation, do we only need to send an email? Is there a recommended email template?
b) For each language repo, should I manually remove the code, or will the SDK team handle the removal?
c) Is the final deprecation outcome to add a Deprecated annotation?
Please confirm and add any missing steps. Thanks!
rows.inputs.ground_truth:
Before you remove the specs folder, you need to make sure that any REST API docs on Learn are moved first:  Retiring Azure APIs.
Details on how to mark each SDK library as deprecated are here:  Deprecating Azure SDKs.  If you have already emails your service customers as part of the service deprecation, no separate email for SDKs is required.
Josephine can assist with coordinating on the removal of code (but you should be able to submit PRs after all other work is done).
rows.inputs.response:
Here is the confirmed deprecation workflow for retiring the HDInsightOnAks Preview API and its SDKs based on the provided Azure SDK onboarding documentation:

1. **API Spec Removal:**
   - For preview REST APIs, follow the Azure REST API wiki deprecation process (see https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Deprecating-Preview-APIs). Once the API version is fully retired, you should remove the corresponding API spec folder from the `azure-rest-api-specs` repo. Ensure you follow the process for preview API deprecation, which may include communication and documentation steps.

2. **SDK Deprecation Communication:**
   - Sending an email alone is **not sufficient** for formal SDK deprecation. The required steps are:
     - Update the SDK package status in the Azure SDK inventory dashboard and public package managers.
     - For official process and guidance, refer to [Azure SDK deprecation guidelines](https://aka.ms/azsdk/deprecation).
     - There is no mandated email template in the knowledge, but communications should include the EOL date, replacement package (if any), and migration guide (if available). The recommended message format for package managers is:
       - "This package has been deprecated and will no longer be maintained after <EOLDate>. Upgrade to the replacement package, <Replace>, to continue receiving updates. Refer to the migration guide (<ReplaceGuide>) for guidance on upgrading. Refer to our deprecation policy for more details."

3. **Update SDK Dashboard and Package Managers:**
   - You must update the language-specific CSV files in the Azure SDK repo (`_data/releases/latest/{language}-packages.csv`) for each deprecated SDK package. Set `Support` to `deprecated`, add the `EOLDate`, and fill out `Replace`/`ReplaceGuide` fields as appropriate. See full step-by-step instructions in the knowledge context.
   - After updating the CSV and merging the PR, automation will update the Azure SDK dashboard and, for .NET, also update NuGet.
   - For other package managers (PyPI, NPM, Maven, pkg.go.dev), follow the linked language-specific deprecation process to update the package metadata and add a deprecation notice.

4. **SDK Source Code Removal:**
   - After deprecation, Track 1 library code can be moved out of the repository (deleted or archived), but release tags will still provide access. The service team is generally responsible for initiating code removal. You should update the README and package manager with a deprecation notice first. 
   - For zero-usage, preview SDKs, you may mark them deprecated at any time and remove/archive the code once deprecation is communicated.
   - If you need help with code removal, reach out to the relevant language release driver (contact info in the knowledge).

5. **Deprecation Annotation:**
   - The final deprecation outcome is to have the package metadata (dashboard and package manager) reflect the deprecated status. There is **no requirement** to add a Deprecated annotation in code, but it is best practice to add deprecation notices in the README and in package manager metadata.

**Missing Steps/Requirements:**
- Make sure to unpublish any REST API reference documentation before removing the spec from GitHub (reach out to the Learn API Reference Docs team and/or fill out the provided template).
- For preview APIs, follow the preview deprecation process as outlined in the Azure REST API specs wiki.
- If a GA version existed, a 12-month notification period is required for deprecation, but preview versions can be deprecated immediately if unused.

**Summary Action Items:**
- Remove API spec folder (after following preview API deprecation steps).
- Unpublish REST API reference docs.
- Update SDK dashboard and package managers via CSV edits and language-specific processes.
- Communicate deprecation (update README, package metadata, optional email notification).
- Remove/archive SDK source code after dashboard/package manager updates.

If you need further help or have questions about specific language repos, reach out to the Azure SDK Onboarding channel or the listed release drivers.

SDK Release Support](https://teams.microsoft.com/l/channel/19%3A084875bb626242ed95f3ac8dddfaa12a%40thread.skype/SDK%20release%20support?groupId=3e17dcb0-4257-4a30-b843-77f47f1d4121&tenantId=72f988bf-86f1-41af-91ab-2d7cd011db47)."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"develop#sdk-release#sdk-release.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/develop/sdk-release/sdk-release","content":"# Release SDK ## Before you begin - You have [access](xref:access) to the GitHub repositories, respective GitHub groups, and release security groups. - You have a [release plan](xref:release-plan) created to manage and understand the steps required to generate, test, and release an SDK. - The REST API specs need to be merged in the main branch of the public repository [Azure/azure-rest-api-specs](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs). - Ensure to complete all tasks outlined on this page [Prerequisites to release SDKs](xref:sdk-release-prerequisites). - Breaking changes to GAed SDKs are not permitted as they conflict with the [Azure SDK design principle](https://azure.github.io/azure-sdk/general_introduction.html#dependable). If breaking changes are inevitable, ensure to get approval from [Azure Breaking Changes Board](https://aka.ms/azbreakingchangespolicy) in your service API Spec review. - Ensure your service is available to the public before the SDK release date."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"design#api-specs-pr#api-versions-and-branches.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-specs-pr/api-versions-and-branches","content":"# API versions and branches ## API version lifecycle stages An API version is a TypeSpec/OpenAPI specification contract identified by its `api-version` value. Given API version is located in its own directory in the specs repositories. It can be in following lifecycle stages: - `generally available` (aka `GA`, `stable`) - `public preview` - `private preview` - `in development` - `closing down` > [!NOTE] > A `closing down` API spec version need to be kept in the spec repository until it is fully `deprecated`. A `deprecated` API spec version need to be removed from the spec repository, with removal initiated by the service to begin deprecating related APIs, SDKs, and CLIs. These stages corresponds to [service tree lifecycle stages] as elaborated on in [ARM lifecycle stages requirements]."}]

See full step-by-step instructions in the knowledge context.\\n   - After updating the CSV and merging the PR, automation will update the Azure SDK dashboard and, for .NET, also update NuGet.\\n   - For other package managers (PyPI, NPM, Maven, pkg.go.dev), follow the linked language-specific deprecation process to update the package metadata and add a deprecation notice.\\n\\n4. **SDK Source Code Removal:**\\n   - After deprecation, Track 1 library code can be moved out of the repository (deleted or archived), but release tags will still provide access. The service team is generally responsible for initiating code removal. You should update the README and package manager with a deprecation notice first. \\n   - For zero-usage, preview SDKs, you may mark them deprecated at any time and remove/archive the code once deprecation is communicated.\\n   - If you need help with code removal, reach out to the relevant language release driver (contact info in the knowledge).\\n\\n5. **Deprecation Annotation:**\\n   - The final deprecation outcome is to have the package metadata (dashboard and package manager) reflect the deprecated status. There is **no requirement** to add a Deprecated annotation in code, but it is best practice to add deprecation notices in the README and in package manager metadata.\\n\\n**Missing Steps/Requirements:**\\n- Make sure to unpublish any REST API reference documentation before removing the spec from GitHub (reach out to the Learn API Reference Docs team and/or fill out the provided template).\\n- For preview APIs, follow the preview deprecation process as outlined in the Azure REST API specs wiki.\\n- If a GA version existed, a 12-month notification period is required for deprecation, but preview versions can be deprecated immediately if unused.\\n\\n**Summary Action Items:**\\n- Remove API spec folder (after following preview API deprecation steps).\\n- Unpublish REST API reference docs.\\n- Update SDK dashboard and package managers via CSV edits and language-specific processes.\\n- Communicate deprecation (update README, package metadata, optional email notification).\\n- Remove/archive SDK source code after dashboard/package manager updates.\\n\\nIf you need further help or have questions about specific language repos, reach out to the Azure SDK Onboarding channel or the listed release drivers.\", \"ground_truth\": \"Before you remove the specs folder, you need to make sure that any REST API docs on Learn are moved first:  Retiring Azure APIs.\\nDetails on how to mark each SDK library as deprecated are here:  Deprecating Azure SDKs.  If you have already emails your service customers as part of the service deprecation, no separate email for SDKs is required.\\nJosephine can assist with coordinating on the removal of code (but you should be able to submit PRs after all other work is done).\"}"}]

rows.inputs.query:
title: Official API documentation publishing

question: General,
How do we generate official API documentation like below?
Azure REST API reference documentation | Microsoft Learn
For a new RP like below. Is this done by the SDK team?
[azure-rest-api-specs/specification/cdn/resource-manager/Microsoft.Cdn/Cdn/preview/2024-07-22-previe…](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/specification/cdn/resource-manager/Microsoft.Cdn/Cdn/preview/2024-07-22-preview/edgeaction.json)
rows.inputs.ground_truth: You can find information about this here: https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-docs
rows.inputs.response:
The official Azure REST API reference documentation on Microsoft Learn (https://learn.microsoft.com/rest/api/) is published automatically for new resource providers (RPs) once their OpenAPI specs are merged into the `main` branch of the public Azure REST API specs repository (`azure-rest-api-specs`).

The process is not handled by the SDK team directly, but rather by the Azure Content Publishing Services team and automated pipelines:

1. **Merge Your Spec**: You must ensure your OpenAPI (or TypeSpec-generated OpenAPI) files and the necessary README configuration are merged into `main` in the `azure-rest-api-specs` repo.

2. **Onboarding**: For first-time onboarding of a new RP, you need to submit an onboarding request to the Content Publishing Services team. This enables your RP's specs to be picked up for documentation generation. See [Onboard reference content on Microsoft Learn](https://learn.microsoft.com/help/onboard/reference?branch=main).

3. **Automatic Refresh**: After initial onboarding, API references are automatically refreshed weekly (typically on Tuesdays) if the README is correctly configured and merged. Any changes merged to the repo will be picked up and published without manual intervention.

4. **Publishing Pipeline**: When a PR is opened, the `spec - api-doc-preview` pipeline runs, onboarding the updated specs into a preview repo, and triggers a pipeline in the Learn organization to generate preview documentation. The results are reported back to your PR.

**Summary**: Publishing the official documentation is managed by the Content Publishing Services team and automated Azure pipelines, not by the SDK team. Your responsibility is to ensure the spec and configuration files are correctly merged and to onboard with the publishing team for first-time RP documentation.

For more details and support, you can:
- Review the [official publishing guide](https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-docs)
- Ask questions in the [API Reference and Samples Teams Channel](https://teams.microsoft.com/dl/launcher/launcher.html?url=%2F_%23%2Fl%2Fchannel%2F19%3A7506cc3e220f430ab89d992c7db5284f%40thread.skype%2FAPI%2520Reference%2520and%2520Samples%3FgroupId%3Dde9ddba4-2574-4830-87ed-41668c07a1ca%26tenantId%3D72f988bf-86f1-41af-91ab-2d7cd011db47).

**Note:** If your RP is already onboarded and uses the automatic refresh, no further action is needed for subsequent updates—just merge your changes to `main` and they will be picked up.

When you're ready for a final review, it's time to create a pull request (PR) from your release branch you created originally to the `main` branch on [Azure/azure-rest-api-specs](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs). * :warning: Do not merge `main` or other release branches unless you know there are changes required. * :white_check_mark: Rebase on `main` if changes are required in a separate topic branch. ## Clean PR against main If you're fairly certain there should be no conflicting changes in files you added or modified in the release branch, you can most often just create a pull request (PR) against `main` on [Azure/azure-rest-api-specs](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs). 1. Go to your branch in [Azure/azure-rest-api-specs](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs) or [Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr). This is particularly interesting for common infrastructure changes that are committed in the repo (i.e. github actions, tools, etc). Depending on how old your branch is some of the pull request checks may not correctly function without taking a merge from main. If you are working in a non-protected branch you can do a `git merge main` like you would normally do a merge and then push your changes to your remote branch. However, if you are working in a branch with branch protection enabled (i.e. `release-*`) then you will need to make a pull request to your branch with the merge. Depending on how out-of-date your branch is from `main` your merge may have a lot of unwanted and unnecessary changes and the checks not pass. In such cases see below on how to [update the infrastructure](#updating-only-the-infrastructure-changes-from-main). ### Updating only the infrastructure changes from main In cases you need to only update the infrastructure code and not the specifications we have a helper pipeline which you can run that will create a pull request with a selective merge. The selective merge will include everything except for specs under the specifications folder. This will enable you to only update the infrastructure and not other specs which should get your checks passing in your protected branch. Follow these steps to run the helper pipeline. > [!NOTE] > This should only be needed for protected branches, such as `release-*`. If you are in an unprotected branch, just use a normal `git merge main`. 1. Go to [tools - update-release-branch-in-specs](https://dev.azure.com/azure-sdk/internal/_build?definitionId=7487) and select **Run Pipeline**. If you don't have permission see [GitHub account linked with your Microsoft account](xref:access). 2. Enter the name of your branch in the **BranchToMergeTo** parameter. Usually this will be in the form `release-`. You shouldn't need to set the other parameters but if your branch is in the private repo then you will need to update **Repo** to be `Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr`. 3. Click the **Run** button. 4. The pipeline should only take a few minutes to run and once it is complete then go find the pull request it created. You can find a link to it in the pipeline logs under the **Create Pull Request to merge** step. 5. Monitor the created pull request and approve it. Once the checks are green then merge the pull request and then your branch should be updated with the latest infrastructure changes. If you have open PRs against your branch with failing checks, go to those PRs and retrigger the checks. The easiest way to retrigger all checks is to hit the close button followed by the open button, which should cause the checks to re-run. ## Next steps 1. [Create a new branch](api-tutorial-1-branch.md) 2. [Work against the release branch](api-tutorial-2-update.md) 3. Indicate whether your REST API changes will be public or private. 10. Provide a link to the REST API specs pull request that contains your latest changes. 11. These fields will be auto populated if you have provided these documents when you [onboarded to the Azure SDK team](xref:onboard). ## Requesting an offline REST API review For small changes, consider asking for an offline review. This may be a better use of your time and leave the meeting time for teams with larger changes - especially important prior to large customer engagements like Build or Ignite. ### When offline reviews are appropriate An offline review is appropriate when the following conditions hold: - The prior API version was reviewed and approved by the API Stewardship board. - The new API version makes only minor changes to the prior API version, such as - Fields added to an API response - Optional parameters or fields added to a request - The PR for the new API version is passing all PR pipeline checks. - The TypeSpec and OpenAPI APIViews for the PR were successfully generated and clearly show the changes without extra "noise". ### How to request an offline review The service team should schedule a review meeting using the scheduling tool for the next available open review slot. This will create an API review issue that will record the progress / status of the API review. Make sure that the API review issue contains: - A link to the PR for the new API version - Links to design docs / hero scenarios (even if these are unchanged) Then the service team should post a comment in the API review issue with the following information: - A link to the API review issue for the prior API version - A description of the changes being made in the new API version Then send a e-mail to the Azure review board core e-mail alias [azureapirbcore@microsoft.com](mailto:azureapirbcore@microsoft.com) including the link to the review issue and requesting an offline review. Add the `offline-review-requested` label to the PR to make it easier for API reviewers to search for PRs to be reviewed offline. ### Conducting the offline review Upon receiving the email requesting offline review, API Stewardship board members may review the PR and leave comments. The service team may use the Teams chat for the meeting to communicate with the review board to recruit reviewers or answer questions. When an API Steward has reviewed the PR and has no concerns they submit an "Approved" review. When at least two API stewards have approved and none have requested changes, any member of the Stewardship board can add the "signedOff" label and the review is complete. ### Following a completed offline review Once the PR has received sign off, the service team should cancel the review meeting to free up the slot for another team. The signedOff label will unblock merge for the PR, but merging should be done only when the API version is ready to be released to customers. ## What happens during the review > [!NOTE] > The m"},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"design#api-docs.md","document_title":"Publish REST API reference docs","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-docs","content":"# design#api-docs.md # Publish REST API reference docs ## Before you begin A valid and reviewed REST API spec is __required__ for API reference to be published on [learn.microsoft.com](https://learn.microsoft.com) for your service. For a sample REST API spec, refer to [Sample OpenAPI spec]. ## Onboard to the content publishing services team After your REST API spec and README configuration file are merged into the [Azure/azure-rest-api-specs] repository (usually the __main__ branch), create an onboarding request to the Content Publishing Services team. To create an onboarding request, visit [Onboard reference content on Microsoft Learn](https://learn.microsoft.com/help/onboard/reference?branch=main). If you get a 404, you need to click on "Sign In" on the upper right to authenticate as a Microsoft employee. ### Automatic refresh API references can be automatically refreshed on the latest API version after first time onboarding. To enable automatic refresh, a README configuration file with a default tag referring to all spec files of the latest API version is __required__. See the [sample README]. ## Update an existing API reference If your service is __already using README__ for publishing configuration and utilizing automatic refresh, as long as the README is properly updated, any API updates merged to the [Azure/azure-rest-api-specs] repository will be automatically picked up by the [Azure REST API reference site on Microsoft Learn](https://learn.microsoft.com/rest/api/) weekly (on Tuesdays). Request an OOB publishing by [creating a Work Item in Azure DevOps] (https://dev.azure.com/msft-skilling/Content/_workitems/create/User%20Story?templateId=39fb91e3-64a2-4c8a-83db-b2bdf3603dd3&ownerId=c4a28f90-17ae-4384-b514-7273392b082b), if needed. If you had to use the __alternative publishing configuration__ with direct paths to the OpenAPI spec files, you’ll need to have the publishing configuration manually updated to document any API updates in the [Azure/azure-rest-api-specs] repository. The easiest way is to create a publishing request by [submitting a User Story in Azure DevOps] (https://dev.azure.com/msft-skilling/Content/_workitems/create/User%20Story?templateId=39fb91e3-64a2-4c8a-83db-b2bdf3603dd3&ownerId=c4a28f90-17ae-4384-b514-7273392b082b). Or you can create a pull request into the [REST API documentation repository] (https://github.com/Azure/azure-docs-rest-apis) and update the publishing configuration. Read [this document on publishing configurations] (https://learn.microsoft.com/help/onboard/admin/reference/rest/api-publishing-configuration) for more details on the recommended and alternative publishing configurations. ## More info * Learn more about [onboarding reference content to Microsoft Learn](https://learn.microsoft.com/help/onboard/reference?branch=main). * For help and support, you can ask questions in the ["API reference and Samples" Teams Channel](https://teams.microsoft.com/dl/launcher/launcher.html?url=%2F_%23%2Fl%2Fchannel%2F19%3A7506cc3e220f430ab89d992c7db5284f%40thread.skype%2FAPI%2520Reference%2520and%2520Samples%3FgroupId%3Dde9ddba4-2574-4830-87ed-41668c07a1ca%26tenantId%3D72f988bf-86f1-41af-91ab-2d7cd011db47&type=channel&deeplinkId=4d931d59-a8ff-489e-a010-100f7f950bd6&directDl=true&msLaunch=true&enableMobilePage=true&suppressPrompt=true). [Sample OpenAPI spec]: https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/documentation/samplefiles/Microsoft.YourServiceName/stable/YYYY-MM-DD/YourServiceName.json [sample README]: https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/documentation/samplefiles/README.md [Azure/azure-rest-api-specs]: https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs"},{"document_source":"typespec_azure_docs","document_filename":"getstarted#createproject.md","document_title":"Creating a project","document_link":"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/getstarted/createproject","content":"# getstarted#createproject.md # Creating a project If you've installed TypeSpec on your local machine, you can create a new TypeSpec project by following these steps: 1. **Open your command prompt** (PowerShell, cmd.exe, bash, etc.), create an empty folder for your new project, and `cd` into it. 2. If creating a new service in the [Azure/azure-rest-api-specs](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs) repository, create the new service folder following our [directory structure guidelines](https://aka.ms/azsdk/spec-dirs). 3. To create a new Azure service specification, use the `tsp init` command: ```bash tsp init https://aka.ms/typespec/azure-init ``` You will be prompted with a few questions regarding the service template, project name, and library updates. ### Understanding Project Templates When initializing a new project, you'll encounter four templates: | Template Name | Description | | --------------------------------------------------------------- | ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ | | **(rest-api-spec repo) Azure Data Plane Service Project** | This template is configured for projects within the `azure-rest-api-specs` repository, with settings that comply with the repo's requirements, such as file paths and linting rules. | | **(rest-api-spec repo) Azure Resource Manager Service Project** | Similar to the above, but tailored for Azure Resource Manager services within the `azure-rest-api-specs` repository. | | **(standalone) Azure Data Plane Service Project** | This template is configured for local use or in a personal repo, allowing for API development without the specific directory structure of the `azure-rest-api-specs` repo. | | **(standalone) Azure Resource Manager Service Project** | Similar to the above but designed for Azure Resource Manager services, configured for local use or in a personal repo. | ### Target Users - **Rest-API-Spec Repo Projects**: Ideal for those contributing directly to the Azure REST API specifications, ensuring production-quality SDK generation. - **Standalone Projects**: Suited for API-first development, allowing users to generate OpenAPI specs, service code, and clients without conforming to the specs repo's structure. ### Install the dependencies Now that the new project has been created, you can install the dependencies by running the following command: - `npm ci` - If in the `azure-rest-api-specs` repo. - `tsp install` - If a standalone project After setting up your project, run `tsp install` to install dependencies. You can then open the file `main.tsp` to continue with the tutorial. Reach out to the relevant parties. [This PR](https://github.com/Azure/avocado/pull/157) gives more context on why this was upgraded to an error. If relevant parties agree, the PR can be unblocked by adding the `Approved-Avocado` label to the PR. | | I merged a PR, when does the REST API documentation update on the Learn site? | Docs are published every week on Tuesdays | | If the specs in the standard branches of `RPSaaSMaster` and `RPSaaSDev` are out of sync, who is responsible for syncing them with main? | The spec owner is responsible for syncing their service’s spec files from `main` to `RPSaaSMaster/RPSaaSDev` to ensure consistency across branches. |"},{"document_source":"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki","document_filename":"Azure-REST-API,-SDK-development-process-with-TypeSpec.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Azure-REST-API,-SDK-development-process-with-TypeSpec","content":"# Azure REST API, SDK development process with TypeSpec ## Table Of Content ### 4. Prepare and submit a Pull Request for reviewing 5. Generate OpenAPI files: - sync with the target branch in the azure-rest-api-specs repo ```git git pull upstream ``` - in the root directory, run `npm install` - in the project directory, `npx tsp compile`. This will generate OpenAPI files under `{service}` folders. 6. Ensure all generated files under `{service}` have been added to PR. 7. Send a pull request . - commit all your changes. - push your branch to your fork of the repo. - send a pull request to the original repo from your forked repo. See the ARM Wiki for information on the [supported repos and branches for management-plane services](https://armwiki.azurewebsites.net/rpaas/swaggeronboarding.html#supported-github-reposbranches). #### 4.1 Fix the errors of PR reviewing CI checks The CI checks result will be commented on the PR. you can refer to the [CI fix Guide](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/documentation/ci-fix.md). Note: Since the OpenAPI is generated from TypeSpec, to change the OpenAPI, you must update the TypeSpec file and regenerate the OpenAPI and avoid updating OpenAPI directly to keep the consistency between OpenAPI and TypeSpec. For support & help, you can post a message to [TypeSpec Discussion - teams channel](https://teams.microsoft.com/l/channel/19%3A906c1efbbec54dc8949ac736633e6bdf%40thread.skype/TypeSpec%20Discussion?groupId=3e17dcb0-4257-4a30-b843-77f47f1d4121&tenantId=72f988bf-86f1-41af-91ab-2d7cd011db47)."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"design#api-specs-pr#pr-move-private-to-public.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-specs-pr/pr-move-private-to-public","content":"# Move private specs to public > [!CAUTION] > Copying over specs from private specs repo to public specs repo is effectively converting a `private preview` > API version to `public preview`. The copying of specs is only one element of a larger process. > Consult with the service & spec owner to ensure you complete all the required steps, like disabling [AFEC] flags, > publishing relevant docs to external customers, etc. > ([example requirements doc for ARM][ARM lifecycle stages requirements]) > Do this consultation **before you open the PR** to the public specs repo. > [!NOTE] > These instructions replace the former OpenAPI Hub feature **Publish a pull request**"},{"document_source":"typespec_azure_docs","document_filename":"getstarted#azure-resource-manager#step05.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/getstarted/azure-resource-manager/step05","content":"# 6. Complete Example and Generate OpenApi 2.0 spec To generate an OpenAPI v2 (Swagger) specification from the service definition, run the following command inside of the project folder: ``` tsp compile . --emit @azure-tools/typespec-autorest ``` This will create a file in the `tsp-output` subfolder called `openapi.json`. You can learn more about the `typespec-autorest` emitter and its options by reading its [README.md](https://github.com/Azure/typespec-azure/blob/main/packages/typespec-autorest/README.md)."},{"document_source":"typespec_azure_docs","document_filename":"howtos#generate-client-libraries#00howtogen.mdx","document_title":"","document_link":"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/howtos/generate-client-libraries/00howtogen","content":"# How to generate client libraries import { ClientTabs, ClientTabItem } from "@components/client-tabs"; This page outlines the steps to build a client library based on your TypeSpec specification. It provides a guide for the whole process from initial API design to the release of SDKs. please visit https://aka.ms/azsdk/dpcodegen. The best documentation on how to generate can be found using those links: - https://aka.ms/azsdk/dpcodegen/net - https://aka.ms/azsdk/dpcodegen/python - https://aka.ms/azsdk/dpcodegen/java - https://aka.ms/azsdk/rlc/js - https://aka.ms/azsdk/dpcodegen/js (do not use unless told to do so by the archboard) - https://aka.ms/azsdk/dpcodegen/go At a glance, add your emitter name to your `package.json`, along with the right options in the `tspconfig.yaml`. > **NOTE:** Generating all languages from the same folder may be complicated due to the preview status of the emitters and TypeSpec libraries, such as `typespec-azure-core` and `typespec-azure-resource-manager`. > It is recommended to have a unique language emitter in each `package.json` to avoid conflicts until all emitters and the TypeSpec libraries reach their first stable release. Modify your `package.json` to include the necessary dependencies for the language emitter(s). Remember to run `npm install` after making changes to the file: ```json { "name": "clients", "dependencies": { "@typespec/compiler": "latest", "@typespec/rest": "latest", "@typespec/http": "latest", "@azure-tools/typespec-azure-core": "latest", "@azure-tools/typespec-autorest": "latest", "@azure-tools/typespec-python": "latest", "@azure-tools/typespec-java": "latest", "@azure-tools/typespec-csharp": "latest", "@azure-tools/typespec-ts": "latest", "@azure-tools/typespec-go": "latest" }, "private": true } ``` Always update your `tspconfig.yaml` file rather than passing options through the command line. ```yaml emit:"},{"document_source":"typespec_azure_docs","document_filename":"howtos#rest-api-publish#checking-in-api-specs-guide.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/howtos/rest-api-publish/checking-in-api-specs-guide","content":"# Checking in typespec and generated OpenAPI to azure-rest-api-specs repo See documentation on the azure-rest-api-specs repo https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/documentation/Getting-started-with-TypeSpec-specifications.md"},{"document_source":"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki","document_filename":"API-Doc-Preview.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/API-Doc-Preview","content":"## How does it work? When a user opens a PR to a specs repo, the [`spec - api-doc-preview`](https://dev.azure.com/azure-sdk/internal/_build?definitionId=7767&_a=summary) pipeline launches, selects and onboards swaggers into the [preview repo](https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/AzureRestPreview), then launches a pipeline in the Learn org to generate an API preview. The `spec - api-doc-preview` pipeline waits for the Learn org's pipeline to complete, then reports the status back to the PR in the form of a commit status. ```mermaid sequenceDiagram participant User participant spec_api_doc_preview as spec - api-doc-preview (Azure SDK Org) participant REST_Preview as REST-Preview-AzureRestPreview (Learn's DevOps Org) User->>spec_api_doc_preview: Opens a Pull Request spec_api_doc_preview->>spec_api_doc_preview: Generates onboarding info for changed files spec_api_doc_preview->>REST_Preview: Launches REST-Preview-AzureRestPreview pipeline spec_api_doc_preview->>REST_Preview: Waits for completion REST_Preview-->>spec_api_doc_preview: Pipeline completes spec_api_doc_preview->>User: Interprets results and sets PR status ```"},{"document_source":"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki","document_filename":"API-Doc-Preview.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/API-Doc-Preview","content":"## How do I onboard my API to publish docs? Follow instructions at [Publish REST API reference docs ](https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-docs)"},{"document_source":"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki","document_filename":"Azure-REST-API,-SDK-development-process-with-TypeSpec.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Azure-REST-API,-SDK-development-process-with-TypeSpec","content":"# Azure REST API, SDK development process with TypeSpec ## Table Of Content ### 1. Introduction This document describes the processes of developing Azure REST APIs and SDKs with TypeSpec language. The steps below assumes that you are developing TypeSpec API specifications in the `azure-rest-api-specs` and `azure-rest-api-specs-pr`repos. If you are developing within your own ADO repo first and then submitting into `azure-rest-api-specs` repos for review and release, you will need to copy the TypeSpec files over."},{"document_source":"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki","document_filename":"Specification-Folder-Structure-Guide.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Specification-Folder-Structure-Guide","content":"# Azure REST API Specification Directory Structure ## Contact Us If you have any questions regarding folder structure and Azure Service Versioning Guideline, you can reach out by: - [TypeSpec Discussion] Channel. - Email to azversioning@service.microsoft.com > [!WARNING] > **All violations described above are considered legacy and deprecated.** They are strongly discouraged for any new development and will be addressed through the ongoing migration efforts. [`specification/common-types`]: https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/tree/main/specification/common-types [`specification/containerservice/resource-manager/Microsoft.ContainerService/aks`]: https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/tree/main/specification/containerservice/resource-manager/Microsoft.ContainerService/aks [`x-ms-examples`]: https://azure.github.io/autorest/extensions/#x-ms-examples [aka.ms/azsdk/api-versions]: https://aka.ms/azsdk/api-versions [aka.ms/azsdk/typespec]: https://aka.ms/azsdk/typespec [aka.ms/typespec]: https://aka.ms/typespec [API versioning guidelines]: https://github.com/microsoft/api-guidelines/blob/vNext/azure/Guidelines.md#api-versioning [AutoRest config `README.md` file]: https://aka.ms/azsdk/autorest [glossary]: https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Specification-Glossary [Resource Provider list]: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-resource-manager/management/azure-services-resource-providers#match-resource-provider-to-service [Specification index]: https://azure.github.io/azure-sdk/releases/latest/all/specs.html [uniform versioning guideline]: https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Azure-Service-Versioning-Guideline [Conflict Resolve Guide]: https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Resolving-Folder-Migration-Conflicts:-A-Guide-for-PR-Authors [Widget]: https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/specification/widget"},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"design#api-specs-pr#api-repos.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-specs-pr/api-repos","content":"# Azure REST API specs repositories on GitHub The REST API descriptions for all Azure services should be published in the Azure REST API specs GitHub repositories. The [Azure/azure-rest-api-specs] is the public repository. All work done in this repository is public, i.e. visible to everyone, including people outside of Microsoft. Any Azure REST API specification updates must be merged to the `main` branch as part of the process of releasing those updates to Microsoft customers. The [Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr] is the private repository (the "pr" stands for "private"). It is for work that must remain private until it is ready to be published. For example, if your team is working on a new product with a new Azure Resource Manager (ARM) or Resource Provider (RP) namespace, you want to keep developing it in the private repository until you have drafted, tested and went through the API review process. Only after this is done, you must merge your changes to the `main` branch in the public repository. The `main` branch in the private repository is read-only, as it is mirrored from the public repository `main` branch."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"design#api-specs#api-openapi.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-specs/api-openapi","content":"# What is OpenAPI? of JSON Schema. In addition: - Azure management plane services must conform to the ARM [Resource Provider Guidelines] - Azure data plane services must conform to the [Azure REST API Guidelines] and the Azure OpenAPI Style Guide. OpenAPI allows [specification extensions], properties with an `x-` prefix, to provide additional information for particular use cases. Azure uses the [specification extensions for the AutoRest client library generator][autorest specification extensions] to guide the generation of client libraries, command line utilities, and documentation. Finally, Azure has established the [Azure OpenAPI Style Guidelines] to ensure that the descriptions of Azure REST APIs are consistent and easy to use."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"design#specs-pr-guides#specs-pr-guides.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/specs-pr-guides/specs-pr-guides","content":"# Azure REST API specs PRs Guides This section contains articles with detailed guidance for various aspects of getting your [Azure REST API specs PR](xref:api-specs-pr) merged. By design, you are expected to be linked to these articles from your specs PR. As such, these articles assume very specific context which may not be evident if you read them without having a corresponding PR."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"design#api-specs-pr#api-repos.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-specs-pr/api-repos","content":"# Azure REST API specs repositories on GitHub ## Publishing your spec to the spec repos To publish your spec to the API specs repositories, you must first understand what kind of API version you are trying to publish and make a PR to appropriate branch based on that. Read about this in [this article](xref:pr-move-private-to-public). [Azure/azure-rest-api-specs]: https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs [Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr]: https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr"}]
rows.inputs.testcase: Official API documentation publishing
rows.outputs.similarity.similarity_sample_inp: [{"role": "user", "content": "{\"query\": \"title: Official API documentation publishing\\n\\nquestion: General,\\nHow do we generate official API documentation like below?\\nAzure REST API reference documentation | Microsoft Learn\\nFor a new RP like below. Is this done by the SDK team?\\n[azure-rest-api-specs/specification/cdn/resource-manager/Microsoft.Cdn/Cdn/preview/2024-07-22-previe\\u2026](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/specification/cdn/resource-manager/Microsoft.Cdn/Cdn/preview/2024-07-22-preview/edgeaction.json)\", \"response\": \"The official Azure REST API reference documentation on Microsoft Learn (https://learn.microsoft.com/rest/api/) is published automatically for new resource providers (RPs) once their OpenAPI specs are merged into the `main` branch of the public Azure REST API specs repository (`azure-rest-api-specs`).\\n\\nThe process is not handled by the SDK team directly, but rather by the Azure Content Publishing Services team and automated pipelines:\\n\\n1. **Merge Your Spec**: You must ensure your OpenAPI (or TypeSpec-generated OpenAPI) files and the necessary README configuration are merged into `main` in the `azure-rest-api-specs` repo.\\n\\n2. **Onboarding**: For first-time onboarding of a new RP, you need to submit an onboarding request to the Content Publishing Services team. This enables your RP's specs to be picked up for documentation generation. See [Onboard reference content on Microsoft Learn](https://learn.microsoft.com/help/onboard/reference?branch=main).\\n\\n3. **Automatic Refresh**: After initial onboarding, API references are automatically refreshed weekly (typically on Tuesdays) if the README is correctly configured and merged. Any changes merged to the repo will be picked up and published without manual intervention.\\n\\n4. **Publishing Pipeline**: When a PR is opened, the `spec - api-doc-preview` pipeline runs, onboarding the updated specs into a preview repo, and triggers a pipeline in the Learn organization to generate preview documentation. The results are reported back to your PR.\\n\\n**Summary**: Publishing the official documentation is managed by the Content Publishing Services team and automated Azure pipelines, not by the SDK team. Your responsibility is to ensure the spec and configuration files are correctly merged and to onboard with the publishing team for first-time RP documentation.\\n\\nFor more details and support, you can:\\n- Review the [official publishing guide](https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-docs)\\n- Ask questions in the [API Reference and Samples Teams Channel](https://teams.microsoft.com/dl/launcher/launcher.html?url=%2F_%23%2Fl%2Fchannel%2F19%3A7506cc3e220f430ab89d992c7db5284f%40thread.skype%2FAPI%2520Reference%2520and%2520Samples%3FgroupId%3Dde9ddba4-2574-4830-87ed-41668c07a1ca%26tenantId%3D72f988bf-86f1-41af-91ab-2d7cd011db47).\\n\\n**Note:** If your RP is already onboarded and uses the automatic refresh, no further action is needed for subsequent updates\\u2014just merge your changes to `main` and they will be picked up.\", \"ground_truth\": \"You can find information about this here: https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-docs\"}"}]

rows.inputs.query:
title: Problem with merging PR into target branch

question: Hello team,
I am having trouble merging my PR. It seems I am being blocked by breaking changes errors. After consulting with the breaking changes team, they say the pr pipeline must be bust. Can you please help on this.
PR: Enabling free services acquisition via APIs by adrianta · Pull Request #25230 · Azure/azure-rest-ap…
rows.inputs.ground_truth:
You are confusing two checks:
Breaking Changes(Cross-Version) - Analyze Code
implementation detail
not required
Breaking Changes(Cross-Version)
required
passing due to label
I suspect your PR cannot be merged, because your github account is missing one or more required permissions. https://aka.ms/azsdk/access
This must be public, not private: https://github.com/orgs/Azure/people?query=adrianta
Once your permissions are fixed, push a change to your PR (empty commit is fine) to rerun checks.
rows.inputs.response:
Based on the Azure API versioning and breaking change policies, if your PR is blocked due to breaking changes errors, there are specific steps you must follow to resolve this.

1. **Diagnose the Cause**: Breaking changes errors in PR pipelines usually mean your changes either introduce a breaking change to a published API version or violate versioning rules (e.g., modifying a published version, even for non-breaking changes).
   - Use the guidance at [aka.ms/brch](https://aka.ms/brch) for a step-by-step process.
   - If your PR is labeled with `BreakingChangeReviewRequired` or `VersioningReviewRequired`, you must resolve these before further review or merging can proceed.

2. **Pipeline Bust Diagnosis**: If the breaking changes team says the pipeline is "bust," it's important to verify if this is due to a tooling failure or a genuine spec issue:
   - Run the validation locally using the documented process (see references below). This will help determine if the error is reproducible outside the CI system:
     ```
     git clean -xdf
     git pull
     npm ci
     npx tsv specification/your-service-folder
     ```
   - If the problem persists locally, it's a real spec issue. If not, there may be a CI configuration or sync problem.

3. **Resolving Breaking Changes**:
   - If your change is a real breaking change and you believe it is benign, a bugfix, or already approved, you (or the review board) can apply the appropriate approval label as documented (see references).
   - If your change is not intended to be breaking, review your TypeSpec changes and ensure you are not modifying any published API contracts. For any required changes, always introduce a new API version instead of modifying an existing one.

4. **Branch Sync Issues**: If the error is due to branch sync (e.g., target branch out of sync with `main`), follow the documented process to update your branch with changes from main:
     - [Update your branch with changes from main](https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-specs-pr/api-tutorial/api-tutorial-3-publish#update-your-branch-with-changes-from-main)

5. **Further Help**:
   - If local validation matches the pipeline error, and you believe it is a false positive or a tooling bug, document the steps and reach out on the [TypeSpec Discussion teams channel](https://teams.microsoft.com/l/channel/19%3A906c1efbbec54dc8949ac736633e6bdf%40thread.skype/TypeSpec%20Discussion?groupId=3e17dcb0-4257-4a30-b843-77f47f1d4121&tenantId=72f988bf-86f1-41af-91ab-2d7cd011db47).
   - If you are blocked by a spec repo sync issue, the spec owner is responsible for keeping branches synchronized (main <-> RPSaaSMaster, etc.).

**Summary:**
- Run validation locally to confirm whether the error is real or a CI pipeline issue.
- Do not modify published API versions directly; create new versions for changes.
- Apply the appropriate approval label if your breaking change is a bugfix or previously approved.
- If the issue is a pipeline tooling failure, contact the spec repo owner or TypeSpec Discussion teams channel.

Let me know if you need help with specific error logs or validation output!

[{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"design#api-specs-pr#api-versions-and-branches.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-specs-pr/api-versions-and-branches","content":"# design#api-specs-pr#api-versions-and-branches.md

| Short Link: | [aka.ms/azsdk/api-versions](https://aka.ms/azsdk/api-versions) |
|--|--|

# API versions and branches

This article explains the various lifecycle stages of spec API versions and how do they relate to git branches of the  
[specs repositories](xref:api-repos).

## Spec repos branches table

This table serves as a quick summary. Read the rest of the article for details.

| Branch                 | [Public repository][public specs repo]        | [Private repository][private specs repo]              |
|------------------------|-----------------------------------------------|-------------------------------------------------------|
| `main`                 | All API versions in `GA` and `public preview` | Mirrored from public `main`                           |
| `RPSaaSMaster`         | N/A                                           | For RPaaS-based specs in `private preview`   |
| `RPSaaSDev`            | N/A                                           | For dogfooding RPaaS-based specs.                     |
| `release-*`            | Feature branches.                             | Feature branches.                                     |
| `dev-*`                | Obsolete. Use `release-*` instead.            | Obsolete. Use `release-*` instead.                    |
| `ARMCoreRPDev`         | N/A                                           | [Obsolete ShiftLeft branch]. Use `release-*` instead. |
| `InternalARMContracts` | N/A                                           | For ARM-internal APIs, never published to customers.  |

If a given branch in the public or private spec repos is not listed in the table above, then most likely
it is obsolete, deprecated, or otherwise not recommended for use.

## Branch protection rules table

This table serves as a quick summary. Read the rest of the article for details.

This table shows which GitHub checks are marked as `required` on respective branches. Even when a check is marked as ❌
it **may** still be running on given branch; just that if it fails, the PR won't be blocked from merging.

| Branch | Merge | SDK | TSVal | BrCh | BrChC | LintRPaaS | LintDiff | Model | Semantic | Spell | Prettier | license | approver |
|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|
| public `main`                  | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ |
| private `RPSaaSMaster`         | ✅ | ❌ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ |
| public/private `release-*`     | ✅ | ❌ | ✅ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ |
| private `RPSaaSDev`            | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ✅ |
| private `InternalARMContracts` | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ✅ |
| private `ARMCoreRPDev`         | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ✅ |

Legend:

| Column name | Full GitHub check name               |

| `BrChC`     | `Breaking Change(Cross-Version)`     |
| `license`   | `license/cla`                        |

| `LintRPaaS` | `Swagger Lint(RPaaS)`                |
| `Merge`     | `Automated merging requirements met` |
| `Model`     | `Swagger ModelValidation`            |
| `Prettier`  | `PrettierCheck`                      |
| `SDK`       | `SDK azure-sdk-for-go`               |
| `Semantic`  | `Swagger SemanticValidation`         |
| `Spell`     | `SpellCheck`                         |
| `TSVal`     | `TypeScript Validation`              |
| `approver`  | Requires team member approval        |

For more information on these checks, see:

- https://aka.ms/azsdk/pr-getting-help
- https://aka.ms/ci-fix

## API version lifecycle stages

An API version is a TypeSpec/OpenAPI specification contract identified by its `api-version` value.

Given API version is located in its own directory in the specs repositories. It can be in following lifecycle stages:

- `generally available` (aka `GA`, `stable`)
- `public preview`
- `private preview`
- `in development`
- `closing down`

> [!NOTE]
> A `closing down` API spec version need to be kept in the spec repository until it is fully `deprecated`. A `deprecated` API spec version need to be removed from the spec repository, with removal initiated by the service to begin deprecating related APIs, SDKs, and CLIs.

These stages corresponds to [service tree lifecycle stages] as elaborated on in [ARM lifecycle stages requirements].

### Generally available

**GA** API versions have been released to all Azure customers.

For an API version to be in GA it must:

- Be present in the `main` branch of the [public specs repo].
- Be in a parent `stable` folder and without a `-preview` suffix. See [spec directory structure] for full details.
- Not be gated by any feature flags, including Azure Feature Exposure Control ([AFEC]) flags.

### Public preview

**Public preview** API versions have been released to all Azure customers, but are not yet GA.
For an API version to be in `public preview`, it must:

- Not yet be GA.
- Be present in the `main` branch of the [public specs repo].
- Be in a parent `preview` folder and have `-preview` suffix in its folder name.
  See [spec directory structure] and [ARM preview guidelines] for full details.
- Not be gated by any feature flags, including [AFEC] flags.

### Private preview

**Private preview** API versions have been released to a limited set of Azure customers.

Usually API versions are in `private preview` for following reasons:

- The spec API version preview cannot yet be made public due to business or marketing reasons.
- Early customer feedback is being gathered for given API version preview.

For an API version to be in `private preview`, it must:

- Not yet be `GA` or in `public preview`.
- Not be present in the [public specs repo] `main` branch or any other branch in that repo.
- Be in a parent `preview` folder and have `-prefix` in its folder name.
  See [spec directory structure] and [ARM preview guidelines] for full details.
- Have at least one customer. If an API version has no customers, it is `in development`, not in `private preview`.
- In case of ARM specs:
  - Be present in the `RPSaaSMaster` branch of the [private specs repo].
    See [ARM branches] and [ARM lifecycle stages requirements] for details.
  - Be under access control done with [AFEC] flags.
- In case of data-plane specs:
  - Can be in any branch in the [private specs repo], except `main` or `RPaaS*` branches,
    as there is no designated branch like `RPSaaSMaster` for ARM specs.
  - There is no need for access control done with [AFEC] flags, as data plane services should have some mechanism
    for allowing `private preview` customers to onboard the preview.

> [!NOTE]
> A `private preview` API spec version can be published as `public preview` by following  
> [this how-to](xref:pr-move-private-to-public).

### In development

**In development** API versions are all API versions that are not `GA`, in `public preview` or in `private preview`.
Notably, such API versions are not present in the [public specs repo] `main` branch and do not have any customers.
However, they may be present in the public repo feature branches.

> [!IMPORTANT]
> REST API definitions for a service or API version that is `in development` MUST NOT be present in the  
> [public specs repo] `main` at all.

> [!NOTE]
> ARM spec API version, while `in development`, should not be trying to merge into `RPSaaSMaster`.
> The ARM guidance for this is in [ARM spec onboarding] article.

**Special cases** There are few special situations that do not fit in the API versioning model described above.
In such situations, attend appropriate office hours:

- In case of ARM specs, **ARM API Review Office Hours** in [aka.ms/armofficehoursinfo].
- In case of data-plane specs, [aka.ms/azapi/officehours].

## Spec repos branches

### Public specs repo `main` branch

All API versions in the [public specs repo] `main` branch are published to all Azure customers.
This branch includes `GA` and `public preview` API versions.

> [!CAUTION]
> This is not a dev branch. It should contain **only** finished specs that represent services deployed to customers.

### Private specs repo `main` branch

[Private specs repo] `main` branch is mirrored from [public specs repo] `main` branch by a CI job on a regular basis.
As such, it is **read only**.

### Private specs repo `RPSaaSMaster` branch

[Private specs repo] `RPSaaSMaster` contains RPaaS-based ARM specifications.

When an RPaaS-based ARM API goes into `public preview` or `GA` lifecycle stage it must be merged to [public specs repo]
`main` as well.

Some parts of this branch are being mirrored from public `main` branch
by the [mirror-repos] pipeline, triggered manually on at least daily basis.

Service teams are responsible for keeping their API specifications in this branch synchronized with
the public specs repo `main` branch.

See also [ARM lifecycle stages requirements] and [ARM branches].

### `RPSaaSDev` branch

Used for internal ARM dogfooding. See `RPSaaSDev` in [ARM branches].

Some parts of this branch are being mirrored from public `main` branch
by the [mirror-repos] pipeline, triggered manually on at least daily basis.

Service teams are responsible for keeping their API specifications in this branch synchronized with
the public specs repo `main` branch.

See also [ARM lifecycle stages requirements] and [ARM branches].

### `release-*` branches

All branches with prefix `release-`, both in public and private specs repos. Also known as "feature" branches.

# Resolving Pipeline Failures

This document explains how to resolve pipeline failures in TypeSpec migration PRs.

## Swagger BreakingChange

### Multiple OpenAPI Files Before Migration

This pipeline will fail if there is more than one OpenAPI file in the latest version. See the detailed explanation in this [issue](https://github.com/Azure/typespec-azure/issues/2194#issue-2844564216).

To properly identify real breaking changes, use the "TypeSpec Migration Validation" pipeline instead:

1. Navigate to the TypeSpec Migration Validation pipeline
2. Check the report on the "Summary" page
3. The output should match exactly what you see in [this step](../01-get-started.md#review-and-adjust-the-typespec) on the local machine
4. Review the changes to verify they are expected

### Single OpenAPI File Before Migration

If you have only one OpenAPI file in the latest version, use this pipeline to detect breaking changes. If it fails, refer to [Resolving OpenAPI Breaking Change Violations](./faq/breakingchange.md).

**Known Issues**: The following pipeline failures are false alerts and can be safely ignored:

#### 1017 - ReferenceRedirection

This typically occurs when an inlined anonymous enum becomes a named enum.

**Before:**

```json
"SomeModel": {
  "enumProperty": {
    "type": "string",
    "enum": [
      "If",
      "Else",
      "None"
    ],
    "x-ms-enum": {
      "name": "EnumType",
      "modelAsString": true
    }
  }
}
```

**After:**

```json
"SomeModel": {
  "enumProperty": {
    "$ref": "#/definitions/EnumType"
  }
},
"EnumType": {
  "type": "string",
  "enum": [
    "If",
    "Else",
    "None"
  ],
  "x-ms-enum": {
    "name": "EnumType",
    "modelAsString": true
  }
}
```

#### 1023 - TypeFormatChanged

The error message `The new version has a different format 'uri' than the previous one ''.` on the `nextLink` property is expected because the [page template defines the `nextLink` as `uri`](./mustread.md#using-page-model-from-azurecore-library).

#### 1047 - XmsEnumChanged

After migration, all models (including enums) will have capitalized names.

**Before:**

```json
"SomeModel": {
  "someProperty": {
    "type": "string",
    "enum": [
      "If"
    ],
    "x-ms-enum": {
      "name": "someName",
      "modelAsString": true
    }
  }
}
```

**After:**

```json
"SomeModel": {
  "someProperty": {
    "$ref": "#/definitions/SomeName"
  }
},
"SomeName": {
  "type": "string",
  "enum": [
    "If"
  ],
  "x-ms-enum": {
    "name": "SomeName",
    "modelAsString": true
  }
}
```

## Swagger ModelValidation

Some validation rules may fail because TypeSpec fixes certain legacy patterns. Review the known issues below and take appropriate action.

### INVALID_FORMAT: Object didn't pass validation for format uri: {nextlink}

#### Root Cause

The response model of a pageable operation uses the Azure.Core.Page template:

```typespec
model ResponseModel is Azure.Core.Page<ItemType>;
```

This standardized approach changes the `nextLink` type from plain `string` to `uri`. If previous example's `nextLink` value isn't a valid URI, it will cause a validation error.

#### Resolution

Choose one of the following options:

1. **Update your example** to include a valid URI value, or
2. **Modify your TypeSpec response model** to use a custom definition if the nextLink returned by the service is not a URI:

```typespec
model ResponseModel {
  @pageItems
  value: ItemType[];

  @nextLink
  nextLink?: string;
}
```

### INVALID_FORMAT: Object didn't pass validation for format arm-id

#### Root Cause

This error typically occurs when a custom resource definition is mapped to a resource defined in common-types. See [this section](./breakingchange.md#using-resources-from-common-types) for details. The `id` property for `Resource` in common-types may use the `arm-id` format, depending on the version of common-types used.

#### Resolution

Update the value in the example file to meet the `arm-id` format requirements."},{"document_source":"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki","document_filename":"Azure-REST-API,-SDK-development-process-with-TypeSpec.md","document_title":"Azure REST API, SDK development process with TypeSpec","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Azure-REST-API,-SDK-development-process-with-TypeSpec","content":"# Azure-REST-API,-SDK-development-process-with-TypeSpec.md

# Azure REST API, SDK development process with TypeSpec

## Table Of Content

1. Introduction
2. Repo setup & prerequisites
3. Creating a new TypeSpec project
4. Prepare and submit a Pull Request for reviewing
5. Generate SDK code from a TypeSpec project

### 1. Introduction

This document describes the processes of developing Azure REST APIs and SDKs with TypeSpec language. The steps below
 assumes that you are developing TypeSpec API specifications in the `azure-rest-api-specs` and `azure-rest-api-specs-pr`repos.
If you are developing within your own ADO repo first and then submitting into `azure-rest-api-specs` repos for review and
 release, you will need to copy the TypeSpec files over.

### 2. Repo setup & prerequisites

- The main repos for Azure REST APIs are [azure-rest-api-specs](https://github.com/azure/azure-rest-api-specs) and [azure-rest-api-specs-pr](https://github.com/azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr)
 repos. The `-pr` repo contains `RPSaaSMaster` and `RPSaaSDev` branches for ProviderHub based ARM service specs.
#### 2.1 With local machine development
- [Node.js LTS](https://nodejs.org/en) version 18 or above (LTS Recommended).
 Ensure you can run the npm command in a command prompt:
  ```npm
    npm --version
  ```
- Run following command in the **repository root folder**. This will install required packages such as TypeSpec
 compilers and Azure Library packages.
  ```npm
     npm ci
  ```
- Ensure you can run TypeSpec command within the repo folders.
  ```npm
     npx tsp --version
  ```
- One-time set up: Install TypeSpec VisualStudio or VS Code extensions to get syntex highlighting, tool tips in IDE:  
  ```npm
    npx tsp code install
  ```
  OR
    ```npm
      npx tsp vs install
    ```
#### 2.2  VS Code with local docker .devcontainer
All prerequisites have been installed in the dev container. You should to have `Docker Desktop` and `WSL2` running if
 you are on Windows machine.
To start, you just need to install `Dev Containers` VS code extension, then open the repo path.
- VS Code will detect the .devcontainer and prompt you to reopen the workspace.
- Alternatively, you can use Command Palette -> Dev Containers: Reopen in Container.  
Once VS Code reopened in Container, you can run any of the program below in the VS Code integrated terminal.
#### 2.2 VS Code in browser via GitHub codespaces
GitHub codespaces leverage the same dev container in the repo. The difference is it is hosted in cloud with VS Code in
 browser.
To start, you just need to browse to the `azure-rest-api-specs` repo, select `<> Code` drop down and follow `Codespaces`
 instructions.

### 3. Creating a new TypeSpec project

Please first review recommended folder structure detailed in [this document](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/documentation/directory-structure.md).
1. Under `[reporoot]\specification`, create service folder directly.
   - Select `(rest-api-spec repo) ARM` or `(rest-api-spec repo) Data-plane` and answer appropriate naming questions.
   - If it's ARM service, the service folder would be `specification/{organization}/resource-manager/<RPNS>/{service}`.
   - If it's Data Plane service, the service folder would be `specification/{organization}/data-plane/{service}`
2. Create a new TypeSpec project based on Azure template with command:
    ```cli
       npx tsp init https://aka.ms/typespec/azure-init
    ```
3. Compile the generated TypeSpec project with command:
    ```cli
      npx tsp compile .
    ```
    The generated OpenAPI files should be correctly placed in the `{service}`folders following the naming conventions.
4. Now the project has been set up. You can modify the sample and develop your own APIs with TypeSpec.

### 4. Prepare and submit a Pull Request for reviewing

1. Create a branch in your local repository for your changes.
2. Create or update the TypeSpec files for your service.
3. Add or update 'examples' files for each operation of your OpenAPI file.
   The [oav](https://github.com/Azure/oav) provides two ways to generate OpenAPI examples:
   1. Generating basic examples and then manually modify the values. It will generate two examples for each operation:
    one contains minimal properties set, the other contains the maximal properties set. Since the auto-generated
     examples consist of random values for most types, you need replace them with meaningful values.
       ```bash
       oav generate-examples openapi.json
       ```
    Note, latest OAV tool should automatically generate the following. However, if you are generating the examples manually,
     please ensure you have:
    - include `title` field and make sure it is descriptive and unique for each operation.
    - include `operationId`. This is used to match with declared operations in TypeSpec and correctly output in OpenAPI.
4. Add/update the `readme.md` file in the `{service}` folder to specify the version and location of the OpenAPI files. The `readme.md` is needed for both management-plane and data-plane services for REST API Docs generation.
   Example:[sample-readme](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/specification/widget/resource-manager/Microsoft.Widget/Widget/readme.md)
5. Generate OpenAPI files:
   - sync with the target branch in the azure-rest-api-specs repo
      ```git
       git pull upstream <target-branch>
      ```
   - in the root directory, run `npm install`
   - in the project directory, `npx tsp compile`. This will generate OpenAPI files under `{service}` folders.
6. Ensure all generated files under `{service}` have been added to PR.
7. Send a pull request .
   - commit all your changes.
   - push your branch to your fork of the repo.

5. Generate OpenAPI files:
   - sync with the target branch in the azure-rest-api-specs repo
      ```git
       git pull upstream <target-branch>
      ```
   - in the root directory, run `npm install`
   - in the project directory, `npx tsp compile`. This will generate OpenAPI files under `{service}` folders.
6. Ensure all generated files under `{service}` have been added to PR.
7. Send a pull request .
   - commit all your changes.
   - push your branch to your fork of the repo.
   - send a pull request to the original repo from your forked repo.
   See the ARM Wiki for information on the [supported repos and branches for management-plane services](https://armwiki.azurewebsites.net/rpaas/swaggeronboarding.html#supported-github-reposbranches).
#### 4.1 Fix the errors of PR reviewing CI checks
The CI checks result will be commented on the PR. you can refer to the [CI fix Guide](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/documentation/ci-fix.md).
Note:
Since the OpenAPI is generated from TypeSpec, to change the OpenAPI, you must update the TypeSpec file and regenerate the
 OpenAPI and avoid updating OpenAPI directly to keep the consistency between OpenAPI and TypeSpec.
For support & help, you can post a message to [TypeSpec Discussion - teams channel](https://teams.microsoft.com/l/channel/19%3A906c1efbbec54dc8949ac736633e6bdf%40thread.skype/TypeSpec%20Discussion?groupId=3e17dcb0-4257-4a30-b843-77f47f1d4121&tenantId=72f988bf-86f1-41af-91ab-2d7cd011db47).

### 5. Generate SDK code from a TypeSpec project
