# Deep-dive into breaking changes on spec PRs

## Important information about this article

This article provides a deep-dive into breaking changes on spec PRs. It applies if your spec PR has
`BreakingChangeReviewRequired` or `VersioningReviewRequired` label.

> [!IMPORTANT]
> This is an advanced deep-dive. If your PR is blocked on breaking changes or versioning issues, you should always
> start by following the guidance at [aka.ms/brch].

### Prerequisites

This article assumes you are familiar with [API versions and branches](xref:api-versions-and-branches).

### Video overview and slides

For video overview of the breaking changes process, see this [Azure Core Day of Learning talk from March 6, 2024].
Slides for the talk are available [here][talk slides].

### Summary

Per the [PR diagram], the first step of getting your specs PR approved is ensuring your PR obeys the  
[Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy]. Relevant details of this policy follow.

- Once published, no changes to given API version are allowed, except when fixing the spec to match
actual implementation (see the `-Approved-BugFix` labels in this doc).
This applies regardless of whether the API version is for `private preview`, `public preview`, or `GA`.
- When introducing a new API version (any `preview` or `GA`), the new API version must be backwards compatible with
the previous, latest `GA` API version.
- During a (`private` or `public`) `preview` cycle, a new `preview` API version does not have to be backwards
compatible with the previous `preview` API version.
- The rules listed above are checked by automated GitHub checks. The exact ruleset is given in [`oadMessagesRuleMap.ts`].
Details follow.

## Breaking changes and versioning issues

There are two automatic checks running on your PR checking for conformance
to the [Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy]:

- `Breaking Change(Cross-Version)` that ensures you don't introduce breaking changes or violate versioning policy
*across* two API versions.
- `Swagger BreakingChange` that ensures you didn't introduce breaking changes or violated versioning policy
*within* any single API version.

The result of running these checks may result in one of these labels being applied: `BreakingChangeReviewRequired`
or `VersioningReviewRequired`. If this happens, your PR is **blocked** from any further review, including ARM review,
if applicable.

The breaking change/versioning checks are performed only on PRs targeting the `main` branch in the [public specs repo]
or `RPSaaSMaster` branch of the [private specs repo].

These two branches are `production branches`. Merging an API specification to either of them publishes it
for all customers to use & consume.

### `BreakingChangeReviewRequired` label

The label `BreakingChangeReviewRequired` is added to your PR if the tooling detects a change that could
be breaking for customers. This can happen in two cases:

- In your PR you have possibly introduced a breaking change in a new API version, placed in a new folder,
as compared to most recent previous `GA`.
The new API version can be either `preview` or `GA`.
  - For example, an existing `GA` API version in leaf folder of `2023-11-15`
may contain API route of `GET .../resoruces/{resourceName}`, but a new `preview` API version of `2024-03-15-preview`
may no longer have this route (REST API path), because you are removing the `resoruces` typo and instead introducing
`GET .../resources/{resourceName}` route.
- In your PR you are modifying existing `GA` API version in-place. For example, you have recently released
`2024-03-18` API version and realized you made a typo and are editing the contents of the leaf folder `2024-03-18`
containing that API version.

### `VersioningReviewRequired` label

The label `VersioningReviewRequired` denotes that your PR has a **versioning issue** possibly violating the  
[Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy]. This happens when you made a **non-breaking change**,
aka **compatible change** to an API version that was already published (merged to a production branch).

> [!NOTE]
> According to [the policy][Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy], compatible (non-breaking changes) are not
> allowed within an existing API version. You must create a new API version. Otherwise, we would confuse our customers
> by having to explain "which version of given API version" has a particular change/feature.

`VersioningReviewRequired` label is added by automation if:

- You made any compatible changes **within** any API version, `GA` or `preview`.
- You made any breaking changes in a `preview` API version.

If your PR has both breaking changes and versioning issues, only `BreakingChangeReviewRequired` label
is added to it.

### In case there is no latest GA API version

If there is no latest GA OpenAPI spec, then the the cross-version check is instead comparing to
latest available preview if it more than 1 year old.

If neither a GA API version or at least 1 year old preview version exists, then the cross-version check automatically
passes.

### Diagram explaining breaking changes and versioning issues

The logic for automation adding `BreakingChangeReviewRequired` and `VersioningReviewRequired` labels explained above
can be summarized in the following diagram:

![Breaking Changes Confusion Matrix](../../img/breaking_changes_confusion_matrix.png)

## Addressing `BreakingChangeReviewRequired`

If your PR is labelled with `BreakingChangeReviewRequired`, per Step 1 from the [PR diagram],
you must follow the process given at [aka.ms/brch].

If the Breaking Change Review Board determines the breaking changes in your PR are acceptable, they will be
approved by one of these labels:

### `BreakingChange-Approved-Benign`

The changes to the REST API definition are not breaking at the REST API level and have at most minor impact to
generated SDKs, so the change is allowed.

### `BreakingChange-Approved-BugFix`

The changes to the REST API definition are correcting the definition to accurately describe the service behavior.

> [!TIP]
> As a PR author, you are allowed to apply the `BreakingChange-Approved-BugFix` label. See [aka.ms/brch] for details.

### `BreakingChange-Approved-UserImpact`

- The spec PR describes actual breaking changes to the service.
- This is the only case that triggers customer notifications, a 3 year migration period (possibly shorter), etc.
- Within this set, the changes may be distinguished further for security or legal compliance, which may be granted
a shorter migration period.
- Details at [aka.ms/brch].

### `BreakingChange-Approved-BranchPolicyException`

The API version that triggered the review violates the GitHub repository branch policy, but we allow it.
Usually this is because it has not yet been released, despite having been merged to a production branch.

> [!TIP]
> As a PR author, you are allowed to apply the `BreakingChange-Approved-BranchPolicyException` label,
> but only in the [private specs repo]. See [aka.ms/brch] for details.

### `BreakingChange-Approved-Previously`

- The PR contains breaking changes that were previously reviewed and approved.
- It is desirable but not mandatory to add a link the previously approved PR in a comment on given PR.
- As of 3/11/2024 we have planned work to reduce occurrences of this scenario.
See [#7259](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-tools/issues/7259) for details.

## Addressing `VersioningReviewRequired`

If your PR is labelled with `VersioningReviewRequired`, per Step 1 from the [PR diagram],
you must follow the process given at [aka.ms/brch].

If the Breaking Change Review Board determines the versioning issue in your PR caused by non-breaking (compatible)
changes is acceptable, the board will approve it by one of these labels:

### `Versioning-Approved-Benign`

The changes to the REST API definition are not breaking at the REST API level and have at most minor impact to
generated SDKs, so the change is allowed.

### `Versioning-Approved-BugFix`

The changes to the REST API definition are correcting the definition to accurately describe the service behavior.

> [!TIP]
> As a PR author, you are allowed to apply the `Versioning-Approved-BugFix` label. See [aka.ms/brch] for details.

### `Versioning-Approved-PrivatePreview`

The API version change that triggered the review is in `private preview`, and non-breaking changes are permitted
in the same API version during `private preview`.

> [!TIP]
> As a PR author, you are allowed to apply the `Versioning-Approved-PrivatePreview` label. See [aka.ms/brch] for details.

### `Versioning-Approved-BranchPolicyException`

The API version that triggered the review violates the GitHub repository branch policy, but we allow it.
Usually this is because it has not yet been released, despite having been merged to a production branch.

> [!TIP]
> As a PR author, you are allowed to apply the `Versioning-Approved-BranchPolicyException` label,
> but only in the [private specs repo]. See [aka.ms/brch] for details.

### `Versioning-Approved-Previously`

- The PR contains breaking changes that were previously reviewed and approved.
- It is desirable but not mandatory to add a link the previously approved PR in a comment on given PR.
- As of 3/11/2024 we have planned work to reduce occurrences of this scenario.
See [#7259](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-tools/issues/7259) for details.

## Common misconceptions

### FALSE: compatible (non-breaking) changes are allowed in published API versions

**Why?**

An API version is a contract, and once the contract is published it cannot be changed.
Otherwise, it would create customer confusion about "which version of this API version" are they using.

Any change of this kind w"},{"document_source":"static_typespec_qa","document_filename":"typespec_2025_09_05.md","document_title":"PR in azure-rest-api-specs-pr/main branch isnt merged to RPSaasMaster","document_link":"","content":"# typespec_2025_09_05.md

# Swagger breaking change

## question

PR check run: https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/pull/35346/checks?check_run_id=44501918225
My typespec conversion PR is failing in swagger breaking change check with the following error: 
"new":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/a1ac3f6f98bb1ea3583b765d00dfceab6d85654f/specification/devtestlabs/resource-manager/Microsoft.DevTestLab/stable/2018-09-15/DTL.json",
"old":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/specification/devtestlabs/resource-manager/Microsoft.DevTestLab/stable/2018-09-15/DTL.json",
"details":"incompatible properties : tags\n definitions/TrackedResource/properties/tags\n at file:///mnt/vss/_work/1/azure-rest-api-specs/specification/common-types/resource-management/v3/types.json#L489:8\n definitions/Resource/properties/tags\n at file:///mnt/vss/_work/1/azure-rest-api-specs/specification/devtestlabs/resource-manager/Microsoft.DevTestLab/stable/2018-09-15/DTL.json#L12397:8" 
This PR is just having typespec conversion change and I am avoiding any change to the swagger file that is generated as part of typespec conversion. In the old swagger there is a Resource definitionwhich is similar Azure resource definition. Should I suppress this check and how to do it?

## answer

This occurs because in your original swagger, you did not use swagger common-types. 
The 'tags' definitions are compatible, so there is no change in the actual api from this.  This could result in changes in some management sdks, although this change to using the common resource types has generally been accepted. 
docs on suppressions for false positives are here: [Suppress validation failures on a PR](https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/specs-pr-guides/pr-suppressions) 
Note that it is important to go through these violations, as the conversion is not guaranteed to be 100% accurate."},{"document_source":"static_typespec_qa","document_filename":"typespec_2025_08_14.md","document_title":"Looking for someone to suppress CI failures https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/pull/36221","document_link":"","content":"# typespec_2025_08_14.md

## question

I've a PR where the Typespec validation is failing with some weird error. This is not being reproduced locally - 
```
  specification/storagedatamanagementrp/Private.StorageDataManagement.Management/main.tsp:17:10 - error expect-value: Is a model expression type, but is being used as a value here. Use #{} to create an object value.
53  > 17 | @service({

```

60  > 19 |   @visibility("read")

```
I'm not sure how to resolve this error. Could someone please help here?
[Update Connector and DataShare Swagger by ujjawaljain-msft · Pull Request #21997 · Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/pull/21997)

## answer

You may need to update to the latest typespec version - some of these particular properties have changed in a recent version. What you are using here isn't the latest style to specify these things.
Doc for future reference: https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/TypeSpec-Validation#running-locally :
```
Running Locally
To ensure you see the same results from TypeSpecValidation in your PR check and tsv on your local machine:
Merge latest from parent (e.g. main or RPSaaSMaster) to your PR branch
Run locally
git clean -xdf (may revert any local changes)
git pull
npm ci
npx tsv specification/contosowidgetmanager/Contoso.Management
git status
If any changes, git add, git commit, git push to update your PR.
If you are still having problems, try cloning your branch to a new folder, or try on another machine.
If the problem can be reproduced on a clean machine, request assistance from the TypeSpec Discussion teams channel.
```"},{"document_source":"static_typespec_qa","document_filename":"typespec_2025_09_12.md","document_title":"SDK Validation steps are failing with not much helpful logs","document_link":"","content":"# typespec_2025_09_12.md

If `Swagger BreakingChange` fails with `AutoRest threw a runtime error`, the root cause is likely a problem in your spec causing AutoRest to crash.  To debug (all commands run from repo root):

1. Determine if the problem is "before" or "after" your PR (or both)
   1. Checkout the target branch of your PR (likely `main` or `RPSaaSMaster`)
   2. `npm i`
   3. Run `@azure/oad` against the copy of your spec in the target branch.  Specify the same path twice, which should always pass unless AutoRest crashes.
    ```
    $ npx @azure/oad compare \
        specification/contosowidgetmanager/resource-manager/Microsoft.Contoso/stable/2021-11-01/contoso.json \
        specification/contosowidgetmanager/resource-manager/Microsoft.Contoso/stable/2021-11-01/contoso.json
    ```
   4. If your spec is valid, this should return `"code":"NoVersionChange"`, since you are comparing the spec to itself.  If your spec is invalid, this will fail with `AutoRest threw a runtime error`, and the stack trace should include `path` properties pointing to the error.  For instance, here's a failure caused by example with a disallowed property:

    ```
    code: 'OBJECT-ADDITIONAL-PROPERTIES'
    params: [ [Array] ]
    message: 'Additional properties not allowed: headers'
    path: '#/paths/~1executions/post/x-ms-examples/CodeExecution-Execute-Async-Running'
    ```

   5. If `@azure/oad compare` passed on the copy of your spec in the target branch, repeat these steps on the copy of your spec in the source branch.
2. If the problem is "before" your PR, open another PR dedicated to fixing just this problem.  BreakingChanges may fail in this fixup PR, but should pass going forward.
3. If the problem is "after" your PR, just fix the problem in your PR."},{"document_source":"azure_api_guidelines","document_filename":"azure#VersioningGuidelines.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://github.com/microsoft/api-guidelines/blob/vNext/azure/VersioningGuidelines.md","content":"# Azure Versioning Guidelines
## Guidelines
This document provides a "Dos and Don'ts" list for complying with the Azure Versioning and Breaking Change Policy,
as documented [internally](aka.ms/AzBreakingChangesPolicy) and [externally](https://learn.microsoft.com/azure/developer/intro/azure-service-sdk-tool-versioning).

:white_check_mark: **DO** thoroughly ensure/test the API contract is entirely correct before merging it into a production branch of the specs repo.

Testing helps avoid "BugFix" changes to the API definition. Testing should be done at the HTTP level as well as through generated SDKs.

:white_check_mark: **DO** retire all prior preview API versions 90 days after a new GA or preview API version is released.

:white_check_mark: **DO** contact the Azure Breaking Change Review board to coordinate communications to customers
when releasing an API version requiring the retirement of a prior version.

:white_check_mark: **DO** create a new preview API version for any features that should remain in preview following a new GA release.

:white_check_mark: **DO** use a date strictly later than the most recent GA API version when releasing
a new preview API version.

:white_check_mark: **DO** deprovision any API version that has been retired. Retired APIs versions should behave like
an unknown API version (see [ref](https://aka.ms/azapi/guidelines#versioning-api-version-unsupported)).

:white_check_mark: **DO** remove retired API versions from the azure-rest-api-specs repo.

:white_check_mark: **DO** review any change to service behavior that could disrupt customers with the Azure Breaking Changes review board, even if the change is not part of the API definition.

Some examples of behavior changes that must be reviewed are:
- Introducing or changing rate limits to be more restrictive than previously
- Changing the permissions required to successfully execute an operation"},{"document_source":"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki","document_filename":"TypeSpec-Validation.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/TypeSpec-Validation","content":"# Running Locally
To ensure you see the same results from TypeSpecValidation in your PR check and `tsv` on your local machine:
1. Merge latest from parent (e.g. `main` or `RPSaaSMaster`) to your PR branch
2. Run locally
   1. `git clean -xdf` (may revert any local changes)
   2. `git pull`
   3. `npm ci`
   4. `npx tsv specification/widget/resource-manager/Microsoft.Widget/Widget`
   5. `git status`
   6. If any changes, `git add`, `git commit`, `git push` to update your PR.
3. If you are still having problems, try cloning your branch to a new folder, or try on another machine.
4. If the problem can be reproduced on a clean machine, request assistance from the [TypeSpec Discussion](https://teams.microsoft.com/l/channel/19%3A906c1efbbec54dc8949ac736633e6bdf%40thread.skype/TypeSpec%20Discussion?groupId=3e17dcb0-4257-4a30-b843-77f47f1d4121&tenantId=72f988bf-86f1-41af-91ab-2d7cd011db47) teams channel."},{"document_source":"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki","document_filename":"Swagger-Avocado.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Swagger-Avocado","content":"# Known Issues
## MULTIPLE_API_VERSION
Rule [MULTIPLE_API_VERSION](https://github.com/Azure/avocado?tab=readme-ov-file#multiple_api_version) was changed from a warning to an error on 7/1/2025. As this issue is a blocker to TypeSpec conversion which is an Azure wide effort to drive the API first design pattern among all Azure services.

If your PR is blocked due to this error, please check out this [Uniform Versioning Violation Guide](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Uniform-Versioning-Violation-Guide) wiki on how to resolve this.

Please check with azversioning@service.microsoft.com to see if your service can have one-time suppression if you are not sure."},{"document_source":"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki","document_filename":"Resolving-Folder-Migration-Conflicts:-A-Guide-for-PR-Authors.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Resolving-Folder-Migration-Conflicts:-A-Guide-for-PR-Authors","content":"# Resolving Folder Migration Conflicts: A Guide for PR Authors
## The impact to ongoing PRs
1. If the ongoing PRs are targeting to a release-* or dev-* branch which are not created or syncing from the latest main, we recommend to merge these PRs first.
1. If the ongoing PRs are targeting to public main branch, Here's the suggestion to resolve the conflict. 

      1. Merge latest main 
          ```
          git checkout main
          git pull origin main // origin points to Azure rest api specs repo.
          git merge main <your-pr-branch>
          ```
      2. Resolve conflicts  
        - For most of the conflicts, accept the incoming changes.  
        - If it's unclear, please accept both and then update based on your judgement with the folder structure changes above.  

      3. Make sure the new change is aligned with folder structure v2  

         There are some cases where the PR is adding a new version in the original location, but the file diffs don't show as conflict. we should move them into the correct place so that it doesn't break the folder structure v2 as instructions in **Understanding Folder Migration sections** 

      4. clean up the previous folder if exists.

  

**Important**: It's strongly recommended to understand what's really changed in the folder refactor. Always ensure the new PR doesn't include any things that breaks the folder structure."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"design#api-specs-pr#api-specs-pr.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-specs-pr/api-specs-pr","content":"# Create a pull request with your Azure REST API spec update
## Get your PR merged
| Short Link: | [aka.ms/azsdk/specreview/merge](https://aka.ms/azsdk/specreview/merge) |
|-|-|

To get your PR merged:

1. Ensure the `Next Steps to Merge` comment and `Automated merging requirements met` check are green. 
1. Ensure at least one person has approved your PR. Generally another person from your team that has [write access] to the repo.
1. Ensure all required checks are passing and at least investigate to understand any other non-required checks that may be failing. 
1. Once all required checks are green and any other issues understood you can merge the PR yourself as long as you have [write access] to the repo.
1. If your PR is targeting public `main` you will need to first apply the `PublishToCustomers` label to acknowledge you understand this 
   will cause your spec to be published so customers can consume it.
1. If your PR is targeting private repo `main` branch, it **cannot** be merged.
   Instead, you can publish your changes to customers by following the guide at [aka.ms/azsdk/move-pr]."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"design#api-specs-pr#api-tutorial#api-tutorial.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-specs-pr/api-tutorial/api-tutorial","content":"# Tutorial: Create a new service spec
## Why work in a separate branch?
The [Microsoft Azure REST API Guidelines state](https://github.com/microsoft/api-guidelines/blob/vNext/azure/Guidelines.md#api-versioning),

> Azure services need to change over time. However, when changing a service, there are 2 requirements:
>
> 1. Already-running customer workloads must not break due to a service change.
> 2. Customers can adopt a new service version without requiring any code changes.
>    Of course, the customer must modify code to leverage any new service features.

Together with the [Breaking Changes Policy](http://aka.ms/AzBreakingChangesPolicy/), it effectively means that any
changes you merge directly into the `main` branch in  
[Azure/azure-rest-api-specs](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs) must be supported for 90 days for preview
versions, and 3 years for stable versions at a minimum.

Working in a separate branch allows your team to iterate on a design, make changes to the REST API definition or
even the service as needed, and merge those changes to `main` - effectively publishing that service version -
when you're ready."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"design#api-specs-pr#api-repos.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-specs-pr/api-repos","content":"# Azure REST API specs repositories on GitHub
The REST API descriptions for all Azure services should be published in the Azure REST API specs GitHub repositories.

The [Azure/azure-rest-api-specs] is the public repository. All work done in this repository is public, i.e. visible to
everyone, including people outside of Microsoft. Any Azure REST API specification updates must be merged to the `main`
branch as part of the process of releasing those updates to Microsoft customers.

The [Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr] is the private repository (the "pr" stands for "private"). It is for work that must
remain private until it is ready to be published. For example, if your team is working on a new product with a new Azure
Resource Manager (ARM) or Resource Provider (RP) namespace, you want to keep developing it in the private repository
until you have drafted, tested and went through the API review process. Only after this is done, you must merge your
changes to the `main` branch in the public repository.

The `main` branch in the private repository is read-only, as it is mirrored from the public repository `main` branch."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"design#specs-pr-guides#specs-pr-guides.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/specs-pr-guides/specs-pr-guides","content":"# Azure REST API specs PRs Guides

[Azure REST API specs PR](xref:api-specs-pr) merged.

rows.outputs.similarity.similarity_sample_inp: [{"role": "user", "content": "{\"query\": \"title: Problem with merging PR into target branch\\n\\nquestion: Hello team,\\nI am having trouble merging my PR. It seems I am being blocked by breaking changes errors. After consulting with the breaking changes team, they say the pr pipeline must be bust. Can you please help on this.\\nPR: Enabling free services acquisition via APIs by adrianta \\u00b7 Pull Request #25230 \\u00b7 Azure/azure-rest-ap\\u2026\", \"response\": \"Based on the Azure API versioning and breaking change policies, if your PR is blocked due to breaking changes errors, there are specific steps you must follow to resolve this.\\n\\n1. **Diagnose the Cause**: Breaking changes errors in PR pipelines usually mean your changes either introduce a breaking change to a published API version or violate versioning rules (e.g., modifying a published version, even for non-breaking changes).\\n   - Use the guidance at [aka.ms/brch](https://aka.ms/brch) for a step-by-step process.\\n   - If your PR is labeled with `BreakingChangeReviewRequired` or `VersioningReviewRequired`, you must resolve these before further review or merging can proceed.\\n\\n2. **Pipeline Bust Diagnosis**: If the breaking changes team says the pipeline is \\\"bust,\\\" it's important to verify if this is due to a tooling failure or a genuine spec issue:\\n   - Run the validation locally using the documented process (see references below). This will help determine if the error is reproducible outside the CI system:\\n     ```\\n     git clean -xdf\\n     git pull\\n     npm ci\\n     npx tsv specification/your-service-folder\\n     ```\\n   - If the problem persists locally, it's a real spec issue. If not, there may be a CI configuration or sync problem.\\n\\n3. **Resolving Breaking Changes**:\\n   - If your change is a real breaking change and you believe it is benign, a bugfix, or already approved, you (or the review board) can apply the appropriate approval label as documented (see references).\\n   - If your change is not intended to be breaking, review your TypeSpec changes and ensure you are not modifying any published API contracts. For any required changes, always introduce a new API version instead of modifying an existing one.\\n\\n4. **Branch Sync Issues**: If the error is due to branch sync (e.g., target branch out of sync with `main`), follow the documented process to update your branch with changes from main:\\n     - [Update your branch with changes from main](https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-specs-pr/api-tutorial/api-tutorial-3-publish#update-your-branch-with-changes-from-main)\\n\\n5. **Further Help**:\\n   - If local validation matches the pipeline error, and you believe it is a false positive or a tooling bug, document the steps and reach out on the [TypeSpec Discussion teams channel](https://teams.microsoft.com/l/channel/19%3A906c1efbbec54dc8949ac736633e6bdf%40thread.skype/TypeSpec%20Discussion?groupId=3e17dcb0-4257-4a30-b843-77f47f1d4121&tenantId=72f988bf-86f1-41af-91ab-2d7cd011db47).\\n   - If you are blocked by a spec repo sync issue, the spec owner is responsible for keeping branches synchronized (main <-> RPSaaSMaster, etc.).\\n\\n**Summary:**\\n- Run validation locally to confirm whether the error is real or a CI pipeline issue.\\n- Do not modify published API versions directly; create new versions for changes.\\n- Apply the appropriate approval label if your breaking change is a bugfix or previously approved.\\n- If the issue is a pipeline tooling failure, contact the spec repo owner or TypeSpec Discussion teams channel.\\n\\nLet me know if you need help with specific error logs or validation output!\", \"ground_truth\": \"You are confusing two checks:\\nBreaking Changes(Cross-Version) - Analyze Code\\nimplementation detail\\nnot required\\nBreaking Changes(Cross-Version)\\nrequired\\npassing due to label\\nI suspect your PR cannot be merged, because your github account is missing one or more required permissions. https://aka.ms/azsdk/access\\nThis must be public, not private: https://github.com/orgs/Azure/people?query=adrianta\\nOnce your permissions are fixed, push a change to your PR (empty commit is fine) to rerun checks.\"}"}]

rows.inputs.query:
title: Clarification on Folder Structure Alignment for CP and DP SDKs

question: Hi
General
,
Our CP SDKs for both .NET and JavaScript are currently placed under the playwright folder.
js->azure-sdk-for-js/sdk/playwright at main · Azure/azure-sdk-for-js
net->azure-sdk-for-net/sdk/playwright at main · Azure/azure-sdk-for-net
while the non-Azure (DP) SDKs are placed under the loadtesting folder.
js->azure-sdk-for-js/sdk/loadtesting at main · Azure/azure-sdk-for-js
net->azure-sdk-for-net/sdk/loadtestservice at main · Azure/azure-sdk-for-net
we wanted to confirm:
Is it important or recommended to move the DP SDKs under the playwright folder to align with the CP SDK structure or the current structure is fine?
If yes, could you please guide us on the recommended process or steps to make this shift (e.g., repo structure changes, PR approach, or naming conventions to follow)?
Context:
As part of the retirement of Microsoft Playwright Testing (MPT) and its merger into Azure App Testing, we deprecated the old SDK packages associated with MPT and created new alternative packages about whose folder structure I mentioned above.
MPT’s core web testing capabilities are being integrated into Azure App Testing to provide a unified experience for both Load Testing and Playwright-based web testing. The standalone MPT service will be retired, and customers will need to migrate to Azure App Testing.
Qiaoqiao Zhang Please help us with this.
Thanks
cc Madhuri
rows.inputs.ground_truth:
I think this should be a cross-language issue as in your tspconfig, the service-dir is sdk/playwrite which means all languages will generate the code under sdk/playwript. So you should update it in your tspconfig first. Then we can move the generated package into sdk/loadtesting folder in sdk repo
tspconfig:
```
parameters:
"service-dir":
default: "sdk/playwright"
```
For Java, I see you already had a GA release in
https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-java/tree/main/sdk/playwright/azure-resourcemanager-playwright
If this is your SDK, please do not modify the directory on Java. If you update the service-dir in parameters, please add a line
```
service-dir: sdk/playwright
```
under "@azure-tools/typespec-java":
Generally, diretory in Java repo follows your package name and namespace, which both is playwright. Unless your package be e.g. azure-resourcemanager-loadtesting-playwright, the folder won't be loadtesting.
rows.inputs.response:
Based on the provided knowledge, Azure SDK folder structure and naming conventions should be consistent and logical, but there is no explicit requirement to align Data Plane (DP) SDKs under the same folder as Control Plane (CP) SDKs. The current structure, with CP SDKs under 'playwright' and DP SDKs under 'loadtesting' or 'loadtestservice', is acceptable as long as it clearly reflects the functionality and purpose of each SDK. 

If you decide to align the folder structure (e.g., move DP SDKs under 'playwright'), you must ensure the following:
- Update all relevant metadata and documentation (including CSV files for release metadata, README files, and reference docs) to reflect the new locations.
- Follow Azure SDK naming conventions for package names, folders, and namespaces (see [Azure SDK Architecture design guidelines](https://azure.github.io/azure-sdk/general_introduction.html)).
- Coordinate deprecation and migration guidance for any affected packages using the official SDK deprecation guidelines (update EOLDate, Support, Replace, and ReplaceGuide fields in the CSV, and README/package manager notices).
- Submit PRs for the folder moves in each affected repo, and update CODEOWNERS and service labels as needed to ensure correct reviewer assignment and issue routing.
- Verify the changes do not break automated build, test, or documentation generation pipelines (refer to [Publish SDK reference docs] and [Test your SDK]).
- Communicate any migration steps to customers, especially if package names or import paths change.

Given the context of MPT retirement and Azure App Testing merger, clear migration and deprecation communication is essential. Unless there is a specific cross-repo policy or automation dependency requiring alignment, it is acceptable to keep DP and CP SDKs in separate, clearly named folders reflecting their functionality.

If you proceed with the move, the recommended process is:
1. Plan the new folder structure and naming, ensuring alignment with Azure SDK conventions.
2. Update metadata files, README, and package managers to reflect new locations and migration guides.
3. Move the source code and test assets to the new folder in a dedicated PR for each language repo.
4. Update CODEOWNERS, service labels, and review assignments for the new folder.
5. Verify build, test, and docs generation pipelines work post-move.
6. Communicate changes and migration instructions to customers, including deprecation of old package paths if needed.
7. Use the official SDK deprecation process for any retired packages.

If you have further questions or need help with automation or release planner, reach out to the [Azure SDK Onboarding channel](https://aka.ms/azsdk/support/onboarding-channel).

You can also use the links below to quickly get to the files. - [C++](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-cpp/blob/main/.github/CODEOWNERS) - [Go](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-go/blob/main/.github/CODEOWNERS) - [Java](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-java/blob/main/.github/CODEOWNERS) - [JavaScript/TypeScript](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-js/blob/main/.github/CODEOWNERS) - [.NET](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-net/blob/main/.github/CODEOWNERS) - [Python](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/main/.github/CODEOWNERS) - [REST API Specs](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/.github/CODEOWNERS) - [Rust](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-rust/blob/main/.github/CODEOWNERS) ## Validating your alias in CODEOWNERS For your GitHub alias to be valid you must complete the tasks for [Requesting access to Azure REST API and SDK repositories](xref:access#request-access-to-azure-rest-api-and-sdk-repositories). > [!NOTE] > Ensure that your organization visibility is set to **public** before proceeding. If you're unsure if your GitHub alias is a part of the right orgs and has the proper permissions, you can verify the state of your alias by running the [Validate-AzsdkCodeOwner](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-tools/blob/main/tools/github/scripts/Validate-AzsdkCodeOwner.ps1) script from the Azure SDK tools repository. ## Getting mentioned on issues Our repositories have automated processes for adding comments to issues when certain labels are added. Your team can automatically have a GitHub alias or GitHub team mentioned in an issue if the service's label and the `Service Attention` label are added to the issue. The `Service Attention` label signifies that the issue cannot be resolved by the Azure SDK team. The responsibility to resolve the issue will be on your team. To update who gets automatically mentioned in issues related to your service, locate the relevant block in the `CODEOWNERS` file by searching for the `service label` and update the GitHub aliases listed: ```text # ServiceLabel: % # ServiceOwners: @fakeUser1 @Azure/fakeTeam1 ``` See the [Creating and editing a service in CODEOWNERS files](#creating-and-editing-a-service-in-codeowners-files) section to properly update your service's entry. ## Getting assigned as a reviewer on pull requests The Azure SDK and Azure REST API Specs GitHub repositories utilize GitHub's built-in features for automatically adding PR (Pull Request) reviewers using the `CODEOWNERS` file. To update who is automatically added as a reviewer when PRs are opened to your service's API Spec or libraries, locate the relevant block in the `CODEOWNERS` file by searching for the `service label` and update the GitHub aliases listed: ```text # PRLabel: % /sdk// @fakeUser1 @Azure/fakeTeam1 ``` See the [Creating and editing a service in CODEOWNERS files](#creating-and-editing-a-service-in-codeowners-files) section to properly update your service's entry. ## Creating and editing a service in CODEOWNERS files To edit the `CODEOWNERS` files in each SDK repository and the API Specs repository, follow these steps: 1. Go to the `CODEOWNERS` file you plan to edit. *Use the [Where are the CODEOWNERS files](#where-are-the-codeowners-files) list.* 2. Click the pencil icon on the top right to edit this file. This will open the GitHub browser editor. 3. In the `CODEOWNERS` file, locate the lines that follow the pattern below, replacing `` with the associated GitHub label for your Azure service and `` with the directory your service library's source code is located. This entire code block will be your service's entry within the `CODEOWNERS` file. ```text # PRLabel: % /sdk// @fakeUser1 @Azure/fakeTeam1 # ServiceLabel: % # ServiceOwners: @fakeUser1 @Azure/fakeTeam1 ``` > [!TIP] > If you don't know what your service label is, see the [Common Repo Labels] CSV file and look for a row whose first column contains your service's name. If you don't see a row for your service, contact [Ronnie Geraghty]. > **DO NOT** add labels for your service directly to the SDK repositories. If you were able to locate lines that **completely match** the pattern above, proceed to the next step. If you were able to locate lines that **partially match** the pattern above, add lines and information as needed to adhere to the required format. Then, proceed to the next step. If **no lines** match the pattern above, create a new entry for your service. Insert the above pattern into the file and replace: - `` with the associated GitHub label for your Azure service - `` with the directory your service library's source code is located - Fake GitHub aliases with your own alias and/or your team's. pull request will then be reviewed by our team. If we have any questions, we will leave them in the comments of the pull request so please monitor the pull request until it is merged. Once the pull request is reviewed and merged, you will start being mentioned in customer issues and added as a reviewer to PRs that contain changes to the files in the directory location you specified. 10. Repeat these steps for the API Specs repo and each language repository you want to make changes to. [Common Repo Labels]: https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-tools/blob/main/tools/github/data/common-labels.csv [Ronnie Geraghty]: mailto:rgeraghty@microsoft.com above, add lines and information as needed to adhere to the required format. Then, proceed to the next step. If **no lines** match the pattern above, create a new entry for your service. Insert the above pattern into the file and replace: - `` with the associated GitHub label for your Azure service - `` with the directory your service library's source code is located - Fake GitHub aliases with your own alias and/or your team's. For GitHub teams you'll need to prefix the team name with the GitHub organization it was created under (Ex: `@/`) > [!NOTE] > Service entries in `CODEOWNERS` should be ordered and inserted alphabetically by the service label. 4. Update your service's entry as needed, ensuring that the standards below are maintained and always met: - There are at least 2 valid aliases for both the SDK directory and `#ServiceOwners:`. See the [Validating your CODEOWNERS](#validating-your-alias-in-codeowners) section to see how you can check codeowner aliases and what you need to do to make them valid. - The placement of your GitHub alias(es) is vertically aligned with others in the file. - Entries are listed alphabetically by service label. - An empty line separates your service entry from other service entries in the file. For example: ```text # PRLabel: %Other Service Label /sdk// @fakeUser1 @Azure/fakeTeam1 # ServiceLabel: %Other Service Label # ServiceOwners: @fakeUser1 @Azure/fakeTeam1 # PRLabel: %Your Service Label /sdk// @myalias @Azure/myTeam1 # ServiceLabel: %Your Service Label # ServiceOwners: @myalias @Azure/myTeam1 # PRLabel: %Another Service Label @fakeUser1 @Azure/fakeTeam1 # ServiceLabel: %Other Service Label # ServiceOwners: @fakeUser1 @Azure/fakeTeam1 # PRLabel: %Your Service Label /sdk// @myalias @Azure/myTeam1 # ServiceLabel: %Your Service Label # ServiceOwners: @myalias @Azure/myTeam1 # PRLabel: %Another Service Label /sdk// @fakeUser2 @Azure/fakeTeam2 # ServiceLabel: %Another Service Label # ServiceOwners: @fakeUser2 @Azure/fakeTeam2 ``` 5. Click on the green **Commit changes...** button at the top right. 6. In the pop-up, change the **Commit message** text box to `Update for CODEOWNERS`. Replace `` with the same service label you used in the previous steps. 7. Add a description with any relevant information and click **Propose changes**. Note the name of the new branch created for your changes. The branch name is shown in the bottom text box and usually follows the pattern `-patch-1`. 8. Review the pull request form that appears making sure that the base branch is `main` and the compare branch is the one you just created in the previous step. Then click the **Create pull request** button. 9. The pull request will then be reviewed by our team. If we have any questions, we will leave them in the comments of the pull request so please monitor the pull request until it is merged. Once the pull request is reviewed and merged, you will start being mentioned in"},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"develop#sdk-test.md","document_title":"Test your SDK","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/develop/sdk-test","content":"# develop#sdk-test.md # Test your SDK Usability is a critical factor in the success of SDKs for our customers, which is why our SDKs must include tests. ## Before you begin - You have [access](xref:access) to the GitHub repositories and respective GitHub groups. - You are familiarized with the [Azure SDK Architecture design guidelines](https://azure.github.io/azure-sdk/general_introduction.html). - You read our [repository branches strategy](https://azure.github.io/azure-sdk/policies_repobranching.html). - You need to have an SDK to write tests against. ### [Management plane (ARM)](#tab/management) For a GA (stable) SDK release, .NET recommends to include live tests to verify that the SDK functions correctly with the targeted new service version. :point_right: [.NET](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-net/blob/main/sdk/resourcemanager/Azure.ResourceManager/docs/TestGuide.md) :point_right: [Java](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-java/wiki/TypeSpec-Java-Quickstart#adding-tests) :point_right: [JavaScript](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-js/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md#testing) :point_right: [Python](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/main/doc/dev/mgmt/tests.md) :point_right: [Go](https://github.com/Azure/autorest.go/blob/main/packages/autorest.gotest/doc/gotest_howto.md#generate-mock-test-and-execute) ### [Data plane](#tab/dataplane) According to the target phase of your SDK, these are the requirements you will need to accomplish so you can release your SDK: - Public preview: at least one test per language for the most common usage scenario. - GA: at least one test per shipped method. Tutorials to add tests: :point_right: [.NET](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-net/blob/main/doc/DataPlaneCodeGeneration/Azure_SDK_Package_Ship_Requirements.md#tests) :point_right: [Java](https://aka.ms/azsdk/dpg/java/tests) :point_right: [JavaScript](https://aka.ms/azsdk/dpg/js/tests) :point_right: [Python](https://aka.ms/azsdk/dpg/python/tests) :point_right: [Go (optional)](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-go/blob/main/documentation/developer_setup.md#write-tests). ## Get help Reach out to the specific language Teams channel under our [Azure SDK channel](https://teams.microsoft.com/l/team/19%3af6d52ac6465c40ea80dc86b8be3825aa%40thread.skype/conversations?groupId=3e17dcb0-4257-4a30-b843-77f47f1d4121&tenantId=72f988bf-86f1-41af-91ab-2d7cd011db47)."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"develop#sdk-develop.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/develop/sdk-develop","content":"# develop#sdk-develop.md | Short Link: | [aka.ms/azsdk/dpcodegen](https://aka.ms/azsdk/dpcodegen) | | --- | --- | # Develop client libraries (SDK) Once your [REST API specification](xref:api-design) defined using [TypeSpec](xref:api-typespec) is approved, you can generate client libraries and reference documentation for each supported SDK language. Your Azure SDKs should be designed to enhance the productivity of developers connecting to Azure services. They must follow the [Azure SDK Architecture design guidelines](https://azure.github.io/azure-sdk/general_introduction.html) and specific language guidelines. > [!NOTE] > - Azure services are required to release client libraries for all Tier 1 SDK languages for Public Preview and GA, which include .NET, Python, > Java, JavaScript, and Go (optional for data plane SDKs). > - Avoiding breaking changes under most circumstances. The Azure SDK team recommends on the SDK release cycle can be > found in [Release Cycle and Package Versioning](https://azure.github.io/azure-sdk/policies_releases.html#release-cycle). > - Azure services must have a beta release available for at least one month to allow for community feedback before > graduating to stable. For more details, may refer to [Beta Releases and Stable Graduation](https://azure.github.io/azure-sdk/policies_releases.html#beta-releases-and-stable-graduation) ## Before you begin - You have [access](xref:access) to the GitHub repositories and respective GitHub groups. - You read our [repository branches strategy](https://azure.github.io/azure-sdk/policies_repobranching.html). - You are familiarized with the [Azure SDK Architecture design guidelines](https://azure.github.io/azure-sdk/general_introduction.html). - You have a [release plan](xref:release-plan) created to manage and understand the steps required to generate, test, and release an SDK. - [Request a namespace review](xref:namespace-review). This review process take 1-2 weeks to complete or longer depending on the complexity of the review. ## Generate SDK Your Azure SDKs will be generated from the configurations you set on your TypeSpec project. 1. Locate or create the `tspconfig.yaml` file in your TypeSpec project. 2. There are emitters per SDK language supported. Add the required emitters with their respective options. - [Management plane tspconfig.yaml sample](https://aka.ms/azsdk/tspconfig-sample-mpg). - [Data plane tspconfig.yaml sample](https://aka.ms/azsdk/tspconfig-sample-dpg). For OpenAPI, the configurations should be in `readme.md`. Refer to the [Sample Readme](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/documentation/samplefiles/README.md#swagger-to-sdk). >[!TIP] > We are piloting our new AzSDK tools MCP server which includes the ability to generate the SDKs and > create a draft pull request in the respective language repository. Refer to [AzSDK tools MCP server](xref:azsdk-tools-mcp) > for instructions on how to install it and use it. ### [Management plane (ARM)](#tab/management) >[!NOTE] > The process for generating management plane SDK from TypeSpec has changed. Learn more about our [latest changes](xref:upcoming_release_planner_change). A release plan is required to generate and release the SDK. If the API spec is written using *TypeSpec* then you can generate the SDK for all tier-1 in *Generate SDK* step in the release planner. If API spec is written using *Open API* SDK generation happens when you [request a release](xref:sdk-release) for all tier-1 languages except .NET. For .NET, follow the steps in the [Generate .NET management plane SDK](xref:sdk-generate-mgmt-dotnet). Although the SDK is autogenerated for you, you can also generate it manually and locally by following the steps outlined in the linked documentation: :point_right: [.NET](xref:sdk-generate-mgmt-dotnet) :point_right: [Go](https://aka.ms/azsdk/mpg/go) :point_right: [Java](https://aka.ms/azsdk/mpg/java) :point_right: [JavaScript](https://aka.ms/azsdk/mpg/js) :point_right: [Python](https://aka.ms/azsdk/mpg/python) ### [Data plane](#tab/dataplane) The following information will guide you from your data plane REST API spec, to code in the respective SDK repositories with the generated SDK: :point_right: [.NET](https://aka.ms/azsdk/dpcodegen/net) :point_right: [Java](https://aka.ms/azsdk/dpcodegen/java) :point_right: [JavaScript DPG](https://aka.ms/azsdk/dpcodegen/js) (aka modular). This is the preferred JS flavor for codegen. :point_right: [JavaScript RLC](https://aka.ms/azsdk/rlc/js) (aka Rest Level Client). You must not attempt to generate RLC unless SDK archboard told you to. :point_right: [Python](https://aka.ms/azsdk/dpcodegen/python) :point_right: [Go (optional)](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-go/blob/main/documentation/developer_setup.md). ## Get help - If you need help with an automation tool or the Release planner, reach out to [Azure SDK / Azure SDK Onboarding](https://aka.ms/azsdk/support/onboarding-channel) channel. - If you need help with the development of the SDKs reach out to the [language specific Team's channel](xref:support#get-help-with-the-azure-sdks-development). - If you need to request an exception for a language review the [request release exception](xref:request-exception)."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"develop#sdk-generate-mgmt-dotnet.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/develop/sdk-generate-mgmt-dotnet","content":"# Generate .NET management plane SDK ## Generate SDKs with OpenAPI - Specify a target version using `tag` as belows if you don't want to use the default tag in [the README configuration file](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/documentation/samplefiles/README.md). For example, ``` tag: package-2022-01-01-preview ``` > [!NOTE] > To ensure the preview of the corresponding .NET SDK in the API Spec PR, refrain from adding the tag here. Instead, use the default tag to generate the SDK and preview it as desired. 2. Run `dotnet build` command to generate the SDK code, then AutoRest will create your .NET SDK using the latest version of your API specs. ``` dotnet build /t:GenerateCode ``` > [!NOTE] > Currently there could be some compatibility issues that the AutoRest tool can't handle. If you encounter generation errors, file an issue in the GitHub Repo [Azure/azure-sdk-for-net](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-net) to get support. 3. Generate the API file with the following command, review it and update any SDK API if it does not follow the [.NET Azure SDK Design Guidelines](https://azure.github.io/azure-sdk/dotnet_introduction.html) with [mgmt configurations](https://github.com/Azure/autorest.csharp/blob/feature/v3/docs/mgmt/readme.md#management-plane-configurations) in `autorest.md`. Then regenerate the API file. ``` \eng\scripts\Export-API.ps1 servicelinker ``` :point_right: Replace `servicelinker` with your SDK service directory name under azure-sdk-for-net\sdk. 4. Once the SDK is generated, build your project either in VS or from command line (follow steps in the section [Build & test SDKs](#build--test-sdks)"},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"develop#sdk-release#sdk-release-prerequisites.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/develop/sdk-release/sdk-release-prerequisites","content":"# Prerequisites to release client libraries (SDK) ## Customize SDKs After generating client code with automation, it may be necessary to rename models, attributes, operations, or parameters to maintain consistent naming conversions. > [!NOTE] > Azure SDK mandates adherence to a consistent set of naming conventions, which significantly enhances the overall usability of the SDK. For instance, in the case of Azure SDK for .NET, developers are required not only to follow the [general naming conventions of .NET](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/standard/design-guidelines/general-naming-conventions), but also to comply with specific guidelines regarding the naming of classes, properties, and methods. Further information is available at [Azure SDK for .NET – naming conventions](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-net/blob/main/doc/dev/Mgmt-Naming-Conventions.md). Guidelines for additional languages are available at the [Azure SDKs site](https://azure.github.io/azure-sdk/general_introduction.html) To customize the SDK as needed, you need to configure `client.tsp`. rows.inputs.testcase: Clarification on Folder Structure Alignment for CP and DP SDKs
rows.outputs.similarity.similarity_sample_inp: [{"role": "user", "content": "{\"query\": \"title: Clarification on Folder Structure Alignment for CP and DP SDKs\\n\\nquestion: Hi\\nGeneral\\n,\\nOur CP SDKs for both .NET and JavaScript are currently placed under the playwright folder.\\njs->azure-sdk-for-js/sdk/playwright at main \\u00b7 Azure/azure-sdk-for-js\\nnet->azure-sdk-for-net/sdk/playwright at main \\u00b7 Azure/azure-sdk-for-net\\nwhile the non-Azure (DP) SDKs are placed under the loadtesting folder.\\njs->azure-sdk-for-js/sdk/loadtesting at main \\u00b7 Azure/azure-sdk-for-js\\nnet->azure-sdk-for-net/sdk/loadtestservice at main \\u00b7 Azure/azure-sdk-for-net\\nwe wanted to confirm:\\nIs it important or recommended to move the DP SDKs under the playwright folder to align with the CP SDK structure or the current structure is fine?\\nIf yes, could you please guide us on the recommended process or steps to make this shift (e.g., repo structure changes, PR approach, or naming conventions to follow)?\\nContext:\\nAs part of the retirement of Microsoft Playwright Testing (MPT) and its merger into Azure App Testing, we deprecated the old SDK packages associated with MPT and created new alternative packages about whose folder structure I mentioned above.\\nMPT\\u2019s core web testing capabilities are being integrated into Azure App Testing to provide a unified experience for both Load Testing and Playwright-based web testing. The standalone MPT service will be retired, and customers will need to migrate to Azure App Testing.\\nQiaoqiao Zhang Please help us with this.\\nThanks\\ncc Madhuri\", \"response\": \"Based on the provided knowledge, Azure SDK folder structure and naming conventions should be consistent and logical, but there is no explicit requirement to align Data Plane (DP) SDKs under the same folder as Control Plane (CP) SDKs. The current structure, with CP SDKs under 'playwright' and DP SDKs under 'loadtesting' or 'loadtestservice', is acceptable as long as it clearly reflects the functionality and purpose of each SDK. \\n\\nIf you decide to align the folder structure (e.g., move DP SDKs under 'playwright'), you must ensure the following:\\n- Update all relevant metadata and documentation (including CSV files for release metadata, README files, and reference docs) to reflect the new locations.\\n- Follow Azure SDK naming conventions for package names, folders, and namespaces (see [Azure SDK Architecture design guidelines](https://azure.github.io/azure-sdk/general_introduction.html)).\\n- Coordinate deprecation and migration guidance for any affected packages using the official SDK deprecation guidelines (update EOLDate, Support, Replace, and ReplaceGuide fields in the CSV, and README/package manager notices).\\n- Submit PRs for the folder moves in each affected repo, and update CODEOWNERS and service labels as needed to ensure correct reviewer assignment and issue routing.\\n- Verify the changes do not break automated build, test, or documentation generation pipelines (refer to [Publish SDK reference docs] and [Test your SDK]).\\n- Communicate any migration steps to customers, especially if package names or import paths change.\\n\\nGiven the context of MPT retirement and Azure App Testing merger, clear migration and deprecation communication is essential. Unless there is a specific cross-repo policy or automation dependency requiring alignment, it is acceptable to keep DP and CP SDKs in separate, clearly named folders reflecting their functionality.\\n\\nIf you proceed with the move, the recommended process is:\\n1. Plan the new folder structure and naming, ensuring alignment with Azure SDK conventions.\\n2. Update metadata files, README, and package managers to reflect new locations and migration guides.\\n3. Move the source code and test assets to the new folder in a dedicated PR for each language repo.\\n4. Update CODEOWNERS, service labels, and review assignments for the new folder.\\n5. Verify build, test, and docs generation pipelines work post-move.\\n6. Communicate changes and migration instructions to customers, including deprecation of old package paths if needed.\\n7. Use the official SDK deprecation process for any retired packages.\\n\\nIf you have further questions or need help with automation or release planner, reach out to the [Azure SDK Onboarding channel](https://aka.ms/azsdk/support/onboarding-channel).\", \"ground_truth\": \"I think this should be a cross-language issue as in your tspconfig, the service-dir is sdk/playwrite which means all languages will generate the code under sdk/playwript. So you should update it in your tspconfig first. Then we can move the generated package into sdk/loadtesting folder in sdk repo\\ntspconfig:\\n```\\nparameters:\\n\\\"service-dir\\\":\\ndefault: \\\"sdk/playwright\\\"\\n```\\nFor Java, I see you already had a GA release in\\nhttps://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-java/tree/main/sdk/playwright/azure-resourcemanager-playwright\\nIf this is your SDK, please do not modify the directory on Java. If you update the service-dir in parameters, please add a line\\n```\\nservice-dir: sdk/playwright\\n```\\nunder \\\"@azure-tools/typespec-java\\\":\\nGenerally, diretory in Java repo follows your package name and namespace, which both is playwright. Unless your package be e.g. azure-resourcemanager-loadtesting-playwright, the folder won't be loadtesting.\"}"}]

rows.inputs.query:
title: Error running "npx prettier": Cannot find module 'prettier/plugins/estree'

question: $  npx prettier --write specification/maps/data-plane/Weather/stable/1.1/weather.json
[error] Cannot find module 'prettier/plugins/estree'
[error] Require stack:
[error] - C:\github\azure-rest-api-specs\eng\scripts\prettier-swagger-plugin.js
[error] - C:\github\azure-rest-api-specs\node_modules\prettier\index.js
[error] - C:\github\azure-rest-api-specs\node_modules\prettier\cli.js
[error] - C:\github\azure-rest-api-specs\node_modules\prettier\bin-prettier.js
rows.inputs.ground_truth:
you should't need to install prettier yourself in any way.  Just run npm ci from the specs repo root.
If you've installed prettier globally, using either npx prettier or npm install -g prettier, they might interfere.  I believe npm/npx are supposed to handle this, and prefer the local install from the specs repo, but maybe that wasn't happening on your dev machine.
rows.inputs.response:
This error is not directly related to TypeSpec, but it does affect the PR workflow for azure-rest-api-specs, which expects your OpenAPI/Swagger files to be formatted with Prettier before submission. The error message 'Cannot find module prettier/plugins/estree' typically indicates that your local Prettier installation is missing required dependencies, or that the Prettier version installed does not match the expected one by the repo (especially with custom plugins like 'prettier-swagger-plugin.js').

To resolve this:

1. Ensure you are using the correct Prettier version and that all dependencies are installed:
   - Run `git clean -xdf` in the root of your repo to remove all node_modules and build artifacts (note: this deletes all untracked files).
   - Run `npm ci` to install the exact versions specified in package-lock.json. This will ensure all required Prettier plugins (including any custom ones for Swagger) are installed.

2. After installation, re-run your prettier command:
   - `npx prettier --write specification/maps/data-plane/Weather/stable/1.1/weather.json`

3. If you still see errors, check that your repo is up to date:
   - Run `git pull` to ensure you have the latest scripts and configuration.

If problems persist, try cloning your repo into a new directory and repeat the steps above, as sometimes local environment issues can interfere.

This advice is consistent with the troubleshooting steps documented in the Azure REST API specs wiki for local validation and formatting. Prettier and its plugins must match what the CI expects, and a fresh npm install after cleaning out node_modules is the best way to ensure that.

For more details, refer to the 'Running Locally' section in the TypeSpec Validation wiki, which addresses similar issues for formatting and validation scripts.

[{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"design#api-design.md","document_title":"Create a high-level REST API design","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-design","content":"# design#api-design.md

# Create a high-level REST API design

> [!IMPORTANT]
> TypeSpec Azure usage for API definition is a mandatory requirement for all new (greenfield) data plane and management plane
> services. This requirement is enforced by the ARM API Review Board for management plane services and by the API
> Stewardship Board for data plane services.
> Brownfield services will eventually be required to transition to TypeSpec Azure as well.  PRs for brownfields services
> that have not transitioned to TypeSpec Azure will receive notices in FY2024, followed by warnings in FY2025 and
> errors in FY2027. The requirement to move to TypeSpec Azure will ensure a consistent, high-quality developer experience across
> Azure that aligns with Azure SDK guidelines. For more information on TypeSpec Azure, visit [here](xref:api-typespec).

## Why you need good a REST API design

Great APIs make your service usable to customers. They are intuitive, naturally reflecting and communicating the
underlying model and its behavior. They lend themselves easily to client library implementations in multiple
programming languages. And they don't "get in the way" of the developer, by remaining stable and predictable,
especially over time.

## Start with hero scenarios

Start the design process by identifying a small number of the most important *jobs to be done* by customers and how
these will be accomplished with the service. These are often called the *hero scenarios*.

Focusing on hero scenarios reduces development, support, and maintenance costs, enables teams to align and reach
consensus faster, and accelerates the time to delivery.

For example, a hero scenario for Azure Blob Storage could be:

> Upload the contents of a file to a new Azure Blob in an existing Blob Storage container.

## Define terms and concepts

After you identify the hero scenarios that you want to address, list the terms that describe any new abstractions
and relationships that you're introducing in your API design.

> [!NOTE]
> You'll need to show and describe any new concepts or terms during [REST API review](xref:api-review).

1. Define the terms and core concepts of your new service or feature.

Be sure to define simple, understandable abstractions with clear names that you use consistently throughout your API
and documentation. Keep in mind that the words that you use in your REST API design impact the content experience
for all other downstream customer-facing assets, such as SDK, CLI, product documentation, and Azure Portal
experiences.

Tip: Work with your PM and content developer to review new concepts or terms.

2. Keep a glossary of terms and definitions that describe the relationships between your resources.

## Follow the Azure API guidelines and conventions

Azure has established guidelines and conventions for REST API structure and style. It is important to adhere
to these guidelines wherever possible to ensure that customers have a consistent high-quality experience.

Here are links to the ARM and data plane REST API guidelines and associated resources.

- [ARM Resource Provider guidelines](https://armwiki.azurewebsites.net/api_contracts/guidelines/rpguidelines.html)
- [Azure REST API guidelines for data plane](https://aka.ms/azapi/guidelines)
- [Jeffrey Richter's YouTube series on REST API design](https://aka.ms/azapi/training)

## API boards office hours

### [Management plane (ARM)](#tab/management)

Review the **ARM API Modeling Office Hours** information [here](https://aka.ms/armofficehoursinfo).

### [Data plane (API Stewardship Board)](#tab/data)

| Short Link: | [aka.ms/azapi/officehours](https://aka.ms/azapi/officehours) |
| --- | --- |

The API Stewardship board is here to help! Join us for an informal chat to discuss our  
[REST API guidelines](https://aka.ms/azapi/guidelines), ask follow-up questions from a past review, or engage with
the board for the first time to create a personalized review plan.

WHEN: **1st through 3rd Wednesday of every month** at alternating times so our Azure Service teams around the globe can
get one-on-one advice about API design.

- 1st Wed of month - @10am PST
- 2nd Weds of month - @5pm PST
- 3rd Weds of month – @8am PST

**To attend**:

  1. Join the [API Stewardship Team]
  2. Go to our [REST API calendar] and join the office hours meeting."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"design#api-specs#api-typespec.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-specs/api-typespec","content":"# design#api-specs#api-typespec.md

| Short Link: | [aka.ms/azsdk/typespec](https://aka.ms/azsdk/typespec) |
| --- | --- |

# What is TypeSpec?

> [!IMPORTANT]
> TypeSpec Azure usage for API definition is a mandatory requirement for all new (greenfield) data plane and management plane
> services. This requirement is enforced by the ARM API Review Board for management plane services and by the API
> Stewardship Board for data plane services.
> Brownfield services will eventually be required to transition to TypeSpec Azure as well.  PRs for brownfields services
> that have not transitioned to TypeSpec Azure will receive notices in FY2024, followed by warnings in FY2025 and
> errors in FY2027. The requirement to move to TypeSpec Azure will ensure a consistent, high-quality developer experience across
> Azure that aligns with Azure SDK guidelines. For more information on TypeSpec Azure, visit [here](https://aka.ms/typespec/azure).

[TypeSpec](https://typespec.io) is the new standard API definition language for Azure, developed by Microsoft. It is an open-source tool designed to generate OpenAPI specifications and other API description languages. TypeSpec can also produce client code, with service code generation in progress. TypeSpec offers highly extensible core language primitives that can describe API shapes common among REST patterns used for Azure.

## Benefits of TypeSpec

- **Consistency across APIs**: TypeSpec ensures consistency across APIs by using high-level templates, reducing the need for repetitive tasks and minimizing errors. This uniform design approach acts as a single source of truth for API definitions, enhancing both consistency and quality.
- **Efficiency and speed**: TypeSpec significantly reduces the amount of code needed to define API specifications. A ten-line code snippet in TypeSpec can generate a hundred lines of an OpenAPI specification, drastically reducing manual effort.
- **Enhanced tooling**: TypeSpec comes with advanced tools that catch errors early, leading to more robust APIs. Additionally, extensions for [Visual Studio](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=typespec.typespecvs) and [VS Code](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=typespec.typespec-vscode) aid in efficient TypeSpec creation.
- **Accessibility**: The compact nature of TypeSpec, combined with its familiar JavaScript-style syntax, allows even non-technical stakeholders to participate in the API review and design process.

## Case Studies

Hear directly from teams who have successfully transitioned to TypeSpec Azure and learn about their experiences:

### Azure Batch

[Case Study](https://microsoft.sharepoint.com/:w:/t/AzureDeveloperExperience/EUkgwSc69lpPsBjQBfLfMEgB0WCTBe9x7ozU8VNK2s8mAw?e=1MIXZi)

> "There's definitions in Swagger, but … TypeSpec has much more flexibility when it comes to doing things like mix or not mixing in traits and defining core things that you export."
> "I want to highlight the tooling improvements, like not having to figure out how to install things locally [like Swagger tooling], having it all in the same tool set that includes the emitters and things like that is really nice. The VS code integration right out of the box is something I've really liked."

### MS Learn

[Case Study](https://microsoft.sharepoint.com/:w:/t/AzureDeveloperExperience/EXjQ3t7i-z9BpxVUgZVcS6QBxjLYdRLUquX2y8xczNxfbA?e=nesl3Q)

> “One of the highlights [of using TypeSpec] was our ability to author API specs in a very simple and intuitive language. This meant that even [our PMs] who are not engineers were able to understand these API specifications. They could review them, make comments, and participate in designing those APIs.”

### Azure AI Content Safety

[Case Study](https://microsoft.sharepoint.com/:w:/t/AzureDeveloperExperience/EdlE2PYtZ9BKoXQ-R0h-O10B9RidePBT4mwB1JgIqRC01A?e=JRneI2)

> "I find TypeSpec to be much simpler to learn and write compared to Swagger. In my experience, Swagger often encounters many conflicts due to its JSON format. TypeSpec proves to be a much better alternative as it allows everyone to work independently on their own sections, making it more user-friendly. Furthermore, TypeSpec allows for the separate definition of models and routes. So, from my perspective, it's a superior choice at present."

## Examples of TypeSpec Azure in Action

Whether you're working with Data Plane (DP) or Azure Resource Manager (ARM), having clear examples to follow can make your transition to TypeSpec smoother. Here are some resources that can help:

- **Playground Examples**: Our playground provides ARM and DP examples that serve as excellent models for teams new to TypeSpec Azure. These examples are concise and take full advantage of our standard operation templates. You can use these as a gold standard for your own TypeSpec definitions. Visit the [TypeSpec Azure Playground](https://aka.ms/trytypespec/azure) to explore these examples.
- **ARM Samples**: For more specific scenarios, check out our additional [ARM samples](https://github.com/Azure/typespec-azure/tree/main/packages/samples/specs/resource-manager/arm-scenarios). These are tutorial-like examples that cover various scenarios. You can adapt these to fit your specific needs.

The playground examples are a great starting point for getting familiar with TypeSpec Azure. As you gain more experience, you can leverage the ARM samples to understand how to apply TypeSpec to a variety of scenarios.

## TypeSpec office hours

Join us on Mondays from 4-5 PM PT for our TypeSpec office hours. These sessions are designed to answer your questions and offer guidance on using TypeSpec Azure effectively. You can find the invite in the calendar in the [TypeSpec Discussion Teams Channel](https://aka.ms/typespec/discussions).

## Resources

- [TypeSpec Azure Docs](https://aka.ms/typespec/azure): A comprehensive guide to using TypeSpec in Azure.
- [TypeSpec tutorial](https://aka.ms/typespec/getstarted): TypeSpec tutorial to define REST APIs with HTTP.
- [TypeSpec Azure Playground](https://aka.ms/trytypespec/azure): An interactive platform to experiment with TypeSpec.
- [Getting Started with TypeSpec in azure-rest-api-specs repo](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/documentation/Getting-started-with-TypeSpec-specifications.md): A step-by-step guide to getting started with TypeSpec.
- [Tool converting OpenAPI specs to TypeSpec](https://aka.ms/typespec/migrate): A handy tool to help you transition from OpenAPI to TypeSpec.

## Get help

If you need help or have questions, join the [TypeSpec Discussion Teams channel](https://aka.ms/typespec/discussions).  
This is a community of TypeSpec users and experts who are ready to assist you.

### Azure SDK Q&A Bot

The TypeSpec Discussion Teams channel includes an Azure SDK Q&A Bot that is designed to help you with questions  
related to TypeSpec, Azure TypeSpec, and the related emitters. Simply mention `@Azure SDK Q&A Bot` directly in your  
message with a clear description of the problem you're facing.

**Example usage:**

```
@Azure SDK Q&A Bot: How can I describe HTTP status codes for responses in TypeSpec?
```

**Best practices for using the bot:**

- Start a conversation by mentioning `@Azure SDK Q&A Bot` in the TypeSpec Discussion Teams channel - note that  
  modifying existing posts won't trigger a response
- The bot only has context from messages that directly mention it and cannot access or see messages outside of that  
  context
- It supports images and GitHub pull request links for better context
- All replies are generated by AI, so please double-check to ensure the information is correct"},{"document_source":"azure_resource_manager_rpc","document_filename":"v1.0#common-api-details.md","document_title":"Common API Details","document_link":"https://github.com/cloud-and-ai-microsoft/resource-provider-contract/blob/master/v1.0/common-api-details.md","content":"# v1.0#common-api-details.md

The resource provider proxy will preserve all the client requests headers, with the exception of modifications per the details below. The headers below are reserved and cannot be set by clients.
