## Client Request Headers ##

Any non-reserved headers provided by the client will pass as-is to the resource provider. All requests to resource providers may include the following standard headers and **must** be supported:

| Header | Description |
| --- | --- |
| Content-Type | Set to application/json. This header is not sent in requests that don't have any content, such as all GET calls. |
| Accept-Language | Specifies the preferred language for the response; all RPs should use this header when generating error messages or client facing text. |
| x-ms-client-request-id | Caller-specified value identifying the request, in the form of a GUID with no decoration such as curly braces (e.g. `client-request-id: 9C4D50EE-2D56-4CD3-8152-34347DC9F2B0`). If the caller provides this header – the resource provider **must** log this with their traces to facilitate tracing a single request. If specified, this will be included in response information as a way to map the request if "x-ms-return-client-request-id"; is specified as "true". Because this header can be client-generated, it should not be assumed to be unique by the RP implementation. |
| x-ms-correlation-request-id | Optional. Caller-specified value identifying a set of related operations that the request belongs to, in the form of a GUID. If the caller does not specify this header, ARM will randomly generate a unique GUID. Used for tracing the correlation Id of the request; the resource provider **must** log this so that end-to-end requests can be correlated across Azure. Because this header can be client-generated or re-used for multiple requests, it should not be assumed to be unique by the RP implementation. |
| x-ms-return-client-request-id | Optional. True or false and indicates if a client-request-id should be included in the response. Default is false. |

## Request Query Parameters ##

ARM will proxy request parameters (e.g. $filter; $expand; $skipToken; etc.) as-is to the Resource Providers. It will not delete, modify or add any query parameters before relaying the request. The only exceptions are the following query parameters which are not supported on requests into ARM and will cause the request to be rejected with a 400 status code:

- `sub`
- `subId`
- `subscription`
- `subscriptionId`

## Case Insensitivity for Requests ##

When satisfying incoming requests, it is assumed that the following values are stored / indexed / compared in a case **insensitive** way:

- Resource group name
- Resource name
- Other names of entities in the URL, even if they are not resources.

## Client Request Timeout ##

Requests proxied to the resource provider are made with a client timeout of 60 seconds. If requests take more than 60 seconds please consider using asynchronous request/response pattern.

The resource provider must respond within that time interval or the client will receive a 504 (timeout) error code and will not see the response from the RP.

## Request Throttling ##

ARM provides subscription level throttling. More details on these limits can be found [here](https://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/documentation/articles/azure-subscription-service-limits/#overview).

## Common API Response Details ##

### Response Headers ###

All responses from resource providers should include the following headers:

| Header | Description |
| --- | --- |
| `Content-Type` | Set to application/json. This header is not required in responses that don't have any content. |
| `Date` | The date that the request was processed, in RFC 1123 format. |
| `x-ms-request-id` | A unique identifier for the current operation, service generated. All the resource providers \*must\* return this value in the response headers to facilitate debugging. |
| `x-ms-failurecause` | An ___optional___ header used to provide additional failure attribution on error responses. See [below](#x-ms-failurecause-header) for additional information. |

All long running operations response details are described below.

## Instrumentation and Tracing across services ##

Resource providers should associate the correlation Id and client request Id with all of their management operations.

This will enable end-to-end troubleshooting from the portal, through CSM and to the RP, via four key headers:

1. x-ms-client-request-id: associated with a logical action in the client; e.g. loading the portal monitoring part may have a single client request id for many calls to ARM (e.g. load VMs + load metric definitions + load metrics)
2. x-ms-correlation-request-id: associated with a logical action in ARM; e.g. deleting a resource group or running a template
3. x-ms-request-id: returned by the RP per request; typically maps to the RP's ActivityId
4. x-ms-routing-request-id: maps to ARM's activity id (which is not otherwise exposed). This maps to implementation boundaries in ARM / the platform –RPs should not use this as their ActivityId.

## ETags for Resources ##

ETags may be returned for individual resources, and then sent via If-Match / If-None-Match headers for concurrency control. The resource provider is responsible for storing and validating ETags – the frontdoor will never inspect these values.

The behavior for ETags can be seen below:

| PUT | Resource does not exist | Resource exists |
| --- | --- | --- |
| If-Match = "" / absent | 201 Created | 200 OK |
| If-Match = "\*" | 412* Precondition Failed | 200 OK |
| If-Match = "xyz" | 412** Precondition Failed | 200 OK / 412 Precondition Failed |
| If-None-Match = "\*" | 201 Created | 412**** Precondition Failed |


| PATCH | Resource does not exist | Resource exists |
| --- | --- | --- |
| If-Match = "" / absent | 404 Not Found | 200 OK |
| If-Match = "\*" | 404** Not Found | 200 OK |
| If-Match = "xyz" | 404** Not Found | 200 OK / 412 Precondition Failed |

| DELETE | Resource does not exist | Resource exists |
| --- | --- | --- |
| If-Match = "" / absent | 204 No Content | 200 OK |
| If-Match = "\*" | 204*** No Content | 200 OK |
| If-Match = "xyz" | 204*** No Content | 200 OK / 412 Precondition Failed |

## Regional Endpoints ##

The Resource Provider should partition services across multiple regions in order to allow for continued service if there is a regional outage. It is recommended that the RP offer services in all Azure supported regions so that users may collocate interdependent resources within a resource group.

The RP should register all the regions that they support, and should provide a different regional endpoint for each region. This regional endpoint and its backing state/data should be isolated from the other regions in order to isolate failure within Azure. ARM will proxy the request to the appropriate region based on the resource's location.

The resource provider should register regional DNS names for each regional endpoint. The naming of this region should follow the below convention:

1. {region}.{provider namespace}.azure.com
2. {region}.{subservice name}.{provider namespace}.azure.com

In a concrete form:

1. westus.cache.api.azure.com, eastus.cache.api.azure.com
2. westus.redis.cache.api.azure.com

If a Resource Provider is creating resources on behalf of a customer the resource location should match the location of the resource group. This will co-locate the resource data in the RP and the resource metadata in ARM within the same region thus reducing the exposure to regional failures.

## Resource Group Deletes ##

If the resource group containing resources is deleted, the RP will receive a DELETE call on each individual tracked resource in that group. In some cases, the resources will have interdependencies and therefore can only be deleted in a certain order that ARM does not understand.

To address this, ARM can simply ask each resource to delete in arbitrary order. If the resource refuses the deletion, then ARM will revisit it after trying to delete the rest of the group's resources. It will continue to revisit resources until all tracked resources are deleted, or there is no further delete progress (for example if a delete fails because of an ACL).

As a result, it is essential that the RPs follow proper REST guidelines when returning 2xx for a successful delete, and 4xx for a delete that is invalid (until a related resource is deleted first).

## Retrying REST Calls ##

The recommended pattern for REST clients is to retry calls that:

1. Return 408 indicating a request timeout;
2. Return a 5xx status code indicating a server failure (e.g. 500 InternalServerError; 503 Service Unavailable);
3. Experience a socket exception (e.g. DNS resolution failures; network drop; no listening socket).
4. Any other response where a Retry-After header is present.

The retry interval, strategy (e.g. exponential/linear) and max timeout should be defined by the _server_ and not the client. The server indicates how long it expects the client to wait before retrying the call by including a (Retry-After header)[https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7231#section-7.1.3] in the response. That allows various server workloads to advertise different retry policies.

## Designing Resources ##

3. If the objects have an independent lifetime but are not important to the model, they should only be top-level resources if no other design can be made to work.

**Objects should be nested resources if:**

1. They meet the guidelines for Azure resources above (billable, orchestration supported, taggable)
2. Their lifetime is dependent on a containing resource

**Objects should be proxy only resources if:**

1. They don't need to be Azure resources for one of the reasons above
2. if the objects/properties are required for the parent resource to be created, then they should \*not\* be Azure resources
3. It is important that they be simple to create in context of a containing resource.
4. The lifecycle of the resources are managed outside ARM (e.g. agent based discovery).
5. They are very common and would incur a performance overhead on the system (for example by cluttering the indices and GET resources calls)

**Comparison of Tracked Resources and proxy only Resources**

| ​ **Feature** | ​ **Tracked Resources** | ​ **Proxy only Resources** |
| --- | --- | --- |
| ​Understood by template processor | ​Yes | ​ Yes |
| Can be top-level resource | Yes | Only if global/single region |
| Defined JSON format to payload | ​Yes -- must comply with general Azure resource format (id, type, name, tags, properties, location etc.) | ​Yes -- must comply with general Azure resource format (id, type, name, properties, etc.) but no tags or location |
| Defined URL format | ​Yes -- must use providers/{namespace}/{typename} URL | ​Yes -- must use providers/{namespace}/{typename} URL |
| ​Tagging and Indexing supported | ​Yes | ​No |
| ​Billing supported     | ​Yes | ​No |
| ​Have their own URLs | ​Yes | ​Yes |
| ​​Can be PUT (created) with the parent in a single call | ​No - $batch/deep insert not available | ​​Yes, see deep insert recommendation |
| ​Supports RBAC | ​Yes -- based on URL     | ​ Yes -- based on URL |
| ​

The Azure Resource Provider contract and template language have special semantics around "registered" Azure resources – we call these **tracked resources**.

If these objects are addressable by URIs but not "registered", we call these **proxy only** resources to differentiate them.

**Background REST philosophy**

1. Azure API guideline compliant and OData compliant where it makes sense.
2. APIs must be callable from any client implementation, language or framework.
3. Making things simple and regular for machine processing often makes things easier for humans to understand, even when it increases verbosity.
4. When we choose between understandable URLs and understandable templates, we should make the templates human understandable and the URLs machine consumable.
5. Everything that is possible from a template should be possible through imperative APIs, but not necessarily as easily and may require special client code (orchestration is an obvious example).

**Objects should be Tracked resources if:**

1. They are billable entities, including freemium models
2. Need to be orchestrated by the template execution engine
3. Related to above, they have dependencies on other resources

**Objects should be top-level resources if:**

1. They should be resources as per above
2. Their lifetime is independent of other resources (only dependent on the containing resource group)
3. If the objects have an independent lifetime but are not important to the model, they should only be top-level resources if no other design can be made to work.

**Objects should be nested resources if:**

1. They meet the guidelines for Azure resources above (billable, orchestration supported, taggable)
2. Their lifetime is dependent on a containing resource

**Objects should be proxy only resources if:**

1. They don't need to be Azure resources for one of the reasons above

## Introduction

These guidelines apply to Azure service teams implementing _data plane_ APIs. They offer prescriptive guidance that Azure service teams MUST follow ensuring that customers have a great experience by designing APIs meeting these goals:
- Developer friendly via consistent patterns & web standards (HTTP, REST, JSON)
- Efficient & cost-effective
- Work well with SDKs in many programming languages
- Customers can create fault-tolerant apps by supporting retries/idempotency/optimistic concurrency
- Sustainable & versionable via clear API contracts with 2 requirements:
  1. Customer workloads must never break due to a service change
  2. Customers can adopt a version without requiring code changes

Technology and software is constantly changing and evolving, and as such, this is intended to be a living document. [Open an issue](https://github.com/microsoft/api-guidelines/issues/new/choose) to suggest a change or propose a new idea. Please read the [Considerations for Service Design](./ConsiderationsForServiceDesign.md) for an introduction to the topic of API design for Azure services. *For an existing GA'd service, don't change/break its existing API; instead, leverage these concepts for future APIs while prioritizing consistency within your existing service.*

*Note: If you are creating a management plane (ARM) API, please refer to the [Azure Resource Manager Resource Provider Contract](https://github.com/cloud-and-ai-microsoft/resource-provider-contract).*

### Prescriptive Guidance

This document offers prescriptive guidance labeled as follows:

:white_check_mark: **DO** adopt this pattern. If you feel you need an exception, contact the Azure HTTP/REST Stewardship Board **prior** to implementation.

:ballot_box_with_check: **YOU SHOULD** adopt this pattern. If not following this advice, you MUST disclose your reason during the Azure HTTP/REST Stewardship Board review.

:heavy_check_mark: **YOU MAY** consider this pattern if appropriate to your situation. No notification to the Azure HTTP/REST Stewardship Board is required.

:warning: **YOU SHOULD NOT** adopt this pattern. If not following this advice, you MUST disclose your reason during the Azure HTTP/REST Stewardship Board review.

:no_entry: **DO NOT** adopt this pattern. If you feel you need an exception, contact the Azure HTTP/REST Stewardship Board **prior** to implementation.

*If you feel you need an exception, or need clarity based on your situation, please contact the Azure HTTP/REST Stewardship Board **prior** to release of your API.*

## Building Blocks: HTTP, REST, & JSON

The Microsoft Azure Cloud platform exposes its APIs through the core building blocks of the Internet; namely HTTP, REST, and JSON. This section provides you with a general understanding of how these technologies should be applied when creating your service.

<a href="#http" name="http"></a>

### HTTP

case-sensitive, multiple delimiter
UUID      | 123e4567-e89b-12d3-a456-426614174000 (no {}s, hyphens, case-insensitive) [RFC 4122](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc4122)
Date/Time (Header) | Sun, 06 Nov 1994 08:49:37 GMT [RFC 7231, Section 7.1.1.1](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc7231#section-7.1.1.1)
Date/Time (Query parameter) | YYYY-MM-DDTHH:mm:ss.sssZ (with at most 3 digits of fractional seconds) [RFC 3339](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc3339)
Byte array | Base-64 encoded, max length
Array      | One of a) a comma-separated list of values (preferred), or b) separate `name=value` parameter instances for each value of the array


The table below lists the headers most used by Azure services:

Header Key          | Applies to | Example
------------------- | ---------- | -------------
_authorization_     | Request    | Bearer eyJ0...Xd6j (Support Azure Active Directory)
_x-ms-useragent_    | Request    | (see [Distributed Tracing & Telemetry](#distributed-tracing--telemetry))
traceparent         | Request    | (see [Distributed Tracing & Telemetry](#distributed-tracing--telemetry))
tracecontext        | Request    | (see [Distributed Tracing & Telemetry](#distributed-tracing--telemetry))
accept              | Request    | application/json
If-Match            | Request    | "67ab43" or * (no quotes) (see [Conditional Requests](#conditional-requests))
If-None-Match       | Request    | "67ab43" or * (no quotes) (see [Conditional Requests](#conditional-requests))
If-Modified-Since   | Request    | Sun, 06 Nov 1994 08:49:37 GMT (see [Conditional Requests](#conditional-requests))
If-Unmodified-Since | Request    | Sun, 06 Nov 1994 08:49:37 GMT (see [Conditional Requests](#conditional-requests))
date                | Both       | Sun, 06 Nov 1994 08:49:37 GMT (see [RFC 7231, Section 7.1.1.2](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc7231#section-7.1.1.2))
_content-type_      | Both       | application/merge-patch+json

name="http-header-names-casing">:white_check_mark:</a> **DO** specify headers using kebab-casing

<a href="#http-header-names-case-sensitivity" name="http-header-names-case-sensitivity">:white_check_mark:</a> **DO** compare request header names using case-insensitivity

<a href="#http-header-values-case-sensitivity" name="http-header-values-case-sensitivity">:white_check_mark:</a> **DO** compare request header values using case-sensitivity if the header name requires it

<a href="#http-header-date-values" name="http-header-date-values">:white_check_mark:</a> **DO** accept date values in headers in HTTP-Date format and return date values in headers in the IMF-fixdate format as defined in [RFC 7231, Section 7.1.1.1](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc7231#section-7.1.1.1), e.g. "Sun, 06 Nov 1994 08:49:37 GMT".

Note: The RFC 7231 IMF-fixdate format is a "fixed-length and single-zone subset" of the RFC 1123 / RFC 5822 format, which means: a) year must be four digits, b) the seconds component of time is required, and c) the timezone must be GMT.

<a href="#http-header-request-id" name="http-header-request-id">:white_check_mark:</a> **DO** create an opaque value that uniquely identifies the request and return this value in the `x-ms-request-id` response header.

Your service should include the `x-ms-request-id` value in error logs so that users can submit support requests for specific failures using this value.

<a href="#http-allow-unrecognized-headers" name="http-allow-unrecognized-headers">:no_entry:</a> **DO NOT** fail a request that contains an unrecognized header. Headers may be added by API gateways or middleware and this must be tolerated

<a href="#http-no-x-custom-headers" name="http-no-x-custom-headers">:no_entry:</a> **DO NOT** use "x-" prefix for custom headers, unless the header already exists in production [[RFC 6648](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc6648)].

**Additional References**

Azure services must adhere to the HTTP specification, [RFC 7231](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc7231). This section further refines and constrains how service implementors should apply the constructs defined in the HTTP specification. It is therefore, important that you have a firm understanding of the following concepts:

- [Uniform Resource Locators (URLs)](#uniform-resource-locators-urls)
- [HTTP Request / Response Pattern](#http-request--response-pattern)
- [HTTP Query Parameters and Header Values](#http-query-parameters-and-header-values)

#### Uniform Resource Locators (URLs)

A Uniform Resource Locator (URL) is how developers access the resources of your service. Ultimately, URLs are how developers form a cognitive model of your service's resources.

<a href="#http-url-pattern" name="http-url-pattern">:white_check_mark:</a> **DO** use this URL pattern:
```text
https://<tenant>.<region>.<service>.<cloud>/<service-root>/<resource-collection>/<resou"},{"document_source":"static_typespec_qa","document_filename":"typespec_2025_06_26.md","document_title":"Untitled","document_link":"","content":"# typespec_2025_06_26.md

# Untitled

## question

Hi All, the 'tsp compile .' command is throwing the following error. Could anyone kindly help with resolving the error? 
error file-load: Package subpath './experimental' is not defined by "exports" in C:\VSTS\PDG\ActiveGlossary\typespec\node_modules\@typespec\http\package.json imported from C:\VSTS\PDG\ActiveGlossary\typespec\node_modules\@typespec\rest\dist\src\rest.js
error file-load: Package subpath './experimental' is not defined by "exports" in C:\VSTS\PDG\ActiveGlossary\typespec\node_modules\@typespec\http\package.json imported from C:\VSTS\PDG\ActiveGlossary\typespec\node_modules\@typespec\rest\dist\src\rest.js
error file-load: Package subpath './typekit' is not defined by "exports" in C:\VSTS\PDG\ActiveGlossary\typespec\node_modules\@typespec\compiler\package.json imported from C:\VSTS\PDG\ActiveGlossary\typespec\node_modules\@azure-tools\typespec-azure-core\dist\src\decorators.js
error import-not-found: Couldn't resolve import "@azure-tools/typespec-autorest"

Hi All, when I run the tsp-client convert --swagger-readme .\spec.json command, it throws this error
 
error   | Autorest completed with an error. If you think the error message is unclear, or is a bug, please declare an issues at https://github.com/Azure/autorest/issues with the error message you are seeing.
error   | invalidType | Expected a boolean but got object: { title: 'Purview Data Catalog Client', version: '2023-10-01-preview' }
    - file:///C:/VSTS/PDG/ActiveGlossary/typespec/spec.json:3:3

## answer

This seems like you have an issue with the dependencies you have installed. Did you get any error when using npm install? What versions are you using? Try a fresh install (delete node_modules first).

These are not compatible. Please upgrade to the latest or make sure you are using versions that match if you can't for now.

For the latest, you can look on npm: https://www.npmjs.com/package/@typespec/compiler
Or at the bottom of the repo: https://github.com/microsoft/typespec

There are 3 version groups you need to know since we are at 1.0:

Stable packages: 1.x (compiler, http, openapi, openapi3)

Core preview packages: 0.y (rest, versioning, stream, see)

Azure packages: 0.z (all Azure packages)
All packages in the same group have the same major.minor version.

If you are in the spec repo, read this doc for next steps:
https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/documentation/typespec-rest-api-dev-process.md

You should use the `readme.md`, not the swagger file, as input.
Refer to the migration guide: https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/migrate-swagger/01-get-started/

Do you have a `readme.md` or another autorest markdown configuration file?
Is that spec part of the Azure REST API spec repo?
Did you actually run the command using the `readme.md` as input?

Try running `autorest <readme>`.
Also, your `spec.json` must be a valid Swagger file — from the error, you likely have a name mismatch (casing issue).

You can validate the Swagger file at: https://editor.swagger.io/ — that’s a good place to start.
But be aware: Autorest imposes additional restrictions, so you may need to keep running `autorest` or `tsp-client convert` repeatedly until the spec passes."},{"document_source":"static_typespec_qa","document_filename":"typespec_2025_06_26.md","document_title":"SecurityDefinitionsStructure error on PR","document_link":"","content":"# typespec_2025_06_26.md

## Clean PR against main
If you're fairly certain there should be no conflicting changes in files you added or modified in the release branch,
you can most often just create a pull request (PR) against `main` on  
[Azure/azure-rest-api-specs](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs).

1. Go to your branch in [Azure/azure-rest-api-specs](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs) or  
   [Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr). Read more about  
   [our repositories](xref:api-repos) for what is public and what is private.

2. If you do not already see an open PR in the upper-right just above the list of files, click **Contribute** and click
   **Open pull request** to open a new one.

3. Select either the **Control Plane (ARM) API** or **Data Plane API** PR template, depending on the type of REST API
spec updates you are submitting.

## Spec repos branches
### Private specs repo `RPSaaSMaster` branch
[Private specs repo] `RPSaaSMaster` contains RPaaS-based ARM specifications.

When an RPaaS-based ARM API goes into `public preview` or `GA` lifecycle stage it must be merged to [public specs repo]
`main` as well.

Some parts of this branch are being mirrored from public `main` branch
by the [mirror-repos] pipeline, triggered manually on at least daily basis.

Service teams are responsible for keeping their API specifications in this branch synchronized with
the public specs repo `main` branch.

See also [ARM lifecycle stages requirements] and [ARM branches]."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"design#api-specs-pr#pr-move-private-to-public.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-specs-pr/pr-move-private-to-public","content":"| Short Link: | [aka.ms/azsdk/move-pr](https://aka.ms/azsdk/move-pr) |

## System Metadata for all Azure resources ##
As of 2020, all Azure resources may implement a read-only `systemData` object property in the top-level envelope. 

```
{
  "id": "/subscriptions/{id}/resourceGroups/{group}/providers/{rpns}/{type}/{name}",
  "name": "{name}",
  "type": "{resourceProviderNamespace}/{resourceType}",
  "location": "North US",
  "systemData":{
      "createdBy": "<string>",
      "createdByType": "<User|Application|ManagedIdentity|Key>",
      "createdAt": "<date-time>",
      "lastModifiedBy": "<string>",
      "lastModifiedByType": "<User|Application|ManagedIdentity|Key>",
      "lastModifiedAt": "<date-time>"
  },
  "tags": {
    "key1": "value 1",
    "key2": "value 2"
  },
  "kind": "resource kind",
  "properties": {
    "comment": "Resource defined structure"
  }
}
```"},{"document_source":"azure_api_guidelines","document_filename":"azure#VersioningGuidelines.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://github.com/microsoft/api-guidelines/blob/vNext/azure/VersioningGuidelines.md","content":"# Azure Versioning Guidelines
## Guidelines
**DO** remove retired API versions from the azure-rest-api-specs repo.

:white_check_mark: **DO** review any change to service behavior that could disrupt customers with the Azure Breaking Changes review board, even if the change is not part of the API definition.

Some examples of behavior changes that must be reviewed are:
- Introducing or changing rate limits to be more restrictive than previously
- Changing the permissions required to successfully execute an operation

:no_entry: **DO NOT** change the behavior of an API version that is available to customers either in public preview or GA.
Changes in behavior should always be introduced in a new API version, with prior versions working as before.

:no_entry: **DO NOT** introduce breaking changes from a prior GA version just to satisfy ARM or Azure API guidelines.

Avoiding breaking changes in a GA API takes precedence over adherence to API guidelines and resolving linter errors.

:no_entry: **DO NOT** keep a preview feature in preview for more than 1 year; it must go GA (or be removed) within 1 year after introduction."},{"document_source":"typespec_docs","document_filename":"libraries#http#reference#data-types.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://typespec.io/docs/libraries/http/reference/data-types","content":"# Data types
## TypeSpec.Http
### `ApiKeyAuth` {#TypeSpec.Http.ApiKeyAuth}
An API key is a token that a client provides when making API calls. The key can be sent in the query string:

```
GET /something?api_key=abcdef12345
```

or as a request header

```
GET /something HTTP/1.1
X-API-Key: abcdef12345
```

or as a cookie

```
GET /something HTTP/1.1
Cookie: X-API-KEY=abcdef12345
```

```typespec
model TypeSpec.Http.ApiKeyAuth<Location, Name>
```

#### Template Parameters

| Name     | Description                 |
| -------- | --------------------------- |
| Location | The location of the API key |
| Name     | The name of the API key     |

#### Properties

| Name | Type                            | Description |
| ---- | ------------------------------- | ----------- |
| type | `TypeSpec.Http.AuthType.apiKey` |             |
| in   | `Location`                      |             |
| name | `Name`                          |             |"},{"document_source":"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki","document_filename":"Azure-REST-API,-SDK-development-process-with-TypeSpec.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Azure-REST-API,-SDK-development-process-with-TypeSpec","content":"# Azure REST API, SDK development process with TypeSpec
## Table Of Content
### 4. Prepare and submit a Pull Request for reviewing
5. Generate OpenAPI files:
   - sync with the target branch in the azure-rest-api-specs repo
      ```git
       git pull upstream <target-branch>
      ```
   - in the root directory, run `npm install`
   - in the project directory, `npx tsp compile`. This will generate OpenAPI files under `{service}` folders.
6. Ensure all generated files under `{service}` have been added to PR.
7. Send a pull request .
   - commit all your changes.
   - push your branch to your fork of the repo.
   - send a pull request to the original repo from your forked repo.
   See the ARM Wiki for information on the [supported repos and branches for management-plane services](https://armwiki.azurewebsites.net/rpaas/swaggeronboarding.html#supported-github-reposbranches).
#### 4.1 Fix the errors of PR reviewing CI checks
The CI checks result will be commented on the PR. you can refer to the [CI fix Guide](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/documentation/ci-fix.md).
Note:
Since the OpenAPI is generated from TypeSpec, to change the OpenAPI, you must update the TypeSpec file and regenerate the
 OpenAPI and avoid updating OpenAPI directly to keep the consistency between OpenAPI and TypeSpec.
For support & help, you can post a message to [TypeSpec Discussion - teams channel](https://teams.microsoft.com/l/channel/19%3A906c1efbbec54dc8949ac736633e6bdf%40thread.skype/TypeSpec%20Discussion?groupId=3e17dcb0-4257-4a30-b843-77f47f1d4121&tenantId=72f988bf-86f1-41af-91ab-2d7cd011db47)."},{"document_source":"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki","document_filename":"TypeSpec-Validation.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/TypeSpec-Validation","content":"# Running Locally
To ensure you see the same results from TypeSpecValidation in your PR check and `tsv` on your local machine:
1. Merge latest from parent (e.g. `main` or `RPSaaSMaster`) to your PR branch
2. Run locally
   1. `git clean -xdf` (may revert any local changes)
   2. `git pull`
   3. `npm ci`
   4. `npx tsv specification/widget/resource-manager/Microsoft.Widget/Widget`
   5. `git status`
   6. If any changes, `git add`, `git commit`, `git push` to update your PR.
3. If you are still having problems, try cloning your branch to a new folder, or try on another machine.
4. If the problem can be reproduced on a clean machine, request assistance from the [TypeSpec Discussion](https://teams.microsoft.com/l/channel/19%3A906c1efbbec54dc8949ac736633e6bdf%40thread.skype/TypeSpec%20Discussion?groupId=3e17dcb0-4257-4a30-b843-77f47f1d4121&tenantId=72f988bf-86f1-41af-91ab-2d7cd011db47) teams channel."},{"document_source":"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki","document_filename":"Specification-Glossary.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Specification-Glossary","content":"# Glossary
## Service
An Azure service is a set of operations that version uniformly (in perpetuity). See [Azure Service Versioning Guide] for more details.
In specs repository, an ARM service has a path of form:
`specification/<organization>/resource-manager/<RPNS>/<service>`
A data-plane service has a path of form:
`specification/<organization>/data-plane/<service>`
> [!NOTE]
> Some existing services follow different directory structure layouts.
> All such layouts are legacy, deprecated, and strongly discouraged going forward.
For example, [`specification/containerservice/resource-manager/Microsoft.ContainerService/aks`]
is a folder for the `aks` service within the `Microsoft.ContainerService` ARM Resource Provider namespace.
You can learn more about how a `service` maps to its directory in the [directory structure article]."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"design#api-specs-pr#api-versions-and-branches.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-specs-pr/api-versions-and-branches","content":"# API versions and branches
## Branch protection rules table
This table serves as a quick summary. Read the rest of the article for details.

This table shows which GitHub checks are marked as `required` on respective branches. Even when a check is marked as ❌
it **may** still be running on given branch; just that if it fails, the PR won't be blocked from merging.

| Branch | Merge | SDK | TSVal | BrCh | BrChC | LintRPaaS | LintDiff | Model | Semantic | Spell | Prettier | license | approver |
|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|
| public `main`                  | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ |
| private `RPSaaSMaster`         | ✅ | ❌ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ |
| public/private `release-*`     | ✅ | ❌ | ✅ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ |
| private `RPSaaSDev`            | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ✅ |
| private `InternalARMContracts` | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ✅ |
| private `ARMCoreRPDev`         | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ✅ |

Legend:

| Column name | Full GitHub check name               |
|-------------|--------------------------------------|
| `BrCh`      | `Swagger BreakingChange`             |
| `BrChC`     | `Breaking Change(Cross-Version)`     |
| `license`   | `license/cla`                        |
| `LintDiff`  | `Swagger LintDiff`                   |

| `SDK`       | `SDK azure-sdk-for-go`               |

| `Spell`     | `SpellCheck`                         |
| `TSVal`     | `TypeScript Validation`              |
| `approver`  | Requires team member approval        |

For more information on these checks, see:

## Enable SDK generation
### [TypeSpec](#tab/typespec)
Add the specific SDK language emitter settings to `tspconfig.yaml`. For example, to generate CSharp SDK code from your TypeSpecs:

1. Add `@azure-tools/typespec-csharp` to the `options` settings in `tspconfig.yaml`.
2. Refer to the 'ContosoWidgetManager' samples to set the default values for each SDK language emitter:
    - For management plane TypeSpecs, refer to [Contoso.Management tspconfig.yaml](https://aka.ms/azsdk/tspconfig-sample-mpg).
    - For data plane TypeSpecs, refer to [Contoso.WidgetManager tspconfig.yaml](https://aka.ms/azsdk/tspconfig-sample-dpg).

````
"@azure-tools/typespec-csharp":
    flavor: azure
    package-dir: "Azure.ResourceManager.Contoso"
    clear-output-folder: true
    model-namespace: true
    namespace: "{package-dir}"
````"}]

rows.outputs.similarity.similarity_sample_inp: [{"role": "user", "content": "{\"query\": \"title: Error running \\\"npx prettier\\\": Cannot find module 'prettier/plugins/estree'\\n\\nquestion: $  npx prettier --write specification/maps/data-plane/Weather/stable/1.1/weather.json\\n[error] Cannot find module 'prettier/plugins/estree'\\n[error] Require stack:\\n[error] - C:\\\\github\\\\azure-rest-api-specs\\\\eng\\\\scripts\\\\prettier-swagger-plugin.js\\n[error] - C:\\\\github\\\\azure-rest-api-specs\\\\node_modules\\\\prettier\\\\index.js\\n[error] - C:\\\\github\\\\azure-rest-api-specs\\\\node_modules\\\\prettier\\\\cli.js\\n[error] - C:\\\\github\\\\azure-rest-api-specs\\\\node_modules\\\\prettier\\\\bin-prettier.js\", \"response\": \"This error is not directly related to TypeSpec, but it does affect the PR workflow for azure-rest-api-specs, which expects your OpenAPI/Swagger files to be formatted with Prettier before submission. The error message 'Cannot find module prettier/plugins/estree' typically indicates that your local Prettier installation is missing required dependencies, or that the Prettier version installed does not match the expected one by the repo (especially with custom plugins like 'prettier-swagger-plugin.js').\\n\\nTo resolve this:\\n\\n1. Ensure you are using the correct Prettier version and that all dependencies are installed:\\n   - Run `git clean -xdf` in the root of your repo to remove all node_modules and build artifacts (note: this deletes all untracked files).\\n   - Run `npm ci` to install the exact versions specified in package-lock.json. This will ensure all required Prettier plugins (including any custom ones for Swagger) are installed.\\n\\n2. After installation, re-run your prettier command:\\n   - `npx prettier --write specification/maps/data-plane/Weather/stable/1.1/weather.json`\\n\\n3. If you still see errors, check that your repo is up to date:\\n   - Run `git pull` to ensure you have the latest scripts and configuration.\\n\\nIf problems persist, try cloning your repo into a new directory and repeat the steps above, as sometimes local environment issues can interfere.\\n\\nThis advice is consistent with the troubleshooting steps documented in the Azure REST API specs wiki for local validation and formatting. Prettier and its plugins must match what the CI expects, and a fresh npm install after cleaning out node_modules is the best way to ensure that.\\n\\nFor more details, refer to the 'Running Locally' section in the TypeSpec Validation wiki, which addresses similar issues for formatting and validation scripts.\", \"ground_truth\": \"you should't need to install prettier yourself in any way.  Just run npm ci from the specs repo root.\\nIf you've installed prettier globally, using either npx prettier or npm install -g prettier, they might interfere.  I believe npm/npx are supposed to handle this, and prefer the local install from the specs repo, but maybe that wasn't happening on your dev machine.\"}"}]

rows.inputs.query:
title: Error writing to PR in RPSAASDev branch

question: I'm seeing an error when trying to push my changes to a branch off of RPSaaSDev. Has anyone seen this before or would it be a sign that my write access request (Azure SDK Partners on CoreIdentity) is still propagating?
pushing to this PR:[Private.DeviceRegistry 2026-04-01 by yijinglu-microsoft · Pull Request #25274 · Azure/azure-rest-ap…](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/pull/25274/files)
rows.inputs.ground_truth: GitHub is experience an outage on all HTTP and SSH git operations, please check status using https://www.githubstatus.com/.
rows.inputs.response:
Based on the provided knowledge, the most common cause for being unable to push changes to a branch in the azure-rest-api-specs-pr repository (such as one off RPSaaSDev) is a lack of proper write access. Your suspicion that your Azure SDK Partners write access request may still be propagating is highly plausible. Write access is granted once you join the Azure SDK Partners team, and it can take up to one day after manager approval for permissions to propagate and be reflected in GitHub. 

Before troubleshooting further, verify:
- You have joined the Microsoft and Azure GitHub organizations, and your memberships are set to **Public**.
- You have requested and received approval for Azure SDK Partners team membership.
- It has been at least one business day since approval.

If all above steps are complete and the issue persists, try validating your alias with the [Validate-AzsdkCodeOwner](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-tools/blob/main/tools/github/scripts/Validate-AzsdkCodeOwner.ps1) script. Also, note that some branches (like private `main`) are read-only, but RPSaaSDev is intended for dogfooding and should accept pushes if you have write access.

If the error message specifically references permissions (e.g., 'permission denied' or 'authentication failed'), it almost certainly means your write access is not yet active. If it has been more than one day since your access was approved, or if you have other permission-related issues, reach out via the [Azure SDK / Azure SDK Onboarding](https://aka.ms/azsdk/support/onboarding-channel) channel for assistance.

Other causes for push errors can include branch protection policies, but these typically result in error messages about branch protection, not authentication or permission. If you cannot access the linked PR or error logs, please paste the exact error message for more targeted troubleshooting.

[{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"design#api-specs-pr#api-tutorial#api-tutorial-3-publish.md","document_title":"Create a PR against main","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-specs-pr/api-tutorial/api-tutorial-3-publish","content":"# design#api-specs-pr#api-tutorial#api-tutorial-3-publish.md

# Create a PR against main

> [!NOTE]
> You must have a [GitHub account linked with your Microsoft account](xref:access) and permissions to any of the
> repositories listed in this tutorial.

When you're ready for a final review, it's time to create a pull request (PR) from your release branch you created
originally to the `main` branch on [Azure/azure-rest-api-specs](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs).

* :warning: Do not merge `main` or other release branches unless you know there are changes required.
* :white_check_mark: Rebase on `main` if changes are required in a separate topic branch.

## Clean PR against main

If you're fairly certain there should be no conflicting changes in files you added or modified in the release branch,
you can most often just create a pull request (PR) against `main` on  
[Azure/azure-rest-api-specs](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs).

1. Go to your branch in [Azure/azure-rest-api-specs](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs) or  
   [Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr). Read more about  
   [our repositories](xref:api-repos) for what is public and what is private.

2. If you do not already see an open PR in the upper-right just above the list of files, click **Contribute** and click
   **Open pull request** to open a new one.

3. Select either the **Control Plane (ARM) API** or **Data Plane API** PR template, depending on the type of REST API
spec updates you are submitting.

<!-- Todo: Figure out best way to embed videos on site.
:::video source="https://microsoft.sharepoint.com/teams/AzureDeveloperExperience/_layouts/15/embed.aspx?UniqueId=b199159f-5d7c-4b22-8ba4-98025a2a1f2e":::
-->

## Update your branch with changes from main

If you know there are other changes in the `main` branch or that other services have updated shared files in `main`
already and you need to pick up changes before merging, we recommend you take a merge from main. This is particularly interesting
for common infrastructure changes that are committed in the repo (i.e. github actions, tools, etc). Depending on how old your
branch is some of the pull request checks may not correctly function without taking a merge from main. 

If you are working in a non-protected branch you can do a `git merge main` like you would normally do a merge and then push
your changes to your remote branch. However, if you are working in a branch with branch protection enabled (i.e. `release-*`) then
you will need to make a pull request to your branch with the merge. Depending on how out-of-date your branch is from `main` your 
merge may have a lot of unwanted and unnecessary changes and the checks not pass. In such cases see below on how to [update the infrastructure](#updating-only-the-infrastructure-changes-from-main).

### Updating only the infrastructure changes from main

In cases you need to only update the infrastructure code and not the specifications we have a helper pipeline 
which you can run that will create a pull request with a selective merge. The selective merge will include everything except for specs 
under the specifications folder. This will enable you to only update the infrastructure and not other specs which should get your checks 
passing in your protected branch. Follow these steps to run the helper pipeline.

> [!NOTE]
> This should only be needed for protected branches, such as `release-*`. If you are in an unprotected branch, just use a normal `git merge main`.

1. Go to [tools - update-release-branch-in-specs](https://dev.azure.com/azure-sdk/internal/_build?definitionId=7487) and select **Run Pipeline**.
If you don't have permission see [GitHub account linked with your Microsoft account](xref:access).

2. Enter the name of your branch in the **BranchToMergeTo** parameter. Usually this will be in the form `release-<name>`.  You shouldn't need to set 
the other parameters but if your branch is in the private repo then you will need to update **Repo** to be `Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr`.

3. Click the **Run** button.

4. The pipeline should only take a few minutes to run and once it is complete then go find the pull request it created. You can find a link to it in the 
pipeline logs under the **Create Pull Request to merge** step. 

5. Monitor the created pull request and approve it. Once the checks are green then merge the pull request and then your branch should be updated with the latest infrastructure changes.
If you have open PRs against your branch with failing checks, go to those PRs and retrigger the checks. The easiest way to retrigger all checks
is to hit the close button followed by the open button, which should cause the checks to re-run.

## Next steps

1. [Create a new branch](api-tutorial-1-branch.md)
2. [Work against the release branch](api-tutorial-2-update.md)
3. Create a PR against main"},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"onboard#access.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/onboard/access","content":"# onboard#access.md

| Short Link: | [aka.ms/azsdk/access](https://aka.ms/azsdk/access) |
| --- | --- |

## Request access to Azure REST API and SDK repositories

Request access to Azure REST API and SDK repositories on GitHub so that you can leverage our tooling to check-in your
files, assign issues, and more.

### Before you begin

You'll need a [GitHub](https://github.com) account to contribute to Azure REST API and SDK repositories.
Before you get started, be sure that you also:

- Join the [Microsoft](https://repos.opensource.microsoft.com/orgs/Microsoft) organization on GitHub.
- Join the [Azure](https://repos.opensource.microsoft.com/orgs/Azure) organization.
- Check the visibility of your Microsoft and Azure org memberships.

Your GitHub memberships must be set to **Public**. For more information, see  
[Changing the visibility for your organization membership](https://docs.github.com/en/account-and-profile/setting-up-and-managing-your-personal-account-on-github/managing-your-membership-in-organizations/publicizing-or-hiding-organization-membership#changing-the-visibility-of-your-organization-membership).

### Request access to REST API or SDK repositories

If you are working on your [REST API spec](xref:api-repos) or building client libraries (SDKs) for your service you will
need to request the appropriate permissions needed for that work.

These permissions control access to the repositories such as `Azure/azure-rest-api-specs[-pr]` or `Azure/azure-sdk-for-[lang][-pr]`.

### Write access

If you're working on branches in the main repo for your spec, or working in the Azure SDK repositories to submit pull
requests or serving as the support contact for issues, you'll need write access so that you can apply or dismiss labels,
create or modify issues, and assign issues to others. It also allows you to add/update test recordings in the test assets repo.

To get access to Azure SDK repos, request to join the [Azure SDK Partners](https://aka.ms/azsdk/join/azuresdkpartners) 
and have the request approved by your manager.  *After your manager approves*, it may take up to one day for you to automatically
be added to the [azure-sdk-partners](https://github.com/orgs/Azure/teams/azure-sdk-partners) GitHub team. This will get you
write access to all Azure SDK related repos. These membership requests will need to be renewed every 180 days.

Note that write access will also give you the ability to merge to the 'main' branch in each of the Azure SDK repos. However,
through branch protection rules, CODEOWNERS approval of PRs is required. This means that for each file/folder your PR has
modified you will need to get approval from the corresponding people listed in the repo's  
[CODEOWNERS file](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk/blob/main/docs/policies/opensource.md#codeowners). GitHub will automatically
add all matching CODEOWNERS as reviewers to the PR. You need approval from one CODEOWNER in each area in order to merge."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"design#api-specs-pr#api-versions-and-branches.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-specs-pr/api-versions-and-branches","content":"# design#api-specs-pr#api-versions-and-branches.md

| Short Link: | [aka.ms/azsdk/api-versions](https://aka.ms/azsdk/api-versions) |
|--|--|

# API versions and branches

This article explains the various lifecycle stages of spec API versions and how do they relate to git branches of the  
[specs repositories](xref:api-repos).

## Spec repos branches table

This table serves as a quick summary. Read the rest of the article for details.

| Branch                 | [Public repository][public specs repo]        | [Private repository][private specs repo]              |
|------------------------|-----------------------------------------------|-------------------------------------------------------|
| `main`                 | All API versions in `GA` and `public preview` | Mirrored from public `main`                           |
| `RPSaaSMaster`         | N/A                                           | For RPaaS-based specs in `private preview`   |
| `RPSaaSDev`            | N/A                                           | For dogfooding RPaaS-based specs.                     |
| `release-*`            | Feature branches.                             | Feature branches.                                     |
| `dev-*`                | Obsolete. Use `release-*` instead.            | Obsolete. Use `release-*` instead.                    |
| `ARMCoreRPDev`         | N/A                                           | [Obsolete ShiftLeft branch]. Use `release-*` instead. |
| `InternalARMContracts` | N/A                                           | For ARM-internal APIs, never published to customers.  |

If a given branch in the public or private spec repos is not listed in the table above, then most likely
it is obsolete, deprecated, or otherwise not recommended for use.

## Branch protection rules table

This table serves as a quick summary. Read the rest of the article for details.

This table shows which GitHub checks are marked as `required` on respective branches. Even when a check is marked as ❌
it **may** still be running on given branch; just that if it fails, the PR won't be blocked from merging.

| Branch | Merge | SDK | TSVal | BrCh | BrChC | LintRPaaS | LintDiff | Model | Semantic | Spell | Prettier | license | approver |
|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|
| public `main`                  | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ |
| private `RPSaaSMaster`         | ✅ | ❌ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ |
| public/private `release-*`     | ✅ | ❌ | ✅ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ |
| private `RPSaaSDev`            | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ✅ |
| private `InternalARMContracts` | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ✅ |
| private `ARMCoreRPDev`         | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ✅ |

Legend:

| Column name | Full GitHub check name               |
|-------------|--------------------------------------|
| `BrCh`      | `Swagger BreakingChange`             |
| `BrChC`     | `Breaking Change(Cross-Version)`     |
| `license`   | `license/cla`                        |
| `LintDiff`  | `Swagger LintDiff`                   |
| `LintRPaaS` | `Swagger Lint(RPaaS)`                |
| `Merge`     | `Automated merging requirements met` |
| `Model`     | `Swagger ModelValidation`            |
| `Prettier`  | `PrettierCheck`                      |
| `SDK`       | `SDK azure-sdk-for-go`               |
| `Semantic`  | `Swagger SemanticValidation`         |
| `Spell`     | `SpellCheck`                         |
| `TSVal`     | `TypeScript Validation`              |
| `approver`  | Requires team member approval        |

For more information on these checks, see:

- https://aka.ms/azsdk/pr-getting-help
- https://aka.ms/ci-fix

## API version lifecycle stages

An API version is a TypeSpec/OpenAPI specification contract identified by its `api-version` value.

Given API version is located in its own directory in the specs repositories. It can be in following lifecycle stages:

- `generally available` (aka `GA`, `stable`)
- `public preview`
- `private preview`
- `in development`
- `closing down`

> [!NOTE]
> A `closing down` API spec version need to be kept in the spec repository until it is fully `deprecated`. A `deprecated` API spec version need to be removed from the spec repository, with removal initiated by the service to begin deprecating related APIs, SDKs, and CLIs.

These stages corresponds to [service tree lifecycle stages] as elaborated on in [ARM lifecycle stages requirements].

### Generally available

**GA** API versions have been released to all Azure customers.

For an API version to be in GA it must:

- Be present in the `main` branch of the [public specs repo].
- Be in a parent `stable` folder and without a `-preview` suffix. See [spec directory structure] for full details.
- Not be gated by any feature flags, including Azure Feature Exposure Control ([AFEC]) flags.

### Public preview

**Public preview** API versions have been released to all Azure customers, but are not yet GA.
For an API version to be in `public preview`, it must:

- Not yet be GA.
- Be present in the `main` branch of the [public specs repo].
- Be in a parent `preview` folder and have `-preview` suffix in its folder name.
  See [spec directory structure] and [ARM preview guidelines] for full details.
- Not be gated by any feature flags, including [AFEC] flags.

### Private preview

**Private preview** API versions have been released to a limited set of Azure customers.

Usually API versions are in `private preview` for following reasons:

- The spec API version preview cannot yet be made public due to business or marketing reasons.
- Early customer feedback is being gathered for given API version preview.

For an API version to be in `private preview`, it must:

- Not yet be `GA` or in `public preview`.
- Not be present in the [public specs repo] `main` branch or any other branch in that repo.
- Be in a parent `preview` folder and have `-prefix` in its folder name.
  See [spec directory structure] and [ARM preview guidelines] for full details.
- Have at least one customer. If an API version has no customers, it is `in development`, not in `private preview`.
- In case of ARM specs:
  - Be present in the `RPSaaSMaster` branch of the [private specs repo].
    See [ARM branches] and [ARM lifecycle stages requirements] for details.
  - Be under access control done with [AFEC] flags.
- In case of data-plane specs:
  - Can be in any branch in the [private specs repo], except `main` or `RPaaS*` branches,
    as there is no designated branch like `RPSaaSMaster` for ARM specs.
  - There is no need for access control done with [AFEC] flags, as data plane services should have some mechanism
    for allowing `private preview` customers to onboard the preview.

> [!NOTE]
> A `private preview` API spec version can be published as `public preview` by following  
> [this how-to](xref:pr-move-private-to-public).

### In development

**In development** API versions are all API versions that are not `GA`, in `public preview` or in `private preview`.
Notably, such API versions are not present in the [public specs repo] `main` branch and do not have any customers.
However, they may be present in the public repo feature branches.

> [!IMPORTANT]
> REST API definitions for a service or API version that is `in development` MUST NOT be present in the  
> [public specs repo] `main` at all.

> [!NOTE]
> ARM spec API version, while `in development`, should not be trying to merge into `RPSaaSMaster`.
> The ARM guidance for this is in [ARM spec onboarding] article.

**Special cases** There are few special situations that do not fit in the API versioning model described above.
In such situations, attend appropriate office hours:

- In case of ARM specs, **ARM API Review Office Hours** in [aka.ms/armofficehoursinfo].
- In case of data-plane specs, [aka.ms/azapi/officehours].

## Spec repos branches

### Public specs repo `main` branch

All API versions in the [public specs repo] `main` branch are published to all Azure customers.
This branch includes `GA` and `public preview` API versions.

> [!CAUTION]
> This is not a dev branch. It should contain **only** finished specs that represent services deployed to customers.

### Private specs repo `main` branch

[Private specs repo] `main` branch is mirrored from [public specs repo] `main` branch by a CI job on a regular basis.
As such, it is **read only**.

### Private specs repo `RPSaaSMaster` branch

[Private specs repo] `RPSaaSMaster` contains RPaaS-based ARM specifications.

When an RPaaS-based ARM API goes into `public preview` or `GA` lifecycle stage it must be merged to [public specs repo]
`main` as well.

Some parts of this branch are being mirrored from public `main` branch
by the [mirror-repos] pipeline, triggered manually on at least daily basis.

Service teams are responsible for keeping their API specifications in this branch synchronized with
the public specs repo `main` branch.

See also [ARM lifecycle stages requirements] and [ARM branches].

### `RPSaaSDev` branch

Used for internal ARM dogfooding. See `RPSaaSDev` in [ARM branches].

Some parts of this branch are being mirrored from public `main` branch
by the [mirror-repos] pipeline, triggered manually on at least daily basis.

Service teams are responsible for keeping their API specifications in this branch synchronized with
the public specs repo `main` branch.

See also [ARM lifecycle stages requirements] and [ARM branches].

### `release-*` branches

All branches with prefix `release-`, both in public and private specs repos. Also known as "feature" branches.

These branches are used for col"},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"design#api-review.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-review","content":"# Schedule a data plane REST API spec review
## Before you begin
> [!NOTE]
> For management plane (ARM-based) APIs, you need to create a pull request (PR) in the [Azure REST API specification repositories](xref:api-repos).
> Such PR is a part of the [release plan](xref:release-plan). The ARM review will happen during the [PR process](xref:api-specs-pr).

Ensure that:

- You have [access](xref:access) to the GitHub repositories and respective Azure open source organization."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"design#api-specs-pr#api-tutorial#api-tutorial-2-update.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-specs-pr/api-tutorial/api-tutorial-2-update","content":"# Work against the release branch
> [!NOTE]
> You must have a [GitHub account linked with your Microsoft account](xref:access) and permissions to any of the
> repositories listed in this tutorial.

Now that you've created a release branch, let people know the branch name you created above. They should create topic
branches against that branch - just like they would against the `main` branch - and submit pull requests (PR).
Read about [API design](xref:api-design) for guidelines and more information.

- :white_check_mark: Create a topic branch from the upstream release branch.
- :white_check_mark: Submit a PR when ready against the upstream release branch.
- :x: Do not merge the `main` branch into your topic branch. If you need specific changes, you can cherry-pick them,
  or simply copy and paste."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"develop#supporting-sdk-customers#codeowners.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/develop/supporting-sdk-customers/codeowners","content":"# CODEOWNERS
## Validating your alias in CODEOWNERS
For your GitHub alias to be valid you must complete the tasks for [Requesting access to Azure REST API and SDK repositories](xref:access#request-access-to-azure-rest-api-and-sdk-repositories).

> [!NOTE]
> Ensure that your organization visibility is set to **public** before proceeding.

If you're unsure if your GitHub alias is a part of the right orgs and has the proper permissions, you can verify the state of your alias by running the [Validate-AzsdkCodeOwner](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-tools/blob/main/tools/github/scripts/Validate-AzsdkCodeOwner.ps1) script from the Azure SDK tools repository."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"design#api-specs-pr#api-tutorial#api-tutorial.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-specs-pr/api-tutorial/api-tutorial","content":"# Tutorial: Create a new service spec
## Before you begin
You must have a [GitHub account linked with your Microsoft account](xref:access) and permissions to any of the
repositories listed in this tutorial."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"design#api-specs-pr#api-specs-pr.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-specs-pr/api-specs-pr","content":"# Create a pull request with your Azure REST API spec update
## Get your PR merged
| Short Link: | [aka.ms/azsdk/specreview/merge](https://aka.ms/azsdk/specreview/merge) |
|-|-|

To get your PR merged:

1. Ensure the `Next Steps to Merge` comment and `Automated merging requirements met` check are green. 
1. Ensure at least one person has approved your PR. Generally another person from your team that has [write access] to the repo.
1. Ensure all required checks are passing and at least investigate to understand any other non-required checks that may be failing. 
1. Once all required checks are green and any other issues understood you can merge the PR yourself as long as you have [write access] to the repo.
1. If your PR is targeting public `main` you will need to first apply the `PublishToCustomers` label to acknowledge you understand this 
   will cause your spec to be published so customers can consume it.
1. If your PR is targeting private repo `main` branch, it **cannot** be merged.
   Instead, you can publish your changes to customers by following the guide at [aka.ms/azsdk/move-pr]."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"support#troubleshoot#PR-failing.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/support/troubleshoot/PR-failing","content":"# I've submitted a pull request, but the build isn't succeeding or tests are failing!
> [!NOTE]
> If you are looking for help with a PR submitted to one of [the Azure REST API specs repositories](xref:api-repos),
> please refer to [this support page](xref:support#get-help-with-prs-submitted-against-the-azure-rest-api-specification-repositories).

Congratulations! You've submitted a pull request. As part of the pull request approval process we ensure that the code
build and tests successfully, as well as performing a range of other validation steps. Generally speaking the build
errors associated with the pipeline run are sufficient to diagnose and fix any issues with your PR. You can access
the build logs by clicking on the failing check run, and then using the view details link to navigate to the error in
Azure Pipelines.

If you cannot understand the reason for the failure, ask a question in the _language team_ channel appropriate to the
repository that you are working in. Each language team is the first point of contact for build failures within their
repository.

Reach to the [language specific Team's channel](xref:support#get-help-with-the-azure-sdks-development)."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"design#specs-pr-guides#pr-brch-deep.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/specs-pr-guides/pr-brch-deep","content":"# Deep-dive into breaking changes on spec PRs
## Breaking changes and versioning issues
There are two automatic checks running on your PR checking for conformance
to the [Azure Versioning and Breaking Changes Policy]:

- `Breaking Change(Cross-Version)` that ensures you don't introduce breaking changes or violate versioning policy
*across* two API versions.
- `Swagger BreakingChange` that ensures you didn't introduce breaking changes or violated versioning policy
*within* any single API version.

The result of running these checks may result in one of these labels being applied: `BreakingChangeReviewRequired`
or `VersioningReviewRequired`. If this happens, your PR is **blocked** from any further review, including ARM review,
if applicable.

The breaking change/versioning checks are performed only on PRs targeting the `main` branch in the [public specs repo]
or `RPSaaSMaster` branch of the [private specs repo].

These two branches are `production branches`. Merging an API specification to either of them publishes it
for all customers to use & consume."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"support#troubleshoot#engsys.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/support/troubleshoot/engsys","content":"# Help! The engineering system itself is broken
Oh no! This happens from time to time when one of our dependencies (e.g. Maven Central or Azure Pipelines) goes offline
or starts having service issues. It is also possible for the Engineering System team to inadvertently introduce
a problem which breaks our build and release pipelines.

If you believe that the engineering system itself is failing
(as opposed to something in your PR causing a build/test failure), reach out to the Azure SDK Engineering System team.
Our preferred method is for you to drop a message in our Teams Channel.

- [Azure SDK / Engineering System]

Note that when one of our dependencies goes offline we often just need to wait the issue out unless there is a simple
mitigation. You can see the latest status updates for many of our dependencies on this channel:

- [Azure SDK / System Status]

For tools connected with the REST API specs used in the [Azure/azure-rest-api-specs] repo refer to:

- [This support page](xref:support#get-help-with-prs-submitted-against-the-azure-rest-api-specification-repositories)"},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"plan#upcoming_release_planner_change.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/plan/upcoming_release_planner_change","content":"# SDK self-serve for TypeSpec generated management plane SDKs
## **2. Generate SDK**
Responsible: Service owner

1. Submit a request using release planner. More information about release planner is available  
[here](https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/plan/release-plan).
2. Automation creates an issue in the [Azure/azure-rest-api-specs](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs) repository and it is assigned to Copilot.
3. This uses our [automation pipelines](xref:sdk-generate) and as a result it creates a PR in each language repo.
4. PRs are open in `DRAFT` state and links for these PRs will be visible in the generate SDK step in the release planner.
5. Service owner needs to verify the content of the PRs.
6. When the PR is ready for review, access the PR URL and click on `Ready for review` button in GitHub. This will assign the Azure SDK team as reviewers.
7. Azure SDK team reviews and approves PR.
8. Service team addresses feedback and is responsible for merging the PR.

**Troubleshooting steps:**

SDK is generated by GitHub Copilot Agent when a generate SDK request is submitted. The release planner contains the link to this GitHub tracking issue.

If the SDK PR doesn’t appear in the release planner within **~30 minutes** after submitting a request, or if you need to **regenerate** the SDK, follow these steps to check the status:

1. Identify the GitHub issue created for SDK generation. This is visible in the **Generate SDK** step in the release planner. 
2. Open the GitHub issue and identify the PR associated with the GitHub issue. This PR is assigned to GitHub Copilot.
3. Check for any comment on GitHub PR that indicates any failure to generate SDK. If SDK generation pipeline is in failed status, you can access the failure reason by clicking on pipeline run link.
4. If failure indicates any changes required in API spec TypeSpec project:

  -  Update the **TypeSpec project** as needed
- Create a new TypeSpec PR or push changes to existing one (if it's still open)."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"develop#sdk-develop.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/develop/sdk-develop","content":"# Develop client libraries (SDK)
## Get help
- If you need help with an automation tool or the Release planner, reach out to 
[Azure SDK / Azure SDK Onboarding](https://aka.ms/azsdk/support/onboarding-channel) channel.
- If you need help with the development of the SDKs reach out to the [language specific Team's channel](xref:support#get-help-with-the-azure-sdks-development).
- If you need to request an exception for a language review the [request release exception](xref:request-exception)."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"design#api-specs-pr#api-repos.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-specs-pr/api-repos","content":"# Azure REST API specs repositories on GitHub
## Publishing your spec to the spec repos
To publish your spec to the API specs repositories, you must first understand what kind of API version you are
trying to publish and make a PR to appropriate branch based on that. Read about this in [this article](xref:pr-move-private-to-public).

<!-- links -->
[Azure/azure-rest-api-specs]: https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs
[Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr]: https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr"}]
