rows.outputs.similarity.similarity_sample_inp: [{"role": "user", "content": "{\"query\": \"title: Error writing to PR in RPSAASDev branch\\n\\nquestion: I'm seeing an error when trying to push my changes to a branch off of RPSaaSDev. Has anyone seen this before or would it be a sign that my write access request (Azure SDK Partners on CoreIdentity) is still propagating?\\npushing to this PR:[Private.DeviceRegistry 2026-04-01 by yijinglu-microsoft \\u00b7 Pull Request #25274 \\u00b7 Azure/azure-rest-ap\\u2026](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/pull/25274/files)\", \"response\": \"Based on the provided knowledge, the most common cause for being unable to push changes to a branch in the azure-rest-api-specs-pr repository (such as one off RPSaaSDev) is a lack of proper write access. Your suspicion that your Azure SDK Partners write access request may still be propagating is highly plausible. Write access is granted once you join the Azure SDK Partners team, and it can take up to one day after manager approval for permissions to propagate and be reflected in GitHub. \\n\\nBefore troubleshooting further, verify:\\n- You have joined the Microsoft and Azure GitHub organizations, and your memberships are set to **Public**.\\n- You have requested and received approval for Azure SDK Partners team membership.\\n- It has been at least one business day since approval.\\n\\nIf all above steps are complete and the issue persists, try validating your alias with the [Validate-AzsdkCodeOwner](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-tools/blob/main/tools/github/scripts/Validate-AzsdkCodeOwner.ps1) script. Also, note that some branches (like private `main`) are read-only, but RPSaaSDev is intended for dogfooding and should accept pushes if you have write access.\\n\\nIf the error message specifically references permissions (e.g., 'permission denied' or 'authentication failed'), it almost certainly means your write access is not yet active. If it has been more than one day since your access was approved, or if you have other permission-related issues, reach out via the [Azure SDK / Azure SDK Onboarding](https://aka.ms/azsdk/support/onboarding-channel) channel for assistance.\\n\\nOther causes for push errors can include branch protection policies, but these typically result in error messages about branch protection, not authentication or permission. If you cannot access the linked PR or error logs, please paste the exact error message for more targeted troubleshooting.\", \"ground_truth\": \"GitHub is experience an outage on all HTTP and SSH git operations, please check status using https://www.githubstatus.com/.\"}"}]

rows.inputs.query:
title: Override description property in referenced parameter.

question: In this PR I need to override the description for the typeahead parameter for a specific API, so that all other API that reference this property will not be affected:
But this is throwing an error:
error: Schema violation: must NOT have additional properties (paths > /search/address/{format} > get > parameters > 4)
additionalProperty: description
I don't know why it is throwing an error, it worked in a similar situation for the BoundingBoxCompassNotation object in PR38554
rows.inputs.ground_truth: You should be able to workaround this be slightly refactoring your swagger, for example create a new parameter TypeaheadDeprecated with the new description.
rows.inputs.testcase: Override description property in referenced parameter.
rows.outputs.similarity.similarity_sample_inp: [{"role": "user", "content": "{\"query\": \"title: Override description property in referenced parameter.\\n\\nquestion: In this PR I need to override the description for the typeahead parameter for a specific API, so that all other API that reference this property will not be affected:\\nBut this is throwing an error:\\nerror: Schema violation: must NOT have additional properties (paths > /search/address/{format} > get > parameters > 4)\\nadditionalProperty: description\\nI don't know why it is throwing an error, it worked in a similar situation for the BoundingBoxCompassNotation object in PR38554\", \"response\": \"This error occurs because in OpenAPI (and thus in TypeSpec's OpenAPI emitter), you cannot override or add additional properties (like `description`) directly on a `$ref` parameter in an operation. When you use a `$ref` to a parameter, you are importing the entire parameter object as-is; any attempt to add a property (such as a new `description`) to the reference creates an invalid OpenAPI structure and results in a schema violation. \\n\\nThis is different from objects/models: for schemas, you can use `allOf` to combine a `$ref` with additional properties (like overriding the description), but for parameters, OpenAPI does not allow this pattern. Parameters must be fully defined inline if you need to override anything (such as `description`, `example`, etc.).\\n\\n**How to achieve your goal in TypeSpec:**\\n\\nIf you need a custom description for a parameter in a single operation, you must define a new parameter (not just use the reference) for that operation, and apply the desired description:\\n\\n```tsp\\n// Define your parameter with the custom description\\n@query\\n@doc(\\\"Custom description for typeahead for this operation only.\\\")\\ntypeahead: string;\\n\\n// Use this in the operation's parameters instead of spreading the reference\\nop searchAddress(\\n  @path format: string,\\n  @query typeahead: string, // <-- this uses the custom description\\n  ... // other parameters\\n): SearchResult;\\n```\\n\\nThis way, only this operation gets the custom description, while all other operations using the original parameter reference are unaffected.\\n\\n**Why did it work for BoundingBoxCompassNotation?**\\n\\nFor schemas (objects), OpenAPI allows you to use `allOf` to extend or override properties, including documentation. For parameters, this is NOT allowed by the OpenAPI spec, and the emitter will fail validation if you try to add additional properties to a `$ref` parameter.\\n\\n**Summary:**\\n- You cannot override a referenced parameter's description in OpenAPI (and TypeSpec) by adding properties to the `$ref`.\\n- You must define a new parameter with the custom description for the specific operation where you want it.\\n- For schemas (objects), overriding documentation via `allOf` works; for parameters, it does not.\\n\\nThis approach aligns with Azure API guidelines and OpenAPI standards.\", \"ground_truth\": \"You should be able to workaround this be slightly refactoring your swagger, for example create a new parameter TypeaheadDeprecated with the new description.\"}"}]

rows.inputs.query:
title: doc only update?

question: Hey team,
I'm a PM on the VMSS team. I'm trying to understand the new Typespec way to do a documentation only update to swagger? In this case, I just want to update these doc strings to remove/modify the preview notes. I believe I updated the correct text in the models.tsp files. The swagger compiled correctly. Now my questions:
I want this to be updated in current documentation posted online, as well as SDK docs. How do I submit this change against main or the latest feature branch? Do I need to do additional work to make sure this change is propagated through to SDKs?
When I submitted the PR, got this error. Not sure how to fix: "The default tag contains multiple API versions swaggers."
The PR for reference:
[VMSS prioritizeunhealthyvm and force delete doc update by fitzgeraldsteele · Pull Request #25785 ](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/pull/25785)
rows.inputs.ground_truth:
Swagger and TSP must always match.  So the same PR, but to public/main instead of private/main.The error from "Swagger Avocado" is an existing problem in your spec, that should be fixed eventually.  See this run from a previous PR to your spec.
https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/actions/runs/18538687430
Docs:
https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Swagger-Avocado#multiple_api_version
rows.inputs.response:
You are following the correct process for a documentation-only update in TypeSpec. Documentation/comments (docstrings) in TypeSpec models are emitted into both the generated OpenAPI/Swagger and SDK docs, provided you compile with TypeSpec and check in the results. No special versioning is required for doc-only changes—just update the comments in your TypeSpec source and recompile.

**How to submit the change:**
- Submit your PR against `main` in the azure-rest-api-specs repo. This is the standard branch for public documentation and SDK generation, unless your team is actively working in a feature branch that is not yet merged to main.
- Make sure your PR only includes the updated TypeSpec source and the newly compiled Swagger (OpenAPI JSON files), plus examples if changed.
- No additional work is needed to propagate the changes to SDKs—the docstrings will be picked up automatically in the next SDK generation cycle once the PR is merged.

**Resolving the CI error: "The default tag contains multiple API versions swaggers":**
- This error is caused by the presence of more than one OpenAPI file in the default tag for the API version. This is a hard blocker in the TypeSpec migration pipeline, and you must resolve it before your doc-only update can be accepted.
- To fix this, ensure that only one OpenAPI file is present in the default tag. Remove any additional swagger files from the default tag in the readme configuration (usually `readme.md`). For more details, refer to the guidance: https://github.com/Azure/typespec-azure/issues/2194#issue-2844564216
- If you are unsure which file should be kept, keep only the latest stable or preview version intended for public documentation and SDK generation.

**Summary:**
- Make docstring changes in TypeSpec source, recompile, and submit against main.
- Remove any duplicate OpenAPI files from the default tag to resolve the CI error.
- No extra steps needed for SDK propagation; documentation changes do not trigger new SDK releases unless API surface changes are made.

If you need more help with migration conflicts, see: https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Resolving-Folder-Migration-Conflicts:-A-Guide-for-PR-Authors
And for validation steps: https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/TypeSpec-Validation

[{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"design#api-specs-pr#api-tutorial#api-tutorial-3-publish.md","document_title":"Create a PR against main","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-specs-pr/api-tutorial/api-tutorial-3-publish","content":"# design#api-specs-pr#api-tutorial#api-tutorial-3-publish.md

# Create a PR against main

> [!NOTE]
> You must have a [GitHub account linked with your Microsoft account](xref:access) and permissions to any of the
> repositories listed in this tutorial.

When you're ready for a final review, it's time to create a pull request (PR) from your release branch you created
originally to the `main` branch on [Azure/azure-rest-api-specs](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs).

* :warning: Do not merge `main` or other release branches unless you know there are changes required.
* :white_check_mark: Rebase on `main` if changes are required in a separate topic branch.

## Clean PR against main

If you're fairly certain there should be no conflicting changes in files you added or modified in the release branch,
you can most often just create a pull request (PR) against `main` on  
[Azure/azure-rest-api-specs](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs).

1. Go to your branch in [Azure/azure-rest-api-specs](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs) or  
   [Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr). Read more about  
   [our repositories](xref:api-repos) for what is public and what is private.

2. If you do not already see an open PR in the upper-right just above the list of files, click **Contribute** and click
   **Open pull request** to open a new one.

3. Select either the **Control Plane (ARM) API** or **Data Plane API** PR template, depending on the type of REST API
spec updates you are submitting.

<!-- Todo: Figure out best way to embed videos on site.
:::video source="https://microsoft.sharepoint.com/teams/AzureDeveloperExperience/_layouts/15/embed.aspx?UniqueId=b199159f-5d7c-4b22-8ba4-98025a2a1f2e":::
-->

## Update your branch with changes from main

If you know there are other changes in the `main` branch or that other services have updated shared files in `main`
already and you need to pick up changes before merging, we recommend you take a merge from main. This is particularly interesting
for common infrastructure changes that are committed in the repo (i.e. github actions, tools, etc). Depending on how old your
branch is some of the pull request checks may not correctly function without taking a merge from main. 

If you are working in a non-protected branch you can do a `git merge main` like you would normally do a merge and then push
your changes to your remote branch. However, if you are working in a branch with branch protection enabled (i.e. `release-*`) then
you will need to make a pull request to your branch with the merge. Depending on how out-of-date your branch is from `main` your 
merge may have a lot of unwanted and unnecessary changes and the checks not pass. In such cases see below on how to [update the infrastructure](#updating-only-the-infrastructure-changes-from-main).

### Updating only the infrastructure changes from main

In cases you need to only update the infrastructure code and not the specifications we have a helper pipeline 
which you can run that will create a pull request with a selective merge. The selective merge will include everything except for specs 
under the specifications folder. This will enable you to only update the infrastructure and not other specs which should get your checks 
passing in your protected branch. Follow these steps to run the helper pipeline.

> [!NOTE]
> This should only be needed for protected branches, such as `release-*`. If you are in an unprotected branch, just use a normal `git merge main`.

1. Go to [tools - update-release-branch-in-specs](https://dev.azure.com/azure-sdk/internal/_build?definitionId=7487) and select **Run Pipeline**.
If you don't have permission see [GitHub account linked with your Microsoft account](xref:access).

2. Enter the name of your branch in the **BranchToMergeTo** parameter. Usually this will be in the form `release-<name>`.  You shouldn't need to set 
the other parameters but if your branch is in the private repo then you will need to update **Repo** to be `Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr`.

3. Click the **Run** button.

4. The pipeline should only take a few minutes to run and once it is complete then go find the pull request it created. You can find a link to it in the 
pipeline logs under the **Create Pull Request to merge** step. 

5. Monitor the created pull request and approve it. Once the checks are green then merge the pull request and then your branch should be updated with the latest infrastructure changes.
If you have open PRs against your branch with failing checks, go to those PRs and retrigger the checks. The easiest way to retrigger all checks
is to hit the close button followed by the open button, which should cause the checks to re-run.

## Next steps

1. [Create a new branch](api-tutorial-1-branch.md)
2. [Work against the release branch](api-tutorial-2-update.md)
3. Create a PR against main"},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"design#api-specs-pr#api-specs-pr.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-specs-pr/api-specs-pr","content":"# design#api-specs-pr#api-specs-pr.md

# Create a pull request with your Azure REST API spec update

This article explains how to create a pull request (PR) in the [Azure REST API specification repositories](xref:api-repos).
Such PR is a part of the [release plan](xref:release-plan).

## Before you begin

Ensure that:

- You have onboarded to Azure SDK team processes by following our [onboarding process](xref:onboard).
- You have [access](xref:access) to the GitHub repositories and respective Azure open source organization.
- You understand the conventions for the [Azure REST API specs GitHub repositories](xref:api-repos).
- You have reviewed and validated your REST API spec updates within your team, using a development branch in one of
  the specs repos.
- You are ready to release the features described in your REST API spec updates in a private preview, public preview,
  or GA release.

>[!TIP]
> We are piloting our new AzSDK tools MCP server which includes the ability to generate the SDKs and
> create a draft pull request in the respective language repository. Refer to [AzSDK tools MCP server](xref:azsdk-tools-mcp)
> for instructions on how to install it and use it.

## Create a PR against a specs repo

> [!TIP]
> If you have an existing PR in the private repo and you want to move it to the public repo, refer to [this guide](xref:pr-move-private-to-public).

When you are ready to submit your REST API spec updates for review, you must create a pull request (PR) in either the  
[public or private specs repository](xref:api-repos). When creating the PR, you should select either the
**Control Plane (ARM) API** or **Data Plane API** PR template, depending on the type of REST API spec updates you are
submitting.

> [!NOTE]
> The PR template and comments added by the PR automation will guide you through the process of getting your PR reviewed,
approved, and merged.

## Get your PR merged

| Short Link: | [aka.ms/azsdk/specreview/merge](https://aka.ms/azsdk/specreview/merge) |
|-|-|

To get your PR merged:

1. Ensure the `Next Steps to Merge` comment and `Automated merging requirements met` check are green. 
1. Ensure at least one person has approved your PR. Generally another person from your team that has [write access] to the repo.
1. Ensure all required checks are passing and at least investigate to understand any other non-required checks that may be failing. 
1. Once all required checks are green and any other issues understood you can merge the PR yourself as long as you have [write access] to the repo.
1. If your PR is targeting public `main` you will need to first apply the `PublishToCustomers` label to acknowledge you understand this 
   will cause your spec to be published so customers can consume it.
1. If your PR is targeting private repo `main` branch, it **cannot** be merged.
   Instead, you can publish your changes to customers by following the guide at [aka.ms/azsdk/move-pr]."},{"document_source":"typespec_azure_docs","document_filename":"typespec-getting-started.md","document_title":"What is TypeSpec?","document_link":"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/typespec-getting-started","content":"# typespec-getting-started.md

# What is TypeSpec?

TypeSpec (Compact API Definition Language) is a typescript-like language for defining APIs. TypeSpec is designed for code reuse,
and for Azure services, there are Azure service extensions for TypeSpec that provide high level building blocks you should use to build
your service. These libraries also contain rules that encourage following established patterns for Azure APIs. Using these building blocks
and guard rails, your service API will be easier to build, will have an easier time passing API reviews, will be consistent with other Azure
services, and will produce good API documentation, good SDKs, and good CLIs.
TypeSpec can emit the following artifacts for your service:

- OpenAPI3 specs
- OpenAPI2 specs, suitable for check-in in to the azure-rest-api-specs repo

For more information on the TypeSpec language and core libraries, see [Getting started with TypeSpec](https://typespec.io/docs)

## Setting up TypeSpec and compile first project

### Install TypeSpec

There are two simple options for getting TypeSpec up and running in your environment:

- [Install directly from npm](https://github.com/microsoft/typespec#using-node--npm)

- Use the [TypeSpec docker images](https://github.com/microsoft/typespec/blob/main/docs/docker.md)

### Create a new TypeSpec Azure project

- Run `tsp init` command with Azure template URL `https://aka.ms/typespec/azure-init` to create a new TypeSpec Azure project for ARM or Data-plane service APIs. This will initialize an empty TypeSpec project with correct npm package references and emitter settings for Azure services.

- Run `tsp compile` in the project folder will compile the TypeSpec project and emit output in `tsp-output` folder.

Once TypeSpec project has been create, the [TypeSpec language tutorial](https://typespec.io/docs) provides a good overview of the basics of the language.

## Getting Started for Azure Management Plane Services

Use the resources in this section for creating Azure ARM rest API specs. For ProviderHub User RP specs and service implementation, please follow the steps in the next section.

- Documentation
  - [TypeSpec Azure ARM library](https://github.com/Azure/typespec-azure/tree/main/packages/typespec-azure-resource-manager/README.md)

## Getting Started for Azure Data Plane Services

- Documentation
  - [Getting started with TypeSpec for REST APIs](https://github.com/microsoft/typespec/blob/main/README.md#getting-started)
  - [TypeSpec language tutorial](https://typespec.io/docs)
  - [TypeSpec Swagger Cheat Sheet](https://github.com/microsoft/typespec/blob/main/docs/typespec-for-openapi-dev.md)
- Samples
  - [Petstore Sample using Low-level Http APIs](https://github.com/microsoft/typespec/tree/main/packages/samples/petstore)
  - [Petstore Sample using High-level Resource APis](https://github.com/microsoft/typespec/tree/main/packages/samples/rest/petstore)
  - You can also browse the [Samples package](https://github.com/microsoft/typespec/tree/main/packages/samples)
- Video Walkthroughs
  - [Getting Started with TypeSpec](https://microsoft.sharepoint.com/:v:/t/AzureDeveloperExperience/Ee5JOjqLOFFDstWe6yB0r20BXozakjHy7w2adGxQi5ztJg?e=QgqqhQ)

## How to Get Help

- Ask questions in the [TypeSpec Discussions Channel](https://teams.microsoft.com/l/channel/19%3a906c1efbbec54dc8949ac736633e6bdf%40thread.skype/TypeSpec%2520Discussion%2520%25F0%259F%2590%25AE?groupId=3e17dcb0-4257-4a30-b843-77f47f1d4121&tenantId=72f988bf-86f1-41af-91ab-2d7cd011db47)
- File issues in the [typespec-azure github repo](https://github.com/azure/typespec-azure/issues)
  - For bugs, please include:
    - A high-level description of the bug
    - Expected and Actual Results
    - Repro steps, including any TypeSpec code that you used
    - Any error messages you saw, including stack traces. For issues with VS or VS Code tooling see [Troubleshooting VSCode Tooling and Filing Issues](#troubleshooting-vscode-tooling-and-filing-issues)

### Troubleshooting VSCode Tooling and Filing Issues

If you run into a problem with the TypeSpec-specific tooling in VS Code, please try to capture the issue, and include any log information. If IntelliSense, syntax highlighting or other language features don't appear to be working:

- Ensure that 'TypeSpec' is the selected language format for your document (this should happen automatically if your file uses the .tsp suffix)
  ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1054056/144310539-4e9bfbb9-1366-4b6f-a490-875e9bd68669.png)
- Choose Output from the View menu to see the output of the language server (View -> Output)
  ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1054056/144310719-4bca242f-f11c-484c-91c7-6914fcf7fe3a.png)
- Capture any output, including stack traces, and include in your [github issue](https://github.com/azure/typespec-azure/issues).
  ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1054056/144310907-ec945f54-0fd8-40a4-936c-60669f4a052f.png)
- Restart VS Code to restart the language server

# Introduction

TypeSpec is a language for describing cloud service APIs and generating other API description languages, client and service code, documentation, and other assets. TypeSpec provides highly extensible core language primitives that can describe API shapes common among REST, GraphQL, gRPC, and other protocols.

You can find more information at https://typespec.io/docs.

This site is focused on using TypeSpec in the context of Azure. We have published a set of libraries with standard patterns and templates to make defining Azure management and data-plane services easy and compliant with Azure API guidelines. Using these building blocks
and guard rails, your service API will be easier to build, will have an easier time passing API reviews, will be consistent with other Azure
services, and will produce good API documentation, good SDKs, and good CLIs.
TypeSpec can emit the following artifacts for your service:

- OpenAPI3 specs
- OpenAPI2 specs, suitable for check-in in to the azure-rest-api-specs repo

# Getting Started with TypeSpec For REST APIs

import { FileTree } from "@astrojs/starlight/components";

## Introduction

Welcome to our tutorial on using TypeSpec to define REST APIs with HTTP. In this section, we'll introduce you to TypeSpec, help you set up your development environment, and cover the basic syntax and structure of TypeSpec. By the end of this section, you'll have a solid foundation to build upon in the subsequent sections.

### What is TypeSpec?

TypeSpec is a language and toolset developed by Microsoft for defining data models and service APIs. It provides a structured way to describe the shape and behavior of data and services, ensuring consistency and reducing errors in API development. With TypeSpec, you can generate code, documentation, and other artifacts from your API definitions, making it easier to maintain and evolve your services. Microsoft uses TypeSpec internally to define APIs for various products and services, including Azure.

TypeSpec is used to define the **interface** of your API, which clients will use to interact with resources provided by your service. This includes specifying the operations, request and response models, and error handling mechanisms. The actual API logic is implemented in the backend service, which processes the requests and communicates with the database.

Before we start writing TypeSpec code, we need to set up our development environment. For detailed instructions on setting up your environment, please refer to the [Installation Guide](../../../).

### Summary of Setup and Installation

1. **Install Node.js**: Download and install Node.js from [nodejs.org](https://nodejs.org/). This will also install npm, the Node.js package manager. The minimum versions required are Node.js 20.0.0 and npm 7.0.0.
2. **Install TypeSpec CLI**: Run `npm install -g @typespec/compiler` to install the TypeSpec CLI.
3. **Verify Installation**: Run `tsp --version` to verify that the TypeSpec CLI is installed correctly.
4. **Create a New Project**:
   - Run `tsp init` and select the `Generic REST API` template.
   - Run `tsp install` to install dependencies.
   - Run `tsp compile .` to compile the initial file.
   - Run `tsp compile . --watch` to automatically compile changes on save.

### Project Structure Overview

Once you've completed these steps, you'll have a basic TypeSpec project set up. Here's an overview of the files and directories in your TypeSpec project:

{/* prettier-ignore */}
<FileTree>
- main.tsp
- tspconfig.yaml
- package.json
- node_modules/
- tsp-output/
  - @typespec/
    - openapi3/
      - openapi.yaml
</FileTree>

- **main.tsp**: Entry point for TypeSpec definitions.
- **tspconfig.yaml**: TypeSpec compiler configuration.
- **package.json**: Project metadata and dependencies.
- **node_modules/**: Installed dependencies.
- **tsp-output/**: Generated files.
- **openapi.yaml**: Generated OpenAPI specification.

As we work through the tutorial, keep the openapi.yaml file open in Visual Studio or VS Code to watch the API specification evolve as we make changes.

## Basic Syntax and Structure

Now that we have our environment set up, let's dive into the basic syntax and structure of TypeSpec. We'll create a simple REST API for a pet store by introducing concepts in a layered fashion, increasing complexity as we progress through the tutorial.

As the tutorial advances and the code examples grow more complex, we'll highlight changes in the code to help you easily spot where new lines have been added.

### Import and Using Statements

Before defining models and services, we need to import the necessary TypeSpec libraries and make them available in our namespace.

As we progress through the tutorial, you can follow along by updating the `main.tsp` file in your project and compiling the changes to see the results reflected in the generated `openapi.yaml` specification.

You can also alternatively use the `Try it` feature with the code samples to quickly view the generated OpenAPI spec in your browser via the TypeSpec Playground.

Let's begin by adding the following import and using statements to the `main.tsp` file:

```tsp title=main.tsp tryit="{"emit": ["@typespec/openapi3"]}"
import "@typespec/http";

using Http;
```

In this example:

- `import` statement brings in the [TypeSpec HTTP library](../../../libraries/http/reference/), which provides the decorators and models we'll be using to define our REST API.
- `using` statement makes the imported library available in the current namespace, allowing us to use its features and decorators.

**NOTE: Your generated project file likely already has these import/using statements, plus import/using for the `@typespec/openapi3` library. The `@typespec/openapi3` library is necessary for emitting the OpenAPI specification file but is not required for creating our Pet Store API in TypeSpec. Remove them from your `main.tsp` file so your code matches the example above.**

## Defining a REST Service

A REST service in TypeSpec is defined using the [`@service`](../../../standard-library/built-in-decorators/#@service) decorator. This decorator allows you to specify metadata about your service, such as its title. Additionally, you can use the [`@server`](../../../libraries/http/reference/decorators/#@TypeSpec.Http.server) decorator to define the server endpoint where your service will be hosted.

### Example: Defining a Service with a Title and Server Endpoint

Let's start by defining a simple REST service for a Pet Store:

```"},{"document_source":"static_typespec_qa","document_filename":"typespec_2025_07_03.md","document_title":"Avocado error after @renamedFrom on custom action route","document_link":"","content":"# typespec_2025_07_03.md

# Avocado error after @renamedFrom on custom action route

## question

For PR [Add Microsoft.Mission version 2025-05-01-preview - Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/pull/22581) I was asked to consider renaming routes for some custom actions to meet naming conventions. For example, I now have this in my routes:
```
@doc("Community Endpoint Interface")
@armResourceOperations
interface CommunityEndpoints {
  @doc("Callback that triggers on approval state change.")
  @armResourceAction(CommunityEndpointResource)
  @added(Microsoft.Mission.Versions.v2024_12_01_preview)
  @renamedFrom(
    Microsoft.Mission.Versions.v2025_05_01_preview,
    "approvalCallback"
  )
  notifyOnApprovalCreation is ArmResourceActionAsync<
    CommunityEndpointResource,
    ApprovalCallbackRequest,
    ApprovalActionResponse
  >;
}
```
This unfortunately now produces Avocado errors for [MISSING_APIS_IN_DEFAULT_TAG](https://github.com/Azure/avocado/blob/master/README.md#MISSING_APIS_IN_DEFAULT_TAG) , 

The default tag should contain all APIs. The API path 
```
/subscriptions/{}/resourcegroups/{}/providers/microsoft.mission/virtualenclaves/{}/enclaveendpoints/{}/approvalcallback
```
is not in the default tag. Please make sure the missing API swaggers are in the default tag.
readme: [specification/mission/resource-manager/readme.md](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/blob/589a07c8dcfe05714c746dcaf2052da06ae6ad74/specification/mission/resource-manager/readme.md)
json: [Microsoft.Mission/preview/2024-12-01-preview/openapi.json](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/blob/589a07c8dcfe05714c746dcaf2052da06ae6ad74/specification/mission/resource-manager/Microsoft.Mission/preview/2024-12-01-preview/openapi.json)

Is there something that I need to do differently to define this route renaming?
 
Link to [Avocado check](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/pull/22581/checks?check_run_id=45066798540). Thanks!

## answer

Avocado doesn't handle moves/renames.  You can suppress by adding label `Approved-Avocado`."},{"document_source":"static_typespec_qa","document_filename":"typespec_2025_07_31.md","document_title":"TypeSpec Validation error","document_link":"","content":"# typespec_2025_07_31.md

# TypeSpec: How can I change only descriptions/comments between versions while keeping models identical?

## question

Hi TypeSpec Discussion, 
 
What’s the recommended way to change only the documentation (description/comments) between API versions while keeping all properties and models the same?
From what I understand, versioning decorators don’t apply to descriptions/comments, so doc changes propagate to all emitted JSON/OpenAPI versions. I tried versioning a property by removing and re-adding it with an updated comment, but the compiler fails with:
`Model already has a property named 'sku'`
Attempted snippet (simplified):
 
model CapacityReservationUpdate extends UpdateResource {
  /**
   * Properties of the Capacity reservation.
   */
  #suppress "@azure-tools/typespec-azure-core/no-private-usage" "For backward compatibility"
  @Azure.ResourceManager.Private.conditionalClientFlatten
  properties?: CapacityReservationProperties;
 
  /**
   * OLD description...
   */
  @removed(Versions.v2025_04_01)
  sku?: Sku;
 
  /**
   * NEW description for v2025_04_01...
   */
  @added(Versions.v2025_04_01)
  sku?: Sku;
}
 
Question:
Is there a supported approach to have version-specific descriptions (model-level or property-level) without duplicating and renaming the model/property? If not, what’s the best-practice pattern to achieve doc-only differences while keeping the wire shape unchanged?
Context:
Goal: same schema and property names across versions; only descriptions/comments differ.
Error seen: `Model already has a property named 'sku'`.
Thanks in advance for any guidance!

## answer

Documentation changes that improve the documentation should be made without regard to versioning.  Any listed breaking changes in ci checks that are only related to documentation will be easily accepted.  Documentation changes also do not trigger releases of new SDKs.

Documentation changes that improve the documentation should be made without regard to versioning.  Any listed breaking changes in ci checks that are only related to documentation will be easily accepted.  Documentation changes also do not trigger releases of new SDKs.
 
It is almost always possible to make versioned changes (for example, using the add/remove/rename pattern [like this](https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/playground/?options=%7B%22linterRuleSet%22%3A%7B%22extends%22%3A%5B%22%40azure-tools%2Ftypespec-azure-rulesets%2Fresource-manager%22%5D%7D%7D&%%%2FIRyBjcmXEJ3JlcXVlc3QgaGFzIGJlZW4gYWNjZXDkAkXlAN5Bxw46ICLICyLWUGnEQOQAtOkAwchE7ACcOiAizA%2FaTOUCy8RPxUNVxw46ICLIC8o76QYv6QDE5gDcZOcBolN1Y2NlZWTlAMXJDNM%2FxTbkAU1mYWlsyT5GxQ06ICLGCdw4d2FzIGNhbmNlyj5Dxw%2FkBofHC%2F8BQCBkZWxl6QGARMQN5gD5yAsi6QTC6QQ85ANd6QHK6QQ%

/** Employee properties */

  /** Age of employee with updated docs */
  @added(Versions.`2024-10-01-preview`)
  age?: int32;

  /** Age of employee */
  @renamedFrom(Versions.`2024-10-01-preview`, "age")

# How to properly update the TypeSpec environment?

## question

I tried inferring steps from the various installation documents but just managed to break my environment and have no idea how to fix it. 
I saw a recent post where it was said to run `npm install -g @typespec/compiler` to get the latest (0.66) but it looks like it did not work for me. My compiler is still 0.64.
```
NORTHAMERICA+darkoa@darkoa-ws MINGW64 /d/Dev/Projects/git/github/azure-rest-api-specs-pr (RPSaaSMaster)
$ npm install -g @typespec/compiler

changed 268 packages in 11s

34 packages are looking for funding
  run `npm fund` for details

NORTHAMERICA+darkoa@darkoa-ws MINGW64 /d/Dev/Projects/git/github/azure-rest-api-specs-pr (RPSaaSMaster)
$ tsp compile specification/deviceupdate/DeviceUpdate.Edge.Management/
TypeSpec compiler v0.64.0

Diagnostics were reported during compilation:
```
I get a bunch of errors, although we made no changes recently. I am guessing those changes were made by the TypeSpec team and I am also guessing that if I manage to properly update tools, the errors should go away. 
So, is there a single document that describes how to update the environment to the latest?

## answer

The issue you're facing is related to updating your local TypeSpec environment. Here's a summary of the solution:
Update Local Dependencies:
Running npm install -g @typespec/compiler only updates the global TypeSpec compiler, which is not typically used for local development unless you need access to TypeSpec commands globally.
To properly update your local environment, navigate to your repository and run npm ci. This command installs the exact versions of dependencies specified in the package-lock.json, ensuring consistency.
TypeSpec Versions in Repositories:
When working with repositories like azure-rest-api-specs, you should always install dependencies based on the local package.json and package-lock.json at the root of your branch. This ensures you're using the correct version of TypeSpec and associated tools for your current project.
Dealing with Configuration Warnings:
The warnings you're seeing (such as missing options for SDK emitters) are configuration-related, not errors. These warnings appear when SDK emitters for specific languages (like Go, Python, C#) are not installed, but they do not affect your immediate work with TypeSpec validation. These can be safely ignored unless you need to work with SDK generation.
Suppression and Documentation:
If you want to suppress specific warnings, you can modify the suppressions.yaml file, but it's important to follow the TypeSpec guidelines to ensure proper environment configuration."},{"document_source":"static_typespec_qa","document_filename":"typespec_2025_06_26.md","document_title":"Typespec Validation required check","document_link":"","content":"# typespec_2025_06_26.md

# TypeSpec: How can I change only descriptions/comments between versions while keeping models identical?

## question

Hi TypeSpec Discussion, 
 
What’s the recommended way to change only the documentation (description/comments) between API versions while keeping all properties and models the same?
From what I understand, versioning decorators don’t apply to descriptions/comments, so doc changes propagate to all emitted JSON/OpenAPI versions. I tried versioning a property by removing and re-adding it with an updated comment, but the compiler fails with:
`Model already has a property named 'sku'`
Attempted snippet (simplified):
 
model CapacityReservationUpdate extends UpdateResource {
  /**
   * Properties of the Capacity reservation.
   */
  #suppress "@azure-tools/typespec-azure-core/no-private-usage" "For backward compatibility"
  @Azure.ResourceManager.Private.conditionalClientFlatten
  properties?: CapacityReservationProperties;
 
  /**
   * OLD description...
   */
  @removed(Versions.v2025_04_01)
  sku?: Sku;
 
  /**
   * NEW description for v2025_04_01...
   */
  @added(Versions.v2025_04_01)
  sku?: Sku;
}
 
Question:
Is there a supported approach to have version-specific descriptions (model-level or property-level) without duplicating and renaming the model/property? If not, what’s the best-practice pattern to achieve doc-only differences while keeping the wire shape unchanged?
Context:
Goal: same schema and property names across versions; only descriptions/comments differ.
Error seen: `Model already has a property named 'sku'`.
Thanks in advance for any guidance!

## answer

Documentation changes that improve the documentation should be made without regard to versioning.  Any listed breaking changes in ci checks that are only related to documentation will be easily accepted.  Documentation changes also do not trigger releases of new SDKs.

Documentation changes that improve the documentation should be made without regard to versioning.  Any listed breaking changes in ci checks that are only related to documentation will be easily accepted.  Documentation changes also do not trigger releases of new SDKs.
 
It is almost always possible to make versioned changes (for example, using the add/remove/rename pattern [like this](https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/playground/?options=%7B%22linterRuleSet%22%3A%7B%22extends%22%3A%5B%22%40azure-tools%2Ftypespec-azure-rulesets%2Fresource-manager%22%5D%7D%7D&%%%2FIRyBjcmXEJ3JlcXVlc3QgaGFzIGJlZW4gYWNjZXDkAkXlAN5Bxw46ICLICyLWUGnEQOQAtOkAwchE7ACcOiAizA%2FaTOUCy8RPxUNVxw46ICLIC8o76QYv6QDE5gDcZOcBolN1Y2NlZWTlAMXJDNM%2FxTbkAU1mYWlsyT5GxQ06ICLGCdw4d2FzIGNhbmNlyj5Dxw%2FkBofHC%2F8BQCBkZWxl6QGARMQN5gD5yAsi6QTC6QQ85ANd6QHK6QQ%

# Is TypeSpec migration complete for folder: recoveryservicesbackup.

## question

Hi TypeSpec Discussion, 
We had PR in flight: [Adding stable 2025 08 01 for completeness by risraj10 · Pull Request #37381 · Azure/azure-rest-api-…](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/pull/37381)
However, I see that TypeSpec migration was done couple of days ago for this folder. 
I have cancelled the above PR and trying to raise a new PR. However, just running npx tsp compile without any change is giving errors.
And also it is making unintended change to OpenAPI json file even to existing version. I guess the tsp and OpenAPI json are not in sync.
Hence, wanted to check if the migration is really complete for this folder.

## answer

Main typespec validation should always be passing are you sure you are up you are with dependencies locally?
Make sure to follow instructions here https://aka.ms/ci-fix
Just to reiterate, this is almost always because you need to pull the latest from the target branch into your local clone of the repo, and re-install dependencies at the root.

## Create your REST API definition
### [OpenAPI Specs](#tab/openapi)
| Short Link: | [https://aka.ms/azsdkdocs/createopenapispec](https://aka.ms/azsdkdocs/createopenapispec) |
| --- | --- |

To update an existing OpenAPI specification, just edit the specification file and skip to the [Next steps](##next-steps) section.
To create a new OpenAPI spec, additional steps must be taken for services that still rely on OpenAPI:

#### Create new OpenAPI specs

To create a new OpenAPI specs version you need to create a new directory with all the specs files, examples,
and update the readme configuration file manually.

#### Required steps for new OpenAPI versions

When creating a new OpenAPI spec version, you'll need to:

- Create a new directory that will include all the OpenAPI spec files and examples.
- Copy the OpenAPI specs files from an existing version to use it as a base for your new work, and update all the
  old version references in said specs files to the new version.
- Update the Autorest configuration readme with the new version Tag.

After making these changes, commit them to your branch and make the wanted changes in the specification files."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"design#api-review.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-review","content":"# Schedule a data plane REST API spec review
## Prepare for API review
When you have your REST API definition ready for review, [create a pull request with your Azure REST API spec update](xref:api-specs-pr).

You should prepare and be ready to present the following information during your review:

| Title | Importance | Brief description | Example and support documentation |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |

API spec PR link | Must Have | PR with your API spec definition against [azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr](https://github.com/azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr) or [azure/azure-rest-api-specs](https://github.com/azure/azure-rest-api-specs) | In order to access the PR, it may be necessary to join the [Azure GitHub organization](https://repos.opensource.microsoft.com/orgs/Azure). <p><p><ol><li>Go to https://repos.opensource.microsoft.com/orgs/Azure</li><li>Click **Join Organization**.</li></ol><p><p>The PR should be linked to the issue no less than 2 days before your meeting. To properly link your PR, in the issue click on the settings icon next to `Development` on the right side:<p><p>![Screenshot](../img/link-pr.png)  |
API spec PR CI checks | Important |Make sure all CI is passing before requesting a review. | [ci-fix](https://aka.ms/ci-fix) |
Core concepts | Must have | A glossary of nouns and verbs  | [Example](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-pr/blob/main/onboarding/Core_Concepts.pdf)
API reference docs | Good to have | Your API documentation consists of two parts, the API spec document (TypeSpec/OpenAPI spec), and the generated developer docs. These docs are often the first experience a developer will have with your service. Make a good first impression!!| **Recommended for OpenAPI spec**: [VS Code extension](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=42Crunch.vscode-openapi) load this extension and then open your OpenAPI spec file in VS Code and select **Preview**. <p><p><ol><li>Go to your PR and look for the comment added by the `openapi-pipeline-app bot` and title `Swagger Generation Artifacts`."},{"document_source":"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki","document_filename":"Swagger-Avocado.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Swagger-Avocado","content":"# Known Issues
## MULTIPLE_API_VERSION
Rule [MULTIPLE_API_VERSION](https://github.com/Azure/avocado?tab=readme-ov-file#multiple_api_version) was changed from a warning to an error on 7/1/2025. As this issue is a blocker to TypeSpec conversion which is an Azure wide effort to drive the API first design pattern among all Azure services.

If your PR is blocked due to this error, please check out this [Uniform Versioning Violation Guide](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Uniform-Versioning-Violation-Guide) wiki on how to resolve this.

Please check with azversioning@service.microsoft.com to see if your service can have one-time suppression if you are not sure."},{"document_source":"typespec_azure_docs","document_filename":"migrate-swagger#faq#pipeline.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/migrate-swagger/faq/pipeline","content":"# Resolving Pipeline Failures
## Swagger BreakingChange
### Multiple OpenAPI Files Before Migration
This pipeline will fail if there is more than one OpenAPI file in the latest version. See the detailed explanation in this [issue](https://github.com/Azure/typespec-azure/issues/2194#issue-2844564216).

To properly identify real breaking changes, use the "TypeSpec Migration Validation" pipeline instead:

1. Navigate to the TypeSpec Migration Validation pipeline
2. Check the report on the "Summary" page
3. The output should match exactly what you see in [this step](../01-get-started.md#review-and-adjust-the-typespec) on the local machine
4. Review the changes to verify they are expected"},{"document_source":"typespec_docs","document_filename":"standard-library#built-in-decorators.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://typespec.io/docs/standard-library/built-in-decorators","content":"# Built-in Decorators
## TypeSpec
### `@pattern` {#@pattern}
Specify the the pattern this string should respect using simple regular expression syntax.
The following syntax is allowed: alternations (`|`), quantifiers (`?`, `*`, `+`, and `{ }`), wildcard (`.`), and grouping parentheses.
Advanced features like look-around, capture groups, and references are not supported.
This decorator may optionally provide a custom validation _message_. Emitters may choose to use the message to provide
context when pattern validation fails. For the sake of consistency, the message should be a phrase that describes in
plain language what sort of content the pattern attempts to validate. For example, a complex regular expression that
validates a GUID string might have a message like "Must be a valid GUID."
```typespec
@pattern(pattern: valueof string, validationMessage?: valueof string)
```
#### Target
`string | bytes | ModelProperty`
#### Parameters
| Name | Type | Description |
|------|------|-------------|
| pattern | [valueof `string`](#string) | Regular expression. |
| validationMessage | [valueof `string`](#string) | Optional validation message that may provide context when validation fails. |
#### Examples
```typespec
@pattern("[a-z]+", "Must be a string consisting of only lower case letters and of at least one character.")
scalar LowerAlpha extends string;
```"},{"document_source":"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki","document_filename":"Resolving-Folder-Migration-Conflicts:-A-Guide-for-PR-Authors.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Resolving-Folder-Migration-Conflicts:-A-Guide-for-PR-Authors","content":"# Resolving Folder Migration Conflicts: A Guide for PR Authors
## The impact to ongoing PRs
### After Resolution
Make sure to compile the TypeSpec project so that the TypeSpec Validation could pass.

1. **Comprehensive validation**:
   ```bash
   # Run full validation suite
   npm ci
   npm run lint
   npm run validate
   
   # Test TypeSpec compilation for your service
   cd specification/app/data-plane/DynamicSessions/
   npx tsp compile .
   npx tsp compile . --emit @azure-tools/typespec-autorest
   
   # Verify generated files match expectations by checking if there's any diff with the OpenAPI json files.
   ```"},{"document_source":"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki","document_filename":"TypeSpec-Validation.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/TypeSpec-Validation","content":"# Running Locally
To ensure you see the same results from TypeSpecValidation in your PR check and `tsv` on your local machine:
1. Merge latest from parent (e.g. `main` or `RPSaaSMaster`) to your PR branch
2. Run locally
   1. `git clean -xdf` (may revert any local changes)
   2. `git pull`
   3. `npm ci`
   4. `npx tsv specification/widget/resource-manager/Microsoft.Widget/Widget`
   5. `git status`
   6. If any changes, `git add`, `git commit`, `git push` to update your PR.
3. If you are still having problems, try cloning your branch to a new folder, or try on another machine.
4. If the problem can be reproduced on a clean machine, request assistance from the [TypeSpec Discussion](https://teams.microsoft.com/l/channel/19%3A906c1efbbec54dc8949ac736633e6bdf%40thread.skype/TypeSpec%20Discussion?groupId=3e17dcb0-4257-4a30-b843-77f47f1d4121&tenantId=72f988bf-86f1-41af-91ab-2d7cd011db47) teams channel."},{"document_source":"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki","document_filename":"API-Spec-Review-FAQ.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/API-Spec-Review-FAQ","content":"Answers to frequently asked questions in the [Api Spec Review](https://teams.microsoft.com/l/channel/19%3A0351f5f9404446e4b4fd4eaf2c27448d%40thread.skype/API%20Spec%20Review?groupId=3e17dcb0-4257-4a30-b843-77f47f1d4121&tenantId=72f988bf-86f1-41af-91ab-2d7cd011db47). Within that channel, EngSys should be answering questions about validation pipelines and tools that run in those pipelines. Specific questions about typespec, the API Review process, etc. should be answered by others who specialize in those topics. 

| If the question is about | The answer should be | 
| --- | --- | 
| Authoring typespec | Send to [TypeSpec Discussions](https://teams.microsoft.com/l/channel/19%3A906c1efbbec54dc8949ac736633e6bdf%40thread.skype/TypeSpec%20Discussion?groupId=3e17dcb0-4257-4a30-b843-77f47f1d4121&tenantId=72f988bf-86f1-41af-91ab-2d7cd011db47) | 
| My PR is ready to review, will someone review it? | See the "Next steps to merge" comment in your PR and follow directions to ensure you're in the review queue. No need to post here. | 
| API Doc Preview is broken | If the error message linked doesn't make sense, follow instructions at [Troubleshooting REST API documentation](https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-docs-troubleshooting). API Doc Preview is not a required check so you can ignore the failure if it's not relevant to your documentation needs. |
| My PR needs to be reviewed by the ARM team right now | PRs are generally reviewed in order of the ARM queue.  If your PR needs special treatment, you can contact the ARM team: https://aka.ms/armofficehoursinfo | 
| I need a review to merge changes to a non-standard branch (e.g. not `main`, `RPSaaSMaster`, etc.) | Contact the owner of that branch. |
| EngSys is behaving badly in my non-standard/release branch | Update the state of the branch to match with `main`. The owner of the release branch is responsible for doing this."},{"document_source":"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki","document_filename":"TypeSpec-Validation.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/TypeSpec-Validation","content":"# Examples Source and Destination
If you are having problems with diffs from "tsp compile" related to examples, ensure you understand how examples flow from source to destination.
The **source** of examples is under your TypeSpec source code folder, and the **destination** of examples is under the Swagger folder.  The TypeSpec compiler copies from source to destination.  In our sample: 
* source
  * https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/tree/main/specification/contosowidgetmanager/Contoso.Management/examples/2021-10-01-preview 
* destination
  * https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/tree/main/specification/contosowidgetmanager/resource-manager/Microsoft.Contoso/preview/2021-10-01-preview/examples
If you are changing examples, you must **first** change the copy under your TypeSpec folder, and then run `tsp compile` (or `tsv` which calls `compile`) to update the copies in your Swagger folder."},{"document_source":"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki","document_filename":"Deprecating-Preview-APIs.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Deprecating-Preview-APIs","content":"## Process
1. Open a PR deleting one (or more) previews.  All of:
   1. TypeSpec sources (`*.tsp`)
   2. Example sources (examples closest to `*.tsp` files)
   3. Generated swaggers and examples (`preview/YYYY-MM-DD-preview/**`)
   4. readme.md (remove tags)
2. PR should fail check `Swagger BreakingChange`, but pass all other checks.
3. Request approval following the normal process for breaking changes
   - https://aka.ms/brch
   - azbreakchangereview@microsoft.com"},{"document_source":"typespec_http_specs","document_filename":"type#model#inheritance#not-discriminated#main.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://github.com/microsoft/typespec/tree/main/packages/http-specs/specs/type/model/inheritance/not-discriminated/main.tsp","content":"# Usages for Illustrates not-discriminated inheritance model.
## Scenario: Generate and send model.
``` typespec
@route("/valid")
@post
op postValid(@body input: Siamese): NoContentResponse;
```

## Scenario: Generate and receive model.

```"},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"design#api-specs#api-tooling.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-specs/api-tooling","content":"# Use tools to create and validate Azure REST APIs specs
## [Author With TypeSpec](#tab/author-with-typespec)
Author specs with TypeSpec (**recommended approach**)

REST APIs authored in [TypeSpec](xref:api-typespec) with the [Azure TypeSpec libraries] have validation built in.
Compiling the TypeSpec definition will validate the REST API against the Azure API guidelines.
The TypeSpec compiler will also generate an [OpenAPI](xref:api-openapi) definition for the REST API.

> [!TIP]
> TypeSpec has [plugins for Visual Studio and Visual Studio Code][TypeSpec plugins] that will highlight errors and
warnings in your TypeSpec definition.

TypeSpec is the recommended way for generating OpenAPI specs."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"design#api-specs#api-tooling.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-specs/api-tooling","content":"# Use tools to create and validate Azure REST APIs specs
## [Author with OpenAPI](#tab/author-with-openapi)
Author specs with OpenAPI (**legacy approach**)

For REST APIs that cannot be written in TypeSpec and still must be written directly in the OpenAPI format, you can:

- Use [OpenAPI Initiative Swagger editor] for basic authoring.
- Learn about the [spec directory structure].
- Use the [Spectral linter] and the [Azure Spectral ruleset] to validate your OpenAPI definition against the Azure API
  guidelines.
  - Spectral provides a [VSCode plugin][Spectral VSCode plugin] that will highlight errors and warnings in your
    OpenAPI definition in VSCode.

Your OpenAPI definitions, to be published, will have to end up in the specs repos as explained in  
[this article](xref:api-specs). As such, they will be subject to additional mandatory validation requirements.
See [validate your REST API](#validate-your-rest-api-specs) section to learn about them."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"design#api-specs#api-typespec.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-specs/api-typespec","content":"# What is TypeSpec?
## Case Studies
### Azure AI Content Safety
[Case Study](https://microsoft.sharepoint.com/:w:/t/AzureDeveloperExperience/EdlE2PYtZ9BKoXQ-R0h-O10B9RidePBT4mwB1JgIqRC01A?e=JRneI2)

> "I find TypeSpec to be much simpler to learn and write compared to Swagger. In my experience, Swagger often encounters many conflicts due to its JSON format. TypeSpec proves to be a much better alternative as it allows everyone to work independently on their own sections, making it more user-friendly. Furthermore, TypeSpec allows for the separate definition of models and routes. So, from my perspective, it's a superior choice at present.""}]
rows.inputs.testcase: doc only update?
rows.outputs.similarity.similarity_sample_inp: [{"role": "user", "content": "{\"query\": \"title: doc only update?\\n\\nquestion: Hey team,\\nI'm a PM on the VMSS team. I'm trying to understand the new Typespec way to do a documentation only update to swagger? In this case, I just want to update these doc strings to remove/modify the preview notes. I believe I updated the correct text in the models.tsp files. The swagger compiled correctly. Now my questions:\\nI want this to be updated in current documentation posted online, as well as SDK docs. How do I submit this change against main or the latest feature branch? Do I need to do additional work to make sure this change is propagated through to SDKs?\\nWhen I submitted the PR, got this error. Not sure how to fix: \\\"The default tag contains multiple API versions swaggers.\\\"\\nThe PR for reference:\\n[VMSS prioritizeunhealthyvm and force delete doc update by fitzgeraldsteele \\u00b7 Pull Request #25785 ](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/pull/25785)\", \"response\": \"You are following the correct process for a documentation-only update in TypeSpec. Documentation/comments (docstrings) in TypeSpec models are emitted into both the generated OpenAPI/Swagger and SDK docs, provided you compile with TypeSpec and check in the results. No special versioning is required for doc-only changes\\u2014just update the comments in your TypeSpec source and recompile.\\n\\n**How to submit the change:**\\n- Submit your PR against `main` in the azure-rest-api-specs repo. This is the standard branch for public documentation and SDK generation, unless your team is actively working in a feature branch that is not yet merged to main.\\n- Make sure your PR only includes the updated TypeSpec source and the newly compiled Swagger (OpenAPI JSON files), plus examples if changed.\\n- No additional work is needed to propagate the changes to SDKs\\u2014the docstrings will be picked up automatically in the next SDK generation cycle once the PR is merged.\\n\\n**Resolving the CI error: \\\"The default tag contains multiple API versions swaggers\\\":**\\n- This error is caused by the presence of more than one OpenAPI file in the default tag for the API version. This is a hard blocker in the TypeSpec migration pipeline, and you must resolve it before your doc-only update can be accepted.\\n- To fix this, ensure that only one OpenAPI file is present in the default tag. Remove any additional swagger files from the default tag in the readme configuration (usually `readme.md`). For more details, refer to the guidance: https://github.com/Azure/typespec-azure/issues/2194#issue-2844564216\\n- If you are unsure which file should be kept, keep only the latest stable or preview version intended for public documentation and SDK generation.\\n\\n**Summary:**\\n- Make docstring changes in TypeSpec source, recompile, and submit against main.\\n- Remove any duplicate OpenAPI files from the default tag to resolve the CI error.\\n- No extra steps needed for SDK propagation; documentation changes do not trigger new SDK releases unless API surface changes are made.\\n\\nIf you need more help with migration conflicts, see: https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Resolving-Folder-Migration-Conflicts:-A-Guide-for-PR-Authors\\nAnd for validation steps: https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/TypeSpec-Validation\", \"ground_truth\": \"Swagger and TSP must always match.  So the same PR, but to public/main instead of private/main.The error from \\\"Swagger Avocado\\\" is an existing problem in your spec, that should be fixed eventually.  See this run from a previous PR to your spec.\\nhttps://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/actions/runs/18538687430\\nDocs:\\nhttps://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Swagger-Avocado#multiple_api_version\"}"}]

rows.inputs.query:
title: Do ARM SDKs support OData filtering like the APIs do?

question: For list operations in our resource provider, we know we can perform filtering, sorting and searching using query parameters ($filter, $sort, $search) in our  API calls, and we've implemented the backend support for these queries already.
Is it possible to do the same sort of server side filtering (or generally add logic to include query parameters with certain calls) with our Azure SDKs as well?
rows.inputs.response:
Yes, Azure ARM (management plane) SDKs can pass OData-style query parameters such as `$filter`, `$orderby`, and `$search` to enable server-side filtering, sorting, and searching on list operations, mirroring what is supported by the REST APIs. This is a standard pattern for ARM resource providers and is required by the ARM RPC contract for collection/list operations.

To ensure SDKs expose these query parameters:
- In your API specification (ideally using TypeSpec), define these query parameters on your list operations using the appropriate decorators and traits.
- For TypeSpec, Azure provides standard models and traits for OData query parameters (like `FilterQueryParameter`, `OrderByQueryParameter`, and `StandardListQueryParameters`) in the `Azure.Core` library. These can be composed into list operations via traits, so SDK generators will surface them as arguments in the generated SDK methods.
- When you use these traits, the generated SDK methods for list operations will include parameters for `$filter`, `$orderby`, `$search`, etc. This enables consumers to pass these values in SDK calls, and they will be sent as query parameters in the HTTP requests.

Example TypeSpec usage:
```typespec
import "@azure-tools/typespec-azure-core";
using Azure.Core;
using Azure.Core.Traits;

op listWidgets is Azure.Core.ResourceList<
  Widget,
  ListQueryParametersTrait<StandardListQueryParameters & FilterQueryParameter & OrderByQueryParameter>
>;
```

This will generate SDK methods with arguments for filtering, sorting, and pagination, matching the REST API behavior.

**Summary:** As long as your API spec declares the OData query parameters on the list operation, the SDKs generated for Azure ARM will expose them as method arguments. No special SDK logic is needed beyond this; the SDKs will pass these parameters through to the REST API endpoints. If you use TypeSpec, leverage the standard Azure traits and models to ensure consistent and compliant exposure of these parameters.
