[{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"develop#sdk-generate-mgmt-dotnet.md","document_title":"Generate .NET management plane SDK","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/develop/sdk-generate-mgmt-dotnet","content":"# develop#sdk-generate-mgmt-dotnet.md

# Generate .NET management plane SDK

Azure service engineering team is required to work on .NET management plane SDKs.

>[!IMPORTANT]
> The instructions in this document are for generating SDK from an OpenAPI API spec.
> If your API spec is authored on Typespec, follow the instructions in [Generate SDKs](xref:sdk-develop#generate-sdk)

## Before you begin

- You have completed the same prerequisites listed in the [Develop SDK - Before you begin](xref:sdk-develop) section.
- Ensure that you have the latest version of [PowerShell](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/scripting/install/installing-powershell-on-windows) 
installed to run all commands successfully.

## Prerequisites for contributing

:point_right: Read [azure-sdk-for-net/CONTRIBUTING.md](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-net/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md)

:point_right: The guidance is mainly about contributing in the public SDK repositories for .NET. If you require assistance
with working on a feature that needs to be kept confidential until it is publicly available, reach out to us through the 
[Teams channel](#get-help) for additional support.

## Generate SDKs with OpenAPI

- Specify a target version using `tag` as belows if you don't want to use the default tag in [the README configuration file](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/documentation/samplefiles/README.md). For example,

```
tag: package-2022-01-01-preview
```

> [!NOTE]
> To ensure the preview of the corresponding .NET SDK in the API Spec PR, refrain from adding the tag here. Instead, use the default tag to generate the SDK and preview it as desired.

2. Run `dotnet build` command to generate the SDK code, then AutoRest will create your .NET SDK using the latest version of your API specs.

```
dotnet build /t:GenerateCode
```

> [!NOTE]
> Currently there could be some compatibility issues that the AutoRest tool can't handle. If you encounter generation errors, file an issue in the GitHub Repo [Azure/azure-sdk-for-net](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-net) to get support.

3. Generate the API file with the following command, review it and update any SDK API if it does not follow the [.NET Azure SDK Design Guidelines](https://azure.github.io/azure-sdk/dotnet_introduction.html) with [mgmt configurations](https://github.com/Azure/autorest.csharp/blob/feature/v3/docs/mgmt/readme.md#management-plane-configurations) in `autorest.md`. Then regenerate the API file.

```
<RepoRoot>\eng\scripts\Export-API.ps1 servicelinker
```

:point_right: Replace `servicelinker` with your SDK service directory name under azure-sdk-for-net\sdk.

4. Once the SDK is generated, build your project either in VS or from command line (follow steps in the section [Build & test SDKs](#build--test-sdks)

`Azure.ResourceManager.ServiceLinker` is being used as our prime example for OpenAPI.

1. Use any editor to open the `autorest.md` under `src` subfolder, and update:

    - Go to the [ServiceLinker readme.md in Azure REST API Specs Repo](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/specification/servicelinker/resource-manager/readme.md), press 'Y' key to [get the permanent link](https://docs.github.com/en/repositories/working-with-files/using-files/getting-permanent-links-to-files) and substitute the `require` value with your specific path here:

```
require: https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/{guid}/specification/servicelinker/resource-manager/readme.md
```

> [!NOTE]
>  * You can use a local patch as the value, which allows you to test an unpublished local OpenAPI spec.
>  * When releasing your SDKs, it must refer to [the `main` branch of the public Azure REST API specs repository](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/tree/main/specification). Other branches, private repos, or personal repos are **NOT** supported to release an official Azure SDK.
>  * If you need to generate SDKs from specs in [the private REST API Specs repo](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr), there is [an extra step to handle the credential for autorest](https://github.com/Azure/autorest/blob/main/docs/generate/readme.md#generate-from-private-github-repos).

    - Specify a target version using `tag` as belows if you don't want to use the default tag in [the README configuration file](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/documentation/samplefiles/README.md). For example,

```
tag: package-2022-01-01-preview
```

> [!NOTE]
> To ensure the preview of the corresponding .NET SDK in the API Spec PR, refrain from adding the tag here. Instead, use the default tag to generate the SDK and preview it as desired.

## Build & test SDKs

Launch command prompt or PowerShell. Navigate to the subfolder of your project cloned to local workstation. Use `dotnet` command to build and test the project. Take `Azure.ResourceManager` for example:

```
cd .\sdk\resourcemanager\Azure.ResourceManager\
dotnet build /* This builds the Azure.ResourceManager SDK. */
dotnet test -f net6.0 /* This builds the Azure.ResourceManager SDK and run tests with Net 6.0. */
dotnet pack /* This builds Azure.ResourceManager SDK, skips running tests, and finally creates Azure.ResourceManager nuget package. */
```

## Next steps

- [Write tests](xref:sdk-test)
- [Write samples](xref:sdk-samples)
- [Release Management Plane SDK for .NET](xref:sdk-release-mgmt-dotnet)

## Get help

[Code Generation - .NET](https://teams.microsoft.com/l/channel/19%3Aacbd512e57bd475198ea6bf4564599e3%40thread.skype/Code%20Generation%20-%20.NET?groupId=3e17dcb0-4257-4a30-b843-77f47f1d4121&tenantId=72f988bf-86f1-41af-91ab-2d7cd011db47)."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"develop#sdk-release#sdk-release-prerequisites.md","document_title":"Prerequisites to release client libraries (SDK)","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/develop/sdk-release/sdk-release-prerequisites","content":"# develop#sdk-release#sdk-release-prerequisites.md

# Prerequisites to release client libraries (SDK)

After [executing the automation to generate SDKs](xref:sdk-generate) directly from your API
specification in TypeSpec, it is necessary to perform all required tasks outlined on this page before 
[initiating the SDK release pipeline](xref:sdk-release-pipeline) for publication.

## Before you begin

- You have completed [the SDK generation](xref:sdk-generate) and created an SDK pull requests to the respective Azure SDK repository.
- For an initial SDK release of your service, ensure that the [review of your SDK package
  name](xref:namespace-review) — specified in the tspconfig.yaml configuration file — has been completed.

## Customize SDKs

After generating client code with automation, it may be necessary to rename models, attributes, operations,
or parameters to maintain consistent naming conversions.

> [!NOTE]
> Azure SDK mandates adherence to a consistent set of naming conventions, which significantly enhances the overall usability of the SDK. For instance, in the case of Azure SDK for .NET, developers are required not only to follow the [general naming conventions of .NET](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/standard/design-guidelines/general-naming-conventions), but also to comply with specific guidelines regarding the naming of classes, properties, and methods. Further information is available at [Azure SDK for .NET – naming conventions](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-net/blob/main/doc/dev/Mgmt-Naming-Conventions.md). Guidelines for additional languages are available at the [Azure SDKs site](https://azure.github.io/azure-sdk/general_introduction.html)

To customize the SDK as needed, you need to configure `client.tsp`. More details can be found at the 
[setup for SDK customization]( https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/howtos/generate-client-libraries/01setup/)
and [renaming types](https://azure.github.io/typespec-azure/docs/howtos/generate-client-libraries/09renaming/#customizations). 

After set up SDK customization and apply renaming, ensure to re-run the SDK generation to regenerate the client libraries.

## Resolve Breaking Changes

The automation that generates the SDKs detect and report any breaking changes in the APIs to maintain backward compatibility.
It is necessary to review these breaking changes, retaining only those that are unavoidable and have been evaluated and
approved through the [CPEX Breaking Changes Review Process](https://eng.ms/docs/cloud-ai-platform/azure-core/azure-core-product/product-lifecycle-management-plm/service-lifecycle-and-actions-team/service-lifecycle-actions-team/cpex/media/overview_breaking_changes#cpex-breaking-changes-review-process).

> [!NOTE]
> CPEX (Cloud Product Excellence) Breaking Change Policy documentation covers Azure's requirements on service versioning and breaking changes. Generally, we must avoid introducing any breaking changes into our services, products, APIs, or SDKs. If a breaking change is unavoidable, we must provide customers a three-year notification for migration and fully support the prior versions during that period. More details about CPEX Breaking Changes Review Process can be found at this [Azure Breaking Changes](https://eng.ms/docs/cloud-ai-platform/azure-core/azure-core-product/product-lifecycle-management-plm/service-lifecycle-and-actions-team/service-lifecycle-actions-team/cpex/media/overview_breaking_changes) page.

## Commit tests

SDK usability is essential for customer success, so our SDKs must include tests.

For GA SDK releases of the management plane, .NET recommends live tests to ensure compatibility with the new service version.

For the data plane, according to the target phase of your SDK, these are the requirements you need to accomplish before the SDK release:

- Public preview: at least one test per language for the most common usage scenario.
- GA: at least one test per shipped method.

Additional resources on adding SDK tests for various languages and SDK types are available at [test SDKs](xref:sdk-test).

## Write samples

Every SDK needs a quickstart guide with code samples, as developers prefer learning from examples over lengthy documentation.

Each management plane SDK release needs at least one sample per language for the main usage scenario.

For the data plane, according to the target phase of your SDK, these are the requirements you need to accomplish
before the SDK release:

- Public preview: at least one sample per language for the most common usage scenario.
- GA: at least 4 samples for the most common usage scenario.

Additional resources on adding SDK samples for various languages and SDK types are available at [write SDK samples](xref:sdk-samples).

## Update CHANGELOG file

When SDK generation happens with automation, it automatically updates the `CHANGELOG.md` to track changes.
The updates include:
- Replacing `(unreleased)` with the current date in “YYYY-MM-DD” format. 

> [!NOTE]
> Prior to starting the SDK release pipelines, you should confirm that the date for the latest version to be released
is up to date to; or it can lead to pipeline failures.

- Summarizing version updates under Features Added, Breaking Changes, Bug Fixes, and Other Changes.

> [!NOTE]
> To revise, you should only include sections that have content, leaving nonblank.

Take an example of the [CHANGELOG.md of Azure Core](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-net/blob/main/sdk/core/Azure.Core/CHANGELOG.md)

## Get SDK pull request merged

Once you confirm

:white_check_mark: your SDK libraries are generated

:white_check_mark: tests and samples are added

:white_check_mark:`CHANGELOG.md` is up to date

All changes should be committed to the pull request generated by the SDK generation automation (if not already present).
Monitor and address review comments from the SDK engineer for each language as needed until approval is granted to merge
the pull request.

> [!NOTE]
> For GA releases, .NET requires APIView approval from the .NET SDK owner on the SDK pull request for release."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"support#sdk-contribs.md","document_title":"Get Azure SDK EngSys Help","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/support/sdk-contribs","content":"# support#sdk-contribs.md

# Get Azure SDK EngSys Help

> [!NOTE]
> For general, top-level "Get Help" support page, see [here](xref:support).

The Azure SDK engineering system has many [benefits] and [features] that we provide for the Azure SDK team and partners.

<!-- markdownlint-disable MD013 -->
**_The stated goal and purpose of the Engineering System team is to be a force multiplier for all teams delivering SDK libraries to Azure customers._**
By funding a centralized EngSys team the Azure SDK engineering system grows and
improves deliberately and thoughtfully rather than organically and inefficiently.
This also means we have a centralized team that SDK developers can turn to for help when GitHub, DevOps, 1ES, Maven,
NuGet, Azure, or any other dependent system is down or not functioning properly, and that team can drive
the communication and resolution of such issues.

This document details how to get help when using the tools and processes we support. We provide assistance and support
at two levels based on the status of the library in our engineering system.

## Onboarded libraries

The first level of support is for teams and partners seeking assistance related to a library that is onboarded to the
Azure SDK engineering system.  This means the following are true:

1. Your source code is contained in and built from one of our public language-specific GitHub mono-repos
(e.g. [azure-sdk-for-python](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python)).
2. You release using our release pipelines (not [partner release pipelines]).
3. Your reference docs are released to [learn.microsoft.com] automatically as part of our release pipelines.

If the above are true for you and you need assistance, you will get support from either an Azure SDK language team
(for language-specific tools and processes) or from the Azure SDK engineering system team
(for all cross-language tools and processes). As a team, we are committed to providing business hours support
(max 24 hours SLA) if you are blocked from building or releasing using our shared engineering system.

## Libraries that aren't onboarded

Libraries that are not onboarded to our shared engineering system do not receive the same level of support.
Teams and partners who have not onboarded to the Azure SDK engineering system will have one or more
of the following be true:

1. The source code for your library is not in our public, language-specific, GitHub mono-repos.
2. You use the [partner release pipelines] to release your packages publicly.
3. You release reference docs that are included in our TOC on [learn.microsoft.com], but not through our
   release pipelines.

If any of these criteria are true for the library you are seeking assistance for, you will get support from the
Azure SDK engineering system team during business hours with a 5 business day SLA for actionable responses.

## Where to get help

- [Engineering System Teams channel]

[benefits]: https://dev.azure.com/azure-sdk/internal/_wiki/wikis/internal.wiki/33/Benefits-of-a-shared-Engineering-System
[features]: https://dev.azure.com/azure-sdk/internal/_wiki/wikis/internal.wiki/367/Capabilities-and-State
[partner release pipelines]: https://aka.ms/azsdk/partner-release-pipeline
[learn.microsoft.com]: https://learn.microsoft.com
[Engineering System Teams channel]: https://teams.microsoft.com/l/channel/19%3a59dbfadafb5e41c4890e2cd3d74cc7ba%40thread.skype/Engineering%2520System%2520%25F0%259F%259B%25A0%25EF%25B8%258F?groupId=3e17dcb0-4257-4a30-b843-77f47f1d4121&tenantId=72f988bf-86f1-41af-91ab-2d7cd011db47"},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"support#troubleshoot#engsys.md","document_title":"Help! The engineering system itself is broken","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/support/troubleshoot/engsys","content":"# support#troubleshoot#engsys.md

# Help! The engineering system itself is broken

Oh no! This happens from time to time when one of our dependencies (e.g. Maven Central or Azure Pipelines) goes offline
or starts having service issues. It is also possible for the Engineering System team to inadvertently introduce
a problem which breaks our build and release pipelines.

If you believe that the engineering system itself is failing
(as opposed to something in your PR causing a build/test failure), reach out to the Azure SDK Engineering System team.
Our preferred method is for you to drop a message in our Teams Channel.

- [Azure SDK / Engineering System]

Note that when one of our dependencies goes offline we often just need to wait the issue out unless there is a simple
mitigation. You can see the latest status updates for many of our dependencies on this channel:

- [Azure SDK / System Status]

For tools connected with the REST API specs used in the [Azure/azure-rest-api-specs] repo refer to:

- [This support page](xref:support#get-help-with-prs-submitted-against-the-azure-rest-api-specification-repositories)

## Escalation via e-mail

Generally, the Azure SDK team prefers to use Microsoft Teams. However, if you would prefer to e-mail
the Azure SDK Engineering System team you can use the following address:

[Azure/azure-rest-api-specs]: https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs"},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"develop#sdk-release#sdk-release.md","document_title":"Release SDK","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/develop/sdk-release/sdk-release","content":"# develop#sdk-release#sdk-release.md

# Release SDK

| Short Link: | [azsdk/releases/partnerinfo](https://aka.ms/azsdk/releases/partnerinfo) |
| --- | --- |

> [!IMPORTANT]
> TypeSpec usage for API definition is a mandatory requirement for all new (greenfield) data plane and management plane
> services. This requirement is enforced by the ARM API Review Board for management plane services and by the API
> Stewardship Board for data plane services.
> Brownfield services will eventually be required to transition to TypeSpec as well.  PRs for brownfields services
> that have not transitioned to TypeSpec will receive notices in FY2024, followed by warnings in FY2025 and
> errors in FY2027. The requirement to move to TypeSpec will ensure a consistent, high-quality developer experience across
> Azure that aligns with Azure SDK guidelines. For more information on TypeSpec, visit [here](xref:api-typespec).

## Before you begin

- You have [access](xref:access) to the GitHub repositories, respective GitHub groups, and release security groups.
- You have a [release plan](xref:release-plan) created to manage and understand the steps required to generate,
test, and release an SDK.
- The REST API specs need to be merged in the main branch of the public repository [Azure/azure-rest-api-specs](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs).
- Ensure to complete all tasks outlined on this page [Prerequisites to release SDKs](xref:sdk-release-prerequisites).
- Breaking changes to GAed SDKs are not permitted as they conflict with the  
[Azure SDK design principle](https://azure.github.io/azure-sdk/general_introduction.html#dependable).
If breaking changes are inevitable, ensure to get approval from [Azure Breaking Changes Board](https://aka.ms/azbreakingchangespolicy)
in your service API Spec review.
- Ensure your service is available to the public before the SDK release date.

## When to release

### [Management plane (ARM)](#tab/management)

The Azure SDK release processes for management plane SDKs vary based on the API specification type

- TypeSpec: On demand.
- Open API: Request a release **before the cutoff date** for the month that you're targeting.

:point_right: 2nd Friday of every month: Cutoff date

:point_right: 4th Friday of every month: Release date

The functionality to request a release for Java, JavaScript, Python, and Go is available as part of the
management plane release plan. You can learn more about release plans [here](xref:release-plan).

For releasing the .NET SDK release follow the [.NET release process](xref:sdk-release-mgmt-dotnet).

### [Data plane](#tab/dataplane)

Although releases happen every month, you can release the SDK on demand. The Azure SDK team follows a monthly
release calendar where we minimize disruptions to the release tools as much as possible.
Outside of those dates, the tools might not be as stable.

[Release Calendar](https://teams.microsoft.com/l/entity/com.microsoft.teamspace.tab.planner/_djb2_msteams_prefix_1611974298?context=%7B%22subEntityId%22%3Anull%2C%22channelId%22%3A%2219%3Adc2e34377e494a9292d89fbc34125eae%40thread.skype%22%7D&groupId=3e17dcb0-4257-4a30-b843-77f47f1d4121&tenantId=72f988bf-86f1-41af-91ab-2d7cd011db47):
This calendar shows the Package Code Freeze and Package Ship dates for the year.

## Breaking change policy

- Requires approval from Azure SDK Architecture Team <azsdkarch@microsoft.com>
- More information: http://aka.ms/AzBreakingChangesPolicy/

## Next steps

- For each released package by going to the public feed and verifying:
  - Metadata - Verify that the links, documentation, readme, etc. are correct and appear as expected.
  - Download - Download the package and verify that it is the same one you built/published.
- In your release plan, mark the **Release SDK** task as completed and proceed to complete the release plan.
- [Verify SDK reference docs](xref:sdk-docs)
- Verify the content of the release notes PR generated during the release pipeline. Review and approve the PR. See [Producing Release Notes](https://azure.github.io/azure-sdk/policies_releasenotes.html) for details.
- The release pipeline will submit a PR with a version bump for each SDK in their respective language repository.
You need to review and merge each version bump pull request.

## Get help

### [Management plane (ARM)](#tab/management)

[Azure SDK - SDK Release Support](https://teams.microsoft.com/l/channel/19%3A084875bb626242ed95f3ac8dddfaa12a%40thread.skype/SDK%20release%20support?groupId=3e17dcb0-4257-4a30-b843-77f47f1d4121&tenantId=72f988bf-86f1-41af-91ab-2d7cd011db47).

### [Data plane](#tab/dataplane)

If you have any questions about the general release process, please reach out to either of the [Azure SDK Release PMs](#azure-sdk-release-pm)
listed. If your question is related to one of the language specific release processes or you're having
issues using a language specific release process, please reach out to the relative  
[Release Driver](#release-driver--build-facilitating-developer) for that language.

#### Azure SDK release PM

- Ronnie Geraghty rgeraghty@microsoft.com

#### Release driver / Build facilitating developer

- .NET: Jonathan Cardenas Jonathan.Cardenas@microsoft.com
- Java: Jair Myree jairmyree@microsoft.com
- JS: Timo van Veenendaal timov@microsoft.com
- Python: Kashif Khan kashifkhan@microsoft.com
- C/C++: Anton Kolesnyk Anton.Kolesnyk@microsoft.com
- Go: Grace Wilcox gracewilcox@microsoft.com
- Android: Victor Colin victor.colin@microsoft.com
- iOS: Travis Prescott trpresco@microsoft.com
- Rust: Ronnie Geraghty rgeraghty@microsoft.com"},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"develop#sdk-develop.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/develop/sdk-develop","content":"# develop#sdk-develop.md

| Short Link: | [aka.ms/azsdk/dpcodegen](https://aka.ms/azsdk/dpcodegen) |
| --- | --- |

# Develop client libraries (SDK)

Once your [REST API specification](xref:api-design) defined using [TypeSpec](xref:api-typespec) is approved,
you can generate client libraries and reference documentation for each supported SDK language.
Your Azure SDKs should be designed to enhance the productivity of developers connecting to Azure services.
They must follow the [Azure SDK Architecture design guidelines](https://azure.github.io/azure-sdk/general_introduction.html)
and specific language guidelines.
> [!NOTE]
> - Azure services are required to release client libraries for all Tier 1 SDK languages for Public Preview and GA, which include .NET, Python,
> Java, JavaScript, and Go (optional for data plane SDKs).
> - Avoiding breaking changes under most circumstances. The Azure SDK team recommends on the SDK release cycle can be
> found in [Release Cycle and Package Versioning](https://azure.github.io/azure-sdk/policies_releases.html#release-cycle).
> - Azure services must have a beta release available for at least one month to allow for community feedback before
> graduating to stable. For more details, may refer to [Beta Releases and Stable Graduation](https://azure.github.io/azure-sdk/policies_releases.html#beta-releases-and-stable-graduation)

## Before you begin

- You have [access](xref:access) to the GitHub repositories and respective GitHub groups.
- You read our [repository branches strategy](https://azure.github.io/azure-sdk/policies_repobranching.html).
- You are familiarized with the [Azure SDK Architecture design guidelines](https://azure.github.io/azure-sdk/general_introduction.html).
- You have a [release plan](xref:release-plan) created to manage and understand the steps required to generate,
test, and release an SDK.
- [Request a namespace review](xref:namespace-review). This review process take 1-2 weeks to complete or longer
depending on the complexity of the review.

## Generate SDK

Your Azure SDKs will be generated from the configurations you set on your TypeSpec project.
1. Locate or create the `tspconfig.yaml` file in your TypeSpec project.
2. There are emitters per SDK language supported. Add the required emitters with their respective options.
  - [Management plane tspconfig.yaml sample](https://aka.ms/azsdk/tspconfig-sample-mpg).
  - [Data plane tspconfig.yaml sample](https://aka.ms/azsdk/tspconfig-sample-dpg).
For OpenAPI, the configurations should be in `readme.md`. Refer to the [Sample Readme](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/documentation/samplefiles/README.md#swagger-to-sdk).
>[!TIP]
> We are piloting our new AzSDK tools MCP server which includes the ability to generate the SDKs and
> create a draft pull request in the respective language repository. Refer to [AzSDK tools MCP server](xref:azsdk-tools-mcp)
> for instructions on how to install it and use it.

### [Management plane (ARM)](#tab/management)

>[!NOTE]
> The process for generating management plane SDK from TypeSpec has changed. Learn more about our [latest changes](xref:upcoming_release_planner_change).
A release plan is required to generate and release the SDK. If the API spec is written using *TypeSpec* then you
can generate the SDK for all tier-1 in *Generate SDK* step in the release planner.
If API spec is written using *Open API* SDK generation happens when you [request a release](xref:sdk-release) for all
tier-1 languages except .NET. For .NET, follow the steps in the [Generate .NET management plane SDK](xref:sdk-generate-mgmt-dotnet).
Although the SDK is autogenerated for you, you can also generate it manually and locally by following the steps outlined
in the linked documentation:
:point_right: [.NET](xref:sdk-generate-mgmt-dotnet)
:point_right: [Go](https://aka.ms/azsdk/mpg/go)
:point_right: [Java](https://aka.ms/azsdk/mpg/java)
:point_right: [JavaScript](https://aka.ms/azsdk/mpg/js)
:point_right: [Python](https://aka.ms/azsdk/mpg/python)

### [Data plane](#tab/dataplane)

The following information will guide you from your data plane REST API spec, to code in the respective SDK repositories
with the generated SDK:
:point_right: [.NET](https://aka.ms/azsdk/dpcodegen/net)
:point_right: [Java](https://aka.ms/azsdk/dpcodegen/java)
:point_right: [JavaScript DPG](https://aka.ms/azsdk/dpcodegen/js) (aka modular). This is the preferred JS flavor for codegen.
:point_right: [JavaScript RLC](https://aka.ms/azsdk/rlc/js) (aka Rest Level Client). You must not attempt to generate RLC unless SDK archboard told you to.
:point_right: [Python](https://aka.ms/azsdk/dpcodegen/python)
:point_right: [Go (optional)](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-go/blob/main/documentation/developer_setup.md).

## Get help

- If you need help with an automation tool or the Release planner, reach out to 
[Azure SDK / Azure SDK Onboarding](https://aka.ms/azsdk/support/onboarding-channel) channel.
- If you need help with the development of the SDKs reach out to the [language specific Team's channel](xref:support#get-help-with-the-azure-sdks-development).
- If you need to request an exception for a language review the [request release exception](xref:request-exception)."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"develop#sdk-release#sdk-release-mgmt-dotnet.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/develop/sdk-release/sdk-release-mgmt-dotnet","content":"# Prerequisites to release .NET management plane SDK
## Create a pull request for your .NET SDK
- Once your .NET SDK libraries are generated, and tests and samples are added, you should push your updates from the local
clone to a branch in your fork.
- Then create a pull request to merge your updates from the branch of your fork to the `main` branch of the public SDK
repository [Azure/azure-sdk-for-net](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-net).

:point_right: Ensure to monitor the GitHub pull request of your .NET SDK release

:point_right:  For GA release, ensure to obtain APIView approval from .NET SDK owner prior to release.

If you require assistance with working on a feature that needs to be kept confidential until it is publicly
available, reach out to us through the [Teams channel](#get-help) for additional support."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"support#support.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/support/support","content":"# Get help and support
<!-- A short description of this page (fewer than 50 words) that describes the main learning goal or task that readers
will complete. -->

If you have problems or questions when using Azure SDK tools or releasing your updates, you can get help by following
guidance provided in this article."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"plan#upcoming_release_planner_change.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/plan/upcoming_release_planner_change","content":"# SDK self-serve for TypeSpec generated management plane SDKs
## **3. Release SDK**
Responsible: Service owner

After the SDK is merged, you can follow the guidance in the release planner to release the SDK.

Release SDK step will show release readiness status of SDK and you can release the SDK when status is showing as `ready to release`.

1. Confirm that you have access to SDK release pipeline. Release pipeline link is visible in the release step.
2. Confirm service version is deployed.
3. Access SDK release pipeline in Azure DevOps and start a new release pipeline run.

**Action required:**

- Follow the release process detailed at [aka.ms/azsdk/releases/partnerinfo](xref:sdk-release)"},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"faqs#faqs.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/faqs/faqs","content":"# Azure SDK frequently asked questions
## Release SDK package
### How do I generate an SDK during private preview using MCP?
SDK generation is not required for private preview. If you choose to provide SDKs early, follow this process:
1. Create a Private Preview Release Plan
Go to https://aka.ms/release-planner-preview.
Select Private Preview as the release type.
Add your API spec PR link (from azure-rest-api-specs-pr).
Complete API readiness milestones.
2. Clone the Private API Spec Repo (https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr) and the Private SDK Language repos (e.g. https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python-pr) to your local environment.
3. Set Up MCP Server
Install MCP tools in VS Code: aka.ms/azsdk/agent
4. SDK via MCP
Use MCP commands in VS Code Agent Mode - Example: 
  Generate SDK for [service-name] in [language].
5. Share SDK for Internal Use (Optional)
The Azure SDK Team does not support publishing SDK PRs to public repos for private specs, and there is no formal release process for private preview SDKs. If you need internal distribution:Keep SDK changes in a feature branch within the private SDK repo and publish to a private Azure DevOps feed. Do not merge to main because it mirrors the public repo."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"develop#sdk-generation-pipelines.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/develop/sdk-generation-pipelines","content":"# Using the SDK generation pipelines
## Pipeline links
>[!NOTE]
> - SDK pull requests are not created for pipelines associated with the `Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr` repository.
> - SDK pull requests created using SDK generation pipelines are only for development and testing purpose. To release SDKs, please ensure to [start with a release plan](./sdk-release/sdk-release.md#release-your-sdk)."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"develop#sdk-release#sdk-release-mgmt-dotnet.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/develop/sdk-release/sdk-release-mgmt-dotnet","content":"# Prerequisites to release .NET management plane SDK
## Before you begin
- You have completed the same prerequisites listed in the [Release SDK - Before you begin](xref:sdk-release) section.
- For OpenAPI API specs, you have completed [generating library codes for .NET](xref:sdk-generate-mgmt-dotnet), writing [tests](xref:sdk-test)
and [samples](xref:sdk-samples).
  - For any stable version release, we recommend to include live tests to verify that the SDK functions correctly with the
  targeted new service version."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"develop#sdk-docs.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/develop/sdk-docs","content":"# Publish SDK reference docs
## Onboard a released package
### Packages released through the Azure SDK engineering system
If your package is released through the Azure SDK engineering system, almost everything is automated. You'll need to
take action if this is your first time releasing a package.

When releasing a package for the first time:

1. Ensure that your package is tracked in the  
[release work items](https://dev.azure.com/azure-sdk/Release/_queries/query/7d106acd-a1c2-47b9-9676-996422328397/). This can be done by running the [**Prepare-Release.ps1** script](https://aka.ms/azsdk/mark-release-status).

In each item for your release, you should have a value for **Service Name** and **Package Display Name**. The docs table of contents is generated from this data.

> [!NOTE]
> Do not skip this step. If you skip the service name, your item will appear in the TOC in the **Other** > **Uncategorized** section.

1. Ensure that your package-level overview file (the README.md file for your package in the SDK source repo) is up to date
*before* releasing.

In general, the automated system will ensure that updated docs are onboarded within a day or two of your release.

To customize information about your package outside of the engineering system consult documentation for [CSV fields](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk/blob/main/eng/README.md#csv-fields)
and [Service Level Overview](#service-level-overview) and [Package Level Overview](#package-level-overview).

#### Troubleshooting automated documentation updates

An automation job runs every 2 hours during business hours on weekdays. If your data is
not updated and you don't want to wait, [run the job manually](https://dev.azure.com/azure-sdk/internal/_build?definitionId=1284).
This will update the metadata PR.

If you find anything unexpected in the table of contents or service README, check the
[metadata CSV file](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk/tree/main/_data/releases/latest) to ensure that the metadata is
correct. If the metadata is not correct, open a PR with corrections."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"develop#sdk-release#sdk-release-mgmt-dotnet.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/develop/sdk-release/sdk-release-mgmt-dotnet","content":"# Prerequisites to release .NET management plane SDK
## Add/Update CHANGELOG file
In order to publish an SDK package to www.nuget.org, you will need to update the `CHANGELOG.md` file.

- Change the latest `Unreleased` version
- Replace the term `Unreleased` to the exact date in "YYYY-MM-DD" format for this particular release
- Include release comments by selectively incorporating the following sections. When adding any section, make sure it is
not left blank.

```
### Features Added

### Breaking Changes

### Bugs Fixed

### Other Changes
```

- Ensure to create a pull request or include the `CHANGELOG.md` updates in an existing pull request to the `main` branch
of the public SDK repository [Azure/azure-sdk-for-net](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-net).
The pull request kicks off the release process."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"develop#sdk-test.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/develop/sdk-test","content":"# Test your SDK
## Before you begin
### [Data plane](#tab/dataplane)
According to the target phase of your SDK, these are the requirements you will need to accomplish so you can release your SDK:

- Public preview: at least one test per language for the most common usage scenario.
- GA: at least one test per shipped method.

Tutorials to add tests:

:point_right: [.NET](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-net/blob/main/doc/DataPlaneCodeGeneration/Azure_SDK_Package_Ship_Requirements.md#tests)

:point_right: [Java](https://aka.ms/azsdk/dpg/java/tests)

:point_right: [JavaScript](https://aka.ms/azsdk/dpg/js/tests)

:point_right: [Python](https://aka.ms/azsdk/dpg/python/tests)

:point_right: [Go (optional)](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-go/blob/main/documentation/developer_setup.md#write-tests)."}]

rows.inputs.query:
title: azure-rest-api-specs-pr/InternalARMContracts

question: Is this branch getting all changes automatically merged from main, which would itself get merged changes from azure-rest-api-specs?
It looks that way but then
Pull requests · Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr
I'm a bit puzzled about why we should need a PR like this (if that is the right thing to do)
Update redis folder from main to internal branch by JimRoberts-MS · Pull Request #25870 · Azure/azu…
rows.inputs.ground_truth:
Individual specs are not synced between any of our branches.  There is a process to sync the infrastructure, but not the specs themselves, from public/main to these branches in specs-pr:
RPSaaSMaster
RPSaaSDev
RPSaaSCanary
ARMCoreRPDev
InternalARMContracts
Syncing specs between these branches is the responsibility of the spec owner.
https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-tools/blob/813e623459f3e8c47df98ce1196581510f65ffe6/eng/pipelines/mirror-repos.yml#L34-L61
rows.inputs.response:
The 'InternalARMContracts' branch in azure-rest-api-specs-pr does NOT automatically receive all changes merged from 'main' (which itself gets changes from azure-rest-api-specs public repo). According to the official documentation, 'InternalARMContracts' is for ARM-internal APIs and is never published to customers. It is a private, non-standard branch and does not participate in the automatic mirroring that keeps 'main' in azure-rest-api-specs-pr in sync with the public 'main'.

Only the 'main' branch in azure-rest-api-specs-pr is automatically mirrored from the public azure-rest-api-specs 'main'. Other private branches like 'InternalARMContracts', 'RPSaaSMaster', or 'RPSaaSDev' are NOT kept in sync with 'main' unless the branch owner manually updates them. 

Therefore, if you want to bring changes from 'main' (public or private) into 'InternalARMContracts', you must create a pull request like 'Update redis folder from main to internal branch'. This is necessary because there is no automated process to keep 'InternalARMContracts' up-to-date with 'main'; manual PRs are the correct and required process.

This is explicitly stated in the documentation: 'If the specs in the standard branches of RPSaaSMaster and RPSaaSDev are out of sync, who is responsible for syncing them with main? The spec owner is responsible for syncing their service’s spec files from main to RPSaaSMaster/RPSaaSDev to ensure consistency across branches.' The same principle applies to 'InternalARMContracts'.

In summary, PRs are needed to manually sync changes from 'main' into 'InternalARMContracts'. There is no automatic merge or sync for this branch.

# Create a PR against main

> [!NOTE]
> You must have a [GitHub account linked with your Microsoft account](xref:access) and permissions to any of the
> repositories listed in this tutorial.

When you're ready for a final review, it's time to create a pull request (PR) from your release branch you created
originally to the `main` branch on [Azure/azure-rest-api-specs](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs).

* :warning: Do not merge `main` or other release branches unless you know there are changes required.
* :white_check_mark: Rebase on `main` if changes are required in a separate topic branch.

## Clean PR against main

If you're fairly certain there should be no conflicting changes in files you added or modified in the release branch,
you can most often just create a pull request (PR) against `main` on  
[Azure/azure-rest-api-specs](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs).

1. Go to your branch in [Azure/azure-rest-api-specs](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs) or  
   [Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr). Read more about  
   [our repositories](xref:api-repos) for what is public and what is private.

2. If you do not already see an open PR in the upper-right just above the list of files, click **Contribute** and click
   **Open pull request** to open a new one.

3. Select either the **Control Plane (ARM) API** or **Data Plane API** PR template, depending on the type of REST API
spec updates you are submitting.

<!-- Todo: Figure out best way to embed videos on site.
:::video source="https://microsoft.sharepoint.com/teams/AzureDeveloperExperience/_layouts/15/embed.aspx?UniqueId=b199159f-5d7c-4b22-8ba4-98025a2a1f2e":::
-->

## Update your branch with changes from main

If you know there are other changes in the `main` branch or that other services have updated shared files in `main`
already and you need to pick up changes before merging, we recommend you take a merge from main. This is particularly interesting
for common infrastructure changes that are committed in the repo (i.e. github actions, tools, etc). Depending on how old your
branch is some of the pull request checks may not correctly function without taking a merge from main. 

If you are working in a non-protected branch you can do a `git merge main` like you would normally do a merge and then push
your changes to your remote branch. However, if you are working in a branch with branch protection enabled (i.e. `release-*`) then
you will need to make a pull request to your branch with the merge. Depending on how out-of-date your branch is from `main` your 
merge may have a lot of unwanted and unnecessary changes and the checks not pass. In such cases see below on how to [update the infrastructure](#updating-only-the-infrastructure-changes-from-main).

### Updating only the infrastructure changes from main

In cases you need to only update the infrastructure code and not the specifications we have a helper pipeline 
which you can run that will create a pull request with a selective merge. The selective merge will include everything except for specs 
under the specifications folder. This will enable you to only update the infrastructure and not other specs which should get your checks 
passing in your protected branch. Follow these steps to run the helper pipeline.

> [!NOTE]
> This should only be needed for protected branches, such as `release-*`. If you are in an unprotected branch, just use a normal `git merge main`.

1. Go to [tools - update-release-branch-in-specs](https://dev.azure.com/azure-sdk/internal/_build?definitionId=7487) and select **Run Pipeline**.
If you don't have permission see [GitHub account linked with your Microsoft account](xref:access).

2. Enter the name of your branch in the **BranchToMergeTo** parameter. Usually this will be in the form `release-<name>`.  You shouldn't need to set 
the other parameters but if your branch is in the private repo then you will need to update **Repo** to be `Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr`.

3. Click the **Run** button.

4. The pipeline should only take a few minutes to run and once it is complete then go find the pull request it created. You can find a link to it in the 
pipeline logs under the **Create Pull Request to merge** step. 

5. Monitor the created pull request and approve it. Once the checks are green then merge the pull request and then your branch should be updated with the latest infrastructure changes.
If you have open PRs against your branch with failing checks, go to those PRs and retrigger the checks. The easiest way to retrigger all checks
is to hit the close button followed by the open button, which should cause the checks to re-run.

## Next steps

1. [Create a new branch](api-tutorial-1-branch.md)
2. [Work against the release branch](api-tutorial-2-update.md)

# API versions and branches

This article explains the various lifecycle stages of spec API versions and how do they relate to git branches of the  
[specs repositories](xref:api-repos).

## Spec repos branches table

This table serves as a quick summary. Read the rest of the article for details.

| Branch                 | [Public repository][public specs repo]        | [Private repository][private specs repo]              |
|------------------------|-----------------------------------------------|-------------------------------------------------------|
| `main`                 | All API versions in `GA` and `public preview` | Mirrored from public `main`                           |
| `RPSaaSMaster`         | N/A                                           | For RPaaS-based specs in `private preview`   |
| `RPSaaSDev`            | N/A                                           | For dogfooding RPaaS-based specs.                     |
| `release-*`            | Feature branches.                             | Feature branches.                                     |
| `dev-*`                | Obsolete. Use `release-*` instead.            | Obsolete. Use `release-*` instead.                    |
| `ARMCoreRPDev`         | N/A                                           | [Obsolete ShiftLeft branch]. Use `release-*` instead. |
| `InternalARMContracts` | N/A                                           | For ARM-internal APIs, never published to customers.  |

If a given branch in the public or private spec repos is not listed in the table above, then most likely
it is obsolete, deprecated, or otherwise not recommended for use.

## Branch protection rules table

This table serves as a quick summary. Read the rest of the article for details.

This table shows which GitHub checks are marked as `required` on respective branches. Even when a check is marked as ❌
it **may** still be running on given branch; just that if it fails, the PR won't be blocked from merging.

| Branch | Merge | SDK | TSVal | BrCh | BrChC | LintRPaaS | LintDiff | Model | Semantic | Spell | Prettier | license | approver |
|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|-|
| public `main`                  | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ |
| private `RPSaaSMaster`         | ✅ | ❌ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ |
| public/private `release-*`     | ✅ | ❌ | ✅ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ | ✅ |
| private `RPSaaSDev`            | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ✅ |
| private `InternalARMContracts` | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ✅ |
| private `ARMCoreRPDev`         | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ❌ | ✅ |

Legend:

| Column name | Full GitHub check name               |
|-------------|--------------------------------------|
| `BrCh`      | `Swagger BreakingChange`             |
| `BrChC`     | `Breaking Change(Cross-Version)`     |
| `license`   | `license/cla`                        |
| `LintDiff`  | `Swagger LintDiff`                   |
| `LintRPaaS` | `Swagger Lint(RPaaS)`                |
| `Merge`     | `Automated merging requirements met` |
| `Model`     | `Swagger ModelValidation`            |
| `Prettier`  | `PrettierCheck`                      |
| `SDK`       | `SDK azure-sdk-for-go`               |
| `Semantic`  | `Swagger SemanticValidation`         |
| `Spell`     | `SpellCheck`                         |
| `TSVal`     | `TypeScript Validation`              |
| `approver`  | Requires team member approval        |

For more information on these checks, see:

- https://aka.ms/azsdk/pr-getting-help
- https://aka.ms/ci-fix

## API version lifecycle stages

An API version is a TypeSpec/OpenAPI specification contract identified by its `api-version` value.

Given API version is located in its own directory in the specs repositories. It can be in following lifecycle stages:

- `generally available` (aka `GA`, `stable`)
- `public preview`
- `private preview`
- `in development`
- `closing down`

> [!NOTE]
> A `closing down` API spec version need to be kept in the spec repository until it is fully `deprecated`. A `deprecated` API spec version need to be removed from the spec repository, with removal initiated by the service to begin deprecating related APIs, SDKs, and CLIs.

These stages corresponds to [service tree lifecycle stages] as elaborated on in [ARM lifecycle stages requirements].

### Generally available

**GA** API versions have been released to all Azure customers.

For an API version to be in GA it must:

- Be present in the `main` branch of the [public specs repo].
- Be in a parent `stable` folder and without a `-preview` suffix. See [spec directory structure] for full details.
- Not be gated by any feature flags, including Azure Feature Exposure Control ([AFEC]) flags.

### Public preview

**Public preview** API versions have been released to all Azure customers, but are not yet GA.
For an API version to be in `public preview`, it must:

- Not yet be GA.
- Be present in the `main` branch of the [public specs repo].
- Be in a parent `preview` folder and have `-preview` suffix in its folder name.
  See [spec directory structure] and [ARM preview guidelines] for full details.
- Not be gated by any feature flags, including [AFEC] flags.

### Private preview

**Private preview** API versions have been released to a limited set of Azure customers.

Usually API versions are in `private preview` for following reasons:

- The spec API version preview cannot yet be made public due to business or marketing reasons.
- Early customer feedback is being gathered for given API version preview.

For an API version to be in `private preview`, it must:

- Not yet be `GA` or in `public preview`.
- Not be present in the [public specs repo] `main` branch or any other branch in that repo.
- Be in a parent `preview` folder and have `-prefix` in its folder name.
  See [spec directory structure] and [ARM preview guidelines] for full details.
- Have at least one customer. If an API version has no customers, it is `in development`, not in `private preview`.
- In case of ARM specs:
  - Be present in the `RPSaaSMaster` branch of the [private specs repo].
    See [ARM branches] and [ARM lifecycle stages requirements] for details.
  - Be under access control done with [AFEC] flags.
- In case of data-plane specs:
  - Can be in any branch in the [private specs repo], except `main` or `RPaaS*` branches,
    as there is no designated branch like `RPSaaSMaster` for ARM specs.
  - There is no need for access control done with [AFEC] flags, as data plane services should have some mechanism
    for allowing `private preview` customers to onboard the preview.

> [!NOTE]
> A `private preview` API spec version can be published as `public preview` by following  
> [this how-to](xref:pr-move-private-to-public).

### In development

**In development** API versions are all API versions that are not `GA`, in `public preview` or in `private preview`.
Notably, such API versions are not present in the [public specs repo] `main` branch and do not have any customers.
However, they may be present in the public repo feature branches.

> [!IMPORTANT]
> REST API definitions for a service or API version that is `in development` MUST NOT be present in the  
> [public specs repo] `main` at all.

> [!NOTE]
> ARM spec API version, while `in development`, should not be trying to merge into `RPSaaSMaster`.
> The ARM guidance for this is in [ARM spec onboarding] article.

**Special cases** There are few special situations that do not fit in the API versioning model described above.
In such situations, attend appropriate office hours:

- In case of ARM specs, **ARM API Review Office Hours** in [aka.ms/armofficehoursinfo].
- In case of data-plane specs, [aka.ms/azapi/officehours].

## Spec repos branches

### Public specs repo `main` branch

All API versions in the [public specs repo] `main` branch are published to all Azure customers.
This branch includes `GA` and `public preview` API versions.

> [!CAUTION]
> This is not a dev branch. It should contain **only** finished specs that represent services deployed to customers.

### Private specs repo `main` branch

[Private specs repo] `main` branch is mirrored from [public specs repo] `main` branch by a CI job on a regular basis.
As such, it is **read only**.

### Private specs repo `RPSaaSMaster` branch

[Private specs repo] `RPSaaSMaster` contains RPaaS-based ARM specifications.

When an RPaaS-based ARM API goes into `public preview` or `GA` lifecycle stage it must be merged to [public specs repo]
`main` as well.

Some parts of this branch are being mirrored from public `main` branch
by the [mirror-repos] pipeline, triggered manually on at least daily basis.

Service teams are responsible for keeping their API specifications in this branch synchronized with
the public specs repo `main` branch.

See also [ARM lifecycle stages requirements] and [ARM branches].

### `RPSaaSDev` branch

Used for internal ARM dogfooding. See `RPSaaSDev` in [ARM branches].

Some parts of this branch are being mirrored from public `main` branch
by the [mirror-repos] pipeline, triggered manually on at least daily basis.

Service teams are responsible for keeping their API specifications in this branch synchronized with
the public specs repo `main` branch.

See also [ARM lifecycle stages requirements] and [ARM branches].

### `release-*` branches

All branches with prefix `release-`, both in public and private specs repos. Also known as "feature" branches.

# Azure REST API, SDK development process with TypeSpec

## Table Of Content

1. Introduction
2. Repo setup & prerequisites
3. Creating a new TypeSpec project
4. Prepare and submit a Pull Request for reviewing
5. Generate SDK code from a TypeSpec project

### 1. Introduction

This document describes the processes of developing Azure REST APIs and SDKs with TypeSpec language. The steps below
 assumes that you are developing TypeSpec API specifications in the `azure-rest-api-specs` and `azure-rest-api-specs-pr`repos.
If you are developing within your own ADO repo first and then submitting into `azure-rest-api-specs` repos for review and
 release, you will need to copy the TypeSpec files over.

### 2. Repo setup & prerequisites

- The main repos for Azure REST APIs are [azure-rest-api-specs](https://github.com/azure/azure-rest-api-specs) and [azure-rest-api-specs-pr](https://github.com/azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr)
 repos. The `-pr` repo contains `RPSaaSMaster` and `RPSaaSDev` branches for ProviderHub based ARM service specs.
#### 2.1 With local machine development
- [Node.js LTS](https://nodejs.org/en) version 18 or above (LTS Recommended).
 Ensure you can run the npm command in a command prompt:
  ```npm
    npm --version
  ```
- Run following command in the **repository root folder**. This will install required packages such as TypeSpec
 compilers and Azure Library packages.
  ```npm
     npm ci
  ```
- Ensure you can run TypeSpec command within the repo folders.
  ```npm
     npx tsp --version
  ```
- One-time set up: Install TypeSpec VisualStudio or VS Code extensions to get syntex highlighting, tool tips in IDE:  
  ```npm
    npx tsp code install
  ```
  OR
    ```npm
      npx tsp vs install
    ```
#### 2.2  VS Code with local docker .devcontainer
All prerequisites have been installed in the dev container. You should to have `Docker Desktop` and `WSL2` running if
 you are on Windows machine.
To start, you just need to install `Dev Containers` VS code extension, then open the repo path.
- VS Code will detect the .devcontainer and prompt you to reopen the workspace.
- Alternatively, you can use Command Palette -> Dev Containers: Reopen in Container.  
Once VS Code reopened in Container, you can run any of the program below in the VS Code integrated terminal.
#### 2.2 VS Code in browser via GitHub codespaces
GitHub codespaces leverage the same dev container in the repo. The difference is it is hosted in cloud with VS Code in
 browser.
To start, you just need to browse to the `azure-rest-api-specs` repo, select `<> Code` drop down and follow `Codespaces`
 instructions.

### 3. Creating a new TypeSpec project

Please first review recommended folder structure detailed in [this document](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/documentation/directory-structure.md).
1. Under `[reporoot]\specification`, create service folder directly.
   - Select `(rest-api-spec repo) ARM` or `(rest-api-spec repo) Data-plane` and answer appropriate naming questions.
   - If it's ARM service, the service folder would be `specification/{organization}/resource-manager/<RPNS>/{service}`.
   - If it's Data Plane service, the service folder would be `specification/{organization}/data-plane/{service}`
2. Create a new TypeSpec project based on Azure template with command:
    ```cli
       npx tsp init https://aka.ms/typespec/azure-init
    ```
3. Compile the generated TypeSpec project with command:
    ```cli
      npx tsp compile .
    ```
    The generated OpenAPI files should be correctly placed in the `{service}`folders following the naming conventions.
4. Now the project has been set up. You can modify the sample and develop your own APIs with TypeSpec.

### 4. Prepare and submit a Pull Request for reviewing

1. Create a branch in your local repository for your changes.
2. Create or update the TypeSpec files for your service.
3. Add or update 'examples' files for each operation of your OpenAPI file.
   The [oav](https://github.com/Azure/oav) provides two ways to generate OpenAPI examples:
   1. Generating basic examples and then manually modify the values. It will generate two examples for each operation:
    one contains minimal properties set, the other contains the maximal properties set. Since the auto-generated
     examples consist of random values for most types, you need replace them with meaningful values.
       ```bash
       oav generate-examples openapi.json
       ```
    Note, latest OAV tool should automatically generate the following. However, if you are generating the examples manually,
     please ensure you have:
    - include `title` field and make sure it is descriptive and unique for each operation.
    - include `operationId`. This is used to match with declared operations in TypeSpec and correctly output in OpenAPI.
4. Add/update the `readme.md` file in the `{service}` folder to specify the version and location of the OpenAPI files. The `readme.md` is needed for both management-plane and data-plane services for REST API Docs generation.
   Example:[sample-readme](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/specification/widget/resource-manager/Microsoft.Widget/Widget/readme.md)
5. Generate OpenAPI files:
   - sync with the target branch in the azure-rest-api-specs repo
      ```git
       git pull upstream <target-branch>
      ```
   - in the root directory, run `npm install`
   - in the project directory, `npx tsp compile`. This will generate OpenAPI files under `{service}` folders.
6. Ensure all generated files under `{service}` have been added to PR.
7. Send a pull request .
   - commit all your changes.
   - push your branch to your fork of the repo.

5. Generate OpenAPI files:
   - sync with the target branch in the azure-rest-api-specs repo
      ```git
       git pull upstream <target-branch>
      ```
   - in the root directory, run `npm install`
   - in the project directory, `npx tsp compile`. This will generate OpenAPI files under `{service}` folders.
6. Ensure all generated files under `{service}` have been added to PR.
7. Send a pull request .
   - commit all your changes.
   - push your branch to your fork of the repo.
   - send a pull request to the original repo from your forked repo.
   See the ARM Wiki for information on the [supported repos and branches for management-plane services](https://armwiki.azurewebsites.net/rpaas/swaggeronboarding.html#supported-github-reposbranches).
#### 4.1 Fix the errors of PR reviewing CI checks
The CI checks result will be commented on the PR. you can refer to the [CI fix Guide](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/blob/main/documentation/ci-fix.md).
Note:
Since the OpenAPI is generated from TypeSpec, to change the OpenAPI, you must update the TypeSpec file and regenerate the
 OpenAPI and avoid updating OpenAPI directly to keep the consistency between OpenAPI and TypeSpec.
For support & help, you can post a message to [TypeSpec Discussion - teams channel](https://teams.microsoft.com/l/channel/19%3A906c1efbbec54dc8949ac736633e6bdf%40thread.skype/TypeSpec%20Discussion?groupId=3e17dcb0-4257-4a30-b843-77f47f1d4121&tenantId=72f988bf-86f1-41af-91ab-2d7cd011db47).

### 5. Generate SDK code from a TypeSpec project

Refer to [Develop client libraries](https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/develop/sdk-develop?tabs=management) for more details."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"design#api-specs-pr#api-specs-pr.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-specs-pr/api-specs-pr","content":"# design#api-specs-pr#api-specs-pr.md

# Create a pull request with your Azure REST API spec update

This article explains how to create a pull request (PR) in the [Azure REST API specification repositories](xref:api-repos).
Such PR is a part of the [release plan](xref:release-plan).

## Before you begin

Ensure that:

- You have onboarded to Azure SDK team processes by following our [onboarding process](xref:onboard).
- You have [access](xref:access) to the GitHub repositories and respective Azure open source organization.
- You understand the conventions for the [Azure REST API specs GitHub repositories](xref:api-repos).
- You have reviewed and validated your REST API spec updates within your team, using a development branch in one of
  the specs repos.
- You are ready to release the features described in your REST API spec updates in a private preview, public preview,
  or GA release.

>[!TIP]
> We are piloting our new AzSDK tools MCP server which includes the ability to generate the SDKs and
> create a draft pull request in the respective language repository. Refer to [AzSDK tools MCP server](xref:azsdk-tools-mcp)
> for instructions on how to install it and use it.

## Create a PR against a specs repo

> [!TIP]
> If you have an existing PR in the private repo and you want to move it to the public repo, refer to [this guide](xref:pr-move-private-to-public).

When you are ready to submit your REST API spec updates for review, you must create a pull request (PR) in either the  
[public or private specs repository](xref:api-repos). When creating the PR, you should select either the
**Control Plane (ARM) API** or **Data Plane API** PR template, depending on the type of REST API spec updates you are
submitting.

> [!NOTE]
> The PR template and comments added by the PR automation will guide you through the process of getting your PR reviewed,
approved, and merged.

## Get your PR merged

| Short Link: | [aka.ms/azsdk/specreview/merge](https://aka.ms/azsdk/specreview/merge) |
|-|-|

To get your PR merged:

1. Ensure the `Next Steps to Merge` comment and `Automated merging requirements met` check are green. 
1. Ensure at least one person has approved your PR. Generally another person from your team that has [write access] to the repo.
1. Ensure all required checks are passing and at least investigate to understand any other non-required checks that may be failing. 
1. Once all required checks are green and any other issues understood you can merge the PR yourself as long as you have [write access] to the repo.
1. If your PR is targeting public `main` you will need to first apply the `PublishToCustomers` label to acknowledge you understand this 
   will cause your spec to be published so customers can consume it.
1. If your PR is targeting private repo `main` branch, it **cannot** be merged.
   Instead, you can publish your changes to customers by following the guide at [aka.ms/azsdk/move-pr]."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"design#api-specs-pr#api-tutorial#api-tutorial.md","document_title":"Tutorial: Create a new service spec","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-specs-pr/api-tutorial/api-tutorial","content":"# design#api-specs-pr#api-tutorial#api-tutorial.md

# Tutorial: Create a new service spec

When [working on a new REST API definition](xref:api-design) for a new or existing REST API definition, it's best to
work in a topic branch in git and on GitHub so you can later submit a pull request (PR) and iterate on feedback.
When a team is involved, you'll need a branch everyone can target that can also validate and find errors early.

This tutorial is recommended for anyone working on a new REST API definition, especially as part of a team.
It will guide you through the entire process from creating the branch to merging in into main.

## Why work in a separate branch?

The [Microsoft Azure REST API Guidelines state](https://github.com/microsoft/api-guidelines/blob/vNext/azure/Guidelines.md#api-versioning),

> Azure services need to change over time. However, when changing a service, there are 2 requirements:
>
> 1. Already-running customer workloads must not break due to a service change.
> 2. Customers can adopt a new service version without requiring any code changes.
>    Of course, the customer must modify code to leverage any new service features.

Together with the [Breaking Changes Policy](http://aka.ms/AzBreakingChangesPolicy/), it effectively means that any
changes you merge directly into the `main` branch in  
[Azure/azure-rest-api-specs](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs) must be supported for 90 days for preview
versions, and 3 years for stable versions at a minimum.

Working in a separate branch allows your team to iterate on a design, make changes to the REST API definition or
even the service as needed, and merge those changes to `main` - effectively publishing that service version -
when you're ready.

## Before you begin

You must have a [GitHub account linked with your Microsoft account](xref:access) and permissions to any of the
repositories listed in this tutorial.

## Next steps

1. [Create a new branch](xref:api-tutorial-branch)
2. [Work against the release branch](xref:api-tutorial-update)
3. [Create a PR against main](xref:api-tutorial-publish)"},{"document_source":"static_typespec_qa","document_filename":"typespec_2025_05_22.md","document_title":"Typespec Validation issue","document_link":"","content":"# typespec_2025_05_22.md
