I've a PR where the Typespec validation is failing with some weird error. This is not being reproduced locally - 
```
  specification/storagedatamanagementrp/Private.StorageDataManagement.Management/main.tsp:17:10 - error expect-value: Is a model expression type, but is being used as a value here. Use #{} to create an object value.
53  > 17 | @service({
54       |          ^
55  > 18 |   title: "Storage Data Management Resource Provider",
56       | ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
57  > 19 | })
58       | ^^
```
```
specification/storagedatamanagementrp/Private.StorageDataManagement.Management/Connectors/connectorModels.tsp:19:15 - error invalid-argument: Argument of type '"read"' is not assignable to parameter of type 'valueof EnumMember'
60  > 19 |   @visibility("read")
61       |               ^^^^^^
```
I'm not sure how to resolve this error. Could someone please help here?
[Update Connector and DataShare Swagger by ujjawaljain-msft · Pull Request #21997 · Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr/pull/21997)

## answer

You may need to update to the latest typespec version - some of these particular properties have changed in a recent version. What you are using here isn't the latest style to specify these things.
Doc for future reference: https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/TypeSpec-Validation#running-locally :
```
Running Locally
To ensure you see the same results from TypeSpecValidation in your PR check and tsv on your local machine:
Merge latest from parent (e.g. main or RPSaaSMaster) to your PR branch
Run locally
git clean -xdf (may revert any local changes)
git pull
npm ci
npx tsv specification/contosowidgetmanager/Contoso.Management
git status
If any changes, git add, git commit, git push to update your PR.
If you are still having problems, try cloning your branch to a new folder, or try on another machine.
If the problem can be reproduced on a clean machine, request assistance from the TypeSpec Discussion teams channel.
```"},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"design#api-review.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-review","content":"# Schedule a data plane REST API spec review
## Prepare for API review
When you have your REST API definition ready for review, [create a pull request with your Azure REST API spec update](xref:api-specs-pr).

You should prepare and be ready to present the following information during your review:

| Title | Importance | Brief description | Example and support documentation |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |

API spec PR link | Must Have | PR with your API spec definition against [azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr](https://github.com/azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr) or [azure/azure-rest-api-specs](https://github.com/azure/azure-rest-api-specs) | In order to access the PR, it may be necessary to join the [Azure GitHub organization](https://repos.opensource.microsoft.com/orgs/Azure). <p><p><ol><li>Go to https://repos.opensource.microsoft.com/orgs/Azure</li><li>Click **Join Organization**.</li></ol><p><p>The PR should be linked to the issue no less than 2 days before your meeting. To properly link your PR, in the issue click on the settings icon next to `Development` on the right side:<p><p>![Screenshot](../img/link-pr.png)  |
API spec PR CI checks | Important |Make sure all CI is passing before requesting a review. | [ci-fix](https://aka.ms/ci-fix) |
Core concepts | Must have | A glossary of nouns and verbs  | [Example](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-pr/blob/main/onboarding/Core_Concepts.pdf)
API reference docs | Good to have | Your API documentation consists of two parts, the API spec document (TypeSpec/OpenAPI spec), and the generated developer docs. These docs are often the first experience a developer will have with your service. Make a good first impression!!| **Recommended for OpenAPI spec**: [VS Code extension](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=42Crunch.vscode-openapi) load this extension and then open your OpenAPI spec file in VS Code and select **Preview**. <p><p><ol><li>Go to your PR and look for the comment added by the `openapi-pipeline-app bot` and title `Swagger Generation Artifacts`."},{"document_source":"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki","document_filename":"Resolving-Folder-Migration-Conflicts:-A-Guide-for-PR-Authors.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Resolving-Folder-Migration-Conflicts:-A-Guide-for-PR-Authors","content":"# Resolving Folder Migration Conflicts: A Guide for PR Authors
## The impact to ongoing PRs
1. If the ongoing PRs are targeting to a release-* or dev-* branch which are not created or syncing from the latest main, we recommend to merge these PRs first.
1. If the ongoing PRs are targeting to public main branch, Here's the suggestion to resolve the conflict. 

      1. Merge latest main 
          ```
          git checkout main
          git pull origin main // origin points to Azure rest api specs repo.
          git merge main <your-pr-branch>
          ```
      2. Resolve conflicts  
        - For most of the conflicts, accept the incoming changes.  
        - If it's unclear, please accept both and then update based on your judgement with the folder structure changes above.  

      3. Make sure the new change is aligned with folder structure v2  

         There are some cases where the PR is adding a new version in the original location, but the file diffs don't show as conflict. we should move them into the correct place so that it doesn't break the folder structure v2 as instructions in **Understanding Folder Migration sections** 

      4. clean up the previous folder if exists.

  

**Important**: It's strongly recommended to understand what's really changed in the folder refactor. Always ensure the new PR doesn't include any things that breaks the folder structure."},{"document_source":"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki","document_filename":"API-Spec-Review-FAQ.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/API-Spec-Review-FAQ","content":"ARM team right now | PRs are generally reviewed in order of the ARM queue.  If your PR needs special treatment, you can contact the ARM team: https://aka.ms/armofficehoursinfo | 
| I need a review to merge changes to a non-standard branch (e.g. not `main`, `RPSaaSMaster`, etc.) | Contact the owner of that branch. |
| EngSys is behaving badly in my non-standard/release branch | Update the state of the branch to match with `main`. The owner of the release branch is responsible for doing this. See documentation: [Update your branch with changes from main](https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-specs-pr/api-tutorial/api-tutorial-3-publish#update-your-branch-with-changes-from-main). |
| I need to set up suppressions for LintDiff violations in my PR | See [Adding Scoped Suppressions](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/Swagger-LintDiff) | 
| I have specific questions about the inner workings of ARM, testing changes to APIs, or rollout/release schedules | Talk to the ARM team: https://aka.ms/armofficehoursinfo |
| I see an Avocado error `MULTIPLE_API_VERSION` | There is a coordinated effort to fix this. Reach out to the relevant parties. [This PR](https://github.com/Azure/avocado/pull/157) gives more context on why this was upgraded to an error. If relevant parties agree, the PR can be unblocked by adding the `Approved-Avocado` label to the PR. |
| I merged a PR, when does the REST API documentation update on the Learn site? | Docs are published every week on Tuesdays | 
| If the specs in the standard branches of `RPSaaSMaster` and `RPSaaSDev` are out of sync, who is responsible for syncing them with main? | The spec owner is responsible for syncing their service’s spec files from `main` to `RPSaaSMaster/RPSaaSDev` to ensure consistency across branches. |"},{"document_source":"azure_rest_api_specs_wiki","document_filename":"About-the-Wiki.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs/wiki/About-the-Wiki","content":"## Editing
The wiki can be edited using the GitHub UI (click "Edit" or "New Page"), or by cloning and pushing changes directly.  Unfortunately there is no way to make a Pull Request to the wiki repo.

1. `git clone https://github.com/azure/azure-rest-api-specs.wiki.git`
2. Make changes
3. `git push` your changes to `master`
   * Branch must be named `master`, not `main`.  The GitHub Wiki code appears to hardcode `origin/master` instead of using `origin/HEAD`."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"design#api-specs-pr#api-repos.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-specs-pr/api-repos","content":"# Azure REST API specs repositories on GitHub
The REST API descriptions for all Azure services should be published in the Azure REST API specs GitHub repositories.

The [Azure/azure-rest-api-specs] is the public repository. All work done in this repository is public, i.e. visible to
everyone, including people outside of Microsoft. Any Azure REST API specification updates must be merged to the `main`
branch as part of the process of releasing those updates to Microsoft customers.

The [Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr] is the private repository (the "pr" stands for "private"). It is for work that must
remain private until it is ready to be published. For example, if your team is working on a new product with a new Azure
Resource Manager (ARM) or Resource Provider (RP) namespace, you want to keep developing it in the private repository
until you have drafted, tested and went through the API review process. Only after this is done, you must merge your
changes to the `main` branch in the public repository.

The `main` branch in the private repository is read-only, as it is mirrored from the public repository `main` branch."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"design#api-docs.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-docs","content":"# Publish REST API reference docs
## Update an existing API reference
If your service is __already using README__ for publishing configuration and utilizing automatic refresh, as long as the
README is properly updated, any API updates merged to the [Azure/azure-rest-api-specs] repository
will be automatically picked up by the [Azure REST API reference site on Microsoft Learn](https://learn.microsoft.com/rest/api/)  
weekly (on Tuesdays).
Request an OOB publishing by [creating a Work Item in Azure DevOps]  
(https://dev.azure.com/msft-skilling/Content/_workitems/create/User%20Story?templateId=39fb91e3-64a2-4c8a-83db-b2bdf3603dd3&ownerId=c4a28f90-17ae-4384-b514-7273392b082b),  
if needed.
If you had to use the __alternative publishing configuration__ with direct paths to the OpenAPI spec files, you’ll need
to have the publishing configuration manually updated to document any API updates in the [Azure/azure-rest-api-specs] repository.
The easiest way is to create a publishing request by [submitting a User Story in Azure DevOps]  
(https://dev.azure.com/msft-skilling/Content/_workitems/create/User%20Story?templateId=39fb91e3-64a2-4c8a-83db-b2bdf3603dd3&ownerId=c4a28f90-17ae-4384-b514-7273392b082b).  
Or you can create a pull request into the [REST API documentation repository]  
(https://github.com/Azure/azure-docs-rest-apis) and update the publishing configuration.
Read [this document on publishing configurations]  
(https://learn.microsoft.com/help/onboard/admin/reference/rest/api-publishing-configuration)  
for more details on the recommended and alternative publishing configurations."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"design#api-specs-pr#api-tutorial#api-tutorial-2-update.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/design/api-specs-pr/api-tutorial/api-tutorial-2-update","content":"# Work against the release branch
> [!NOTE]
> You must have a [GitHub account linked with your Microsoft account](xref:access) and permissions to any of the
> repositories listed in this tutorial.

Now that you've created a release branch, let people know the branch name you created above. They should create topic
branches against that branch - just like they would against the `main` branch - and submit pull requests (PR).
Read about [API design](xref:api-design) for guidelines and more information.

- :white_check_mark: Create a topic branch from the upstream release branch.
- :white_check_mark: Submit a PR when ready against the upstream release branch.
- :x: Do not merge the `main` branch into your topic branch. If you need specific changes, you can cherry-pick them,
  or simply copy and paste."}]
rows.inputs.testcase: azure-rest-api-specs-pr/InternalARMContracts
rows.outputs.similarity.similarity_sample_inp: [{"role": "user", "content": "{\"query\": \"title: azure-rest-api-specs-pr/InternalARMContracts\\n\\nquestion: Is this branch getting all changes automatically merged from main, which would itself get merged changes from azure-rest-api-specs?\\nIt looks that way but then\\nPull requests \\u00b7 Azure/azure-rest-api-specs-pr\\nI'm a bit puzzled about why we should need a PR like this (if that is the right thing to do)\\nUpdate redis folder from main to internal branch by JimRoberts-MS \\u00b7 Pull Request #25870 \\u00b7 Azure/azu\\u2026\", \"response\": \"The 'InternalARMContracts' branch in azure-rest-api-specs-pr does NOT automatically receive all changes merged from 'main' (which itself gets changes from azure-rest-api-specs public repo). According to the official documentation, 'InternalARMContracts' is for ARM-internal APIs and is never published to customers. It is a private, non-standard branch and does not participate in the automatic mirroring that keeps 'main' in azure-rest-api-specs-pr in sync with the public 'main'.\\n\\nOnly the 'main' branch in azure-rest-api-specs-pr is automatically mirrored from the public azure-rest-api-specs 'main'. Other private branches like 'InternalARMContracts', 'RPSaaSMaster', or 'RPSaaSDev' are NOT kept in sync with 'main' unless the branch owner manually updates them. \\n\\nTherefore, if you want to bring changes from 'main' (public or private) into 'InternalARMContracts', you must create a pull request like 'Update redis folder from main to internal branch'. This is necessary because there is no automated process to keep 'InternalARMContracts' up-to-date with 'main'; manual PRs are the correct and required process.\\n\\nThis is explicitly stated in the documentation: 'If the specs in the standard branches of RPSaaSMaster and RPSaaSDev are out of sync, who is responsible for syncing them with main? The spec owner is responsible for syncing their service\\u2019s spec files from main to RPSaaSMaster/RPSaaSDev to ensure consistency across branches.' The same principle applies to 'InternalARMContracts'.\\n\\nIn summary, PRs are needed to manually sync changes from 'main' into 'InternalARMContracts'. There is no automatic merge or sync for this branch.\", \"ground_truth\": \"Individual specs are not synced between any of our branches.  There is a process to sync the infrastructure, but not the specs themselves, from public/main to these branches in specs-pr:\\nRPSaaSMaster\\nRPSaaSDev\\nRPSaaSCanary\\nARMCoreRPDev\\nInternalARMContracts\\nSyncing specs between these branches is the responsibility of the spec owner.\\nhttps://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-tools/blob/813e623459f3e8c47df98ce1196581510f65ffe6/eng/pipelines/mirror-repos.yml#L34-L61\"}"}]

rows.inputs.query:
title: Adoption of CBOR (and COSE) encoding/decoding throughout SDKs

question: Hi, we are adopting CBOR in multiple places in the company, especially in the context of COSE signing envelopes, their verification.
CBOR and COSE encoding/decoding is supported natively in .NET SDK via System.Security.Cryptography.Cose already, and is being used in at least one SDK which follows specific RFC drafts.
However, other languages would need to also adopt it when the service expands. Which poses a question what libraries to use in each? I know specific dependencies that we can leverage but is there an approval process to "allow" them to become part of the SDKs, or should I just include the dependencies and review those in arch/sdk meeting for each language separately?
rows.inputs.ground_truth: I would suggest an email to azsdkarch@microsoft.com to discuss this.
rows.inputs.response:
Based on the provided knowledge, the approval process for including new dependencies (such as CBOR/COSE encoding/decoding libraries) in Azure SDKs is handled as part of the SDK review process for each language. There is no indication in the current documentation of a centralized or global approval policy for such dependencies across all Azure SDKs. Instead, you should:

- Add the proposed language-specific dependencies (e.g., System.Security.Cryptography.Cose for .NET, and the respective CBOR/COSE libraries for other languages) to your SDK implementation.
- Prepare to discuss these dependencies during your SDK review meeting with the Azure SDK Architecture Board (for data plane libraries), or as part of the namespace review (for management plane libraries).
- The review will cover package names, API surface, hero scenarios, and also the appropriateness of dependencies for each language. The architects will provide feedback and approval as part of the standard review workflow.

There is no mention of a centralized approval workflow or pre-approved dependency list in the onboarding or review documentation. All dependencies are subject to review and approval during the regular SDK review process for each language. Ensure that your proposed dependencies meet Azure SDK guidelines and language-specific best practices before presenting them for review.

If you require further clarification or have concerns about a specific dependency, you can contact the Azure SDK Architecture Board directly at azsdkarch-help@microsoft.com, or bring it up during your scheduled SDK review meeting.

A namespace review is required for new libraries that haven't yet been released in an SDK. ## Before you begin - Ensure you have [access](xref:access) to the GitHub repositories and respective GitHub groups. ## Request a namespace review ### [Management plane (ARM)](#tab/management) 1. Open a GitHub issue. 1. If you're working on an SDK for a service that has GA'd, use the following [issue template in the Azure/azure-sdk repo](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk/issues/new?assignees=ronniegeraghty&labels=architecture%2C+board-review%2C+mgmt-namespace-review&template=adp_mgmt_namespace_review.md&title=Board+Review%3A+Management+Plane+Namespace+Review+%3Cclient+library+name%3E). 1. Replace Confidential Ledger with the name of your service. - .NET: `Azure.ResourceManager.ConfidentialLedger` - Java: `azure-resourcemanager-confidentialledger (com.azure.resouremanager.confidentialledger)` - Go/Golang: `sdk/resourcemanager/confidentialledger/armconfidentialledger` - JavaScript: `@azure/arm-confidentialledger` - Python: `azure-mgmt-confidentialledger` ### [Data plane](#tab/data) Package namespace are reviewed during the [SDK review meeting](xref:sdk-review), more concretely in the **Beta SDK review meeting**"},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"develop#sdk-release#sdk-release.md","document_title":"Release SDK","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/develop/sdk-release/sdk-release","content":"# develop#sdk-release#sdk-release.md # Release SDK | Short Link: | [azsdk/releases/partnerinfo](https://aka.ms/azsdk/releases/partnerinfo) | | --- | --- | > [!IMPORTANT] > TypeSpec usage for API definition is a mandatory requirement for all new (greenfield) data plane and management plane > services. This requirement is enforced by the ARM API Review Board for management plane services and by the API > Stewardship Board for data plane services. > Brownfield services will eventually be required to transition to TypeSpec as well. PRs for brownfields services > that have not transitioned to TypeSpec will receive notices in FY2024, followed by warnings in FY2025 and > errors in FY2027. The requirement to move to TypeSpec will ensure a consistent, high-quality developer experience across > Azure that aligns with Azure SDK guidelines. For more information on TypeSpec, visit [here](xref:api-typespec). ## Before you begin - You have [access](xref:access) to the GitHub repositories, respective GitHub groups, and release security groups. - You have a [release plan](xref:release-plan) created to manage and understand the steps required to generate, test, and release an SDK. - The REST API specs need to be merged in the main branch of the public repository [Azure/azure-rest-api-specs](https://github.com/Azure/azure-rest-api-specs). - Ensure to complete all tasks outlined on this page [Prerequisites to release SDKs](xref:sdk-release-prerequisites). - Breaking changes to GAed SDKs are not permitted as they conflict with the [Azure SDK design principle](https://azure.github.io/azure-sdk/general_introduction.html#dependable). If breaking changes are inevitable, ensure to get approval from [Azure Breaking Changes Board](https://aka.ms/azbreakingchangespolicy) in your service API Spec review. - Ensure your service is available to the public before the SDK release date. ## When to release ### [Management plane (ARM)](#tab/management) The Azure SDK release processes for management plane SDKs vary based on the API specification type - TypeSpec: On demand. - Open API: Request a release **before the cutoff date** for the month that you're targeting. :point_right: 2nd Friday of every month: Cutoff date :point_right: 4th Friday of every month: Release date The functionality to request a release for Java, JavaScript, Python, and Go is available as part of the management plane release plan. You can learn more about release plans [here](xref:release-plan). For releasing the .NET SDK release follow the [.NET release process](xref:sdk-release-mgmt-dotnet). ### [Data plane](#tab/dataplane) Although releases happen every month, you can release the SDK on demand. The Azure SDK team follows a monthly release calendar where we minimize disruptions to the release tools as much as possible. Outside of those dates, the tools might not be as stable. [Release Calendar](https://teams.microsoft.com/l/entity/com.microsoft.teamspace.tab.planner/_djb2_msteams_prefix_1611974298?context=%7B%22subEntityId%22%3Anull%2C%22channelId%22%3A%2219%3Adc2e34377e494a9292d89fbc34125eae%40thread.skype%22%7D&groupId=3e17dcb0-4257-4a30-b843-77f47f1d4121&tenantId=72f988bf-86f1-41af-91ab-2d7cd011db47): This calendar shows the Package Code Freeze and Package Ship dates for the year. ## Breaking change policy - Requires approval from Azure SDK Architecture Team - More information: http://aka.ms/AzBreakingChangesPolicy/ ## Next steps - For each released package by going to the public feed and verifying: - Metadata - Verify that the links, documentation, readme, etc. are correct and appear as expected. - Download - Download the package and verify that it is the same one you built/published. - In your release plan, mark the **Release SDK** task as completed and proceed to complete the release plan. - [Verify SDK reference docs](xref:sdk-docs) - Verify the content of the release notes PR generated during the release pipeline. Review and approve the PR. See [Producing Release Notes](https://azure.github.io/azure-sdk/policies_releasenotes.html) for details. - The release pipeline will submit a PR with a version bump for each SDK in their respective language repository. You need to review and merge each version bump pull request. ## Get help ### [Management plane (ARM)](#tab/management) [Azure SDK - SDK Release Support](https://teams.microsoft.com/l/channel/19%3A084875bb626242ed95f3ac8dddfaa12a%40thread.skype/SDK%20release%20support?groupId=3e17dcb0-4257-4a30-b843-77f47f1d4121&tenantId=72f988bf-86f1-41af-91ab-2d7cd011db47). ### [Data plane](#tab/dataplane) If you have any questions about the general release process, please reach out to either of the [Azure SDK Release PMs](#azure-sdk-release-pm) listed. If your question is related to one of the language specific release processes or you're having issues using a language specific release process, please reach out to the relative [Release Driver](#release-driver--build-facilitating-developer) for that language. #### Azure SDK release PM - Ronnie Geraghty rgeraghty@microsoft.com #### Release driver / Build facilitating developer - .NET: Jonathan Cardenas Jonathan.Cardenas@microsoft.com - Java: Jair Myree jairmyree@microsoft.com - JS: Timo van Veenendaal timov@microsoft.com - Python: Kashif Khan kashifkhan@microsoft.com - C/C++: Anton Kolesnyk Anton.Kolesnyk@microsoft.com - Go: Grace Wilcox gracewilcox@microsoft.com - Android: Victor Colin victor.colin@microsoft.com - iOS: Travis Prescott trpresco@microsoft.com - Rust: Ronnie Geraghty rgeraghty@microsoft.com"},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"develop#sdk-test.md","document_title":"Test your SDK","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/develop/sdk-test","content":"# develop#sdk-test.md # Test your SDK Usability is a critical factor in the success of SDKs for our customers, which is why our SDKs must include tests. ## Before you begin - You have [access](xref:access) to the GitHub repositories and respective GitHub groups. - You are familiarized with the [Azure SDK Architecture design guidelines](https://azure.github.io/azure-sdk/general_introduction.html). - You read our [repository branches strategy](https://azure.github.io/azure-sdk/policies_repobranching.html). - You need to have an SDK to write tests against. ### [Management plane (ARM)](#tab/management) For a GA (stable) SDK release, .NET recommends to include live tests to verify that the SDK functions correctly with the targeted new service version. :point_right: [.NET](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-net/blob/main/sdk/resourcemanager/Azure.ResourceManager/docs/TestGuide.md) :point_right: [Java](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-java/wiki/TypeSpec-Java-Quickstart#adding-tests) :point_right: [JavaScript](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-js/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md#testing) :point_right: [Python](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-python/blob/main/doc/dev/mgmt/tests.md) :point_right: [Go](https://github.com/Azure/autorest.go/blob/main/packages/autorest.gotest/doc/gotest_howto.md#generate-mock-test-and-execute) ### [Data plane](#tab/dataplane) According to the target phase of your SDK, these are the requirements you will need to accomplish so you can release your SDK: - Public preview: at least one test per language for the most common usage scenario. - GA: at least one test per shipped method. Tutorials to add tests: :point_right: [.NET](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-net/blob/main/doc/DataPlaneCodeGeneration/Azure_SDK_Package_Ship_Requirements.md#tests) :point_right: [Java](https://aka.ms/azsdk/dpg/java/tests) :point_right: [JavaScript](https://aka.ms/azsdk/dpg/js/tests) :point_right: [Python](https://aka.ms/azsdk/dpg/python/tests) :point_right: [Go (optional)](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-go/blob/main/documentation/developer_setup.md#write-tests). ## Get help Reach out to the specific language Teams channel under our [Azure SDK channel](https://teams.microsoft.com/l/team/19%3af6d52ac6465c40ea80dc86b8be3825aa%40thread.skype/conversations?groupId=3e17dcb0-4257-4a30-b843-77f47f1d4121&tenantId=72f988bf-86f1-41af-91ab-2d7cd011db47)."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"develop#sdk-release#sdk-release-prerequisites.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/develop/sdk-release/sdk-release-prerequisites","content":"# Prerequisites to release client libraries (SDK) ## Before you begin - You have completed [the SDK generation](xref:sdk-generate) and created an SDK pull requests to the respective Azure SDK repository. - For an initial SDK release of your service, ensure that the [review of your SDK package name](xref:namespace-review) — specified in the tspconfig.yaml configuration file — has been completed."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"support#icm.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/support/icm","content":"# Azure SDK in ICM The Azure SDK team is responsible for designing, building, delivering and supporting client SDK libraries for Azure services. The libraries are open source and are published to the appropriate feed for each language (eg. NuGet for .NET, PyPi for Python, etc.). Customers acquire the libraries from the feeds and include them in their own build processes. Therefore, it is effectively impossible to "deploy" a fix for an SDK library to all customers using it or "rollback" a library that has already been released. We have defined processes ([versioning], [branching]) to hotfix the libraries we've released, but even when we do that, we are dependent on our customers to take action to incorporate the updated/fixed libraries. In short, Sev1 and Sev2 incidents that are transferred to the Azure SDK team will likely be transferred back to the service owning team where a fix or rollback can be done to mitigate any immediate customer pain. Then, we can pursue whatever SDK changes are needed and release them to the public feeds or to specific customers giving them time to update to the current version."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"develop#sdk-release#sdk-release-pipeline.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/develop/sdk-release/sdk-release-pipeline","content":"# Run release SDK pipeline ## SDK release pipeline ### Approve the release > [!IMPORTANT] > Once a package is published to a package manger, the action is final and cannot be reversed. > While it is possible to remove or conceal problematic packages, reusing the same version number is not an option. > All future package releases require a version change at minimum. Each package generated by the pipeline has an individual approval checkpoint before it is finalized for publishing. This allows you to selectively approve a specific package for release while declining the rest. 1. Read our [Azure SDK approval release guidelines](xref:sdk-approval-release-guidelines). 1. Click on the **Review** button in the pipeline run to start the approval process. 1. Select which of the packages you want to approve for release. 1. Select **Reject** for the packages you do not want to release. >[!IMPORTANT] > Make sure to approve only your package's release stage as the pipeline is shared among multiple packages. ![Approve release example](../../img/approve_release.png) Once you click approve the pipeline will proceed to tag the sources that were just built with the package name and version and then publish the package to the appropriate package manager."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"retirement#sdk-deprecation-guidelines.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/retirement/sdk-deprecation-guidelines","content":"# Azure SDK deprecation guidelines Note: In this documentation, the words "retirement" and "deprecation" are used interchangeably. Both terms refer to the process of phasing out support for SDKs and APIs. | **Lifecycle Stage** | **Action** | | --- | --- | | **GA libraries that have a Track 2 library available** |
  • Update the old package to point to the new Track 2 library.
  • Update the package manager of the old package as per guidance above on updating package managers. if the package has a README in the Azure SDK language repo, update the README with the same message as the package manager.
  • Post a blog on the Azure Blog, essentially stating that a new package is available which replaces the old package, the old package is scheduled to be deprecated on a specific date, and guidance on adjusting code to use the new package.
  • No new features should be added in Track 1. If the feature request is valid for the new SDK, transition the issue to the new SDK.
  • Major customer-impacting bugs should continue to be addressed in both Track 1 and Track 2, including security vulnerabilities.
  • Serious security vulnerabilities in dependent libraries are addressed in both Track 1 and Track 2.
  • For Track 1 SDK libraries, the EOLDate must be slated for 12 months after a replacement Track 2 library is available. Support during the first year may be limited to critical security fixes. Track 2 libraries must follow the standard 3-year notification as per the Azure Retirement Guidelines linked at the top of this document. | | **After 12 months** |
    • Track 1 library no longer builds in the engineering system.
    • Only high-impact customer-impacting (i.e., Sev1) bugs are addressed in Track 1 when no mitigation to Track 2 is acceptable. This would require re-creating or fixing the engineering system for that one fix.
    • Do a telemetry search on the old SDK."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"develop#sdk-samples.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/develop/sdk-samples","content":"# Write SDK samples ## Before you begin - You have [access](xref:access) to the GitHub repositories and respective GitHub groups. - You are familiarized with the [Azure SDK Architecture design guidelines](https://azure.github.io/azure-sdk/general_introduction.html) and the language sample guidelines. - You read our [repository branches strategy](https://azure.github.io/azure-sdk/policies_repobranching.html). - You need to have an SDK to write samples for."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"develop#sdk-release#sdk-release-prerequisites.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/develop/sdk-release/sdk-release-prerequisites","content":"# Prerequisites to release client libraries (SDK) ## Get SDK pull request merged Once you confirm :white_check_mark: your SDK libraries are generated :white_check_mark: tests and samples are added :white_check_mark:`CHANGELOG.md` is up to date All changes should be committed to the pull request generated by the SDK generation automation (if not already present). Monitor and address review comments from the SDK engineer for each language as needed until approval is granted to merge the pull request. > [!NOTE] > For GA releases, .NET requires APIView approval from the .NET SDK owner on the SDK pull request for release."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"develop#sdk-develop.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/develop/sdk-develop","content":"# Develop client libraries (SDK) ## Before you begin - You have [access](xref:access) to the GitHub repositories and respective GitHub groups. - You read our [repository branches strategy](https://azure.github.io/azure-sdk/policies_repobranching.html). - You are familiarized with the [Azure SDK Architecture design guidelines](https://azure.github.io/azure-sdk/general_introduction.html). - You have a [release plan](xref:release-plan) created to manage and understand the steps required to generate, test, and release an SDK. - [Request a namespace review](xref:namespace-review). This review process take 1-2 weeks to complete or longer depending on the complexity of the review."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"develop#sdk-develop.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/develop/sdk-develop","content":"# Develop client libraries (SDK) ## Get help - If you need help with an automation tool or the Release planner, reach out to [Azure SDK / Azure SDK Onboarding](https://aka.ms/azsdk/support/onboarding-channel) channel. - If you need help with the development of the SDKs reach out to the [language specific Team's channel](xref:support#get-help-with-the-azure-sdks-development). - If you need to request an exception for a language review the [request release exception](xref:request-exception)."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"faqs#glossary.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/faqs/glossary","content":"# Glossary terms for Azure SDKs ## S ### SDK review A review that is designed to help Azure service teams create developer-friendly and consistent SDKs in supported languages."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"faqs#glossary.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/faqs/glossary","content":"# Glossary terms for Azure SDKs ## C ### Client library A library (tools, documentation, and samples) that customers can use to work with an Azure service. Each client library is published separately to the appropriate language-specific repository."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"faqs#glossary.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/faqs/glossary","content":"# Glossary terms for Azure SDKs ## S ### software development kit (SDK) The entire Azure SDK for a single language, which is broken up into numerous Azure SDK client libraries."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"faqs#glossary.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/faqs/glossary","content":"# Glossary terms for Azure SDKs ## T ### track 2 library The set of client libraries that adhere to the design guidelines that were created were the Azure SDK team. All track 2 libraries reside in language-focused repositories on GitHub."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"support#apiview.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/support/apiview","content":"# What is APIView? ## API approvals ### [Approve GA release](#tab/garelease) If package version is GA then all APIs must be reviewed, and API needs to be approved by a language architect to release a GA version package."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"develop#sdk-develop.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/develop/sdk-develop","content":"# Develop client libraries (SDK) Once your [REST API specification](xref:api-design) defined using [TypeSpec](xref:api-typespec) is approved, you can generate client libraries and reference documentation for each supported SDK language. Your Azure SDKs should be designed to enhance the productivity of developers connecting to Azure services. They must follow the [Azure SDK Architecture design guidelines](https://azure.github.io/azure-sdk/general_introduction.html) and specific language guidelines. > [!NOTE] > - Azure services are required to release client libraries for all Tier 1 SDK languages for Public Preview and GA, which include .NET, Python, > Java, JavaScript, and Go (optional for data plane SDKs). > - Avoiding breaking changes under most circumstances. The Azure SDK team recommends on the SDK release cycle can be > found in [Release Cycle and Package Versioning](https://azure.github.io/azure-sdk/policies_releases.html#release-cycle). > - Azure services must have a beta release available for at least one month to allow for community feedback before > graduating to stable. For more details, may refer to [Beta Releases and Stable Graduation](https://azure.github.io/azure-sdk/policies_releases.html#beta-releases-and-stable-graduation)"},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"develop#sdk-generate-mgmt-dotnet.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/develop/sdk-generate-mgmt-dotnet","content":"# Generate .NET management plane SDK ## Prerequisites for contributing :point_right: Read [azure-sdk-for-net/CONTRIBUTING.md](https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-net/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md) :point_right: The guidance is mainly about contributing in the public SDK repositories for .NET. If you require assistance with working on a feature that needs to be kept confidential until it is publicly available, reach out to us through the [Teams channel](#get-help) for additional support."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"onboard#informational-meeting.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/onboard/informational-meeting","content":"# Schedule an Azure SDK informational meeting An informational meeting is designed to review with you the service and products requirements, timelines, and action items that apply to you. For example, you should schedule this meeting if you are unsure if the product is in scope for the Azure SDK CPEX launch requirements."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"support#support.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/support/support","content":"# Get help and support ## Get help with the Azure SDKs Engineering system (language repositories) If you need help with the engineering system supporting the `azure-sdk-for-*` language repositories, like e.g. [azure-sdk-for-python], refer to [the EngSys support page](xref:support-engsys)."},{"document_source":"azure-sdk-docs-eng","document_filename":"develop#sdk-generate-mgmt-dotnet.md","document_title":"","document_link":"https://eng.ms/docs/products/azure-developer-experience/develop/sdk-generate-mgmt-dotnet","content":"# Generate .NET management plane SDK Azure service engineering team is required to work on .NET management plane SDKs. >[!IMPORTANT] > The instructions in this document are for generating SDK from an OpenAPI API spec. > If your API spec is authored on Typespec, follow the instructions in [Generate SDKs](xref:sdk-develop#generate-sdk)"}]
rows.inputs.testcase: Adoption of CBOR (and COSE) encoding/decoding throughout SDKs
rows.outputs.similarity.similarity_sample_inp: [{"role": "user", "content": "{\"query\": \"title: Adoption of CBOR (and COSE) encoding/decoding throughout SDKs\\n\\nquestion: Hi, we are adopting CBOR in multiple places in the company, especially in the context of COSE signing envelopes, their verification.\\nCBOR and COSE encoding/decoding is supported natively in .NET SDK via System.Security.Cryptography.Cose already, and is being used in at least one SDK which follows specific RFC drafts.\\nHowever, other languages would need to also adopt it when the service expands. Which poses a question what libraries to use in each? I know specific dependencies that we can leverage but is there an approval process to \\\"allow\\\" them to become part of the SDKs, or should I just include the dependencies and review those in arch/sdk meeting for each language separately?\", \"response\": \"Based on the provided knowledge, the approval process for including new dependencies (such as CBOR/COSE encoding/decoding libraries) in Azure SDKs is handled as part of the SDK review process for each language. There is no indication in the current documentation of a centralized or global approval policy for such dependencies across all Azure SDKs. Instead, you should:\\n\\n- Add the proposed language-specific dependencies (e.g., System.Security.Cryptography.Cose for .NET, and the respective CBOR/COSE libraries for other languages) to your SDK implementation.\\n- Prepare to discuss these dependencies during your SDK review meeting with the Azure SDK Architecture Board (for data plane libraries), or as part of the namespace review (for management plane libraries).\\n- The review will cover package names, API surface, hero scenarios, and also the appropriateness of dependencies for each language. The architects will provide feedback and approval as part of the standard review workflow.\\n\\nThere is no mention of a centralized approval workflow or pre-approved dependency list in the onboarding or review documentation. All dependencies are subject to review and approval during the regular SDK review process for each language. Ensure that your proposed dependencies meet Azure SDK guidelines and language-specific best practices before presenting them for review.\\n\\nIf you require further clarification or have concerns about a specific dependency, you can contact the Azure SDK Architecture Board directly at azsdkarch-help@microsoft.com, or bring it up during your scheduled SDK review meeting.\\n\", \"ground_truth\": \"I would suggest an email to azsdkarch@microsoft.com to discuss this.\"}"}]
